author: {'steamid': '76561198000305766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2477, 'last_played': 1589304757}
review:
This game is dumb. Not that I didn't think parts of it were fun for a bit, but the fun is just a veneer and wears thin quickly. The game is plagued by poor design, and none of the information provided to you is meaningful. The measurements for fleet strength are useless, the AI refuse to attack you unless they massively overpower you, and even then only attack stations and not outposts. The economy is terrible and wants you to grind for ages to get higher tier stuff, and any fleet ships that you have will die all the time, and they are super expensive. I quit playing because I had a fleet of 2 dreadnought's and 2 carriers parked at a station of 6 k fleetstrength lose an auto combat to a single cruiser. Just buggy and poorly thought out.

Edit - Since I have posted this review, they have released two patches that fix some of the bugs like single ships winning in auto combat against much larger forces. However, the game is in beta and the game mechanics are what they are. This game is not going to change drastically at least until an expansion. The enemy do not play on the same field as you, and as such you will feel like they are cheaters. I knocked the outlands down to a single planet, so they spawned a fleet of 17k power for HOURS. Every 2.5 minutes, or 1 week in game, a new hoard of ships to throw at my defenses. And if i lose 1 cruiser in that battle, it takes me longer to finance and build that ship, but guess what, they are back with 3 dreadnaughts and 2 carriers like that. So I fight them off for hours and save up 44k fleet power to assault their planet. Keep in mind at this point i have around 25 systems, and they are crammed into one. So I go assault the planet and they annihilate my force like it was nothing, then their 17k fleet immediately respawns and takes bases. The AI do not play on a fair field, and it makes everything in this game feel meaningless. I can understand the bugs, this is a Beta, but the game design is what it is. I did not expect a finished game, but a meaningful and fun one. Not one where every decision feels grind, unlikely to succeede, and meaningless.
developer_response:
Hi and apologies for intruding on your review like this.

We're aware of the issues you've noted. Some are bugs while others are balancing issues that will all be addressed in the coming weeks.

I hope you'll give the game another chance at a later date.

Thank you for taking the time to post the review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975742717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1107, 'last_played': 1708008481}
review:
Like with a lot of things, the choice of "the best" simulator is very dependent on personal preferences. For my taste, the DRL Sim feels closest to flying a real quad. 
Even though i am not a racer, i fly mostly freestyle, i really like this Sim. The maps are large and interesting and the occasional solo race is fun, too. It helped me get more confident with some tricks. To be honest, i still do not feel like i got a lot better with this because of the lack of real consequences. If i run my quad into a concrete wall in real life, it may break some stuff. If i hit some treetops a few hundred meters away, there is a chance i will never find my quad are all parts that flew off ;) In the Sim i fly a lot more risky. If something happens i just flip over or press the rest button.
All in all, i like this sim and would recommend it to anyone who flies fpv or wants to get into it. The included learning lessons should be enough to get you into the air and doing basic moves.

review: Game is complete shit, cant even join a game always says disconnected from server, and its just going against AI. cant even use any other buttons.
developer_response: Hello! On the first few levels new players face AI opponents - they are easier to fight, so they are used as the initial training to get used to the game and prepared to face other players. After those first few levels more things will unlock for you and your PvP enemies and teammates will be players, not bots. As for disonnections - it could be caused by major disruptions and outages happening with many ISP lately, but to know for sure you could ping the server, here is the instruction how to do that and a handy script: https://forum.crossout.net/index.php?/topic/265979-info-connection-losses-high-ping-and-related-issues/

author: {'steamid': '76561197995062006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1644096202}
review:
I have to say, compared to all the other laid back builder games this game brings some new concepts. I like that you can build vertically and be more creative with how you want to build your beaver society. But more importantly, I like how you can also alter the world and ecology to enhance your village even more.

The negatives on the other hand, no competing AI, no random gen maps, no fighting/defending. End game you just mass resources and build mega buildings that are expensive (lame).

With all that said, I still enjoy the game, it brings some new cool ideas, but it's no mega hit for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097531374', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1622747455}
review:
This game has crazy potential but there are simple quality of life changes that need to be made first
[list]
[*] Let me use my mouse to turn the camera. No point in having beautiful landscapes if I can't turn to look at them
[*] Make the turbo a toggle. It recharges instantly, what's the point of it turning off just to turn it back on again?
[*] Give me the mission/waypoint before the conversation. I want listen to the conversation while I drive around, not sit through a 5 minute convo then drive in silence after I get my next mission. Good example of this is the mission after the conversation about pirate radio.
[*] Just do something about the elevators. I got stuck on one of the first missions because I didn't realize I was supposed to wait for an elevator because NPCs kept taking it before I even realized it was there. It's such a chore to wait for a single person massive elevator to slowly rise up just to take it slowly down again. This is 1000 years into the future, why don't we have Futurama passenger tubes yet? Or just make it so NPCs dont take elevators.
[/list]
This game has such a great atmosphere and vibe to it, but it's not enjoyable to play.
developer_response:
Thanks for your review. A couple points that might be helpful:
1) You can turn to third person and first person camera while walking, taking the atmosphere and environments all in. You can do this while in vehicle as well. Unlock the camera with "x" and turn the camera to look around.
2) NPCs don't take the elevators, elevators drive up and down on their own. But when you are in a certain range of them and they are on your level, they will wait for you.

review: Every time something happens and I have to uninstall and reinstall this game (which has been frequent) I have to spend almost an hour going through the settings setting up key binds for a joy stick, keyboard, and mouse. It's miserable and the data for the key binds could be saved to the steam cloud with the rest of the save data for this game but isn't. on the off chance that I don't have to reconfigure the whole game upon launch it's stupid grindy for materials and money, both of which you need if you want to explore at all. There are predatory market strategies in play on their market (IE liverlies cost just a bit more than nearest single currency pack gives from purchace), though they are just for looks so not too important but very annoying.
developer_response:
Hey CMDR,

Sorry to hear about this issue.

It's possible to back up all your key bindings so you can quickly recover them if needed. 

We have a guide to help you do this here: https://customersupport.frontier.co.uk/hc/en-us/articles/4405955062802

author: {'steamid': '76561198030772194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3002, 'last_played': 1581844688}
review:
Not so much a "No" from me as it is a "Meh". Not quite worth the full price.

No matter what I build or how much time I put into the creations I never get the satisfaction I get on other, similar games.

This idea is great. Right up my alley. Engineer/build things to achieve some goal(s). I really love this genre... but Nimbatus just can't pull it off for me. I want to like this game, but can't.

In the early stages of a creation I'm hopeful and excited with a thousand ideas spinning in my head... but after hours of work I always have to reduce it back so far that is underwhelms me. Kind of like a DM that doesn't let his/her players push the boundaries with creativity.

Ultimately, the part selection combined with the much-to-be-desired physics engine fall flat. Far too limiting.

The autonomous competition aspect of the game is really the only draw for me. The single player is quite boring.

I'm sure I'll re-review after release. Fingers-crossed
developer_response:
Hi sqweege

Nimbatus has now been released :)
We have tried our best to improve the game further since you last played it 3 months ago. 

Cheers,
Philomena

author: {'steamid': '76561198855056511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 16840, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7914, 'last_played': 1676085474}
review: It's a very simple game but it's also very enjoyable. Where it is cross platform, there's always people to run with and the dungeons are formatted in a way I've never seen and I love how they adjust and scale. It may be simple, but I think AQ3D is going places.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962664407', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1517280555}
review:
For a long time player of Dungeon Keeper 2 and still currently playing it I really want to like this game and I think it is cute and promising. It does give similar feels for Dungeon Keeper 2 but something just doesn't hit the spot for me. 

I did like the my pet dungeon feature it felt like home but the campaign feels lacking somewhere. I feel like the game just kicks my butt, but maybe I am a filthy casual. 

Unfortunately I would rather continue to play DK2 as well as the first one. I may give War for the Overworld another go another time.

Thanks for reading.
developer_response:
Hi Bubsy,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review. Version 2.0 has brought massive changes to every aspect of the game, including new AI, great Performance and an improved interface.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since your review:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. One of these is completely free for you!
- New Game Modes
- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate
- Entirely new Skirmish AI

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561198070053006', 'num_games_owned': 673, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1463908991}
review:
[h1] Overview	[/h1]

Adopting a retro arcade 8-bit art style, the SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect, or Sword Justice Deluxe Selective Memory Erase Effect plays as a 2D platformer where you move your character, a mechanical android cat through different layers of fear clusters in order to reach an end terminal to log out and return to the real world where his link partner, M1Mi resides in.  Along the way, the cat meets many parts of the operating system that take a physical form as enemies.  In order to progress through the game, players must complete each level by moving their character from the left to the right; killing enemies along the way which will increase your score.  The developer has taken an extra step, whether intentional or not to bring the complete experience of a CRT arcade cabinet by featuring in-game screen brightness control for CRTs’, three button layouts found on cabinets and of course, infinite continues.

[h1] The Good	[/h1]

SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect follows true to the standard cabinet platformer.  To give an idea of how the game is like, think of the original metal slug, except your default weapon is a blade instead of a pistol.  Jumping, ducking, dodging, button mashing all the good mechanical components of cabinet games are retained in SWR JST DX SMEE and mesh really well to play a fun to play game.

SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect’s visuals are extremely well done.  For a game with only 256 different shades of colours to work with, this game manages to bring colourful visuals with unique background design for every chapter.  Although enemy mechanics and attack patterns were used in more than one type of enemy, each chapter of the game introduced new and special looking sprites for all the enemies.  

The difficulty of the game increases at a reasonable rate.  The first few chapters introduce players to the mechanics, and slowly become more demanding, such as throwing daggers while dodging and immediately air strafing in the opposite direction to slash an incoming enemy.  

The plot is based off of a good concept which actually revolves around an inner conflict that appears within the player. Taking a step back, you can see there are two sides of the story.  One of which is really evident to the player, the cat’s drive to log out of this nightmare and return to M1Mi.  But in order to reach the terminal, all the operating system enemies’ have everything that they longed for destroyed.  Looking back into the dialogue between the main characters, reveals that the main antagonist isn’t even truly evil, but just someone whose ideals sided with the OS components. 

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

Let’s start with the game itself.  Mentioned earlier, I’m not sure whether or not the developer decided to bring about the whole experience of old arcade games including the problems, or was just simply limited by the game engine they are working with.  Please note, at the time of writing this review, the game cannot save, meaning each time you start the game up, you have to start from the very beginning.  The argument may be that the game is short and can be completed in one sitting, but it is just a poor excuse that a save function not be implemented, if high scores can be recorded.  SWR JST DX SMEE also has problems shutting down properly.  The window may close, but it hangs on steam locking you in-game.  In order to play your other games again you have to shut down steam and restart the client.
 
Level design is not the best, and is very evident in the ice chapter where you utilize the same run and gun strategy.  Progression between levels can be spontaneous and abrupt with no warning narrative as seen by the mine cart stage. The result is a lot of gimmicky level designs that force you to lose a life no matter what, unless you’ve played through a second time.

The game itself is contradictory as to the scoring style.  2D side-scrolling platformer games like these usually are fast paced because they provide you with a ranged default weapon and unlimited ammunition.  Since SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect gives you a sword as a default weapon, you will often find yourself kiting backwards and staying just outside of the enemy hit range.  Anyone who has played a 2D side-scroller knows that going back the way you came from breaks the tempo of the game and since scoring is widely based off of number of enemies killed, you are forced to kill your enemies, making pacifist and speed runs totally redundant, not to mention impossible on some of the later levels. 

The plot itself is pretty shallow and leaves a lot to be desired.  Yes, the writer may have been going for a hero vs villain scenario, but nine lines of text between levels is not enough for the player to connect with the characters, leaving an empty and hollow characters.  It really is not enough for the player to judge the scenario correctly, and is hard to sympathize for the other cast of characters that are being antagonized. 

[h1] Overall Score [/h1]

As a complete package I rate Sword Justice Deluxe Selective Memory Erase Effect at 4/10.  This game is just too large of a hassle to get up and running and an even bigger annoyance when it comes to shutting down.   If you look at just the game, I would personally score this game at 6/10 just for the amazing visuals and good controls.  The reason it isn’t higher is because the game really falls short in terms of level design.  But if the game’s art piques your interest and your computer successfully passes the [url=https://nekomuragames.itch.io/swr-jst-dx-selective-memory-erase-effect] tech demo [/url], give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024879972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2267, 'last_played': 1428648452}
review:
Salvation Prophecy is an older but ambitious game, and is in my opinion a diamond in the rough. I did a few playthroughs with different races and it's clear that a lot of love went into this game. There are parts that definitely could've used more polish, but Salvation Prophecy is still an excellent mix of space combat and ground missions.

The game takes you between space and ground combat, both of which have offense and defense missions. There are primarily squad-based missions for the factions, but the main plot often has the player on a solo mission to explore a mysterious planet. There are also a chain of solo space missions for bounty-hunting. Later, as the player advances ranks within their faction, they can buy upgrades for their ship and eventually assume control of their faction. This lets the player order fleet and ground missions as well as build new buildings and space stations on conquered planets. 


[h1]Pros:[/h1]

--([b]Major[/b]) Space combat. While space stuff could be repetitive, it was overall very fun. The jump and wormhole mechanics made travel more interesting. It was an awesome feeling, being able to single-handedly take down an enemy capital ship and space station in the same mission once my squad had been killed.

--([b]Major[/b]) The ability to go from exploring my faction space station, jump in a ship, fly to another planet, land on it, meet new and interesting monsters, and kill them, in a 3rd person perspective. We seriously need more games like that.

--([b]Minor[/b]) Ship upgrades. I love games that let me upgrade vehicle stuff, and my only complaint here was that there weren't more choices or options. 

--([b]Minor[/b]) Some of the Salvation Prophecy storyline missions involve collecting runes with special powers that give the game a different twist beyond the usual sci-fi trope of simply getting bigger/better guns. Unleashing these runes on the very next ground mission was fun.

--([b]Minor[/b]) While all factions have mostly decent dialogue with occasional fun, the Wyr faction in particular has some great moments here.


[h1]Cons:[/h1]
--([b]Major[/b]) Ground combat. It often seemed a bit clunky and the races felt poorly balanced. For example in most ground missions, fighting the humans or killer robots was easy, but fighting against the blue all-female race that could steal life energy as a ranged attack was much harder (however [i]playing[/i] as the all-female race was a blast). 

--([b]Minor[/b]) Would've liked to see more mission types beyond a simple offense/defense on space and ground, and the bounty hunter chain. The prophecy plotline took care of this sometimes, but still could've used more variety in the faction missions.

--([b]Minor[/b]) The interior layout of the space stations was exactly the same across all factions. While the stuff inside the space station was somewhat different for each faction, it seemed a bit unrealistic that they'd all have the same map, with the exact same NPC jobs in each place. As such, once you know where your weapon vendor is for Race A, it will be in the exact same spot for the others. Definitely could have used more dev time to make the layouts feel unique to each faction.

--([b]Minor[/b]) Controls occasionally felt clunky. Worst was unstable wormholes, though maybe that was the entire point there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074113072', 'num_games_owned': 596, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1120, 'last_played': 1665757009}
review:
I just beat the game and it hurts to give such a small game a bad review. However there is jsut not enough content yet. 2 builders are nowhere near enough. No option to customise a builder with flexible units. No endless mode. Only 6 levels. Super low gold on base kills (maybe intentional but feels awkward). No multiplayer. No reward for beating levels you already beat with another builder. Wonky balance (Orc is a lot stronger than elf until you get the late game units upped dragon or wizard). No multiple upgrades for the same unit. No real point on the world map. Go buy SCII and play the gamemode there. This is barely even an alpha.

WARNING: DEV apparently abandoned the game. No updates in months.

Update: Dev continued development. Maybe this time for longer than for a week. I am replaying the levels to get to the new ones, and I am having a lot of fun.
developer_response: Good job beating the currently implemented levels. The last ones are really hard, I heard. And thanks for mentioning the things you missed. Some, like upgradable units to support the builder ones, will be implemented in the next patch. Other things are in the list, I'm working on the game every day, and it's getting better and better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010673648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1688689636}
review:
The first time ever I have requested a refund for a game. This is broken so badly I'm not even sure where to begin. Sure, if you get through to the actual game, maybe it's good. I don't know, I didn't get that far, I just spent my time argueing with the tutorials (which tell you absolutley nothing about what to do, and then mock you when when you get it wrong)

A control scheme that's just painful. I mean, there was a perfectly good one way back in Frontier: Elite II, but apparently that was forgotten about. So instead let's take everything that was good about Freelancer's mouse control and break it.

-1/10, Do not buy, Bury in the desert.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998979251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 915, 'last_played': 1481763069}
review:
[h1]TLDR:[/h1]
A pay-to-play hack and slash game that paywalls most of their content. This would be a good game if everything was included at the base price; sadly it isn't.

[h1]Positive:[/h1]
+ Decently fun
+ People into hack and slash games will enjoy if the price was right

[h1]Negative:[/h1]
- $6.99 indie game has $78 worth of DLC
--Want another class? Gotta pay
--Want to finish all the acts? Gotta pay
- Don't support devs with bad practices. Pay-walling their entire game is a really bad practice.

[h1]Bad:[/h1] [b]3/10[/b]
developer_response:
So the only negative part is the price?

This is not an indie game, we are a company of 6 people working on this game and we need to pay the salaries just like anyone who is running a business. People like the game, you obviously seem to like it so why is paying for extra content in a game you like a problem? How is making new content for a small price of few bucks somehow bad practice? 

We have been working on this game for the past 6 years every day of the year making it better and better according to community feedback and what the players want, and we need to fund this somehow so we made new classes, acts, content which is mostly all free. We even made ACT 5 and ACT 6 free in the next patch, a part of the base game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034361185', 'num_games_owned': 1231, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1562229256}
review:
Screenshots don't do this justice; they legitimately over-sell the game.

Grain of salt: Oculus Rift via Steam VR

-Does not look this good in-game due heavily to the FoV and resolution. The screenshots of the gameplay have significantly wider FoV; you will spend most of the time never seeing your hands.
-Hit-detection is a bit checkered too, and it's the first game other than Beat Saber to have issues with this for me. A recent update fixed Beat Saber though making it the only game that has hit-detection issues. Along with hit-detection issues, I noticed that the main menu would reset its position on me almost every minute. Knowing both issues could've been one-offs I rebooted my PC and continued having the issues both before and after playing other VR games.
-Music is okay-ish, and the graphics are noticeably bare basic Unity. Taskbar icon is the Unity logo, and the Unity splash screen is there so it's the free version. Looks, sounds, and feels like a cluster of Unity assets and public domain music, but for a $15.99 (on sale) try-&-refund I don't really feel it's my responsibility to check if it is just that. Even the game logo looks like a photoshop of some stock VR image I've seen before... But, again, that's not on me to check these things; it's on the developer to make the game look, sound, and feel like the experience is worth my time. Since I already have and enjoy Beat Saber and Box VR; it's not.

Addendum: Yes, I know it's in Early Access. Yes, I know it is still being developed. I'll check it out again at release, or after at least some significant improvements.

EDIT in response to Developer response:
Then key things to work on to make it not look like stock Unity assets:
1; Flesh out your normal maps. Give objects & environments some depth and smoothness instead of flat faceted polygonal early 2000's 3D.
2; Don't use what look like flame jpegs for the rays.
3; Pay for the Unity Engine so you can remove the stock Unity splash screen.

I hope what you claim about the artwork is true; there are many who gleefully investigate this sort of thing. I am not one of them. I made the statement solely for your benefit in case it was; they WILL find out.

Hit-detection may have been partially due to figuring out how reliable it even was, but I did feel I had reasonable straight punches on many targets that refused to connect. View centering did not occur during a round, but would happen every 30-60 seconds in the menu. I was streaming it at the time and can provide a link and time-stamp if you want evidence of this.
(EDIT2: Redacted link - expired VoD)

I'm not judging an entire game; that's on professional reviewers to do. I am critiquing my first impression; the part of the game that's supposed to impress your players and convince them the game is worth what they spent and their time to continue playing. This is my first impression; to try and invalidate that with a snide comment like that is not only insulting, it's arrogant. And the rest of your response oozes arrogance because of it. Don't be so conceited.
developer_response:
Sorry that you didn't like the game. But, we are still wondering how you can judge an entire game within 0.1h of playtime.

Nevertheless, we must reject your accusation that the game may consist of Unity assets and even the logo image may be made of stock art. Quite some time has been poured into that work, to make these models, these textures and graphics, so that our game does not only consist of simple glowing, non-textured models. By the way, the banner/logo image did take several hours of shooting that photo and making it look like that. So even that is not bought ;-).

Your issue with the main menu and the hit detection is weird and the first time we are hearing of that since a few updates. But, we are always keen to improve the game and take negative reviews seriously, when they describe a possible issue. So, maybe you can describe that in more detail. That would help us in improving the game.

One last comment: You are absolutely free to get a refund. There is no problem with that.

Cheers,
Team PowerBeatsVR

review:
Decent game, easy to 100% however it is rather buggy and imo in an unfinished state (Even if the devs think otherwise) This game had so much potential to rival Cooking Simulator, but as per usual the devs basically abandoned it to most likely work on another project. Unfortunate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198277984478', 'num_games_owned': 1210, 'num_reviews': 607, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1619657446}
review:
I only played for about 30 minutes, and sadly I have to refund and suggest to people interested in this game to wait it out for some quality of life patches, bug fixes and overall polish. 
This is a very expensive game for the lack of polish - hit boxes on edges and slopes are sketchy, you're never climbing UP an edge, you're wading through the sprites on the slope drawn beneath it.
It looks about the quality of the game I'm making in pixel game maker mV, only I'm just a regualr person. This dev has made some really good games.
I'm so confused as to what happened here.
Boshy is fantstic, and Wings isn't my fave, but it was an admirable and challenging effort into pushing forward a more full game than I wnna be the boshy. 
But this game is sloppy, with floaty controls, quesitonable hitboxes, combat that is neither diverse, nor filled wiht " tons of moves " you seem to plataeu as soon as you get your tail. Im told to tail slam, okay... but how do I tail slam? no control on screen, no info in the menu, no anything - I have no clue. 
Game feels unfinisihed. 
not recommended for now.
developer_response:
Sorry that you had a bad launch experience :(

There's recently been made a post on the game page addressing these concerns, hopefully the game is in a better state for you now and you're able to form a new overall opinion on the game.

"tons of moves" was a mistake to write, as that amount can vary from person to person how they perceive it. There are 3 attack buttons each with their own directional inputs and different magic spells to unlock with their own variations. Maybe "several" would've been a better word, I'm sorry if it left a false expectation that there would be hundreds of moves or something like that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001678714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1701812831}
review: Editing my previous review due to problems being fixed. It´s a wonderful game and you owe it to yourself to check it out.
developer_response:
Hi CatMcGregor,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2015. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

Most importantly the performance and stability of the game has been now greatly improved after thousands of man-hours of development from our two-man code team. 

As an early access supporter, you even have the first expansion for free, and the second expansion was free for everyone! 

If you've not tried the game for a while now might be a great time for you to jump in and see how far we've come since release! We'd love to hear what you think now.

Cheers,
Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561197969967281', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1550770735}

author: {'steamid': '76561198134201078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1584070518}
review: Still quite buggy, but didnt stop me playing it for a while.  Villagers get stuck easy, lot of labels show up as code.  Its pretty quick hitting the ceiling on what to build and then it gets repetative.  You also can barely control where the villagers build homes at.  Its still fun, but Id wait on buying it until its fixed up more and possibly more things to do.
developer_response:
Hi lonmc77,

Thank you for taking the time to leave a review! As a small indie developer all feedback is very important to us and we are glad to hear that you found the game fun.

We are currently in Early Access and still developing the game, so some of the points you raised will be addressed before full release.
- We are aware of issues with villagers getting stuck at granaries which is someting we are looking to improve and prevent in a future update.
- Housing is also a work in progress and will be greatly improved as we develop the game.
- More resources and production chains are being worked on through development and will be added in future updates.

Thanks again for your feedback and we hope we can earn a positive review as we further develop the game.

Cheers 
Ash

author: {'steamid': '76561198125995922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 19936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4755, 'last_played': 1657984652}
review: At first this game seemed promising, and had a lot of potential. However don't trend long, this game is designed to waste your time and take your money. It's become all too clear with the newest "ashfall part 2" update. you have to do absurd amounts of grinding to access a new area with the highest level equipment OR you can just pay to speed up the waiting process. P2W is always a silent killer in mmo's but that's just one problem with this situation. after you access this new area you have to kill over half a thousand of a single type of enemy just for the materials of the item. now i'm fond of rpg games and a good bit of grinding, but don't make me sit in one spot, doing ONE THING, over and over for hours on end. you wonder why you have problems with bots? it's because you'd have to be a robot to actually enjoy this game and the grind it throws your way. i respect the developers and their past work but this game is kind of a throw away, don't waste the time or investment like i have. you've been warned.
developer_response: Hi there! Thank you so much for your feedback! The devs are constantly working on fixing and improving issues and releasing updates/patches almost weekly. The devs are working on lessening 'the grind,' quests, class skills, more classes, PVP, etc. We also have a Game Plan posted here that is updated every Monday - https://aq3d.com/game-plan/. We appreciate the time you took to write this very detailed and helpful review!

author: {'steamid': '76561199248091998', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1672116069}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997559839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1679, 'last_played': 1467687547}
review:
This is a servicable dungeon keeper inspired game. 
There are good moments to be had here. 

There are nitpicks all over,but in the end, you have to ask, did you have fun and did you get your moneys worth from the product?  For me the answer is certainly YES.   If you want dungeon keeper 3.. this really isnt it... But if you want dungeon keeper 2 redone so you could play it again and have it feel new with a couple more gimmiks... Yeah this is it!

Dont let my lackluster bland review stop you from buying it. There is fun here, it is not everything you want, but compared to the competition this completely blows it all away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012521670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 5197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1690, 'last_played': 1697994700}
review:
Update October 22, 2023:

Do not play this game, I tried coming back, but with 2+ hours of googling, asking veterans, using
search sites, I did not find a combat zone I could play like I wanted.
I also got a bounty for "trespassing" that I could never have avoided.

Games like this must be warned against and should not be played. This is simply unacceptable on all fronts.


Update: January 15 2023:"

Do not play this game, or Elite Dangerous Odysey;

The game is very unbalanced, buggy, unpolished and often frustrating; you will end up doing a lot of logging in and out.
FPS might be called lack of FPS as the FPS with the same settings in space is drastically lower. The game should have seperate graphics settings for that, but it doesn't.

FPS is wildly more profitable than anything else.

Frameshift drive is super annoying when it comes to planetary landings, sometimes you have to try 4 times and it randomly while re-attempting seems to go into the wrong 'mode' causing an instant exit and you having to wait for a cooldown, that can be avoided by logging in and out.

Doing trade with the fleet carrier is the single most profitable thing you can do and virtually zero risk.
The same is true for the FPS combat in combat zones. You can easily earn millions without any investment in the latter, if you simply focus on making kills of the enemies with the plasma-based sniper rifle. Finding grade 2 or 3 shotguns, snipers or plasma pistols and/or suits you can up your game and go through the enemy more quickly, sometimes racking up to 12 million in a single round of the capture-the-flag game where instead of defending and taking over points, all you need to do is hunt the enemy.

The only things I find fun in the game are unbalanced, and the things that are 'balanced' and 'risk' analyzed and such.. are so relatively underpowered, underwhelming and frustrating in their design that they do not hold my interest at all.














Edit: January 10, 2023.

After 7 years, I can still firmly thumb down this game. There are 3 major frustrations that I ran into virtually immediately when playing, together they have very strongly frustrated me for well over an hour:

- Frameshift and supercruise are bound to the same key, but if you want to leave a planet after setting a course , then you must first rebind them if you are trying to fly to a destination that happens to be on the other side of the planet and in a different system. You must rebind keys to do out-of-system cargo missions.
- Picking up cargo missions DOES NOT PICK UP CARGO anymore (you must manually use the "cargo depot". It took me 20 minutes of Googling and some obscure youtube tutorial that didn't even play properly to find out where to do this. Worse; this was totally inobvious to me and becuase of my scepticism I even checked whether the cargo was on board. It was not. I almost flew 123 lightyears with 8 system hops with a ship to deliver 'unique' biowaste (that can be picked up anywhere and costs nothing) to then deliver it far off for 300K credits. (which doesnt evne make sense)
3. When landing on planetary cities, the hangars are VERY difficult to find if you expect them to not be ON TOP but on the sides of the city. I flew around the entire city to find my dock, then after 6 minutes finally located it ON TOP of the city, and then landed in apparently a 180° incorrect direction to land, which makes no sense. It is completely inverted from other locations and you will always end up approaching from the center.

None of these points make any sense to me whatsoever. Who designed this?  Also I think the flying of the ships sucks, I prefer the realism  and flight controls of KSP, Space Engingers.. .hell, even Empyrion: Galactic Survival to the ones in this game.

Overall it's a boring flight simulator for me that feels desolate, even when you can get off your ship and 'interact' in the station. It's hollow and feels artificial. Just like No Man's Sky, I don't feel fully in control of my ship even when I literally am. Worse, the way you have to land in some places forces you to fully experience all of the inconveniences of the 'unique' downsides of how a ship is flown in this game.

I'm sorry for being so scathing, but a game that's managed to frustrate me for an hour straight after coming back to it after 7 years... and in new ways... No. Just No. I will not recommend this game and strongly recommend anyone stay away from it, unless they are willing to spend 1+ hour googling obscure and stupid issues with the most essential and simplistic aspects of this game. Hell, even the flight controls often sometimes take several minutes to Google, and worse, you're put on tight deadlines that if violated will result in your ship being blown up.

Realism is not to be found in this game, joy might be, but frustration is guaranteed. Guaranteed.

Previous/original review from october 2015 is below: 

I was determined on also buying a joystick for this game, but I will not, I do not see myself playing this game much, if at all in the future. 

My final verdict (I am currently removing local files): Boring and extremely frustrating. Many things are completely counter-intuitive: buy things legal in one place, sell in another where its illegal? Loss instead of profit??... Buy stuff that is 'exported' to a place... nowhere they will actually allow you to sell it, if it happens to be illegal there, and there is no big dock.
Bounty on you? No way to remove it.. oh wait; but it disappears, but if it is 'scanned' it sticks around 7 days and you cannot claim your own bounties.. Oh, and when you die, your 'bounty vouchers' disappear. This game is riddled with things that make no sense at all, and thus cause frustration when you run into them. I am deeply, deeply disappointed, and also very frustrated that I can't play the game I THOUGHT this was. 

I am a total sci-fi geek, I love space sims to bit, I loved Vega Strike to bits, I played KSP for over a 1000 hours.


The tutorial is completely worthless; after completing it  all you can do is manage to leave dock and travel to other planets and dogfight; but you're still left COMPLETELY uneducated on so, so many important things and without this knowledge, the game is ultimately extremely frustrating. But it is addictive, if you can put yourself past that.

However, my conclusion is that, finally mastering navigation without overshooting, stealthy smugling and exploring, there's nothing left to do, since everything is just repetition.

Sadly; the best way to turn a profit is to continually quit to main menu and switch between solo and open play, to stock up on smuggling operations to the very same destination to your cargo's capacity. (I can stack over 500.000 credits on one trip with my Cobra.) 

Ultimately it is all just flying between targets... slowly, without much interesting things to see, or do, unless you like doing this and getting the satisfaction of earning credits, in which case I highly recommend Adventure Capitalist.

P.S: In this game you have all of the disadvantages of a Single Player game and Multiplayer game combined, but none of the benefits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053374920', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1533872033}
review:
This game is not dead, and never will be.  Ever.

"What are you talking about? There aren't any players online!"

No, there aren't many players.  That's right.  But you know what there *are* many of?  BOTS!  Bots for days!  Glorious, glorious bots!  If you're a super competitive player, maybe that's not good enough for you.  But if you just want the shiny graphics and pew-pews, the bots will provide those things just as well as human players would.  Really need human players that much?  Get the four-pack and rope your friends into it.  Hell, you don't even need to do that.  Play with your family or roommates on LAN - only the host actually needs the full version.

Seriously though, the lack of active players is the *only* flaw I can see in this game.  If you're like me and don't mind fighting bots, rest assured that this game's bot battles are just as good as the multiplayer battles.  Same exact content, just better latency.

Also props to the devs for staying active on the forum and not being discouraged by people saying the game's dead.  You guys made a really good & engaging game and just had a bit of bad luck on the multiplayer side of things.  I hope to see more games from you some time in the future. :)
developer_response:
Nice read and review. Thx!!
Yup, the bots where done with a lot of attention to detail. Thanks for noticing and pointing out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081853679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1702421701}
review: Can play only one race. After the race clicking 'next' just hangs it (macos version). But in general great simulator.
developer_response:
Hi there!
 
I'm terribly sorry to tell you, however at the moment we are having issues with Mac builds and are hunting for solutions constantly. Seems to be a conflict with unity.
 
There are a couple of things that some of the Mac users have reported success with, please try them and let me know.
 
1. Force Quit Steam, launch Steam, attempt to launch the game.
2. Head to Steam Settings(Preferences) and check for Steam Client Update
3. Head to Steam Settings(Preferences) Click on Downloads and then click on the Clear Download Cache button.
 
Restart, launch the sim and test.
 
Another thing for you to test.
 
Please launch Steam. and click on the DRL Sim in your Steam Library.
Then click on the Settings cog wheel on the right side of the screen. Choose Manage and then Browse Local Files.
Please delete the two things you see there. should 4.1.3860.rls.osx.version and the other should be DRL Simulator.
Once deleted, head back to Steam, Click on the DRL Sim in your Steam library, click on the same settings cog wheel, and then Manage, this time click Uninstall.Once uninstalled, restart, head back to Steam, download the Sim, and let us know your results.
 
Thanks and again, Im so sorry you have to deal with this.
 
We are hoping for a solution soon.
 
TK

author: {'steamid': '76561198127462787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 8012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8012, 'last_played': 1706682423}
review: welp i legit cant open it anymore cause upisoft dosnt think i own the game its sad how much i love this game and i cant even play anymore
developer_response: Hey Mr,staby, I'm sorry to hear that you're running into some issue launching The Crew 2! If you are receiving an [url=https://support.ubisoft.com/en-GB/Article/000066178]"ownership authentication"[/url] error, let me explain what's occurring. This error denotes that the Ubisoft account you are trying to launch paired with Steam is likely not the one you have the game (or DLC) activated on. This can be easily resolved! If you know that you have a secondary Ubisoft account, you can simply log into that and relaunch the game. If you aren't sure about an alternate account (or that an alt account may have been created by, for example, accidentally misspelling your email address), please contact the Ubisoft Support team on the [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-gb/help/contact#en-GB]Help Site[/url] and provide them with your [url=https://support.ubisoft.com/en-US/Article/000065542]launcher logs[/url], an uncropped screenshot of your [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-us/help/article/accessing-your-transaction-history-and-proof-of-purchase-on-steam/000061770]Steam Proof of Purchase[/url] as well as your [url=https://support.ubisoft.com/en-US/Article/000060565]Steam ID[/url].

author: {'steamid': '76561198087933619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 4564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1603, 'last_played': 1497083948}
review:
Release review:
Congratulations! You guys seem to have fixed all my previous issues, I'm really enjoying the new experience. Looking forward to play your game!

[strike]
EA review:
I know this is EA, but i had high hopes you guys address the following issues reported earlier:
- poor looking starfield! yes, this is important part of a space game
- unconsistent UI designed to slow down your work
- horrible font choice. in addition the font size changes for each UI element. confusing to look at!
- radial menu still hides the action screen! seriously... is it that hard to use alpha?

Various performance issues in general when flying by huge objects. I mean why? How come in X:Rebirth those station complexes do not lag my gameplay?

I know my review sounds negative. Well, you need feedback to make your game better!
[/strike]
developer_response:
Hi Assailer and thanks for posting your review!
I'll go over the noted issues from your review if you don't mind.
- by starfield I believe you're referring to the skyboxes? I'm honestly not sure what more we can do other than upping the skybox textures to double resolution, but that will severely impact the required graphics RAM
- UI will receive further changes before the game is done
- is the problem with the font its size or the font in general?
- radial menu background and game pause are both things we said we'd take care of as an option for player to choose whether or not to use and we will. we simply had more pressing matters
- performance issues - we've done a first part of the optimization in this latest update by compressing all the models (this should have made loading times shorter). another step that will be done is compressing scripts which will reduce the "stutter" when something is going on (usually objects spawning). And finally, general optimization to increase performance. This last step can only come later, once everything or almost everything is finalized. Only then can we run detailed performance tests to see where the problems occur the most.

Thanks for the review once again. We do like and need the feedback :).

author: {'steamid': '76561197964316172', 'num_games_owned': 918, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1535339476}
review:
I was very very excited for this game. I preordered the day I became aware of it's existence. I probably sank hundreds of hours into DK 1 and 2 in my adolescence and every couple of years I play through them even with the terrible emulation of Dosbox. So when I fired up WFTO and saw that it had the best of everything I remembered from both DK's I was ecstatic, the voice of the mentor was back, and it seemed to have the same sardonic humor I could barely contain myself. 

Then I started playing.

The game itself has the same dynamics of the originals. Carve out some rooms, beat some minions, watch the enemies impale themselves upon your floor spikes. But as you keep playing you realize this is just a shadow of what made the original DK great. There is little to discover (no special rooms to summon elite minions, no fun combinations of defenses, no fun things to do with posession) and you can win nearly every level of the campaign by building 5 or 6 beast pits and dropping a flag on the enemy core. In fact, through have the campaign that is exactly what you HAVE to do since defenses are practically worthless. I only found them useful in 1 campaign level. Usually the enemies will rush you so quickly you have no time to build defenses or train your minions and if you can withstand their attack you can immediately counter to win. 

If you do try and build up and turtle the campaign will just punish you with infinite waves of enemies that rush right passed all your minions to start banging on your core or with the flawless AI micromanagement. Where is the valiant freeing of prisoners? Looting the vaults? Why aren't rooms wrecked up and torched so they need to be fixed?

I kept playing despite the campaign really not being my style. I prefer to spend some time crafting a world then crushing my foes but, hey, it's nice to be pushed outside your comfort area now and again. As you keep playing the rough edges of the game will begin to grate through your resilience causing frustration and agony. The UI is sluggish and the buttons small. I have tried to click the little cancel attack flag circle and burrowed through the wall of my base too many times. Paging through the laggy menus to lighting bolt a worker who is stuttering around my base as the AI simultaneously blasts 6 of my workers while dropping 30 minions onto the square they just took in my base is psychological torture.  Or sometimes the game lags so bad you just drop a flag where you need to be and go make lunch, coming back 30 minutes later to see you won while AFK (level 9). 

The final nail in the coffin causing me to uninstall my hopes and dreams of a DK successor are the bugs. Workers standing around doing nothing. Defense parts never being delivered. Walls never being repaired. Dropping an attack flag and watching my soldiers walk into a wall while my core gets demolished. Possession freezing my computer. The game is unplayable in Linux and poorly running in Windows. Probably the worst was when I beat the second to last mission (level 12) and the game just never ended. Apparently there is a bug where you can capture an enemy core without destroying it making it impossible to win. For the record this was patch 1.1.7 which was supposed to be playable. As of now I wish I could get a refund, my 13 hours back, and to wash off this disappointment.
developer_response:
Hi Degovx,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2015. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since release:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. Two of these are completely free for you!
- New Game Modes
- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561198093634326', 'num_games_owned': 342, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1667774674}
review:
Really fun & addicting game like holy sh!t, yea it's in Early Access and of course there's things that need to be done and half of the scenes feel very short and I wish they were longer, probably just a preview. Endless Mode makes it even more intense & fun as hell like having to hold off a wave of enemies, and since it has modes & other maps on Steam Workshop it makes it last longer and YES MORE FUN! Once I saw "Cowboy Bebop" in the announcements I knew I had to get it and was sold.

Overall, yes it feels and gets repetitive after awhile but that doesn't make it a terrible game and there will be more stuff added in the near future. I do hope for gore improvements as well, more dismemberment, more blood, you can't have enough of it.

This game is like if Max Payne, Soldier Of Fortune, Cowboy Bebop had a baby.

Game at it's current state is a 7/10, but I love the game and I hope to see more stuff added in the near future.

I DO RECOMMEND to buy this game when it get's on sale, but $14 USD isn't bad either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073829414', 'num_games_owned': 661, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1509868357}
review: I can usually last around 45 minutes - an hour playing vr games with locomotion. However, this game's controls, along with the feeling of weightlessness made me sick within the first few minutes. If you get motion sick from vr locomotion, I don't reccomend this game.
developer_response:
Hello ReTic,

Sorry to hear that Detached makes you feel uncomfortable. We try to warn all the players (also in the game description here on Steam) that Detached is intense game and it's not suitable for everyone.

I would like to remind that we prepared few control schemes for each controller (Touch controllers, Gamepad, Keyboard). You can choose the best one, which can be more recognizable from FPS games or VR. Player can also enable steering assist or Eagle Eye View to limit field of view in the most nauseating moments (pitch, yaw, acceleration etc.)

I hope maybe you will give Detached another chance soon! 

All the best,
Jacob

author: {'steamid': '76561197990318254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1537236302}
review: Way too short and simple to get into right now. Maybe when there's more to it it'll be good. It just suddenly cuts off and it doesn't take much thought to get to that cutoff point.
developer_response:
Hi, and thanks for your review!

The game is fully released now (with 3 new chapters full of gameplay and a lot of polishing). We’ve made changes to game balance - now the base level of oxygen is at 75 seconds, some tools have more durability, some items are easier to build, and much more. 

We want to make sure the balance is right now. We would be happy if you could try Breathedge again and let us know how it goes. Let us know your thoughts by sending us a message to info@breathedge.com or visit our discord channel: https://discord.com/invite/eyURQXG and let us know what you think! 

Thank you once again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996212738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2635, 'last_played': 1565739041}
review:
Fantastic experience.  The first three or four times I played I really felt like I was gonna chuck, with a headache too. To combat this I started playing sitting down which helped quite a lot, restricted rotation (right-hand) to smaller increments and occasionally closed my eyes during the transition, particularly if the rotation was forwards and down. Finally, when I staretd feeling bad I stopped straight away, instead of trying to push through it (as was my initial response) and left it alone for at least an hour before trying again.

By the time I had played six or seven times the effects began to diminish and now (I still haven't quite finished the campaign) I get no ill effects whatsoever.

I have read a few reviews where people said the sold-off Detached as soon as they started feeling rough. This is a shame as it's a beautifully crafted game with stunning scenery and atmosphere. Also unnecessary since, as I can testify, your body/brain will acclimatize over a relatively brief period.  Even (some) fully trained astronauts do the big space-spit when they first arrive in orbit, so give yourself  a chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058904445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1519582379}
review:
This game did look interesting at first, the characters looked cute and all, but then it just failed me. The game features 3 different stories so it is technically three games in one, except that it isn't really as all of them feel fairly the same. Each of the stories is set in a different timeline, the past (a fantasy world), the present and the future.

[h1]The Modern story[/h1]

To be fair I didn't play it a lot, just launched it for about half an hour just to see how it plays like and I must say it was boring. There was that one joke with the toilet where you take a dump and the game gives you a fake "game over".

[h1] The Future story[/h1]

I've launched it for a moment to see how it would play, kind of used it as the game's last chance, it failed. Stared it, the characters looked really good, then I got into the game itself, the world seemed really empty compared to the two other stories. Got into a random fight against 4 enemies right at the start of the game, and then they killed me.

[h1]The Fantasy world[/h1]

The only one that has actually shown me some promise and kept me in for longer than 15 minutes. In this timeline you follow a story of Princess Yuki which is just about to get married but then it gets interrupted and you as a player have to kill the four elemental slime kings and collect something from them, you know, Final Fantasy 1 style. I've had one problem with it though, it does introduce a lot of characters in such a short time which just doesn't let you as a player get to know a certain character from the start and then maybe switch to another character, but instead you get introduced to around 7 characters in the first 15 minutes of the game, so you have no idea on what each of the characters are all about.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

In general I don't think this game is worth the price which it is going by right now, around £15. It does have some nice points in it though, for example the freedom of choice between the top-down and a first person camera. I have no complaints about the top-down view, it's good and smooth. First person was a good idea, but sometimes when you try to move the camera around with your mouse, it might take you a while as it likes to get out of the game screen, otherwise it's a good idea to have, didn't feel too bad to use it but it could use some polishing.

There were also a couple visual bugs/gliches, for example in the 2D section of the Fantasy world my character's head got gliched in one of the wall tiles of the game. There was also no transitions between different dialogues, so for example you would see the characters talking, the background would be trees for example, then it would just instantly switch to a castle or something. At least there was a lot of effort put into the character art and a fairly good soundtrack, not the best but there was worse.

4/10 - wouldn't reccomend it as it is now, if the price goes down, sure, why not. If you do however feel like you would enjoy the game then by all means, check it out and see if you like it!

If you found this review helpful or interesting in any kind of a way, follow our [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9673931/]curator here![/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198014352786', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1499554997}
review:
ROM: Extraction is a really fun game once you get the hang of it! DO NOT PLAY IT ONCE AND GIVE UP!!!

I see a lot of other reviews here talking about the "amount of content". I think those people are not understanding what kind of game this is. It's an ARCADE style shooter. The point is to replay it over and over to try to get a better score AND to have fun with it, doing trick shots and overall just enjoying the game mechanic for what it is.

Anyone here that said they "beat" the whole game in 12 minutes are idiots. No you didn't, you just played each level at each difficulty once and thought that's it. The first few times I played it was hard, I was throwing orbs and slowing to shoot, but it seemed like i was surfing the line between total chaos and being in control.

THAT'S WHEN IT CLICKED!! The key to this game is using the SLOW MO, use it A LOT!!! I can NOT stress how much more fun this game becomes when you start using the slow mo feature as much as you can. DID YOU KNOW that you can heal while in slow mo? It quickly becomes obvious that the trick to survival is milking that slow mo whenever you are starting to die. The fun for me also came in the realization that I DO have the time to plan each throw and aim with precision. To shoot each orb right in front of a robots face and watch that awesome rag doll take over. Once you get the hang of this game, it's easy to go in feeling like a badass! Neo style taking out robots one after another. Hitting that slow mo, then turning around just in time to see a robot flying through the air straight at me and shooting him in the head, decapitating him, right before he lands.... absolutely, BADASS!!!

Plus it's only $5 right now, I have eaten $5 of Taco Bell in about 10 minutes and never thought twice about it again. How are you people complaining about the worth of this game when it's only $5? I cant replay my taco bell....

TLDR: This game is meant to be replayed, its an ARCADE game. Not Skyrim. Give it some time to master the mechanics, there is a learning curve. And finally, use that SLOW MO!!! If you use it to its full potential, you can be like Neo in the Matrix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036601891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1577905816}
review:
It's not a long game, but it has a couple of hours to it to enjoy. Excellent storytelling, way better from what you would expect from indie developers. The graphical style is very '94, it feels like the Gobliiins did back then. Perhaps there are more aesthetic styles, but this pixelated one suits the atmosphere of the game, and when you have such a good story, you don't pay too much attention to graphic detail.

As it is with similar games you will get stuck a lot of times until you figure something out. For me it was three tims I had to consult with some help, so the puzzles are hard, but not unsolvable ones.
developer_response: Thanks! So glad you enjoyed it -- means a lot, especially coming from a Golbiiins fan. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198319241796', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1530588692}
review:
This game is a must play for any fan of point and clicks, dystopian sci fi or just general lovers of exceptional story telling.
I play a lot of point and clicks, usually finishing a game after a month or so of sporadic game play. 

I finished this game in one sitting.

The puzzles aren't difficult, and allow the stellar story to progress unhindered for the most part which is a pro in my eyes.
The biggest pro however, is the branching story line towards the climax. I won't spoil but there are multiple endings and you become so invested in the story that each ending carries immense gravitas.

This is a masterpiece of gaming, Hall of Fame tier. 10/10
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind words and generous review! We really appreciate it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039778613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1663109769}
review:
I'm not far into this game yet, and I do intend on continuing playing. But early impressions of this game haven't been great for me. The new pixel art is incredibly gorgeous and detailed... Unfortunately to the point where it's actually hard to see what's going on while playing. I've noticed far more bugs in the first 3 stages than I have in the entirety of the first Freedom Planet, frequently clipping through terrain and objects, weird audio quality drops in VO, and on the very first boss somehow triggering a bug that made me invulnerable after I was supposed to die. Most of these can be fixed with a patch, though the cognitive overload of the pixel art may be difficult to patch. The thing that I think can't be patched though? I'm just overall having way less fun with this game than I did with FP1. The level design and combat just *feels* off to me. Combat doesn't connect and have that same crunch that it had in FP1. The levels feel far more convoluted and frustrating to navigate than the first game; I find myself getting lost far more frequently than FP1. As a once or twice thing I'd say that's more on me, but this was a constant struggle for me in the first 3 levels I played.

I really REALLY want to like this game and I'm going to continue playing it in hopes that maybe I'm being just a little too harsh with my first impressions. But I hope by leaving this review the devs can make some adjustments to the game to live up to the first game's greatness.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991190556', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 10642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8249, 'last_played': 1702397518}
review:
Pros: A $20 *** PUZZLE *** Building Game worth pretty much $20.

Cons: No (Extremely Low) replayability.
          Some minor bugs. (Not what most post. They aren't bugs but actually part of the game 
          design.)

Steam needs another kind of recommendation: Meh? Indifferent? Something.

This game is basically a puzzle. Figuring out how many of each kind of job you need, how to handle each enviroment (Planet Type), managing both resource and job priorities *** IS THE GAME ***. (And is pretty much all there it to the game.)

If you read all the spoilers/cheats, there is nothing in the game for you as it has very low replayability. What you are competing against is your ability to manage the above mentioned variables. So your job is to manage and build a base while hitting all the milestones until it finally gets to 300 population.

It is a realitively easy game, the challenge is once again; figuring out the balances of the variables. If you are intelligent and problem solve well, you will likely be bored, or perhaps think like me that it is exactly what you paid for.

That said. A lot of people are reporting things as bugs that actually are not bugs. i.e. If you run low on power, and your then airlocks will not operate. And all the evil that befalls after that is NOT A BUG: It is the game. You messed up. Fixing the issue, (...or actually avoiding it in the first place...) before your base dies is part of playing the game.

Being unable to properly manage types of personnel, job priorities, repairs, security, power, O2, etc... IS NOT A BUG. ***** That is you losing the game. *****

Almost EVERYTHING that goes wrong in the game is UNFORGIVING. And mismanaging priorities is why you are out of <Insert Whatever Here>. (That isn't a complaint about the game. It was in fact one of the few things that made the game good.)

I value replayability very highly in a builder game. There is no replayability here. There are no competing bases, resources are unlimited (...and only run low if you aren't prioritizing correctly). So after playing through once, all you have left is a different map, and RND events from traders/aggressors.

At the end of the day you aren't going to be sad you bought it. But you are going to be sad that it seemed to have a ton of "What if..." and potential that just isn't there because of no replayability or competition.
developer_response:
Hi there,

Thank you for your feedback, we always read users reviews and take them in account to improve our game.

Although you can build most small structures at the beginning, the metagame changes quite a lot later on: you will have to optimize your base for a larger amount of colonists, build bigger domes, deal with intruders and tend to radio transmissions among other things.

Also once you master the first planet you can try out the more advanced ones, as they have different starting condtions, weather patterns, disasters and higher difficulty over all, especially the Storm one.

Additionally we've also recently added the new Challenges, which are tests that let you approach the game in a different way.

Overall the game is designed for about 20-30 hours of gameplay, which taking in account it's $20 price tag should hopefully be reasonable value for money.

Regards.
Martiño.

author: {'steamid': '76561198292131675', 'num_games_owned': 2407, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1558991501}
review:
4/10. - Beautiful/incredible scenery but the quest/story-line makes little to no sense.

The first hour I was amazed at how beautiful this game was and how I was excited to find out the lore/story of the game. I then continued to spend the next three hours running around almost clueless the entire time wondering where to go, what to do. It seems like there is no actual path or assistance other than "go to here. Go to there. Get this." It seems rushed and really poorly designed. 

Rare that I dislike a game but this game was most definitely NOT worthy of a recommendation.
developer_response:
Hi!

Thank you for your feedback.

If you look for a more linear experience may i suggest to try the prologue first, before starting a new game in Die Young?
You can simply right click on game name on steam library and hit 'Play Prologue'.

Die Young: Prologue is a story with a different protagonist ( Nehir ) that happens approximately 24 hours before the beginning of Die Young.
It is shorter than Die Young and is a complete ( not early access ) game on its own with a beginning and an end. It is more linear experience ( both for the level design and for the story ) and, other than telling you infos about the background of the island, it acts also like a sort of 'mini tutorial' to familiarize with Die Young mechanics.

Die Young, instead, is intended more like an experience with a certain degree of freedom on what to explore, where to go and which quests to make and in which order. 

Thank you for playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198810454516', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 45801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39577, 'last_played': 1684360410}
review:
Alright. I've played a lot of this game. Not as much as others have, granted. But I have 650 hours at the time of this review. There's a lot to say, but I'll keep it somewhat short and sweet. This game is complex, it's a simulation and not so much a game. That being said, the new odyssey update that came out in April is absolutely broken and has been for a long time and will be for a long time.

Basically, this game is no man's sky on release, right now. AI is broken as ♥♥♥♥, planets are all bland as hell. And the ones that wouldn't be bland, you can't land on any way. There's a lot to explore and do, but it all feels hollow and repetitive.

It could go two ways. The route no man's sky went, fix everything and constantly add insane free updates to say sorry to the community. No man's sky was the biggest redemption story in gaming. To this day, they still frequently add amazing content updates. Or it could go the route that many other games went, most notably anthem. Amazing promises made and not fulfilled, bland and boring game play and grinds for bland items and upgrades.

If elite dangerous goes the route of anthem, I'll be extremely sad. This game has so much promise and if it goes the route of no man's sky, could be the biggest redemption in gaming history. It has so much to offer and so much potential, but they need to listen to the community more. Stop giving us what you think we want. Give us what we are asking for.

That being said, the game has enough in it to keep you busy for hundreds of hours for sure. It's pretty good, if you can get past the bugs and never ending grind. But has the potential to be so, so much better. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198278404930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1621418768}
review: Z

author: {'steamid': '76561198271827307', 'num_games_owned': 138, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 17283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11922, 'last_played': 1701635247}
review:
Before buying the game, I was wondering, "What if it ends up being pretty boring? What if the activities are repetitive and since I don't have any friends to play the game with (don't judge), exploring gets boring as well?" Well, after buying the game and started playing, once in a long time, I was actually captivated for a good amount of time! Car control feels good, the sounds are really good, and the graphics look fine too despite some of the texture quality being kinda off (understandable since the world is pretty huge and all). The game's collision physics is pretty ridiculous. The activities in this game do have some kind of variety. Some of them are really fun I keep replaying them now and then. If you want to earn money and get new cars, you just have to do those activities and since some of them are pretty fun to replay, you keep getting cash as you complete them. When you level up, you also get a good amount of money. It's not anything like pay to win. I haven't experienced much PvP gameplay though.

The game's world is really awesome and feels great to explore in your favorite car! From the streets of Manhattan to the Grand Canyon highway, the landscapes are really nice. And if you like to use photomode in games (like me), this game will give you great opportunity to take some really good shots. Trust me, you will start spending more time on the photomode once you start using it. Same scene from different angles, at different time of day and different weather, you can't have enough of the photomode. Access to land, air and water vehicles makes exploring even better!

The Crew 2 has a good variety of vehicles- from Lamborghini Aventador to the legendary Pontiac Firebird (KITT), from street racing to offroad rally, Harley Davidson to Suzuki - the diversity is huge! I have to mention the visual customizing. People can actually create their own livery and upload it for other players. Trust me, these liveries know no bound. Expect to see "P*rnhub" and Fake Taxi liveries. Police liveries are pretty common. There's a lot more and of course, you can always create your very own livery.

The Crew 2 is diverse, fun and beautiful. The whole United States is your playground. It has enough to captivate you for hundreds of hours. Just don't expect hardcore racing. Have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032255930', 'num_games_owned': 3206, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 5236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1659965478}
