author: {'steamid': '76561198039769252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 14938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1670833669}
review:
The game crashes whenever I try and launch a scenario. Computer meets system requirements so not sure why this is happening. The game loaded smoothly so not sure what the problem is. A waste of money for me.

Good and timely tech support from the company, actually Tomislav. Ended up getting a new computer though. Have played the game quite a bit now. More gamey then warry. Well put together technically and graphically and I like aspects of the game play, but the narrative episode style of the campaign and the gaminess of the AI I am not a fan of. Some of the scenarios are just boring hard work trying to complete to move forward in the campaign. You can play individual scenarios though and their is a scenario editor, although I haven't tried that yet. Worth a go to see if you like it and if you are a fan of the earlier games you'll probably like this version. The basics of the game are easy to pick up.
developer_response:
Hi, please make sure your graphics card drivers are up to date.

In particular, we get these issues often for older AMD/ATI cards. For such cards, you can go to this site to update your drivers:
https://www.amd.com/en/support/kb/faq/gpu-131

If you have continued technical issues, you can post in the Tech Support subforum:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/809230/discussions/1/3344417304758723339/

Cheers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198296108202', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1392, 'last_played': 1683066952}
review:
23h. played and I can say this is pretty great FPV simulator. You will enjoy FPV world.
I start from 0 lvl, go through the all tutorials and 20h later i race with other guys. Not so fast as they but not so bad.
I use my Jumper T16 controller.
I play on Windows as well on Mac OS. 
On both of them, game works great.
Attention for Mac OS users, currently games doesn't work with macOS Big Sur!
developer_response:
Hi there! 

Thank you so much for the great review! It means a ton that you are enjoying it! 

Id love to help you with your mac issues, as the sim actually does work with Mac, but as stated on the store page, you will need a pretty beefy mac to run it, as Mac arent the best gaming machines. But it can be done with all the graphics settings to the lowest, vsync on and the resolution may need to be lowered a tad as well. 

Let me know if you need any help! 

Thanks again for your support!

TK and the DRL team.

author: {'steamid': '76561198192387373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1577519923}
review:
The game feels like its from '07 in both visuals and game design. Some of the more interesting classes are locked behind a pretty shitty daily quest/token system... [i] of course you can always Pay to get around that :D [/i] Also its gonna be a good while (15+hrs) before your character doesn't look like it fell into a goodwill trash bin... [i] Of course you can always pay to fix that :D [/i] 

Now i know this all sounds like the norm for a "F2P" game but that's exactly my point. It doesn't do anything better or different than any of the other shitty mobile game ports. 

If like me you were drawn by nostalgia for the old  AE games like Dragonfable or Battleon, you're better off just revisiting them. The writing is pretty much the same and hell if you ask me the old flash animations are easier to look at than most of this game. 

TL;DR: There are better F2P games that you can grind away/throw your money at.
developer_response:
Hello. We appreciate you checking out our game. The devs work very hard to fix issues and release new content on a weekly basis. This is a challenge as they are a small team. 

We use similar visuals and game design as other MMO's, but we are very different since AQ3D is inspired by our original single player Flash game AdventureQuest and the fact we have weekly releases. However, a 2D single player Flash game and a 3D multi player Unity game are incomparable. 

You can choose whatever classes you want and we do have an option to pay if you don't want to put in the time to actually work for and earn the classes. Cosmetics are completely optional and we have thousands of beautiful hand drawn items that you can get in the game, it's up to you and what you want to look like and there are countless choices. 

Please make sure you are checking the Design Notes and Game Plan for information about new releases and what else is being added to the game - https://aq3d.com/news/ & https://aq3d.com/game-plan/.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169921151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 6275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1005, 'last_played': 1695670831}
review:
Great game for early release. Obviously it has some issues, sometimes the path finding is a little funky, both for your units and the zombies. Zombie ai is a little weird, sometimes certain zombies will just not do anything until you start shooting at them (Won't react to sound and such). I like that I can land troops on top of roofs, but zombies can't counter that, so it's a little op. I feel like the zombie faction should start out with more than what they have, as I was playing on normal mode, took over almost the entire map (Eventually lost most of it, but it gave me a ton of money) within 20 minutes, and was able to get 50k and upgrade everything within an hour. 
Very interesting tactic is to rush towards the Glenn Military Barracks and dig in there while securing the Southern island. I did this tactic on normal mode, and was able to accomplish a lot in just two in-game days. Because the military base has only one entrance, and the fact that you'll be surrounded, zombies will swarm it, allowing to cut down on the zombie population a bit.
A bug which I love to use is to spam turrets than place a generator. This allows you to have, theoretically, hundreds of turrets for just a few generators.
At the moment it lacks a little in content, but it's an early access. Game performance is a little bad after a few in-game days when thousands are infected. 
Great game, constantly being updated and I can't wait to see what it'll be like in a few months from now.

review: Seems poorly optimized. I have a gaming laptop that isn't anything top tier, but this game causes me to get freeze frames when I don't have any issues in frame drops on many AAA games. It's a fun game, just wish something could be done about these frame drop issues. There's a lack of video settings, only going from windowed to full screen.
developer_response:
Hello and sorry for the late answer (we do not have notifications for reviews).

We recently made an update with more graphic settings, and also if you play with a laptop, sometime windows decide to run the game with the integrated GPU, you have to go in "graphic settings" in windows, select the game, and chose the dedicated GPU.

This should fix your problem.

Best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146101180', 'num_games_owned': 76, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1303, 'last_played': 1625119379}
review:
Absolutely incredible. Didn't run the best on my laptop. Had a couple of soft locks, but I can't tell if that's due to something with the game or if it's just my laptop. If it's worth anything, I didn't notice anything out of the ordinary before the soft locks and it didn't happen at the same part once I rebooted the game.
I'll try to keep spoilers to a minimum, especially since I can't figure out if I'm doing the spoiler formatting right and can't be bothered to write this again if I get it wrong.
I'll put a summary at the bottom where it's segmented off from the spoiler area.

Game's great. Would recommend.


---------SPOILER TERRITORY. SORRY I COULDN'T FIGURE OUT THE FORMATTING---------


The story is fairly well written. It can be a little iffy at times when it comes to the grand scheme of things, but if you hold your suspension of disbelief, mainly the idea that someone could rise through the ranks like that and that you are pretty much the lynchpin for everything that happens in the story, it works well. I do wish that there were more outs from the story as time goes by, but you can only put so many options into a game before you start over-writing it. 
While I'm talking about endings, I'll bring up probably my least favorite one. One of the final endings is just one or two sentences and then it boots you back to the main menu. I get that they weren't trying to take a side in the underlying debate in the game, but it does seem a little strange when you have dialogue choices mean almost the exact same thing multiple times in the story.
I love how the characters are implemented into the story. On Day 2 meet someone who has your back. And that same person is with you until the final major decision. He's well developed and seems almost human with the way he's written, having real motivations behind his actions that are very relatable to many people. Almost every main character you interact with has an effect on the story if they don't straight up give you a way out of the story. For those that don't give you a way out, they still plant seeds into your mind. What those seeds may be will vary and what they grow into is up to you, but the fact still remains that they have really thought the writing out.
The mechanics of the game have also been very thought out. It may look like dots on a map when you first start out, but it quickly expands when you hover over that dot. A name and a picture along with a general location does enough to put meaning into a character that will be on your screen for about a minute. And then there's more information on the person once you click on them, information that will almost never have an impact on the case at hand. As you go through their data, it plants more seeds of doubt in the system. And then you have to click one of two buttons. Do they go free, or do they not go free? No matter what button you click, there will be text that pops up. That text tells you what happens to that person. Solely because of what you decided to do. The weight behind all that is monumental at times. It makes you question your decisions at times. And it is absolutely well done.
The commentary on the security/liberty debate is where this game really shines. By establishing a connection with someone who will be on your side until the end of the game, it ensures that the line for most people will be blurred. It's story is written well enough to have it come out to you at points and ask you if what you are doing is right and warns you that it's a dangerous path that lies ahead if you continue down it. As you keep climbing the ladder at the DoL, it's not just the people around you that starts to make you question the morality of everything that happens here. That's before you start to notice that the decisions are starting to become less and less mundane as time goes by. And as it all comes to a head, there's one question in your mind:
How much are you willing to sacrifice for security?
This question meshes in well with other subplots in the story, whether it be surviving though nepotism or just trying to live a normal life. You see people early in the game have moral dilemmas when they have to do things like authorize a new technology early or have to decide on where to take their career. Adds a nice bit of background to the characters you meet along the way.


---------[END SPOILER TERRITORY]---------


All in all, this is a fantastic game. It's entertaining, has a well-written story, and has a lot of deep questions that you have to ask yourself as technology advances in today's world. Takes a bit of time to complete. It took me about 16 hours to do my first full run of it. And it was 16 hours well spent.

Final Ratings:
Story: 8/10
Need a little bit of suspension of disbelief to get the ball rolling, but once the ball does get rolling it's hard to stop it. Excellent twist that you can just straight up miss if you're not paying attention.
UI: 6/10
Hope you like dots. You'll be seeing them almost exclusively. Does contribute well to the whole computerized atmosphere of the game. Sometimes Person(s) Of Interest (POI) get lost in the southern side of the map or in places that aren't really in conventional areas (looking at you Alaska and Hawaii). Sometimes the UI overlaps itself if you click a button too early and there's dialogue or if there's a POI on the eastern side of the map in the space between the phone and what the office around you looks like. Map scrolling can be annoying, so you disable it and then it's annoying that it isn't scrolling, so you re-enable it and the scrolling gets annoying again, and then you get annoyed that you have to toggle this on and off so you just leave it one or the other an deal with it.
Music: 7/10
Can get a little repetitive with some of the longer levels, but it's pretty well written. It's electronic style fits well with the setting of the game. Musical cues also help out in some scenarios.
Commentary: 10/10
Can't go into too much detail without spoiling a lot of the game. If you don't care about spoilers, go back up and reread the section that I start by mentioning the commentary.
Overall: 8/10
It's fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123939774', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2622, 'last_played': 1608581235}
review:
Adventure Quest 3D (AQ3D) is a cross-platform MMORPG game, developed and published by Artix Entertainment.

This review is being written while the game is still in early access. When it gets fully released, this post will be edited as well.

Generally speaking, AQ3D is a nicely developed game with a few features seldom encountered (e.g. transforming into a mount instead of riding one) and while being in open beta, it still can be easily compared to other more popular MMOs. 

Although the game is good overall, there is a vast drawback that might be an issue for the AQ3D's future which is mentioned last in the cons section but, we still start with the advantages:

PROS:

- Beautiful Cosmetics

Probably the reason people mainly play and enjoy the game (including me). The designers have made an an outstanding job with a variety of cosmetics to choose from.

- All classes in one character

Currently, there are 9 classes in the game, which can be unlocked for free, except guardian which is the premium one. The most convenient part is all classes are playable by the main character and it's not the typical race-class format. Once it's unlocked, the players have access to the class which can be switched just by pressing a couple of buttons.

- Frequently updated

Like the developers have said, the game gets (almost) weekly updated which shows the amount of effort the company and members put in the game.

- Teleport everywhere

Apart from a few areas, the entire map is accessible through the teleportation system. The players are able to teleport wherever they want either from the menu, or through the portal located in the main city.

- Free-to-play

The game is entirely free-to-play with no pay gaps whatsoever. Supporting the developers is optional and by paying, it makes little to no difference for completing the main and sub story. It might take less time to unlock the other classes and acquire the guardian but the progression is quite the same for f2p players. It's more likely to be pay-to-look good than p2w.

Now that we have completed the main pros section, we will continue by including the drawbacks and, as we mentioned earlier, the last one might be the only major problem in this game.

CONS:

- Gear and item drops

These two are probably going together. Although the game revolves around cosmetics, acquiring gear from vendors might need a little rework. While gear can be bought or crafted by NPCs, the whole system is kind of unbalanced due to the fact that in most cases the required items have to be grinded, even though the players are able to find even better gear in the next area.

- Consumable travel form

That is most likely to be a double-edged sword. Although travel form is an exceptional idea, it comes with a price literally and figuratively. Travel form is a consumable item which transforms a character into a mount and gives the player approximately 160% speed which might boost a character's progression. However, the good news is, players usually obtain a few travel forms by opening daily chests.

- No end game content

Probably the major drawback in this game. Apart from lvl 31+ Noxus' return, when the players reach max lvl, there is nothing else to do whatsoever. Players log in to open the daily chest, rerun a lower level dungeon or in order to collect cosmetics.

While summarizing this review, I would like to pinpoint the last drawback due to its importance for the game's future. Unfortunately, this has happened before and it did not end up well. Games that had a massive potential, ended up losing almost all of its playerbase and eventually shutting down. Sadly, with the way games are evolving, 40-60 hours of gameplay and a lot of cosmetics are not enough to increase or even maintain the playerbase. Especially when it comes to MMOs.

This review tends to be more 'mixed' than yes but I'll post it as a yes because there is still room for improvement, the game is in early access and, it is literally free-to-play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963330804', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 2748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1410, 'last_played': 1529712674}
review:
A team-based co-op airship game with a sole emphasis of run-of-the-mill destruction objectives.

The Good:
+Can be run in LQ settings with a medium-tier laptop
+The airship combat leaves room for meaningful tactical choices
+Engineer/gunner jobs are somewhat casual roles, pilot/captain has the depth
+The leveling system is pretty. You get level ups pretty frequently to avoid the impression of being locked out á la some high-revenue games ( *cough League of Legends, CrossFire and Battlefront 2 2017 cough* ).
+It is not pay-to-win. Only cosmetics are sold. There are plenty of free costumes, so there is absolutely no pressure to spend extra money on this game.
+There are community events. Overally the community is pretty cool and non-judging even if you suck at the game. I haven't experienced a single griefer in this game.
+There is a lot of complexity in the ship and crew configurations. You can choose your TF2 style hats, items and special powers, rename the ship as "Your Mom" or "You Are Adopted" and pick some wacky guns for your ship. Very quickly you unlock half a dozen different ships, though the starter one seems to be in casual sense the best. No running through multiple decks for half a minute looking for that pesky balloon to repair on that one.


The Bad:
-The major battles can get unplayable laggy, to be point inputs drop like crazy and simple tasks like aiming with the gun and getting it to shoot reliably requires silly stuff like double-tapping and annoying levels carefulness
-It feels like a job and consequently attracts the MOBA flavour 3L1T3 PR0 gamers who view it as such and are super serious about winning.
-PvE aka "CO-OP"battles feel like endless slogs are worsen the "feels like a job" impression. Killing in PvE is ungratifying as the enemies keep respawning at a rapid rate (often exactly behind the player ship that is awful for killing fun factor in many ways)
-PvP games are simpler and less dull, though there are much less players for that
-The feeling of windedness from 
-The min-maxed PvP tactics. Everyone picks the weapons that are most cheap and most damaging, killing the variety. I see a lot of fire weapons being used.
-The "World" i.e. the tabletop risk game where players dump their otherwise worthless "war coins" (!?) to advance the progress bars of their faction. It is boring busywork.
-The main gameplay is outright repetitive. For instance, an engineer repairs, guns and pilots, a gunner mostly guns and occasionally repairs his gun and pilot pilots the ship. 
-Trying to get the full view of the ship and its surroundings is very difficult, let alone navigating yourself to where you need to be on the ship. On some ships, it can easily take 20 seconds of dedicated moving just to get to a remote part of the ship to fix it. Did I mention the game feels like work?
-The player retention is horrible. Finding players to play with is difficult. Mostly because of how inherently non-casual it is in how much WORK-like dedication it takes to properly play it. It practically has a reverse fun factor: the longer you play it, the worse you will feel. In comparison, the match rewards feel like nothing and the game feels like waste of time.
-It is a bit grindy. Nothing progresses if you do not play, preferrably for the win as defeats yield considerably less goodies regardless of the level of effort on the part of the player.
-It randomly crashes. It is outright unplayable in the defaul DX11 mode and still occasionally hangs in the much more stable DX9 mode, that you can only enter by running the game from Steam app library page.
-It has voice chat. The XBOX Live cancer is possible from those SERIOUS BIZNEZ -crowds. You have been warned. The lack of player retention makes this pleasantly rare, though.
-It is made with Unity. This is a very, very, very bad thing. I had to set my ATI settings to power-saving mode to stop it from overheating my GPU. Every Unity game has this effect and pretty much means it is a diarrhea turd. That is the sugar-coated way to describe it.
-The overuse of signaling gets easily on the nerves. Those repeated audio bites with some voices are godawful.
-The lack of variety in mission objectives. Kill, destroy or protect by killing and destroying, with occasional pressing of G to rope a floating supply balloon for bonus points. It gets old after the first time you do it. You'll end up doing it constantly if you keep playing this game. PvP and PvE are similar in this sense, except that PvP enemies have the variety of a human mind. Holy jumping boredom, Batman!

In summary, if you like airships and overly complicated, feels-like-work Team CO-OP games, this one's for you. 80% score . If you want to have a consistently casual, fun experience, your dissatisfaction is likely. 20% score. Because of the crazies who are likely to enjoy a game like this one, I have to technically recommend the game. Maybe it is better with friends. I got the free promotion entry and frankly it mostly feels like pain and I would have regretted paying any money for it. At least now I have something to boot up in case I feel like becoming a masochist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092972888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1680485405}
review:
A very fun rpg that lets you command spaceships of many sizes on you take over of the Gemini star system. The controls aren't too crazy, so once you get use to it you'll be understand what to do in any and all situations. flying takes place of a 3D plane so you can make all sorts of maneuvers including the famous "barrel roll". Pretty much as far as controls go it's exaclty like Starpoint Gemini 2, along with many other game mechanics. "So why don't I get Starpoint Gemini 2 in that case? Didn't you put like 200 hours into it?" Yes, but this will be even better because in here you'll be able to own a space station from which you can build fleets and send them out to conquer the GALAXY!!! You can assign officers to lead fleets to victory as well as defend your own space station from your quite rude adversarys. You can research weapons and technology! Set up mining in sectors with dense astroid fields! Personally own about 10 ships of your choosing! Titans! Dreadnaughts! Carriers! Battleships! Cruisers! Destroyers! Frigates! Corvettes and Gunships! What's the catch!?!?! 6 to 12 months of waiting for development of this gem to finish..... (depression sets in)

Patience/10 would wait for game development to finish again

author: {'steamid': '76561198001939379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1620, 'last_played': 1702264374}
review: Reductive of other titles without adding anything new to the genre. Depth of the food mechanic is great, but inconsistent with depth of other mechanics. Also early access DLC is just ... scummy.
developer_response: Hi there Bobert Hillson! We're sorry to see that you're disappointed with the game. We acknowledge that some of the mechanics of the game need to be additionally improved and you'll be pleased to know that we will indeed be doing this as we'll be nearing the full release of the game. As for the DLCs - they are purely cosmetic and serve as an additional means for our community to further support the studio and the development of the game. They do not detract us from making progress on the game, however we understand the negative connotations they bring with themselves. Hope this clears it up a bit and we hope that you'll give the game another chance - at least when we fully release the game.

Steve - Community Manager

review: I have played before, about a year ago, but with this new computer the game is not offering the normal options to declare what the villagers can do, other than forbidden areas they cannot build on.  What the heck changed?  I cannot tell them to do anything, or give them permission to harvest, or build,
developer_response: Hi. Since you last played, we introduced a (skippable) onboarding/tutorial, which might explain your early game experience. When you follow the onboarding, you unlock the first buildings gradually, so it's normal you don't have access to some of the painting zones/stuff you get by skipping it. In any case I can help you get off to a good start in the game, don't hesitate to ask =)

review: So far it is not the game I was hoping for even early access.  This is like early early early early access.  For now I'm gonna have to give this a no just because of the fact you apparently have to build a bathroom somewhere other than in the hotel room to get it to quit saying you have a defective bathroom that ironically the customers use just fine. review:
https://youtu.be/jhG0btuoclY
[h1]Mech Action for Somepeople[/h1]
The game has pretty cool concept and some great ideas, but i feel some parts were executed poorly. Controls were something that i couldn´t get used to, i feel the moving was rather clunky with some of the mechs and lack of controller support for the game is also another thing.

The game is not all bad however, the soundtrack is rather dope very good composing and solid tracks. I feel if the controls were better i would have spent more time with the game, but ultimately that made me drop it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008276226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1635695422}
review:
Game does not work for most people (depending on hardware I imagine) after a Windows update a couple of years ago.
Ubisoft are no longer supporting this game. It may work for you - it may not. (Again - seems to depend on whether specific hardware is in your system and how that hardware interacts with Windows)
Ubisoft won't care either way once they have your money
Another warning. The bug often only manifests after about turn 10. So get 10 turns in before your two hours of refund time is up, Once it starts to crash,. It will always crash. Read the rest of this review section to see how common this is.
developer_response: Hiya, Doc! I apologize for the issues you have faced regarding a recent Windows update! You may be able to by pass this issue by enabling [url= https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/make-older-apps-or-programs-compatible-with-windows-10-783d6dd7-b439-bdb0-0490-54eea0f45938]compatibility mode[/url] on your setup! Additionally, it would help to [url=https://ubi.li/cpsff]verify your game files[/url] and disable any [url=https://ubi.li/0YG8Z]background applications.[/url] For any lingering issues, I suggest that you check for pending [url=https://ubisoftconnect.com/en-US/]Ubisoft Connect[/url] updates then follow the steps in this  [url=https://ubi.li/gxhFR]general PC guide.[/url] If you are still unable to properly play your game, please let our [url=https://support.ubisoft.com/en-US]support team[/url] know by providing us with a screenshot of any error messages you see, along with a copy of your [url=https://ubi.li/lOylM]MSinfo/DxDiag Files[/url] and we will be happy to take a closer look at this situation for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065589278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1532229797}
review: Installs hidden program that uses your bandwidth to download without you knowing, hit my ISP bandwidth limit and had no clue why until i figured this out. Sketchy program from a sketchy company, download at own risk.
developer_response: Due to our player's feedback, we have made Gaijin.Net agent entirely optional during a Steam installation (now you can decide whether you want to use it, or not). Please note: Gaijin net agent is completely harmless and useful software, and not using it can lead to delays in updates, if Steam updates are switched off/or not effecient. We still recommend using our solution, it is essential to keep your game up-to-date to be able to play!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000371866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1022, 'last_played': 1698183390}
review: This is a fantastic sequel to the original Glass Masquerade. Very spooky theme, but very enjoyable jigsaws and beautiful moody music. The progression is a nice remix from the first game and was fun to move around the map. By far my favorite addition was the Hard mode, in which you can replay a level except the pieces aren't already at the correct rotation and you must rotate them yourself. it added a second replay to the game and I'm overjoyed!

review: Bought this game on a whim after going through my queue. I'm so glad I found it because it took me back to my early gaming days playing the old point and click adventure games. The story, artwork and voice acting are really well done and I found myself easily drawn in. The puzzles are decent, some requiring me to grab a pencil and paper and jot some things down, but not too difficult where I had to cheat and look up the solution. The game was a welcome break from the competitive multiplayer games I find myself playing too often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038867345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 949, 'last_played': 1674769312}
review:
I love this game so much. I was born in 2002 and found Adventure Quest when I was about eight because of my cousin and just never stopped playing until about 2015 but I eventually picked the game back up because I remembered it existed and here I am.
This game means so much to me and I really do love it a lot and feel like if you're on the fence about it then you should just try it at least because of how many years of content has been put into it.
developer_response:
Hey there and wow! Thank you so much for your heartfelt, extremely sweet review! It really means a lot to our team that you've stuck around with Artix Entertainment for so many years. 

We are so thankful that you've been enjoying AQ3D so far- we are stoked that you decided to give our newest title a try! We always appreciate it when old players reach out to us regarding our newer games, so thank you so much for sharing your thoughts with us! 

Again, thank you so much for making our day with your review! We really appreciate your support! 

Thanks again for reaching out! 

Battle On!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971125253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1548946658}
review:
Full of bugs, pretentious dialogue, characters and plot, the bugs can cause you to start a new game. It's also really boring. Like, spectacurarly dreadful. You have to wait to do everything and everything by itself in this game is monotonous and expectable, also "deep" and "philosophical". Did I mention there are a lot of bugs? "Early access" doesn't mean it's nearly unplayble, it means it's an early build that is supposed convince the public. Not this thing.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SWf_bOkgNXw
developer_response:
Hello, Gamer70s!
Recently we launched a huge update to MOE where we recreated almost the whole game and polished the hell out of the original idea. We understand why you didn't like it the first time, but we would like to ask you to give it another chance and see if you like the newest version of MOE. We believe that now the game is much-much closer to what you expected from the game and we are confident that you'll enjoy it!

Thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008604547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1899, 'last_played': 1448669745}
review:
Oh dear, I would have loved to love this, but that didn't happen, because, this game is just not ready. 

It looks really pretty and I really love the basic idea and concept (space colonization, yay!). However, the AI just does not work. 

In this game, you have to set up and manage a variety of supplie chains. so far so good. But your employees/colonists are just not up for the task and stand around or walk in circles, move boxes from here to there and back and forth and do anything exept following their priorities. That sucks and is a pain in the rear to watch. 

But still, I like the scope of the game, the settings and its presentation. Maybe in a few months, the AI will have grown up and the game will be fun. But as of now: nope.


EDIT (31.7h on record):

I gave this game another good chance. As I said, there's much to love about concept and presentation. But there are too many ways the AI does not work (does the term “artificial intelligence” rally apply here?). And that kills alot of fun.

Once I was lucky and I managed to grow my colony past 100 inhabitants, that's when my colonists started to take extended outdoor hikes to nowhere for no particular reason, only to suffocate one after another. After I lost too many engineers this way, my colony ran out of spares. And that's when the infrastructure started to crumble. I ran out of energy, then oxygen, and my station was rendered into an outrageously expensive space graveyard.

The colonist’s jobs are rather simple, actually. There's only a few basic specializations: worker, biologist, engineer, medic and security. But people are just not doing their jobs and the prioritization button has no function. You desperately need spares? Here's iron and a machine. But where's the engineer? He stands happily, walks, stands again, walks back, takes a nap, passes by the spares machine, looks, walks away, and so forth. Same with all the other roles, these things happen All. The. Frinking. Time.  And this is really very sad to watch. And I have seen enough.
developer_response:
Hello there! We noticed this review is quite old, and the game has been updated quite a bit since you wrote it.
We'd appreciate it if you'd try the latest version (1.0.7), to see if the improvements make you change your mind about Planetbase.
We've made AI improvements, gameplay tweaks, fixed many issues and added some new features too.

Thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198796084550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4362, 'last_played': 1708158764}
review: Love this game but lately, I can't play it well cause sometimes It's hard / error to connect to the server even though your connection is good. I Hope Ubisoft can solve this case so that players can enjoy the game more.
developer_response:
Hello there, Ismaran! I am very sorry to hear that you have been experiencing this behavior in The Crew 2. I can understand this can be frustrating to deal with during events. I would like to see if I can provide some solutions to help relieve these issues.

If you have noticed this after a recent update, I would first try [url=https://ubi.li/k3cYq]verifying your game files[/url] to see if this helps the issue. If this has already been tested with no new results, I would follow up by going through the steps from [url=https://ubi.li/YHecK] in this guide[/url]. While your connection is good and other games are connecting fine, these steps rule out any interferences that could be causing issues with communicating between The Crew service and your Internet Service.

However, if you are still running into any connection issues after exhausting all steps shared here, please don't hesitate to visit us on  [url= https://ubi.li/c0aBB]this site[/url] to continue review this with you one-on-one to provide different solutions. Thank you so much!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031721571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1539834154}
review: One of the most original games I have played in years! Loved the music, the simple yet complex characters, the bleak setting and the world-building. One of the few games that I enjoyed completing. My biggest complaint is that I wish the game had more side-missions and more areas to explore.  Buy this game and complete it, it's worth it!!
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind review! Glad you enjoyed the game -- and sorry we didn't have more for you to explore.  (As it is, we barely survived development, but I can see how more would've been nice.)  We did do a little bit of spin-off material on Primordia-Game.com, including a quasi-sequel story "Fallen," but it's not the same as more game content. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197990686216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1693944941}
review:
This an excellent game, both a great deal of fun and some pointed looks at child rearing and child rearing in China. It is both simple and detailed which I love. In case any readers do not know, the game continues from generation to generation so your mother or father will be an adult version of who you played yesterday. 

The translation is poor but not unusable, but for 10.00 this is maybe the best value on  Steam.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, It would be great if you can tell us which part of the translation is not good enough via contact@coconutislandstudio.com , titled with [Chinese Parents translation feedback], and it would be even better with some example screenshots. So that we can improve the translation, thanks very much in advance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048341101', 'num_games_owned': 598, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1495697403}
review: Everything about the game feels outdated. Horrible PC controls, couldn't get into an even slightly enjoyable vibe. Not for me.
developer_response:
Hi and sorry for intruding on your review like this.

Of course it's not a thrill to see the game disappointed anyone, but we do whatever we can to improve it and make it more enjoyable for everyone. Could you please elaborate a bit more on what troubles you in the game? Specifically, the controls. What do you feel is the main issue and could you perhaps give me a few examples on what you feel would fit better?

Thank you for your time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039159891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1622696673}
review:
TLDR; Its a good short Cyberpunk driving simulator, but it could be much more. Too much effort on the store, not enough on gameplay.

The driving is good, but this game is very shallow. The gameplay is go from A to B and sometimes C. You are given many choices throughout the game but they all feel shallow. You are given a brief and incomplete version of some events and expected to make a binary choice. I kept hoping that there was anything more, some reason to explore the world, but there isn't really anything else. I think that its a shame since the driving is good and the world is huge and looks great.

I think that there were some concepts that were teased early on that I feel could have made this game a lot better. First is racing, we are teased about races going on a lot but we don't see any nor can we participate. Next is interaction with law enforcement. I hit many law enforcement HOVAs, but never received a fine or was chased which made the "CorpSec" seem silly despite the story suggesting otherwise. Another thing is that there are only a few purchasable customizations and it was easy to have enough money for all of them half way through if you spend any time picking up the random items. They could have used them as another way to explore if they had money as a larger incentive.

If there was a "meh" option, I would choose that. However, I feel that it is fitting that this is a binary choice for which the concequences are unclear and I feel I put more effort into making it than it deserves.
developer_response: Thanks for your review. Since the game came out last year, we added many changes to it. But racing for example didn't make it into the main game. I just wanted to mention that we added street racing to the recently launched City of Ghosts expansion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061973882', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3291, 'last_played': 1709230038}
review:
Pros:
Not pay to win. The Dragon Crystals are used to speed up crafting, buy classes without farming (so far only DragonSlayer but I suspect this will be the case for Paladin, Necromancer, etc) and cosmetics. No stat advantage is really given through the micro-transactions.

Regularly updated. I have been keeping up with this game since the kickstarter first started, the developers release a lot of updates that keep people looking forward to the next release.

From my experience other players are willing to help someone with their quest or boss fight which is helpful as certain fights can't be solo'd without potion spam.

Cons:
The graphics are horrible for a game that started it's development in the year it did. The textures aren't smooth, they get blurry and look like they're carelessly painted on without much attention given. I understand this game was intended to be cross-platform for PC and Mobile/Tablets but this holds it back.

The combat system simply isn't fun. It's the same combat system from their 2D game Adventure Quest Worlds just ported over to AQ3D. You press 4 buttons in battles that are not engaging enough. The weapon types don't really matter, the player uses a cross bow as a melee weapon, the team should have figured out how to make different weapon types have different actions and animations before releasing them. The boss Akriloth has a decent take on actual mechanics but it's no where near good enough. There are times when the player clearly dodges an attack from Akriloth but the hit still registers and the player takes damage.

Many mobs in this game are reskins or just plain copy and pasting but with a different time attached to the monster and this includes boss monsters. 

AQ3D has limited character customisation, truthfully it has improved since the Alpha when they added hair colour options, beards and so on. The thing customisation is lacking is different body types. I'm not asking for a detailed body creation but preset templates would be an improvement to give the player a sense of individuality. Right now players are just clones of eachother but with different hairstyles and skin colours. 

Reliance on the player base's nostalgia is also another factor. Most people that play this game were fans of Artix Entertainment's previous games and they are aware of this. This game once again takes place on Lore with characters that have already appeared in the other games. I would have liked it if it took place on the same world but a different continent with fresh new characters and cameos from old characters sprinkled in.

Conclusion:
Can I recommend the game in it's current state? No. If you are someone which has never played an Artix Entertainment game before you probably won't like this game.
If this game was made by an unknown developer it wouldn't have the playerbase it has today.
The team behind this game needs to focus on developing the mechanics of this game further and polishing it instead of the stories and Dragon Crystal cosmetic collections they're releasing right now as if it's a properly released game.
developer_response:
Hi there! Thank you so much for your feedback! The devs are constantly working on fixing and improving issues and releasing updates/patches almost weekly. This has been a constant balance as an indie game company with a small staff. We also have a Game Plan posted here that is updated every Monday - https://aq3d.com/game-plan/. 

Regarding some of your specific points:

For the art style, Artix Entertainment has always had a unique art style and we find that that sets up apart from other companies. If we tried to compete with FFIV graphics or Guild Wars, it'd take forever for our handful of artists to get anything made and people would just play those games instead. We made a decision to help us stand out, and give us a reasonable pipeline.

Combat is definitely still rough. Akriloth is like a rough example of what we want the game to feel like. The fun part of Akriloth is how the mechanics are a hack. The debs haven't had a chance to tackle beefier combat mechanics but we looked at what we had and improvised. One the plus side, it feels a lot better than the usual "stand next to enemy, spam number keys". On the con side, like you said, it's noticeable when you leave the area and still take the hit. Think of it as a proof of concept of what we're aiming for, and eventually we hope to have legit tools to make it happen and not have to jump through the hoops we did.

Most MMOs reskin mobs. It's hard to avoid this one without just buying assets or spending tons of time on more unique enemies. Right now, we try to trickle them in the existing pipeline but our animator ends up spending tons of time on cinematics more than mob animations.

For character customization, we definitely want more features but nothing has been completed yet that is ready to go live.

We're definitely relying on the playerbase right now considering we haven't spent any ad dollars. Despite saying this is beta, this is still closer to early alpha as far as features. Once we feel the game has enough features to start spending ad money on (so far, no ad money spent), we'll see how we stack against the non-nostalgia crowd. The game is still early enough in development that in any AAA studio, no one would even have seen gameplay footage, yet. But we're all about the early access here which means you get to see all the broken stuff that spawns the polished stuff. (even the difference between initial combat visualization and now is incredibly different).

We definitely appreciate you pointing out that we're not pay to win and we are honored you have been keeping up to date with the game for so long! At the end of the day, we're definitely aiming higher than what you see, but it takes time and we are a tiny team!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011539099', 'num_games_owned': 1244, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 4169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1656, 'last_played': 1660756425}
review:
While i only played this game (to completion) 2 times in the 5 years i brought it, it is always on my mind!
i actually can remember most of the game perfectly, it's one of those stories that just sticks with you, the universe that was created for the game is vast and unexplored, not in a bad way, it does feel that there is much more out there, but we are in "This Story" so we can't go poking around, even so, it leaves you with a curiosity to know more.
And this is just story-wise because HOLY DAMN, The Art is AMAZING, and it actually inspires me a lot to this day!
i really wish i was better at reviewing or saying nice things about a product but.... all i can say about this one is:



You like Sci-Fi?
-Get this

You like Robots?
-Get this

You like Steampunk/Cyberpunk?
-Get this

You like Deep Pixelated, Story-Driven Games?
-GET. THIS.



10/10 - No question! i really wish we can go back to this universe one day, it's too unique!~
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind review. It’s a wonderful thing to read at the end of my Thanksgiving day!

author: {'steamid': '76561198357704804', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 152355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151015, 'last_played': 1686430152}
review:
This game is EXTREMELY poorly managed. And trust me, this means alot, because most of the time i overvalue games and i respect the developers alot. I also recommend most of the games i play, to my friends. I would honestly not recommend crossout to anyone. This became one of the worst games i have ever played. Just because of some poor decisions

Let me talk about some key elements of the game.

GRINDING
Don't be fooled by the fact that the game is free. The small playerbase is used to invest lots of money in the game, so as a new player, or a player who really plays for free, it's a dead end. You will be smashed by the others, since the items are tier based and every tier is more expensive than the prior one. The last one takes few months, even years of grinding, depending on how often you play, of course, if you don't pay real money. That being said, you might just find yourself in huge disadvantages if you play for free. There were decent ways to farm in game coins fast, but don't worry, the developers made sure to patch them, so everything is a slow process and you don't get anything significant without paying them.
Also, don't have a mindset where you consider buying a single pack worth, for a single overpowered item. This never stops, they always release packs, and after that they pummel the old stuff into the ground, so new stuff can be on top and that will encourage you to buy it. 

I will rate this with 4/10.

GAMEPLAY
The game had a period when it was decent. That was the time when i enjoyed the game alot.  But they made sure to screw that, just for money. Now the game revolves around cringe playstyles, like pushing, incapacitating, exploiting, slowing, ramming (basically, you can't fight back in many cases) and most importantly, the no need of aiming. The developers love auto-aim, so even on PC, you see it everywhere. There is no such thing as FAIR PLAY in this game. I'd say that exploiting stuff is about 60%, randomness is 30% and skill is 10%. The percentage of skill went in a constant decrease over the time. There are very low chances to see strategic gameplay, like map control, taking vantage points, everything is either full camp, where you wait your enemy and incapacitate them, or brainless push your enemies and also, you incapacitate them by pushing them and pinning them onto a wall. Every update goes into that direction, even more deep. Everything with potential and needed skill is diminished or removed, i guess that comes from the fact that the amount of people which would embarrass themselves and play something that's not fair, are also not that bright, and they have worse financial education, that means more money into the devs' pockets if those people are satisfied.

I will rate with 5/10.

GAME BALANCE
This is awful. I won't explain much here, it's basically determined by what brings most income to the devs. What encourages the players to pay, is extremely strong. After it becomes old and there is new stuff bringing fresh money, that item is balanced or it goes into oblivion and no one uses it anymore. There is a big gap between the items of this game (time to kill differs alot, some things are too resistant, while other fall down in one sneeze). You will convince yourself of this, when you realize how many weapons, movement parts, cabins and hardware parts this game has, and how many are actually used by the majority. You might enjoy this game until you start getting one shotted or when you find yourself in situations where you lose without the chance of fighting back.

2/10.

CREATIVITY
It got diminshed by the time, which is very sad, because it is the main attraction of this game. Now mostly everyone uses ugly crafts, and most likely, easy to use and copied from exhibition.

A solid 8/10 tho.

GAME MECHANICS
Bugs are very numerous, they take months to be solved (while money based packs are released more often xD), or.. they never get solved. Because the engine is like 20 years old. So in my opinion, it has no further potential. The game reached its pinnacle some time ago, now it's only falling down. Mobility is awful, and there are various ways to even decrease the mobility. Is the game related to reality? Hell no.

4/10.

MANAGEMENT
As i said, bugs are not solved too often, not even the game breaking ones. After all, it doesn't give them more money. They don't care too much about the english speaking community. They don't care at all about your progress in the game. They don't care if you get hacked. You can farm for something you desire for months or years, they can always render it useless. The only consolation you will get is that you can sell it or scrap it, which gives you way less of the value it had in the moment you decided to acquire it. They sometimes decide to add A FEW additional details on the current maps. They take the maps away (why tho?), and after few months or years, they release them back with like 4-5 more barrels, 2-3 more rocks and one source of smoke. The game has a small playerbase and too many modes, so queue times are long. The game servers are pretty unstable, you sometimes might find yourself disconnected, with no possiblity to go back to the current match. As a good and funny joke, the game decides to ban you for unsportsmanlike behavior, because you left the battle. Another detail i must mention, if you are not from europe or north america, don't even bother trying the game, the lag makes it close to unplayable. Perpetual beta, good cover for their shady actions.

2/10.

FAIR PLAY
One good aspect of the game is the reduced number of cheaters, you will be really lucky to see one, honestly. But you won't miss them, since the players can exploit so many things in this game, and it's even more frustrating than encountering cheaters. Cheaters can be banned, but you won't be banned for exploiting and ruining someone's experience. Auto aim is all around the place, and sometimes it is more rewarding than aiming manually and playing fair. Sometimes, you will find yourself dead in the beginning of the round, because of a sneaky guy. That's also a very common thing.

5/10

COMMUNITY
Overall, the community is pretty toxic. Some of this toxicity is provided by the frustration, frustration that comes from the gameplay. Some players wanna win with any price, they have no honour, so ruining your experience is not an obstacle for them. They embarrass themselves in the most deplobrable ways just to win, and the developers strongly encourage that. The player of this game are also very hypocrites, good amount of them play only for that small ego boost you get from pvp and pretend it's for fun.

6/10

AI IN THE GAME
Crossout relies on bots alot, because the community is small and activity is low. Man, sorry to say but, if you would hire a janitor, he would do a better job on the AI honestly. The bots have the following behavior, rush blindly at the beginning of the round, they take agro on some player and they're so determined on that, they could chase that specific player through an acid lake, a group of enemies without even considering switching targe. This is very disappointing because the game has alot of PVE.

1/10.

This comes from someone who played the game for over 5k hours total (not only steam), and played alongside the best players in the game, for a long time, so winning was not an issue. Just imagine how bad this game is designed, that you hate it even when you win alot.

Did i mention there are INVISIBLE WALLS ON LITERALLY EVERY ROCK OF EACH AND EVERY MAP?

UPDATE 2nd of december. They just released a battlepass. That battlepass had an item with an unfinished model. But it still got released. Not only that, but half of the content was from a previous battlepass. The greed level is unprecedented

My advice for potential new players? Stay the hell away from this game. Consider it a scam and just avoid it

author: {'steamid': '76561198158196956', 'num_games_owned': 3756, 'num_reviews': 189, 'playtime_forever': 1303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1682720916}
review:
[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/32296668-Casual-Game-Reviews/]More reviews on our Curator Page[/url]

Announced back in 2018, [b]Contraband Police[/b] has been one of the most anticipated titles amongst the [i]PlayWay S.A.[/i] catalogue. Considering their large and wide deck of high quality games, that is saying a lot.
After a couple of delays, and fans questioned if the game was ever coming out, [i]Crazy Rocks[/i] absolutely shutters any doubt, releasing it with an absolutely outstanding quality

The game is good, so good, it's a straight up Double-A title, elevating any expectation you could ever have. If you think this is just another simulation game, you have no idea where you're getting in! [b]Contraband Police[/b] will surprise you, as it surprised me throughout its campaign.

Welcome to Acaristan, a fictional Communist country in an equally fictional world surrounded by different cultures and values. You're the fresh appointed rookie to the border post. Your job? Control everyone that comes in, as you have to look out for criminals, contraband and even deal with humanitarian dilemmas.

All of this looks great on paper, but perhaps a bit simple. That's why [i]Crazy Rocks[/i] went all in, delivering an elaborate and engaging game, fusing management and action in an exciting campaign, surrounding players with a plot, choices and events that further extends the overall experience.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

After the conclusion of the well elaborated tutorial, which does a great job teaching the basic mechanics, a considerable amount of new features will unlock progressively. It's a great way to avoid players being overwhelmed, since there are quite a few of them. Checking ID Cards, Passport Numbers, or possible hidden contraband is just the beginning.

As days progress, new factors will unlock, such as the need to check the licence plate, vehicle type and its weight, and many more. The principles go much deeper, as players start to notice changes amongst the regime rules. Political conflicts may end up in harsh decisions, such as denying entry based on country of origin, or even profession. 

You, as the border officer, can inevitably accept or refuse whoever you see fit, but each time the intended decision is taken, money is earned. Having a negative flow will result in the post bankrupt. However, decisions truly become dilemmas when morality is questioned. Some of the people you either accept or refuse will eventually reach out to you, detailing the impact of your decision. I found this to be a nice little touch.

With your daily obligations completed, you are free to roam the town as you wish. Take prisoners to the Labor Camp for an extra profit, trade or buy new items and weapons, search collectables or treasures, and engage in shoot-outs. I found the time after the working hours to be really satisfying, but also very short.

[b]Contraband Police[/b] is far more than a 3D [b]Papers, Please[/b], in fact, it's a straight-up Police Sim game with no compromises in its arrangement. Random events will trigger which require you to defend an area, support officers of the law or just chase down criminals on the runaway. Other events, however, are story related and progress hand in hand with your rank. These missions are unique and present a special overview regarding the country's regime. Spy on the opposition, tail suspects, or help to solve a murder by collecting evidence and hearing the witness.

As you earn money, experience and new ranks, it's almost obligatory to improve your outpost. Upgrade or hire new guards, expand the jail, storage and your own house. Buy new police vehicles and upgrade them to become an unstoppable force. These updates will save you time and help you further manage the confiscated goods.

Let me tell you, for such a small town, there are terrorists trying to overtake the regime, criminals who want to put their hands on the confiscated goods, or just a bunch of misfits who want to free the prisoners. The roads are not safe, and while driving around you have a new third person camera, in case driving in first person isn't your cup of tea. The overall driving feels substantially solid and satisfying, with welcoming realistic touches included.

You wouldn't be a police officer ready to change the regime without some shooting involved, right? In [b]Contraband Police[/b], the intense shoot-outs feel good, not over the top as you'd expect in a [i]Call of Duty[/i], but instead allowing you to decide the best approach.  Either escape or face the threat. The last option will reward you, especially because you can loot the enemies. Even though they tend to disappear rather quickly after you kill them.

With 30 different days, [b]Contraband Police[/b] is quite lengthy, offering quite the replayability. During scripted moments, the game will save at every major spot. Otherwise, it will save in the beginning of the day, and at the end of your duty. I'd still prefer a quick-save function, but I understand the idea of having players dealing with their choices. You can even consider this to be perhaps the first Police Survival game, if you will. 

Difficulty wise, it's a slow start, where escaping with life may very well be your biggest reward. But as money starts to flow, and with better gear, those criminals have their days numbered. The progression is highly gratifying, and playing it without restarting the day will most likely result in peculiar moments. Not to mention you can in fact lead your border post to bankruptcy, so the whole dynamic value of choices is important.

[h1]Final Notes[/h1]

Visually, Contraband Police looks good, has some nice design touches and textures. I particularly enjoyed the lightning, perhaps out of everything else. However, a lot of work went to create a handful of different vehicle sets, plus a distinguishable deck of NPC's. These two aspects are, after all, obligatory considering the game we're dealing with. If you like how the aesthetics look here on the Steam Store, you'll overall enjoy its visuals through and out.

I have been playing since February 27th, which by then Contraband Police was already very stable. I believe it was already in its stable version, and although updates having been released, the overall performance was always quite decent.

Settings offer some optional changes, but I found the optimization to be quite good for a game developed in Unity. Only lost a few frames when driving in the third person mode. I did, however, had Anti-Aliasing maxed out. Shadows and other details can also be lowered, but with an RX 6700 XT, the game ran flawless at maximum settings. The frame drops were most likely due to my CPU.

Aside from all the possible configurations, I found Field of View to be the most limited one, maxes out at just 70. The language package is very diverse and will most likely satisfy players worldwide.  Considering the active development cycle, you can expect new features being implanted in the future, either by further re-arranging the performance, or by adding new gameplay content.

Which side will you choose? Free the country, or play by the rules of the regime? It's your call. Different outcomes surprised me, as I was expecting a much more linear setting. Still, with an amazing setting, captivating gameplay and a strong sense of freedom, [b]Contraband Police[/b] is incredible for its price tag, especially with a discount on launch day.
developer_response: Thank you very much for such an extensive review, we're glad you enjoyed the experience :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197988821061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1840, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1760, 'last_played': 1639451149}

author: {'steamid': '76561198143095285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1504101493}
review:
I really wanted to like this game and enjoyed it initially. Unfortunately the RNG mechanics just make it no fun. Constantly looking for something to keep your charcters alive with everything in the game working against you. There are no moments of feeling like you are making headway. A real shame.

The save game system also needs work. You can only 'save and quit' for some reason. There is no way to save your game once you get yourself in a position where you feel somewhat comfortable. The game saves your progress automatically.

I'm changing my recommendation to 'yes' since the latest updates. I would still like to see the save system changed up a bit but overall the balance seems better. I will add more to this update when and if I complete the game.

UPDATE: For some reason I cannot stop playing this game even though the RNG seems punishing. I have not made it further than zone 3 but I keep going back. It is definitely worth the asking price.

UPDATE #2: I have only made it as far as zone #4 but I like this game more and more each day. BUY IT.
developer_response:
Thank you for your review!

We've launched a couple of updates where we've fixed balance as well. We hope you'll enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117843545', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1449253092}
review:
It's a nice game, for sure.
The gameplay is interesting and deep, and the multiplayer aspects keep it nice enough to keep it around in your library for a longer time.
The combat system is interesting for sure, especially if you like micro-managing as much as I do.
Point is, while the game itself is very interesting, it has slightly outdated graphics.
While this is perfectly fine if you like Diablo 1-styled graphics, I personally dislike those type of graphics.
Especially because, for some odd reason beyond my knowledge, it's incredibely demanding for my PC (Intel i5, 4 GB RAM, Geforce 920M, so it shouldn't be so difficult for my pc ._.)
However, if you like turn-based micromanaging combat with graphics in between Diablo 1 and Tibia, then this game is definitely for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197981469040', 'num_games_owned': 5564, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1514216021}
review:
The VR aspect of this game is a novelty and reasonably fun until you realise the game is not actually good.

Most of the content is arbitrarily locked and although you can customise your ship loadouts, you're forced to unlock the weapons for them, not to mention the ship classes. Thus in the campaign mode (once unlocked) you are unable to build carriers or battleships until your user account reaches the requisite level.

The game itself is frustratingly buggy - upon loading a campaign whole fleets have disappeared, battles stop working after playing one and the save and exit feature appears to do nothing and you're forced to close the game in order to return to the menu.

The 3D models of ships are fixed for each class - there is no differentiation between nations or any hint of any actual ship classes. There really isn't any depth to the game, which isn't necessarily a bad thing for a casual game but the repeated bugs and content-locking thinned my patience far more quickly than I would have liked.
developer_response: Thanks for the review and feedback. We have just released the 1.6 update that changes the unlock system and also allows players to bypass it if they wish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011846784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1549931465}
review:
Had a lot of fun for the first 2 hours, then i started getting matched with level 20+ people. I don't care about losing, but i had a glimpse of what the game is played at higher levels, and it's just a big, sad mess. The "pass" button goes completely forgotten, everyone just shoot the ball very hard on a wall and tries to deflect it multiple times after every bounce. I ended up getting the hang of it, but IMHO the fun of the game just goes out of the window.

TL,DR: started playing a fun, footbally game - ended playing a couple of tennis-squash messy matches that made me uninstall without a second thought.
developer_response:
What you saw was not high level play. High level play requires very complex and intensive passing.

I'm sorry you got put in a match with too high level players. The more players are online, the better the matchmaking works.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197986853226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 301, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1609134386}
review:
Vortex of Pain is coming along, though I still don't think it's worth full price for most people. There’re only 3 levels, and there's alot of jank. For example, I've died twice so far just from jumping. No nearby explosions, full health, not falling out of the map or off of a ledge, immediate death on landing from a normal jump. If you don't mind this kind of thing, read on. Otherwise, wait for polish.

Vortex of Pain is a side-scrolling beat-em-up with alot of unpolished physics interactions. Sometimes the interactions are hilarious, as when everything or your enemies are blowing up and flying everywhere. Other times, as mentioned above, you're dying for either no apparent reason or for reasons that seem outside your control. There are mundane annoying moments, like when a random enemy headbutts you out of nowhere and you're forced to wait for your character to just get back up already before being knocked down again, and there are awesome moments like when you find yourself bouncing enemies in the air and against walls repeatedly.

The worst moments haven't been bad enough to offset the fun ones. The environments are visually distinct, if odd due to lower-end assets, and the enemy types feel different from each other. There are standard large and small enemies, backflipping ninja enemies, enemies that try to act like cars, mimes that grapple you... there's at least 1 other indie beat-em-up I can think of (but won't mention) that looks better but somehow lacks even this much enemy variety.

Player abilities feel fairly standard, and have been improved from when I first tried the game. You can now automatically grab enemies when you walk into them, which makes grappling far easier and useful over needing to rely on a grapple button. The grappling button is still present, but I've always found it hard to use.

Overall, still fun if a little frustrating for the weird deaths. Even if you don't buy today, I'd recommend keeping an eye on Vortex of Pain.
developer_response:
Thank you for your feedback! We just released an update which addresses some of your critiques.

"It's a bit like rolling a die to determine if you'll randomly explode while playing Streets of Rage."

We'd like to hear from players if there are some places that are too chaotic for their own good. We are trying to find a balance between having funny unexpected situations, but also giving the player a chance to react to them and use them for his/her advantage. In this update, we reduced the bounciness of the ball props to give the player a better chance to react to them, and removed some of them from the mall level's sport shop.

"Another janky aspect of Vortex is how you don't collide with enemies. At all. In several other beatemup titles, walking into enemies automatically triggers a grab state without using a button. In Vortex, you and the enemy can simply pass through each other. This can make it harder to determine when you can actually grab the enemies, and I generally found it to be far more effective to not even try."

We added a traditional grappling mode where the player starts grappling when walking into enemies. We forgot to mention in the tutorial section that it's easier to succeed in grappling if the enemy is staggered first by punching him. We added that hint to the tutorial, and worked on the gameplay guidance in general. We added small video screens which demonstrate the most complex moves to the first level, and loading screen and game over tips about undocumented features, moves and strategies.

"Your general abilites are fairly standard. You can run, jump, execute an attack string, and utilize a heavy attack, in addition to the previously mentioned grab. All feel fine in execution, although I often found myself wishing it was a bit easier to juggle enemies and thereby kill them faster. Everyone (you and your foes) spend so much time lying on the ground that it can get tedious waiting for everyone to get back up."

We reduced the time enemies and players spend lying on ground and slightly sped up the rising animations. We also slightly reduced health from some of the weakest enemies. On the hard difficulty levels, enemies' health is balanced in a way that it is supposed to encourage the player to use and mix diverse moves, like strong attacks, air attacks, grapples and air grapples instead of relying on the basic combo strikes to beat them faster.

"At the moment, Vortex of Pain has only 3 levels. However, the levels are not overly short, and there're significant opportunities to test your skills in each one. If I have any complaints regarding their structure (unrelated to how bland looking they are), 
it's that each level feels fairly similar to me. Each starts kinda easy, then gets hard up to about the same level of difficulty. If more levels are added down the road, I hope the developers go back and adjust the difficulty accordingly."

We are working on new levels, and we plan to adjust the overall difficulty of the game throughout the project. The difficulty was slightly adjusted in the new update
(mostly by adding a few more enemies and making some enemy types stronger) to make overall level of difficulty higher as the game progresses. We'd love to hear more difficulty feedback from players on the discussion board.

Full patch notes: https://store.steampowered.com/newshub/app/887170/view/2896341257764404011

author: {'steamid': '76561198076664688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 99135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98989, 'last_played': 1670467921}
review:
While my initial impression was of a visually stunning, seeming endless open world space opera, it has now shifted more towards an endless grind with little to no incentive, no real content and no soul. Initially, I thought this game was great and, as the number of hours played indicates, I enjoyed trying out the various aspects of the game (space trucking, exploration, combat, mining, etc).  If these types of game play interest you, then maybe wait for a sale and have at it.  The problem is that absolutely everything you do is self-driven.  There is no 'winning', no end-game content...just more of the same, ad infinitum.  Eventually there's a point where the game transitions from cool and interesting, to repetitive and pointless. You'll have billions of credits, own every ship, be elite in every category and have nothing left but more of the same.

Additionally, the Odyssey "expansion" (note the use of quotes - this is NOT an expansion in my opinion) has, if anything, increased the required pointless grinding, decreased the graphical diversity, and has provided absolutely no new story content.  The changes to the game menus and UI actually make no sense and are challenging enough to experienced players and will, in many cases, confuse new players aplenty. Save yourself time and money and look elsewhere for your space opera fix.

There are many great community content creators out there who can provide a more comprehensive review on the current state of Elite Dangerous and I encourage anyone thinking about diving into this game to check them out first.
