author: {'steamid': '76561197993475888', 'num_games_owned': 875, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1547409653}
review:
[h1]Some words and personal relation before actual review:[/h1]
Every job has difficulties and moral dilemmas every now and then. Professional journalists for example, may have to write about thing they aren’t quite interested in, or even worse, criticize something they might have warm feelings about. For fan type reviewers such difficulties are quite uncommon, however sometimes exclusions of the rules happen. 

I was supposed to finish this review by the release date, but decided to hold horses and give developers a bit more time to fix bugs, as game was quite broken on release. Maybe if actual game had <Early Access> plank, the review would’ve been positive as a measure of “prepayment” for a quite promising concept and active development, because it’s one of those nice cases when developers seem to listen to the community and fix what’s not working. 

With that being said, it breaks my heart even more, to give “The Last Train” a negative review, however as of today (that is 10.09.2018) I’m afraid I still cannot recommend the game. Maybe few months later things will be completely different, and people are going to smile, while reading this review. I honestly hope things WILL change, but again, as of today, I’m afraid I still cannot recommend the game. 
However let’s begin our analysis and see why it took me so much text to write such a strange preview:

[h1]So what is this game about?[/h1]
“The last train” is a mixture of adventure, RPG and survival game where you take a role of a train driver in 1945 in alternative universe, where World War 2 ended by Japan making a devastating attack on USA. As name claims, you’ll work as driver of train engine in USA. You are supposed to pick up passengers and deliver them to the point of destination. Upon arrival, those passengers give you food and materials for upgrading the train.

[h1]The story and game world[/h1]
The game offers two gamemodes: Story and Survival. The only real difference between them is that story mode has… Actual storyline. In survival mode you are supposed to deliver passengers till you’re out of resources. Then you’ll get a high score and will be able to compare it with other players.

So let’s return to the story mode: The game starts in quite shiny colors and the narrator gives us brief information on what happened and why there’s an apocalypse now. Basically, that’s the whole story for the upcoming 1-2 in-game months. From now on you’ll have to survive in game world. So yes, the concept is interesting, however the first problems rise here already:[list]

[*]It is unclear how to move the story forward. You just drive from one state to another and deliver passengers. Then suddenly some more pieces of story pop up. Aaaaand done. You’ll have to deliver more passengers. Did this story part activate because I delivered enough passengers? Did it activate because I left many passengers behind? What do I need to do to activate next part of the story? Nobody knows.

[*]The story itself seem to revolve around you and your train. While that doesn’t quite seem like a problem on paper, there actually is a problem behind the lines, as game doesn’t elaborate much on ingame universe: What happened to the other states which you can’t visit? Were they nuked? What’s going on in Europe and Asia? Does the war still go on there? So many questions, so few answers…

[*]That’s mostly nitpicking, but: What kind of technology level is in this universe, if people are starving and suffering, but every second passenger can offer you enough fuel to travel to another state?[/list]

 [h1]Visual Aspect[/h1]
In most cases visuals look interesting. Dark colors really manage to depict depressive universe. Each station has unique look, showing each state’s most famous places. There are also almost all 50 states available for a visit, so if you are uncommon with USA geography, this game might even give you a short lesson on the location of the most states of the country. During journeys you’ll see many nice looking places, be it some city ruins, or oceans with sank ships. Unfortunately game has some unpleasant surprises in store as well: [list]

[*]While overall gamma is introduced via dark colors, there’s a toxic green train for player’s choice which looks quite out of place. Usually dark colors fit with bright red, when one wants to show, for example, blood. But toxic green? That’s something personally I see for the first time.

[*]Lack of animations. This is something I’m really surprised to see. You’ll quickly notice that not a single train part is animated. For a game where train takes an important part of gameplay it’s a really huge letdown.[/list]

 [h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
Saying in advance: no, you cannot control your train via keyboard. The only time when you have direct control over the train is during actual preview. In normal gameplay you’ll have to maintain balance between picking up a passenger you want to help and a passenger who offers better reward. Upon having enough materials you can cook, craft items or upgrade your train, enlarging the inventory size, increasing the amount of passengers you can carry, etc... If you are low on resources, you can visit the city and break into houses (make sure to keep crafted special tools on hand, though). Each house can be broken into only once. Obviously, we’ll cover weak spots here too:[list]

[*]Cooking system is totally broken and unneeded at this point. What’s the point of cooking a salad which gives +5 nutrition points, if you can just eat items separately and have up to +15 nutrition points? That’s not even mentioning the fact some food types have negative nutrition points. Another problem with food is that you can never see the final dish you’ll cook. Because of cooking blind, you also risk to prepare spoiled food with -10 nutrition points. So tell me, how could one break that system so badly?

[*]Unbalanced rewards system. At this point there’s simply no need to travel on far distances as rewards quite often are the same.

[*]A lot of bugs which bring devastating effect to fun:
-When you upgrade the amount of passengers your train can carry, you are supposed to see more train carriages. That doesn’t happen because coordinates for said carriages are misplaced and only on top tier upgrade you can see about ¼ of the first carriage.
-When delivering multiple passengers to the station, each of them is supposed to bring a pop up window and thank your driver, but instead of closing one window, sometimes you somehow manage to close all the windows at same time, which is quite annoying and doesn’t always let you even read the final of their story.
-Passengers walking on the station are easy to be misclicked. Especially when there are multiple of them and they walk closely. Things get even worse once you upgrade your train, as by this upgrade, your train moves further forward and stops by the center of the screen, so you have to blindly move mouse and try to hit needed passenger.[/list]

[b]There are more things I could tell, but let’s just stop it here and sum it all up:[/b]
On the one hand we have a nice looking and somewhat promising game concept. It indeed has some strong points and some day it may shine, even, who knows.

On the other hand we indeed have a CONCEPT of the game in its worst meaning: Lack of train animations, tons of bugs, unbalanced reward system, broken cooking…  All of that indicates on either lack of experience or lack of time from developers. Clearly, game should’ve had Early Access in the end of the days. Maybe it would give developers enough time to fix what’s broken and even add some more interesting features, like more random events. That would certainly spice things up.

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/23741321/]Follow our curator page,[b] Alexander's Club Curations[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]
developer_response:
Hi Rain,
Thanks a lot for taking your time to play the game we really appreciate it. Our team is hard at work fixing most of the issues you've mentioned. As far the story beats go, it is based on which passenger you pick up and which ones you leave behind. We are currently working on version 1.1 which will resolve most of the above mentioned issues including the cooking balance, train carriage issue and pop up close, we are adding the hazmat suit as a craftable item in the game. It will allow you to explore the radiation zones in the game.

This is the first game we've made where we've had to rely on so many different game systems to work together to create a cohesive expereince. We really hope you would give the game a second chance when we launch update 1.1. Once again thanks a lot for the really honest criticism of our game, we want to make the development of the game as transparent as we can so we can iterate on what the community loves and what they don't.

review:
Ok, so i'm making a little premise here. I like this game and recommend it to all battle-royale fans, but I'll hardly come back to play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199137664603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 51, 'playtime_at_review': 3181, 'last_played': 1711859404}
review:
8/10 
TLDR: bit grindy, nice people, low key p2w but you can still get almost everything for free with enough time.

now the real review:
ngl this game is VERY addictive. I started playing and then I suddenly realized that it had been about 5 or 6 hours and I had to take a break to eat, I immediately logged back in. The community is mostly nice and if you ask for help in chat you are almost guaranteed to get a response... it might be someone laughing at you for being under level 10 but most of the maxed players are really nice. I found a sick guild after only a few hours and even though they were all level 30+ they took me in (level 7, 9 hours total). I now over 50 hours on the game and am level 23. This is an amazing game but a massive time sink and it is grindy, you will spend hours fighting the same monsters over and over for one drop. (4 hours of meatcutter with no drop yet.) it also is slightly microtransaction heavy and does feature a subscription program of sorts but totally could be play as a f2p (like me). If you have a few friends who are willing to sink countless hours on a game for a cosmetic? this is the game for you. I convinced some of my league/warframe playing friends to get this game with me and they LOVE it. Adventure quest for LIFEEEEEEEEEE
developer_response: Thank you so much for your thumbs up review and wonderful feedback, we really appreciate it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044146972', 'num_games_owned': 462, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1676962531}
review:
This is one of those free hidden gems you can find on Steam. I highly recommend this game if you're on a tight budget, looking for something fun to play with friends, or simply enjoy UFC games minus all the crazy grappling. 

Drunken Wrestlers 2 simply put is fun. The [b]gameplay[/b] at first may seem a little funny, but once you get used to how the engine works, then fun seriously starts to begin. The control scheme is very simple, yet very fun to use. WASD provide basic movement, shift allows the player to run, up/down arrow keys are kicks, and left/right arrow keys are punches. Pressing a different direction will allow the player to try out different moves (hook vs jab, kick vs round-house kick, etc...). The hitting from a distance isn't an issue; when you get up close to an opponent it gets a little interesting. You're able to hit at a close distance, but all the shots taken don't land. Some may land given what button is pressed. The game seems to encourage players to keep their distance in order to deal maximum carnage. Blocking is a system of it's own and really appreciate when you're playing against button mashers. The player may block as much as they want, given that their blocking meter is full. This discourages players to constantly block, yet comes in handy if timed properly. 

The [b]visuals and graphics[/b] are probably the biggest argument against the game. However, I think the graphics are perfectly fine once you get used to the controls. I think the graphics perfectly suit the game and absolutely work with the devs intended impact when landing a blow. Land that big uppercut, the opponent might go flying. Land a solid round-house kick, and you might just kick the opponents head clean right off. No panic though - they're still alive, but they're slowly losing life due to blood loss. The [b]music and sounds[/b] are quite minimal, but again, the gameplay makes up for the lack in the graphics and sounds domain. 

Overall, a highly recommended game from me. Considering it's free and it's a great UFC substitute (minus the grappling), I'm giving it two solid thumbs up bud! It's free - what are you waiting for - try it out!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198318698105', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1618, 'last_played': 1691643871}
review: There are many issues with this game, but the most glaring of them all is the persistent issue over months and months of development when units just sit there and die because they'd rather shoot something that is no threat to them than to shoot the spitter point blank killing them and their teammates, this wasn't an issue at some point, over a year ago I'd say, but the updates just seem to backtrack and cause more issues without fixing anything.
developer_response:
To a certain degree unit target acquisition will have hedge cases where their AI target enemies they perceive to be a larger threat. You cannot expect the game to prioritize at all times in terms of enemy priority. 

Thats why you have the ability to select them and give them an attack order? This has been a staple in RTS games since the beginning.

author: {'steamid': '76561199641408093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 11597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2647, 'playtime_at_review': 8353, 'last_played': 1712482889}

author: {'steamid': '76561198057461900', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1697450941}
review:
This game is not one of these copy/paste asset flip simulators that get released every day.

Graphics look good and I have not noticed any performance issues.
It doesn't have forced DoF or Bloom effects and it has FoV slider.
I usually get motion sickness pretty easily, but this game has not given me problems at all.

Gameplay is interesting if you like games like Papers Please, but this game has more.
Game is open world, but you can't just run off when ever you want. You have a job to do. But in your off duty time you can explore the world as you please. Just look out for criminals.

Tutorial introduces game mechanics to you at good pace and once they take the training wheels off you know enough to enjoy rest of the game.

Game has choices and lose conditions. If you run your outpost to the ground you lose.

Game world is set in fictional soviet union era communist country, but doesn't use broken fake russian language.
Overall atmosphere and game story fits the era.

It has no controller support, but driving with keyboard works surprisingly well.

Devs plan to add endless mode and that is a big plus.

Overall I would rate it 9/10
developer_response: It's always nice to see such comprehensive review and feedback, thank you very much :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197995626662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4657, 'last_played': 1686339802}
review:
[b]Flawed, but fun.[/b]

Summary: 
I have enjoyed playing this game, though I'll admit my first attempt at a playthrough was maddening.  The harder difficulty level is unreasonably hard.  The easier difficulty level slants as too easy.  There's no middle ground.   The story, however, is interesting and after a while fairly engrossing.

Points of interest:
* The game is not without it's bugs, though nothing severe. Most are minor things like bad text or speech.
* The combat on the harder difficulty borders on minor battles being boss fights.  The easier difficulty makes you feel like superman.
* The story is definitely designed to be quasi-linear.  It's not very open ended.  Your first playthrough you can and will miss many things which you can no longer go back to.
* There's a lot of interface things you won't immediately understand, like how to use health kits.  You have to go to the party management screen for that.  Further, if you have a party member who excels at say computers, it frequently won't use them if it's not setup right in the party management screen. Once you figure that out, you're golden.
* I love the world that was created and the story I've gotten through so far.  HUGE amount of content, plays a lot like FO2 or older isometric RPGs.  Story delivers and definitely puts you in the place of trying to pick what you think is right, which is actually more difficult than it sounds.  There are no cartoonishly evil villains.  Everyone has good and bad in them in each group and it's up to you to decide, which can be complicated and difficult.  Alliances are made and broken at the whim of the player or certain story members.  It's got a solid amount of political intrigue and power-brokering later in the game.
* The tech variations are pretty severe, which I can appreciate.  I like the explanations for the way the world is the way it is from bioprocessors to the advent of gunpowder.

Overall:
I'd give it a 7 or 7.5 out of 10.  Not perfect, but definitely fun if you're into scifi isometric RPGs - just don't play it on hardmode unless you like to lose, a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970483270', 'num_games_owned': 597, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 6312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1601, 'last_played': 1707196876}
review:
Such an impressive game that is ruined by stupid small bugs that should have been fixed long before now. I'll try it again after 1.0 is released. Hopefully there will be mod support by then as well.
-Edit After playing some more I realized that single player is the issue. If you die in single player you lose your body and all of your loot every time in my experience. I've played online some now and i'm not having this issue in this scenario. This doesn't make me want to change my recommendation yet though as I imagine a lot of folks will go to single player first and then find out the hard way that they have wasted their time. If you want to learn to play the game, your best bet is to find a "PVE ONLY" server. That's as close to the single player experience as you're going to get without the despawning body bug.
developer_response: Hi there Splice! We're sorry to see that your experience with the game was soured by bugs. We'd like to emphasize that as we'll be nearing the full, 1.0 release of the game, we'll make a conscious effort to bring as much polish and optimizations to it, as well as fixes to the underlying issues that the game. The team here is committed and motivated to bring out the best possible version of the game as possible for our players and we can't wait for our community to experience the best possible version of it. That is why we hope you'll give the game another chance once we get there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198216320463', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1670098025}
review:
*Quickly running from a minotaur*

Welp, let's start. The game is good. It's hard, It's top-down, and the puzzles are tricky. I enjoy playing it, the music and the voice of the main character makes you feel the atmosphere of the game. The darkness in the game makes you feel a little bit anxious about what you're gonna find next, sometimes you will find a secret trap, or maybe a minotaur, because why not . 

Now with the bad things. Well... I don't really understand how the "Minotaur alert" works. Can we avoid alerting it without crouching?

The game really deserves a try. Not everyone will like it, of course, but it's somehow different than the other games, it has that something that makes you interested in the story.

developer_response:
Hi Hippo,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2015. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

Most importantly the performance and stability of the game has been now greatly improved after thousands of man-hours of development from our two-man code team. 

As an early supporter, you even have the first expansion for free, and the second expansion was free for everyone! 

If you've not tried the game for a while now might be a great time for you to jump in and see how far we've come since release! We'd love to hear what you think now.

Cheers,
Cian

review: How about fixing the bugs, fixing optimisation, overhauling the UI, and a million other base game components before releasing cosmetic dlc?
developer_response:
We haven't released cosmetic DLCs in over 6+ months. We've been committed to.improving performance, fixing bugs and adding more content. I would also add that the cosmetics were voted for and asked for by the community to help further support development.  You're welcome to search our steam forums/discord to confirm that yourself.

If your encountering bugs/issues I would recommend you create a steams thread/discord discussion otherwise we have no idea what your actually encountering.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078131526', 'num_games_owned': 1668, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 1683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1657416491}
review:
Great game! I have no idea what the story is about. All I know is that your a girl in a mental ward who lays in bed and plays out an FPS nightmare. If you die, your tossed back out in the loony bin to hear the screams of your neighbors. There's also a pretty cool mini game that lets you play some Super Mario style levels for power ups which you'd think would be an odd fit, but it actually works really well. There are times I've gotten lost in the mini game section and totally forgot this was an FPS! Really there are three things going on. You've got the bulk of the game which is the shooting, the mini game, and then from time to time you've got some little story bits around your room. The whole thing is very intriguing and I can't wait to see where this ends up.

The bad is that this is early access so its not finished. I've also had some pretty annoying crashes that cost me some really cool weapons and do get some slowdown here and there. Probably just a bit of growing pains and while annoying, nothing has been a deal breaker so far.

I would compare this to Dusk quite honestly. I found Dusk to have a pretty amazing atmosphere with the ability to tell the story without much dialog. Everything was told in the level design, creatures, and backdrop and Nightmare Reaper has a lot of the same vibe. The two games have some significant differences, but as far as delivering a story without really saying anything is where I feel the two have common ground...I mean aside from shooting things. 

One big thing is the weapons and there are a ton. You'd think the guy would run out of ideas, but then you get this spell book that charges up a mini nuke blast and think...ok, lets rock. The sheer variety in death dealers is a really nice touch which I don't think I can stress exactly how well the weapons feel. I wasn't exactly fond of losing pretty much all but one weapon at the end of each level, but then just as fast as I'd get attached to something, I'd find a better one. Ammo is pretty creative too. Found this remote grenade thing that uses your characters health points as ammo. Made some pretty bad mistakes with that thing, but it is a room clearer. 

In closing, I would say if your remotely interested in something like an old school shooter and not too averse to pixels, buy this. I've almost got 8 hours into this thing as of writing this and while probably close to the end of the current content, I'm not there yet. Plus still have quite a bit of the mini game to unlock and I feel like I've missed story bits in the asylum and the game isn't even finished. So I would say replay value is there, but even on a single play through its worth it.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed the game!  Sorry you've had crashes.  Please send me crash minidumps by following the steps in the pinned troubleshooting post in the forums.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013742055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2133, 'last_played': 1707864456}

That is why we hope that you will consider giving SCUM another chance - at least when we manage to get these issues sorted out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971222169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1687482550}
review:
The idea behind the base game is very interesting if you enjoy hard sci-fi simulation. Particularly if you're looking to play something similar to Hardspace: Shipbreaker. The execution still needs a lot of work and since the developer has said that they are going to release it as is, I can't really recommend it.

The main game loop, especially in the start, involves going out in your basic ship, learning to navigate in a realistic fashion and mining though ice which results in runaway minerals that you chase while hoping to not damage your ship too much. Unfortunately, the chasing is actually 90% of the game-play at this point, even after you've unlocked a few upgrades.

After 10 hours I did feel comfortable with the controls and ventured deep enough to find a trade habitat. Unfortunately there is some bug or something but if you choose the wrong option when they initially offer you to trade, they don't ask you again. Restarting the mission didn't fix it.

I just gave up at this point. I was already starting to feel dread at the prospect of going out for more mining runs just to get another piecemeal upgrade with my last one being specifically to trade processed ore to this habitat.

Oh, and while you're flying, if you deaccelerate your ore flies out of your cargo based on physics. I understand why this exists but honestly, this game proved to me that realism doesn't always equal fun.
developer_response:
Thank you for taking the time to share your review of our game. We appreciate your interest in the hard sci-fi simulation genre and your comparison to Hardspace: Shipbreaker - this is indeed high praise!

At this stage, we are not aware of any known bugs, but we appreciate you bringing up the issue with trade options at the habitat. Regarding restarting a mission, our game does not have a mission-based structure, so I apologize if there was any confusion in that aspect.

As we approach the release, our development is currently in a feature freeze phase to ensure stability and prevent introducing new bugs. Enhancements will resume after the release to further improve the gameplay experience.

Lastly, I understand your frustration with the physics-based cargo behavior during deceleration. I aimed to provide a realistic experience but acknowledge that realism doesn't always equate to fun for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101453778', 'num_games_owned': 3786, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 15807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15807, 'last_played': 1586310532}
review:
[h1]A Game About Deciding What You Want to Do.[/h1]

In Elite Dangerous, you're a spaceship pilot and the galaxy is a sandbox for exploration, mining, trading, transportation and combat (either as a bounty hunter or a criminal). Once you get out of the newbie star system, the game doesn't really pressure you into doing anything. You can put in as much or as little time & effort as you want. Your wealth & faction status will probably increase depending on which activities you choose.

Of the available activities, you can take them or leave them. You can take or leave the optional missions. No matter how many missions you complete, the game doesn't portray it as a coherent storyline or a hero's journey. The game won't treat you like a hero or tell you that you're a hero. The game won't allow you to be anything more than a random nobody in a galaxy that is indifferent to your existence. So the purpose and challenge is to find something that you enjoy doing in the game, and to keep doing it.

It's not the kind of game that has a lot of mainstream appeal. For people who want to simulate the day to day work of being a spaceship pilot just for the sake of doing it, to savor the physics & the ship controls, to sense the massive size & empty darkness of outer space, the appeal needs no further explanation. Anybody else will probably not find much to hold their attention in Elite Dangerous.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092307721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1601171171}
review:
Under no circumstances should you purchase this game based upon your love of the PR series.  I agree with the reviewers who have already pointed out how much this game has regressed from previous iterations.

The thing that gets me peeved is that they sold a "beta" version of the game on the premise that they were listening to the players feedback and making improvements based on such.  However, the minimal "improvements" to the game in the "live release" version have no significant impact on the quality of the game.  I mean, yeah, it's great that convoys are named now instead of just having the town, but that was something already done in PR1.  Seriously guys, there are indy games under $20 on Steam right now that have better automation of trading mechanics than this game does.

I streamed the beta version of this game for 16+ hours and had multiple discussions with viewers about how disappointed they were with it.  I defended Kalypso, saying, "don't worry guys, it's just beta, they'll get it worked out by launch.  This is just to get our taste buds wet."  Well, unfortunately, all we're left with now is a sour taste in our mouth.  I will think twice before buying a Kalypso release again.
developer_response:
Hi lordraistlinstower, 

Thank you for your feedback and for streaming the beta version. We always wanted to provide our beta testers the latest version of Port Royale 4. This is why the steps between the beta and release version were fluid.

We will continue to work on Port Royale 4 and we appreciate any feedback that helps us to further improve the game.

With updates 1.1 to 1.3, we have implemented as much as possible of the feedback received from the community, and we feel that the latest update is a big step forward for the game. 

In update 1.1, Port Royale 4 received improvements to department stores, difficulty settings were adjusted and money became a more valuable resource in the game.
With update 1.1.1, we introduced armed dealer convoys. In addition, further adjustments have made pirate life more challenging, entertaining and more profitable - especially at the beginning of the game.  

Update 1.2 brought further design changes, particularly to city governance, trade routes, general trade mechanics and the mini map.

And in update 1.3, there is now the possibility to declare the independence of your nation – which among other things gives you full control over the diplomatic relations of your nation.

Also added was the option of economic shocks, the tavern, improved naval battles and male variants of the merchant and pirate characters. We also received mixed feedback about the loss of fame introduced with update 1.2 due to its harsh effects, so we have replaced it with a satisfaction bonus.

Once again, thank you for playing Port Royale 4 and giving us your feedback. With all the changes we’ve introduced so far (and those that we will deliver in the future), we hope that you will give Port Royale 4 another chance and stick with us as we continue on this journey. Most importantly - have fun!

-Cheers

author: {'steamid': '76561198051484615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1705361650}
review:
Fun little adventure game with an interesting backstory. 

Pros:
+ Decent puzzles with a good variety. Most on the easy side
+ Interesting scifi setting
+ Decent story
+ Good voiceover work
+ Multiple endings

Cons:
- Unfortunately, this game falls into the all-too-familiar adventure game trap of "hunt the pixel". Multiple puzzles require you to notice and click on a tiny clickable area in order to advance, none of which are ever hinted at or called out by the characters. This is made even worse by the samey color palette meaning noticing these one-pixel-wide areas is extremely difficult.
- Brown/gray color palette + lack of any stunning vista-type locations means the scifi setting is wasted a little bit. There's no area in the game that looks particularly impressive or makes you say "wow"
- Story, while decent, is incredibly predictable. If you've experienced any type of scifi at all you already have figured out the entire backstory of the game within the first five minutes. This leaves the game without any real twist, which is unfortunate as the game builds it up as if one is coming but it never does
- On the short side, even for an adventure game
- Nitpicky (spoilers)- there's one puzzle that requires you to click on a specific part of the screen that does not even contain a textual indicator that its different from any other part of the scene. I'm talking about finding the battery in the junkyard. Despite almost the whole scene being described as "junk" without any additional description dialogue, you're supposed to someone intuit this one specific spot will work with your energy locator despite the lack of any textual or audio indicator that it would. This is even more egregious given that all prior junkyard items have specific descriptive text for their locations. I'd go so far as to call this a bug that should be fixed.
developer_response:
Thanks for your thoughtful review! The criticism about pixel hunting and hard-to-read art is fair; there's explanations for why it's that way, but ultimately it's frustrating for most players. I'm glad despite your issues with the graphics and predictability you enjoyed it overall!

On the specific junkpile puzzle you mention, though, I think your critique is slightly off. Unless something is bugged, there *is* an audio cue: a ping that accelerates the closer you get to the energy source -- here's an LP video at that point where you can hear the ping https://youtu.be/ZN_mnbl4fP0?list=PLzg_vZBrP9ng5q8gGWjE8oPdJ-Zk9-4oI&t=1700. (If it's bugged, we'll be sure to fix it.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197960552606', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 776, 'last_played': 1681230630}
review:
** UPDATED REVIEW ***
I must say that I am very impressed with the turnaround made in the past couple of months.  The developers have made a tremendous push to fix the performance problems that were plaguing the game.  To be honest, I didn't think I'd be able to play the game without replacing my hardware -- however, the recent updates and the game is absolutely playable for me now (I'm still on my original hardware).

There have been many additions to the game since I last checked it out.  The introduction cut-scenes were are happy surprise, a lot of Voice work has been done, tons of little UI improvements.  I'm looking forward to playing the full single-player campaign.

In short: I'm very pleased with the game now.  Great Job to the development team!
*** END UPDATED REVIEW ***


*** OLD REVIEW BELOW ***
Do not recommend -- performance problems with unoptimized code make the game unplayable due to severe lag on lower end hardware.  Just one example: opening the "Veins of Evil" can take 5+ seconds on my hardware which is better than minimum spec -- note: that is just to open the VoE, selecting something is another 5+ seconds, etc.

I'm a huge fan of DK1 & DK2 and have high hopes for this game.  I will change this review if the game is fixed or options provided to workaround the performance problems.  I refuse to upgrade hardware that plays other games perfectly fine.
*** END OLD REVIEW ***
developer_response:
Hi Fletch,

Thank you for the feedback, we're really sorry to hear you're having performance issues. In most cases the UI should be running solidly though if you are running on lower end hardware it is possible it's getting held up a little, we're currently in the middle of recoding it for our 0.7.0 release. We expect that the next patch towards the end of february should herald some major improvements in this area.

We hope to hear from you at that time and hope that your issue will be resolved. If you'd like to help us research this issue further please can you see our steam forum thread on [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/230190/discussions/0/540732889578596102/]reporting bugs[/url], a copy of your system specs and output_log would be most useful to us!

Cheers,

Lee

author: {'steamid': '76561198010243459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1515546342}
review: I will never recommend anything from Soda Pop or Ninja Division ever again. I'm angry I bought this game before I knew they were going to shaft me out of my $300 for the Legends kickstarter. Look that debacle up before you buy anything from them. Shame for Underbite, they do good work.
developer_response:
First off, I want to say that we share your frustration on Legends.  I am a backer of the Legends product and also have not received my product as well. 

We started development on the game well before the Legends issues and were in no way part of that.  Underbite is just an indie company trying to make good video games for people to enjoy and allow us to keep doing what we love.

I understand sharing your frustration, but caution doing so when it hurts those not involved - like Underbite

review:
whats the fun in being killed in few or in tens of minutes ? idiotic. No intruductions, explanations of how or what to do.. if not some yt video, which is the reason i bought it, I wouldnt knew about how to make the knife, cut clothes.. and thats about it. LOL.. few hits from some rotten zombie and the guy cant handle anymore,lol, and the ONLY place where I could find some gun is ofc where they are ! :D bare knuckles just dont do.. bow ?  idk how to make one in this game.. dont want to look for video to learn from someone else how to do it.. game has to intruduce me to it. if not, ITS USELESS.
Ohh, and eveythying I pick up, magically disappears somewhere :D , some items dont even have an option to pick up, just to take into hands..  with them stones, one time i can craft large axe head, and 20 other times I only can do knife or small axe..got some sticks and on..thought will make something, I go into inventory and its empty..  I bet 60-70% of ppl that got this game quits it just because of that. theres just no intruduction into the game or how to play it.. :(
developer_response: Hi there MrDRE! We're sorry to see that your experience was marred because of a lack of tutorial. We understand and acknowledge that the game might have a steeper learning curve which can prove insurmountable for some new player. You'll be pleased to know that we will be addressing this through the new patch as we'll be introducing great improvements to the crafting and UI, as well as a manual that will outline and explain the functionalities of all the game's mechanics. Looking at the situation you've experienced, it seems that you would have greatly benefited from such additions, which is why we hope you'll give the game another try as we'll be releasing this new patch quite soon!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060148882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1525, 'last_played': 1541546500}
review: I have to start by saying this game looks really nice. The graphics are really good for a colony/base builder and did not bog down my machine, even with very large sprawled out colonies. This take a lot of planning ahead and resource management to get it just right, just like any base builder should be. The game could use a little better tutorial for newbies but you should get the hang of it pretty quick. On the downside, there is so much potential for expansion, I hope they keep working on the game to flesh it out a bit more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198247323482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 19973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15692, 'last_played': 1670561802}
review:
+ UPDATE +

After hitting max level (15 at the time of this review) I took a little break, and then started leveling a 2nd character because reasons, but I'm back and wanted to share my thoughts.

Pros:
+ Convenient class switching system (see Con #4 below.)
+ Convenient fast travel feature.
+ Developers listen to community feedback.
+ Enjoyable and decently paced progression experience.
+ Game doesn't just give you everything or hold your hand.
+ Not Pay2Win (It's Pay2NotFarmOrWait or Pay2NotWait.)
+ Reasonable cash shop practices and prices.
+ Some content (Pumpkin Lord holiday set) cannot be obtained with cash shop currency.

Cons:
- No character depth.
- No endgame content (but we're nowhere near endgame, still salty though.)
- No real challenge.
- No real replayability (see Pro #1 above.)
- Some content (Guardian class) can only be obtained via cash shop.

8/10 - Please note that Beta is Beta.


And if you're looking for a guild in-game, be sure to check out my guild - Immortals - We're AQ3D's self-proclaimed and soon to be (if not already) #1 guild! :D

You can join our Discord @ http://www.discord.gg/WAqk4Vh

author: {'steamid': '76561198314113769', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4999, 'last_played': 1620663655}
review:
Love it! I was a huge fan of the DKII and i think, that this perfectly fits together with the old DKs.

PROS:
*It feels like a seperate game, with it's own type of style and humor, with quite a lot of new rooms and creatures and not like a new, modified version of the DK series. The gameplay is also improved quite a bit from the old series.
*I love how the spell researching plays bigger role in the WftO, than it did before. And the Titans have replaced Horny.
*The narrator adds to the nostalgic feel of the game.
*The levels do have quite the replay value, (as there are mostly multiple ways to do the levels) especially if you are a freak for the achievements.
*The survival mode. It's quite hardcore in the beginning, but it's also much fun.
*The keepers (underlords) have their own styles and not only colors.

CONS: 
*the game performance (as many others have also noted). Once it gets crowded, the performance drops drastically.
*The main story was too short.

Recap: if you loved the old DK2, you'll probably like this one. As i said - it's not a newer, prettier 1:1 copy of the old games, but it is more of a game of it's own.

Update 2018.11: the game is updated constantly and it feels optimized much better, than it did when writing this review. The achievements and the growing list of custom maps adds to the replay value of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033101690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1376460758}
review:
Like Indie games?

Like Point and click adventures?

LOVE deep in-depth amazingly built worlds and stories?

THIS is the game for you.

Though short and and very VERY tough, this game fulfills the best of the three things stated above. It totally sucked me in, very immersive world, with lots of dialog options.
Plenty of humor involved too.

The RPG mechanic of the game is great too, the amount of dedication required to achieve specific endings is HUGE.

I give this game a 10/10. Definitely worth the 10 dollars.

P.S. If you happen to pick this game up, talk to Crispin and as many people as possible, and try to remember just about EVERYTHING you hear. You never know when what, or knowledge will come in handy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053158585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 60674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28175, 'last_played': 1601265080}
review:
First, I have to say I really enjoy this game.  If you like Banished, you will like this.  So I am recommending this.  That assumes you don't mind eventually losing, because you will under current circumstances, and that you are the type of person that does not enjoy the constant battle / zombie scenario.  Mercifully, battles seem to be at a minimum and you don't have to waste your resources on constant weapon production.

Now, there is one issue I will mention that really really annoys me.  I will call it the poor me scenario.  You have these events happening and trading, such as it is, going on, you finally get the items you need to help your people and they do... absolutely nothing.  Example:  They are standing around doing nothing because they are hungry.  Understood.  We trade for food.  There it is.  And they do, you guessed it, nothing.  Oh, except wander around the station - ok then go get food!  Eat!  Don't starve!  Nope, they wander around until they starve.  

Suggestions to fix the poor me scenario - allow a rescue mission or perhaps more colonists to show up that will care for these people.  Or, make them smart enough to go. eat. food. no starve.

The other thing I would also like to see would be more planets.  

I recommend this game.  It is a fun game and relaxing when I don't want to fight zombies.  This has actually become one of my top 5 favorite games I've played on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198388709646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1669318752}

author: {'steamid': '76561197973312067', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1011, 'last_played': 1562125525}
review:
TL, DR:
Pro: 
>Interesting characters
>excellent voice cast
>lovely vistas
>exploration of religion and religiousness without being sanctimonious
>multiple endings
>semi-sensible puzzle solutions

Con: 
>puzzles aren't given enough clues on whether you can solve them yet or not
>other than 3 endings that all involve your final choice, the rest of endings are harder to figure how to get there. 
>screen resolution is limited to two sizes only due to the limitations of the engine used.
>the adventure game studio engine may require older DirectX libraries than what will be installed with game


Primordia is a game about the earth after us, the stuff we leave behind: junk, devastation, and robots. The game readily explores the concept of religion in non-human sapients, which is fresh and unique in sci-fi settings where religions are regulary viewed with disdain and are associated with less advance societies. The humanist religion is based around man the builder, creator of wonders and robots. In this world humans are missing, where they went and how they went are mysteries; but our lovely robots have carried own in our absence. Our inventor protagonist, Horatio Nullbuilt, is trying to reclaim what was stolen from him in the opening scenes of the game. This puts him on path to solve his immediate problems and eventually his quest leads him to the city of Metropol where the secrets are slowing unraveling the city.

The game is not without it's humor from the banter between Crispin and Horatio, references to other famous robots, and Horatio's object commentary.  

If your stuck on a puzzle try using Crispin, on an area you can't reach. The game never tells you about this before you have to figure it out. 
  
If you like post-apocalyptic worlds without mankind, adventure games, and robots: this is probably up you alley.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202048054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 341, 'playtime_at_review': 934, 'last_played': 1712243683}
review:
It's still in development, therefore we need to distinguish between the game as it is and the game as it will/should be.
Right now it's a pleasant, relaxing game about building a town, but that's all. So far it has no depth, it looks like developers got a great idea of organic building system, but then they realised they have no game to create around it.
But it has potential. I hope that eventually the developers will add content and deepen all the roughly patched-up mechanics to create something great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083961114', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1642749222}
review:
Minor spoilers ahead:  Great game/story, though I don't know why the androids needed religion/gender as it does nothing for their function (unless there were companion/pleasure units, which there aren't.)  Maybe humans wanted to make their creations seem more like them?

I wish there was a little more of the world to explore, There are really only two locations and many associated locations within those.

It's aged pretty well too for a ten year old game, assuming you like SCUMM style point and clicks that is.  This very much had some strong Beneath a Steel Sky vibes tot it.

EDIT: responding to the dev comment:  Forgot about Steeple.  So the robots built by humans built robots as they were made themselves, which makes sense I suppose.  Kind of like the zeroth law of robotics.  Anyway thanks so much for commenting, and of course making such a fun game.  Looking forward to some of the other titles I saw as well.
developer_response:
Glad you liked it! Even finishing a game of this scope was hard for a team of hobbyists, as we opted for depth of areas (plenty of things to interact with) rather than breadth (more rooms). Certainly compared to something like Monkey Island 2 it is much smaller!

The robots have gender (in a very loose sense) because humans gender all sorts of things (ships, tools) including concepts such as justice or the homeland. Most of the gendered robots in the game were made that way by humans—think of Clarity like the statue of justice outside a courthouse. After humans were gone, surviving robots continued to play out the roles they had been assigned, and some even gave themselves such roles to make sense of the world. 

The game mentions that humans had delegated even religious functions to robots (hence Steeple) and after humanity disappeared the AI responsible for religion used that as a lens for explaining the relationship of humans and machines. 

Hope that helps!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044316847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1604961647}
review:
This is not usually the kind of game I play but I fancied something a little different and this had great reviews.

What was supposed to be a 2 hour game session turned into 8 hours! The game didn't disappoint! I just couldn't put it down, had to tear myself away from the screen

The characters, music, art, cutscenes, audio - everything exceeded my expectations. I had a solid 10 hours in the game even though I was following a walkthrough (I felt I had to halfway through as I got a bit stuck and just REALLY wanted to know what happened in the story) - so there are a probably a tonne more hours you could spend in the game if you want to figure out the puzzles on your own. 

The game is wacky, surreal, creepy, hilarious and really pushes the boundaries of story-telling. I'm really excited to see future projects from them!

author: {'steamid': '76561198050479594', 'num_games_owned': 986, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1698006125}

author: {'steamid': '76561197964128895', 'num_games_owned': 1736, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1700519109}
review:
Primordia is a game set in a world where ‘Man’ has mysteriously disappeared from the world. Man, also known as ‘The perfect machine’ were the builders from which sentient robots sprang into ‘life’. You play Horatio, a humanoid robot searching for his power core which was stolen by a ‘big robot with claws that shoots lasers’. You have a companion along the way, Crispin. He’s a cocky little robot, full of witty banter and useful advice (although, that advice can be hard to coax out of the little guy at times).

But I digress, back to the story. All I can say is, ‘Wow’. Ok, so it starts a little slow, but once you start learning about you character and his past the game really opens up. Playing as ‘Horatio Nullbuilt V.5’, your character has four versions of prior history of which the data has become fragmented and corrupted. You’ll meet robots along the way that seem to know you, but you haven’t much recollection of them! On top of the world that you are set exploring, this story mechanic really draws you in and makes you hungry for more. I remember thinking that if this game was a book, I’d read the hell out of it! It’d be one of those books that you can’t put down despite having to work early the next day! And in truth, I couldn’t put this game down. Thanks Wormwood Studios, my daughter finally gets to sleep, and instead of capitalising on this moment of rest that I could be having, I decide to turn on my PC and play a little more Primordia!

The music and sounds effects really help to bring this game to life. The background music can be haunting at times, and other times it can be so subtle to lift the mood of a scene that you hardly notice it has changed. The voices of the many robots that populate the world have a slight tinny, and sometimes electronic sound to them, each different from the last. Being how it’s set in a world of robots, Wormwood Studios could have simply hired the same vocal artist and applied filters to his/her voice, but they haven’t gone this route thankfully. Every robot you meet oozes personality, and the voice acting is top notch, adding real character and a human touch to these robots that were, at least in the past, touched by humanity.

Despite all the things that make Primordia such a wonderful game, there are a couple of things that bugged me whilst playing through it. The first thing is the heads up display, or HUD for short. The HUD is located at the top of the screen, and when you drag your mouse up to the top it will pop down, allowing access to the various menu’s and inventory. Sometimes it can get in the way though, as it’s not located at the upper most pixel, and sometimes when you are on the lookout for that next pick-up, or you want to exit to another area, the HUD can slide down, thus breaking the immersion ever so slightly. It’s not a deal breaker by any means, but it can be a slight annoyance at times.

The second thing that got to me the whole time was the graphics. Don’t get me wrong here, I absolutely adore the art style. This game looks great, my problem is that it could have looked amazing. This game isn’t HD, you can set the resolution higher, but you then have to apply a filter to smooth out the jaggies as the game wasn’t designed to run at high resolutions! This results in the image being a little washed out when you play full screen. This wouldn’t be as noticeable on a smaller monitor, but on my 22” screen it was a slight issue.

Gripes aside, Primordia is a polished and lively world with a great story that compels you to finish the game. Clocking in at around 4-5 hours, it’s a journey so full of history and lore that you can’t help but be fascinated by it, the world they have created is really captivating. The central character and his companion guide you through this gritty world, and even though Crispin can be a little on the sarcastic side, you become attached to all you companions, and enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561199100678203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2146, 'last_played': 1707827569}
review: this game does not even start and i payed for gold edition and i didn't get the items for it
developer_response:
Hey there. I'm sorry to hear that the game is refusing to start, and that you're missing those items. To get the game to start up properly again, I highly recommend that you run through the steps that we have outlined in our [url=https://ubi.li/4mnuS]Basic PC Troubleshooting[/url] guide. These steps may also help with getting those items to show up as well. I also suggest that you [url=https://ubi.li/k3cYq]verify your game files[/url] and [url=https://ubi.li/096ki]disable your background applications[/url] to ensure that there aren’t any corrupted game files or background apps messing with the game as it’s trying to launch.

If you continue to experience issues after running through those steps, or if the game starts up but you’re still missing those items, go ahead and open a ticket with us on our [url=https://ubi.li/46uzK]Support Website[/url]. Be sure to include copies of your [url=https://ubi.li/NAnxo]MSINFO and DxDiag[/url] files so that our agents can get a better idea of what’s going on. Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970695637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1628008949}
review:
BlueByte: Lets make a awesome sequel to the amazing Anno 2070!

Ubisoft: Great! Do it! But let's remove all the horrible boring and hard city-building elements from the sequel, so it won't be so hard to play the game for new gamers!

BlueByte: But... The game IS a city-builder... It's supposed to work like a... City-builder... Where you can actually... Build stuff, collect resources etc, you know?

Ubisoft: No! Remove all the stupid building and material mechanics, its what makes nobody buy our games!

BlueByte: But... It's not going to be a city-builder if you remove all the city-building elements...

Ubisoft: Who's your boss? You want to lose your job? REMOVE ALL CITY-BUILDING ELEMENTS FROM THIS CITY-BUILDER! NOW!!!!

BlueByte: Sorry, boss.. We will get the job done... ._____.

To be continued... Next season: "Lets shuv some freemium pay-2-win on top of this in a DLC, and make the DLC mandatory download". 

???

PROFIT!

author: {'steamid': '76561198160109219', 'num_games_owned': 10, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1547247103}
review:
In a previous review I bashed on some of the things in this game, but that was before I realised that it was released in 2001. While this does not change  my view of it to a positive one, the "subscribtion" system being kinda like one of those EA memes, it completely excuses it's flawed mechanics and movements and graphics what not.

As with that subscribtion mechanics, they literally charge 7 dollars a month to be able to use the SMGs (only the smgs). It's 25$ a month for the whole thing, which is total bullshit. Why would I want to basically rent a 2001 game ofr 30$ a month?
developer_response:
Hello Daniels,

We are upgrading this old lady, indeed. Hard work is going on and subscriptions allows the bills to be paid. 

Starter account offers access to all DLC content (except medium armor), and premium is 15$/month, not 25.

I will rewrite their descriptions to make it more clear. I am also working on tutorials to let you better preview what to expect from the game. 

S!

author: {'steamid': '76561198122290336', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1606429236}
review: Very arcadey. Crashes constantly. I got it at 80% off and feel scammed.
developer_response: Thanks for sharing your review, Gronak! I surely hope that I can help you with getting the game to launch properly. Since it's unclear of whether the game is crashing at launch or while in-game, I'll try and give two scenarios! If you're finding that the game crashes at startup, please go ahead and make sure you have the game and the Ubisoft Connect PC launcher installed to the same internal hard drive ( C: Drive being the best option)! If you're all good on that front, go ahead and complete [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-us/faqs/000025947]these PC troubleshooting steps[/url] and [url=https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=2037-QEUH-3335]verify your game files[/url] before trying to launch again. If you're finding that this happens in-game, it could be that you needed to update your drivers ( which the PC troubleshooting link can help with ) or you may be having an issue with not having enough available RAM to maintain the game ( which [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-GB/Faqs/000025721/Disabling-Background-Application/]disabling background applications[/url] can help with that! If you continue to have issues, however, please feel free to [url=support.ubi.com/Cases/New]create a support ticket[/url] for additional support and we'll see you through it! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198013975397', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2428, 'last_played': 1458593232}
review: As a veteran adventure gamer, I absolutely adored this. This is one of the best distopian worlds and stories created in the last ten years (together with Gemini Rue, Technobabylon and now recently also Whispers of a Machine) and certainly one of the better adventures I have played. The production values are also very high with excellent voiceovers, nice game mechanics and lovely sounds and musix. I so loved this game, yes due to plot and writing, but mainly because the chief characters in this game were done so well and have a lovely interaction. I highly recommend to pick this up, whether it's on sale (it is frequently) or not.
developer_response: Thanks! Very nice company to be named with!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000275990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 665, 'last_played': 1526497309}
review:
I really enjoy the game, it's more an interactive movie, don't espect great gameplay and enjoy the story.
Unfortunately  I encountered some pretty nasty bugs that made me stop trying to run the game.  

The save file didn't save my choices after episode 1, when I started episdoe 2 the wrong person was alive and past choices were wrong.
In episode 2 the game stopped after dying 3 time, in 3 different part of the story and I had to restart the chapter over and over. 

I tried any solution founded around the net, checked the game integrety and all my hardware and software is up to date.

Unfortunately I can 't reccomand the game at this point, I have 11 hours played and I can't pass chapter 2 without a crash.

Maybe I'm just unlucky, maybe the new update of win 10 is giving problems but I surely not trying again this version, 
I'll probably try the ps4 version, hopefully ther is some sale on the collection because I love the story and I want to see how it ends.


Conclusion: For what I saw the game is higlhy reccomended  but the Pc version seems to be broken for me.
developer_response: Thank you for your review. Please temporarily disable your security software to determine whether it is interfering with the game. If the difficulty persists, please feel free to contact us at support@telltalegames.com.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984918581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1534629670}
review:
After a developer reached out to me, asking me to try the game again, i must say the game is definitely an enjoyable experience now

Great job WftO devs!
developer_response:
Hi Muller,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge, huge improvements since your review in 2015. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since release:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. Two of these are completely free for you!
- New Game Modes
- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561198058707699', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1701777679}
review: I would definitely recommend it. Best RTS game I've played in years. Love the concept of the open world and zombies. So much freedom for creativity here. Obviously it's still a WIP and needs a little bit of polish in terms of bug fixes but it runs smooth enough and I've only had one crash. The only issue I have with the game at this time are the Giant worms. You spend ages building a base and gaining ground then all of a sudden they appear randomly at a less protected base and completely annihilate it within seconds. I just think the game would be better without them or have better defences for them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147935617', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1552967935}
review: Pretty fun if you have some time to kill, wish there was a bit more variety in character mods, and the difficulty was a bit higher.
developer_response:
Glad you're enjoying the game! 

If you're looking to increase the game's difficulty there's a few options available. Unlocking and enabling Modifiers from the main menu before starting a run will add various and often unique difficulty to the game but reward you with score multipliers. You can also unlock and enable Hell Mode which again increases the difficulty significantly. If the difficulty is still not enough, you can combine all 12 Modifiers with Hell Mode... which I don't advise but I'll leave that up to you.

Thank you for the great review!
- Alex (Optical Override)

author: {'steamid': '76561198368133728', 'num_games_owned': 118, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1533598689}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018628239', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1514322946}
review:
From its only information being an inspiration from a film I adore I was very looking forward to this game.

After going through the short tutorial I felt prepared to play the game, you start off needing to choose at least 2 characters, despite being singleplayer making it a handful to juggle an extra person for no extra benefit.

The story then consists of finding and pulling random numbered levers across an icy landscape. As I search for Lever 3 without direction or clue my characters tell me they're tired. Great. I mean, the only thing not covered by the Tutorial and now it looks like its a big fucking issue! Beds are also scarce at this point so I am livid.

I find a bed and get to sleep as the anomolys waltz into a lit up building (which the game assured me they would stay away from) and fucked up the Dude, rest his soul.

I found this game confusing, vague, irritating and very much dissapointing with the only "inspiration" taken from The Thing that I could see was the fact that it's set in the arctic.

Cannot recommend you spend any money on this, luckily for me this was included in a bundle, but others may not be so lucky.
developer_response:
Dark anomalies are afraid of light. You can even scare it by using your flashlight. 
Blue anomalies are afraid of warmth. But not afraid of the light.
Electric anomalies can be caught by traps or killed by gun.

review: I have to say that I wonder about the people not enjoying this game.  I just finished playing through the campaign and I only ran into one "bug" the whole time (would requiring spoiling to explain).  That record is _FAR_ better than what I experienced with DKII. author: {'steamid': '76561198009556865', 'num_games_owned': 804, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 33266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 237, 'playtime_at_review': 28053, 'last_played': 1711251758}
review:
TL;DR: At this stage I recommend treating this game like a space flight simulator and not a conventional game as it is advertised.

Hundreds of hours of grind is met with about ten minutes of pay off. The best aspect of this game is being thrown into a world where you have to find your own way, do your own research to find the best way to advance.

But, then you realise it all amounts to nothing, that you spent hundreds of hours in Open play and you have seen five real players, four of which decided to destroy your ship without warning and set you back dozens of hours, you have spent hundreds of hours grinding towards an expensive ship or module and it really only gives you a 5% increase in one stat.

The development team is completely apathetic towards the player base. Every update is broken and lacks content, as if only one or two people even bothered to work on it. They are more then willing to take your money, but don't expect any satisfying game play in return.

The head line feature, five years into development, is a flight tutorial. For existing players the other feature is porting their store from a website into the game. Of course (as of 19/SEPT/19) not only does the site no longer work, but the in game store lacks most of the items they used to sell, which will be added in the next few days. Maybe they should have released it next week after some QA, bug testing and actually finishing the planned features.

Upcoming updates include Fleet carriers, which sounds interesting at first, being able to own and move around a massive ship, but long term players know that beyond eye candy and the clunky ability to move your fleet of ships around they will be mostly useless, yet require hundreds of hours to grind enough credits to buy one.

There is a late 2020 update planned, which will cost money. If this game has a hope of actually being worth the effort we will find out then.
