author: {'steamid': '76561198082365863', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 22382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22052, 'last_played': 1650626250}
review:
Space Engineers could be a wonderful game, more than capable to overcome the success of Minecraft. It Has tons of posibilites, great Mods, cool physics and you can literally play DAYS with creating Stations Ships and Drones for different purposes... wouldnt there be one little problem...

BUGS!!!!

I Play Space Engineer (and its medieval brother) since release and ever since it is the same Pattern: I start playing having fun  and get more and more annoyed by game breaking bugs that make my constructions self destroy in one way or the other. I unistall the game and try again a few Months Later

Literally Space Engineers has more Bugs than features and while Keen House Software is great at adding new content they never seem to be able to get a stable version out. And i dont speak about "minor" things like "Rubber banding" or Low Simulation speed. I speak about stuff like Thrusters suddendly stop working without reason,  Conveyor Tubes becoming super Magnets, Welding Blueprints making you crash or Best over all: Tiny Voxel parts of an Asteroid suddednly appearing INSIDE your ship and becoming a nuclear explosion... Each of these things happened mutiple times in different servers, singleplayer games or even the campaign.

As i said Space Engineers could be such a wonderful game, but the bugs became so unbearable frustrating over time that one just cant stand it. 

And yes i write this review while being slightly pissed (and after unistalling once again) but since i am usual a very calm, very patient, VERY forgiving person i assume that me unistalling a game out oif frustration could count as a heavy argument,too.

I would hope Keen House fixes the stuff someday, but after a few years of waiting and trying again and again and again i kinda doubt it by now
developer_response:
Hi [82DK-✠]Warrior044,

We appreciate the time you took to write this review.

It is our belief that by incorporating your and other community feedback, we will make Space Engineers an even better game.

Please feel free to submit any feedback you may have forgotten or think of in the future here: https://support.keenswh.com/spaceengineers

Cheers,

Keen Software House

author: {'steamid': '76561198043384288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1535803564}
review:
If this game is on special consider buying it, I do not think it is worth the full price. 

CONS:
- Long loading time at the start
- Annoying voices / narration during gameplay
- Does not have the charm of the old dungeon keeper 2
- Pace is much quicker than the old one (this bothers me a lot) 
- Creatures level up quickly and they do not seem to have special abilities when at high levels (unless I am missing something?)
- Not enough attention to detail - especially when it comes to the creatures in your dungeon (this was a big thing in the old one)
- I do not like the "beast" concept
- Game got very laggy during the second last campaign mission. Probably because there are 4 dungeon keepers on the one map. Very frustrating. 

PROS:
- Sort of satisfies my craving for old dungeon keeper 2
- At least someone is trying to remake the old classic
developer_response:
Hi Neesan,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2016. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since release:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. One of these is completely free for you!
- New Game Modes
- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate
- Entirely new Skirmish AI

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561197970623968', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1196, 'last_played': 1487779377}
review:
Good idea bad AI. 

They will die of starvation, but no one will work.
They will not produce, even if you have an abundant supply of raw materials.
The list goes on, I think you get the idea.

It's just frustrating, not the kind of frustration I find fun.
developer_response:
Hello there, thanks for your feedback,

In Planetbase the AI follows some simple rules, that (hopefully) should be easy to understand: the first tend to their needs: food, drink sleep, morale, then they do work, if they can (all the components, resources are there etc...)

The idea behind the game is that once you understand their behaviour you should be able to indirectly manipulate them, to do what you want, just like you would do in real life if you were managing a bunch of people.

We understand that this kind of gameplay is not to everyine's liking, and some people would prefer more micromanagement, but we wanted to try something a bit different in terms of gameplay for this game.

Kind Regards.
Martiño.

review: I like horror games - not mainstream, actually. I think indies are more creative when it comes to making the atmosphere and suspense. We have several examples of great indie horrors, and Typical Nightnare is another title in the row. While it’s quite simple to master, the game has a strong psychological and even detective aspect. To understand what happens to the protagonist and help him, you need to figure out what path is right and follow it. And it’s not easy.
developer_response: We tried to to our best to create a good story for you! Thanks for your feedback and support!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968760646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1646792533}
review:
I don't write a lot of reviews, but I've been watching this develop all the way from the developer making the original Mines and Magic on StarCraft II (Custom map on SC2), to posting up a really alpha version on the subreddit for their game, and now launching this.  I've been playing the standalones released on reddit as soon as they were up and had fun for hours and hours, and now it's on steam!

It's been fun to watch it develop from a custom game on a different engine to coming here onto steam.  The idea of a standalone version is great.  It's still an early release, so the graphics and a few things are limited, and the interface could still use some work.

However, here's some things I really love overall:

- The ability to attack map points is great.  
- Getting resources for each area you attack is great! Being able to upgrade them as you see fit is very cool.  Instead of just conquering a map, there's some strategy to it.
- Right now it's down to being able to buy one other builder, but in the SC2 version there's a ton of builders, I'm hoping to see more, but being able to buy them with in game resources is very cool.  The fact that it's an option in single player is nice.
- The ability to buy spells in the middle of the game is great and makes it for a huge game changer.  Sometimes units may not cut it on a wave and in a bind you may find yourself using a fireball, or regeneration, maybe you need rage, or the other plethora of spells that are available (there is a lot!).
- Buying spells in game gives you more gold income, and so does upgrading your keep, and it is actually very useful and splits towards "the keep" after a round (to help upgrade that area, or others you've attacked).
- The interface is simple so far, and while the buttons are really really big, it's still easy to use and is easy enough laid out to use in a manner that makes sense from a starting sense.
- The units at your disposal make it enough that you can almost always come up with a combo to complete a level, depending on how strategic you lay your stuff out, upgrade, and mix spells with your mines or keep.  While it is random, it is at least difficult enough to provide a challenge if you are patient and take the time to get to know the game.  In the first round it seems like it's almost all on unit composition, and later on as you progress you'll quickly realize just how important the spells become, which makes it balanced to stay strategic and thinking on your feet and ahead.

Some things I hope we'll see in the future:

- The mine zap button kind of pops up in inopportune places when you click it, and am hoping that may improve, or become hotkeyed (such as within the sc2 version).  
- Ability to upgrade zaps? or apply spells to it? (a slow or poison zap would be cool, at cost, of course)
- The buttons are pretty huge and makes the screen seem like you're zoomed way in by comparison of the UI.  It's not bad and this is still an early release, and it is laid out well so things aren't in the way.
- Hotkeys for everything
- More units for a more diverse army would be a plus, though at this moment in time still is a great little layout.
- It would be really helpful to see the hp of units and stats of them as they fight to see and figure out numbers to crunch numbers for the best layout for next rounds.
- Being able to upgrade units into different types would be cool as well, but again, this is early release and the dev has enough on their plate.  It's incredible that they've done this much so fast.  The map is awesome!

All in all this dev is on top of stuff, has been working on the SC2 version for a while (I hope they don't stop because it's AWESOME), and is dedicated to the development of this.  It is so incredibly cool to see them go for a standalone.  This is a great little time killer if you like a map conquer strategy game, and with stuff to do, lots of spells, and something to pass the time.  Since this is essentially a tower defense map there isn't really any lore or quests that go with it, which is fine since these types of maps don't really tend to be that sort of thing.

Think of it like a gem tower defense game, but with mobile "towers" and spell casting.  It's a super fantastic and fun concept.  Hats off to the dev for pushing on with this and making it happen.  It is VERY cool and a lot of fun!  I can only recommend as I've seen how far the original came, and now this making progress? I can only imagine it's going to get better and better and better.
developer_response:
Hey, thank you for this incredibly helpful and inspiring review. Appreciate a lot.

Some of the points you mentioned have already been taken care of, and others are in the to do list :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197980363998', 'num_games_owned': 133, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 49124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20641, 'last_played': 1631654130}
review:
*Update 5/5/2020* Developer has responded to my already positive rating and critical review with a great response and info on where I can see the development roadmap for the game. Stellar and appreciated. This game is money well spent. If you like banished, sim city, stronghold, or any other city builder you will not be disappointed. Bummed I waited so long.

So much potential, and I look forward to updating my review as it evolves. This may literally end up being one of my favorite city builders of all time by the end, however after pouring in literally hundreds of hours I still cannot figure out how housing works. Yes I have read all the discussions about it and even created one of my own, but just when I think I've pinned down all the "rules" for where a villager will build I create a zone that no matter how close to workplaces, how high quality, or how large it is they just won't build there. I think it must be bugged because it is completely unpredictable. I understand the desire to have cities have a "holistic" feeling and therefore not allowing players to define roads, but this is a digital zen garden, it should at the bare minimum be predictable. Also the pathing that villagers choose just because there is a pre-existing path is pretty ridiculous sometimes. they will go around three edges of a square on an existing path instead of blazing a new path down the one side of the square. 

Two changes would make this a 9/10 for me even in it's early state. 

1) Allow players to build houses. Don't do away with residential zones that build wherever for only 10 wood,  but for those who want a house in a particular spot why not let them? You could even make it a little bit more expensive late game option. A mayor/landlord certainly could do this back in the day. Why not in this game?

 2) Allow players to build roads (perhaps at the cost of stone?) and have the villagers prefer roads (albeit perhaps less heavily than they currently prefer paths). Bottom line is forcing player to play your way doesn't work out well. If someone wants to grid their city at the cost of efficiency they should be able to.
developer_response:
Hi Lokius

Thank you for the positive review! 

With regards to the housing, this is still a work in progress and not yet complete. There will be further improvements and iterations as we continue to develop the game and hopefully you will enjoy the improvements. It is unlikely that we will allow for manual placements of housing as this is currently a feature of the game but it will be improved upon. If you are trying to place an individual house in a small zone this may be what is causing your issue but we would be happy to take a look at your save if you need further help.

With regards to roads we are looking at improvements to these as well. You can see a little info in our [url=https://trello.com/b/i5AX944p/foundation-roadmap]trello[/url] roadmap.
If you wish to create a new path for villagers it is possible to temporarily block an old path with the red restricted zone. Once the new path has been created you can remove the zoning and the shortest path will be used depending on the villagers destination. Potentially both paths might be used. You can also remove pathing permanently with this and the grass will slowly grow back over time. 

If you require any further help you can request help on the discussion forums or reach us on our [url=https://discord.gg/Foundation]Discord[/url] server or via email at support@polymorph.games.

Cheers
Ash

author: {'steamid': '76561198407833277', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 350, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1712390443}
review: AdventureQuest 3D is the best game invented by breathing humans. I am so glad you can play it on Steam now as it completely wins over WoW. Aurelio Voltaire is a music man I have seen many times, and he has a pirate quest story-line in here. I liked quests and crafting in Guild Wars and World of Warcraft, but hated the way you had to start new characters to switch classes, could not switch types of crafting, and had to have a super computer to play. This game has low system requirements, can be played on the phone as an app, and one character can play all classes then master all crafts as you battle with goblins, orcs, elf men, and all other D&D classics. I used to play this game as a browser based game, and my character profile page as "Poedaughterz" has the "played before 2016" badge. On PC now it fully beats most MMOs out there with the improved Steam game-play style. You can buy stuff in game, but it is not pay-to-win.  One thing I would like them to add is houses, and crops like Lord of the Rings Online or Stardew (the browser based version DID have pirate house boats for users) yet this is the best mix of funny and good game MMO system I have seen so far.
developer_response: Thank you so much for your thumbs up review and amazing feedback! Housing is currently in development, please keep checking the News and Game Plan via AQ3D.com for updates!

author: {'steamid': '76561198159871539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1554278104}
review:
Edited/Updated Review

Initially there was an issue where players were spawning into my games in a crumpled heap that couldn't quite be interacted with.  As you can see from the developer comment below, that issue was swiftly corrected and I managed to get some online multiplayer action.  SkutteOleg is very much on top of matters, so make sure to list an issue if you find one.

Drunken Wrestlers 2 is loaded with potential and the developer is worthy of support.


The intentionally awkward character controls are a good time to be had, having your wrestler stumble around for balance and trying to land a shot on whomever is nearest is a treat.  The insanity of the impacts feels real nice and satisfying, as well as being completely over the top in the physics and limb dismemberment. 

The in game sounds, like the rest of the game, are comedically over-the-top.  The thuds, rips and impacts really fit with the goofy theme of the title, as well as the soundtrack fitting well into the setting without getting annoying or repetitive.


I really can't find much to complain about as far as the cons go.
The bulk of the I have are minor nitpicks that I suspect are the result of the game still being in development.

The only thing that I don't like too much is that the shift in camera angle can sometimes be jarring and cause you to lose sight of your wrestler in kickboxing mode and that it's a little frustrating starting the fight laying down (as it can be pretty difficult to get onto your feet again and your opponents have an advantage if they can get up first)

The AI bot is a little too overpowered as well, but again, this is just me struggling to find nitpicks.  


Drunken Wrestlers 2 is jam packed with potential and I'm looking forward to seeing how the build progresses.
developer_response:
I broke the multiplayer in a recent update and you just happened to download it in an unfortunate time. Should be working now

Thanks for your review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198249929356', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 35112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3925, 'last_played': 1638261784}
review:
Elite Dangerous is one of the best Space Simulation games of our time. Some of the features in the game include:
-Realistic communications and docking
-Realistic weaponry and module simulation
-Module failure
-VR
-Complex web of corporations that fight, cooperate and more
-Your Actions influence outcomes of different wars, trades, economies, catastrophes, and more
-Excellent sound design with great music and SFX
-Beautiful graphics without heavy strain on your computer

All this and much more creates a vivid and very elaborate game where you feel like your actions matter. You can go the silent path, and transport legal (or illigal!) cargo, or choose to make a name for yourself in warfare. The choice is yours. The most amazing part of it all, is that it all takes place in our very own milky way galaxy, carefully recreated with actual Stars, systems, planets, and stations orbiting them. A large variety of weapons, modules, and internal compartments means you can go all out guns blazing, or be conservative with shield cells and repair modules. If I were to have the choice of whether or not to buy this game, I'd do it again within the blink of an eye.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037638079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1692281970}
review:
A more forgiving and better looking (in my opinion) Binding of Isaac.

Even though I had fun playing The Binding of Isaac I never really got into it. That game is pretty hard and to me it got repetitive relatively quickly because I usually fought the same monsters over and over again and died at the same stage.

Neon Abyss on the other hand is more forgiving (I'm playing on the normal difficulty level). Additionally there are a bunch of very entertaining mini games that break up the combat sections and the graphics are fantastic.

I also enjoy the progression system. When you unlock a new power-up you get that power-up for free in your next run, essentially making you a bit more powerful from the get go which helps you progress through the bosses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051812273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1559716238}
review:
Yea, I go ahead and say "Cannot recommend". 

In it's current state it's just  a huge mess. As you can see, I barely played it for 15 minutes, simply because I was not able to. 
I'm fine with bugs in a generaly working game, really. But as of right now I'm simply not able to play it properly.

- had to restart several times before it even reacted to the language-option.
- in-game start-menu can lead you to a black-screen when you press "Remember" (Continue basically) even though you shouldn't e able to
- QWERTY controls would be nice if you were able to change them since you start with AZERTY controls (understandable, it's the french keyboard layout, but please let us change them?)
- Escape menu only reacts to the first mouse-input and then simply ignores everything that follows; so while you are able to press "Controls" you can't change the controls in the follow-up window


So, that was my current adventure. I'll go to bed now. Kinda dissapointed but I'll simply assume there will be hot-fixes for these kind of things.
developer_response:
Hi! Thank you for taking the time to write a review. The bugs and missing features you talked about have been fixed by now. There's also a lot more content in the game, and the next patch notes will add even more.
Don't hesitate to give it another go, we really hope you'll like it better now!

developer_response:
You might have missed a few things, try starting out as the Carpenter or Fisherman on the Sloop and buy a net from the "items" tab in the shop, or buy food! You can also steal other ships food by attacking them. 

Fishing is meant to be a last resort for earning money of preventing starvation and once you've unlocked a better ship and profession you might not ever need to fish again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123449609', 'num_games_owned': 40, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 17847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4055, 'last_played': 1700924210}
review: Third Negative Review for this game. Dev's seem completely oblivious to the fact that the game has glaring holes, literally, in the mesh. No fresh material, unless you want to count the Pay to Use decor, in years. Same lame gun, same lame blocks, same lack of end game or ambitious reasoning to spend the amount of time required to build and perform anything, and then there is nothing to explore. All servers are really small with no goals for being in space, no fighting AI, no new rewards other than what you can get on the ground. Like so many games it is a pleasant concept with no ambition or long term goals. I did manage to find some mod communities working hard to overcome dev failures, but the game cant really handle modding. It requires massively repetitive resets, usually hourly.  That amounts to quite the loss of time and resources due to memory failure. Cant recommend. Should be moth balled back to beta. Shame on STEAM for not monitoring better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032999074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1703524268}
review:
This is a game with potential. Like, super potential.

It is a case of the lightning in a bottle, that much can be said. Normally, so many ideas and concepts in one wouldn't translate well, and the dev logs show there is a struggle going on behind the scenes. However, the diamond is there in the dirt, and I wish all the best for the devs.

To devs, if you see this, things to note in the current game state:

1) Colliding mesh, leading to stuck units and unmoving units. Copters have also been stuck in building once
2) Units will go for a hike when you tell them to walk a short distance
3) Cerberus APCs cannot refuel with Supply Atlas for whatever reason
4) I have no idea how EVAC works
5) I played the main game, and not the experimental, but it would neat to have a 'free roam' mode to give people a chance to familiarize with the controls.
6) Power Pylon range needs to be longer, like Resistor long, otherwise it's better to place more generators
7) Supply Atlas should have option to manually select who to supply and who to fuel.
8) A custom army painter would have serious potential in this game

That's all I can think of in the short time I've played this game. I say the above in all seriousness, good faith and passion. You have an amazing game in the making, all the best! It speaks volumes I'm uninstalling, because of how addicting it is. I'll happily reinstall when I have more time to kill. Can't wait for the campaign update.

Good luck!
developer_response:

author: {'steamid': '76561197989915391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1657044984}
review:
Holy balls, this game is a piece of crap.

I've never played a RTS game in which your own units are so small and the map is so dark that you just lose them. Hope you had them hot-keyed, buddy.

The UI sucks super bad. Control groups clutter up the screen, the menus are all over the place. The mini map is busted because the icon that indicates where you are looking is off center. The path finding is beyond terrible, units can't seem to figure out how to move around obstacles.

My engineer got stuck in a corner of the very first section of a wall that I ever built - true story.

Can't see my units, can't control my units. Had all these problems in the first 30 minutes of game play, can't imagine all of the bullcrap I'd have encountered if I played an hour.

Dumpster it. Uninstall it. I refunded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082338663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1674389188}
review:
I am giving this game thumb up, because I belive it has a huge potential. I loved my firtst playthough. The whole idea of mixing retroshooter with rogelike game is soo much fun. The only thing that bothered me are performance isues. I do not have super high end computer but well within recomended spec for this game,yet I was able to bearly sqeeze 60 fps on lowest settings and 75% res scaling. Fps dropped to 40-50ish in open areas with rain particles.

On the positive side of things, dev seems to be actively involved in community discusions and is aware of the performance isue. Hopefully it will be fixed soon. Going through this game 120 fps stile would be amazing.

At the end some suggestions from my point of view:
Adding more types of enemies would go nicely with the huge gun roaster. To me, the most fun part of the game is combat itself, yet I felt some of levels were just bit short on the enemy numbers so I would like to see some sort of arena, or bigger levels where you can go absolutely ham and gore tons of monsters with your weapons of choice. And for last sugestion... mod support. Things like community made map chunks, weapons, ememies etc )replayability) and this game would suddenly be my nunumber 1
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed the game.  Performance improvements are a priority during early access!

author: {'steamid': '76561197996283350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1595358030}
review:
i've been a supporter of faulty apprentice for quiet a while. i like the way the game is build up like a visual novel with the story being the main focus. usually with light novels though you at msot get a few choices to make every so often which is why i enjoy this game alot. the fact that the game allows you to freely choose who and what you wanna do instead of simply getting a few choices every now and then makes it very enjoyable. 

although i haven't played the steam version through from start to finish yet, i've played the development builds many times and i do plan on going through the entire game at least once more for archievements later on:)
developer_response:
Past few weeks alone our focus was to polish and test alot defenitly try out the stream version with new save file if possible! From current feedback there seem to be very few bugs left which i been fixing as they come. 

Other than that thanks for sticking with us and believing in our game, we try our best to make the choices matter and give you as much freedom as possible. There are few weird edge cases that sometimes don't work out story wise because of the order you play but we are slowly cleaning them up! 

Without people like you we wouldn't be able to come this far, Thanks again!

review: This game felt a lot like papers please but with free roaming, reviewing cars and map exploration, I really did enjoy this game and hunted after most of the achievements in it, however I only have 1 complaint and that is the gun play is ehh.. it isn't the best but its certainly not terrible and if you upgrade your crack den (house) enough times you're basically invulnerable and can loot the bodies when your border is under attack out in the open without really any repercussions unless you stay in front of them all for to long. author: {'steamid': '76561198117107627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1576027326}
review: I got Rime on sale for 10 bucks, and that was an awesome deal. I absolutely loved this game. Beat it in about 13 hours, but will be going back to try and get the collectibles i missed. After playing it, it makes me mad to know how much criticism this game got. It looks and plays and sounds so amazing. It was beautiful in every way. It fluctuated between 60 and 30 fps on my 6 year old pc, but it was never very noticeable at all. I have ZERO complaints about framerate, or anything else really. It probably takes a specific kind of person to truly appreciate this game, but i am definitely one of them, and recommend it 1,000%

author: {'steamid': '76561198037425823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1699057793}
review:
There's promise in the complexity of some systems, but the overall package just doesn't hit. It's not really a matter of rather it's worth $40 or not but rather the game just doesn't feel like it offers much past PVP. The PvE elements are far from enough.

Can't recommend sale or otherwise, if you don't mind having to drop money for a server, and don't mind PVP being the only reason to play, then watch some videos and decide if the gameplay is enough to deal with the UI. I will end this review on a good note by saying that the simulation aspect of the game systems are amazing and offers something no other survival game I've played does at this level.
developer_response: Hi InAbsentia! We're sorry to see that you find the PvE aspect of the game to be lacking. We'd like to emphasize that the game is still in Early access and that we'll be adding more PvE content as we'll be releasing the full 1.0 version of the game, and that we'll be supporting the game after its release. That being said, we truly hope you'll consider giving the game another chance once we manage to get there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002604604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1466176888}
review:
Primordia is, at it's core, a nostalgic trip to the old days of the Point-and-Click Adventure genre of gaming that at this day and age has almost been completely forgotten and lost.  And what a welcome blast from the past it is indeed.  Following the travels and trials of Horatio and Crispin, this game tells an amazing story with all the conventions of the P&C genre.  But it's not QUITE to same as the games of old, such as King's Quest, or Broken Sword.

For starters, the game tells you outright that you cannot die, or can you take an action that renders the game "unwinnable", a flaw that made many of the classic staples of point-and-click, like King's Quest 5, atrocities of game design.  The locales don't require meticulous pixel hunts to find that one item you need in order to progress.  Travelling the maps is expidited by a fast-travel system that easily lets you jump from place to place.  Combining items is no longer a nonsensical MacGuyver mish-mash of parts, it's all explained and makes perfect sense.  No longer do you need a notebook to take down vital information, a handy item in-game records all the most relevant information for you, and your helper will at times offer a light nudge towards the next possible objective.

And that's just the mechanics.  The game's art and sound, two of the major foundations of point-and-click, which lives and thrives (or fails and dies) off it's atmosphere, are in full force.  The discoloration of the game's settings isn't just to be "realistic", it's a compliment to the setting and aesthetic.  And the music is highly atmospheric.  From the haunting melody of the game's menu theme "Primordia" to the tune of "The City of Glass and Light", the music compliments the setting as much as the color palette.  The characters are all fully voiced, and the voice work is clean and quality, with voices befitting each character and role.

Of course, Primordia isn't perfect.  For starters, the biggest and possibly most glaring flaw, is just how SHORT the game is.  Even if the puzzles make you spend extra time (and at first, they will), you'll likely only wind up spending 5-7 hours on this game.  It's basically over before it seems to really begin.  While it follows the classic story-telling formula, the climax of the story seems to be on you before you know it.  A point in the game that feels like the 50% is more like the 75% mark instead.  And before you know it, you're already at the final scene.  Even with multiple endings (which can be achieved by just reloading and making a different choice) the game feels painfully short-lived.  You'll be left wanting to hear and see more.

The music, while perfectly fitting the mood, never seems to stick with the player much.  I couldn't tell you a moment in the game and point out the music for it, besides the music at the main menu.  Which isn't to say the music is bad, because it's not.  But it's not catchy much.  Or very present.  The music mostly serves as a background to the game, ambience.  And it does it's part amazingly well.  I just wish that perhaps the music felt a bit more powerful at certain scenes.  Speaking of sound, the voice-acting and sound effects are a bit off as well.  Some scenes would have effects, like gunshots, with NO sound accompanying them, which removed something important to the scene.  And the voice actors themselves, while very good, still felt a bit rough.  Horatio's voice actor in particular, either does a stellar job, or seems a bit too stoic when you'd think a situation would call for a more forceful, emotional or venomous delivery.

Overall though, Primordia definitely feels like it was a game that SHOULD have existed back in the Golden Age of the adventure genre of PC gaming.  It feels like a game that I missed from my childhood and I'm just getting to sit down and enjoy it now for the first time in years, and it's not even that old!  But it takes me back to that time in gaming that I've almost forgotten and reminded me of what games I use to partake of, and that's a feeling I can't being to say how much I enjoy.  If you are a person who enjoys the point-and-click genre, grew up in that era, or want a relaxing, easy-paced game that can still deliver a great story, Primordia is worth every possible virtual cent you pay for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155890175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1596512145}
review: Just like the real thing without broken quads or wind. Still would highly recommend to anyone interested in flying a quadcopter- racer or otherwise

Thank you so much for any information you can provide to help us make it better! 

Thanks again! 

TK and the DRL Sim Team

author: {'steamid': '76561198288078688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 28017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3296, 'last_played': 1692672472}
review: I like the variety of skin tones, hairstyles, hair color, eye color and lipstick colors when you first start the game. I like the stories in the game when you're doing a quest and that there's also humor as well. The weapons and armor are cool. What I think would make things a bit easier is adding a trading system between players, for example; someone who is starting needs some craft items to make armor and I have some that I don't need, I would give them some. Also whenever I want to craft a weapon, it asks for a weapon but doesn't show where to get it, showing where to get the weapon/items to craft armor would be helpful. Having more inventory space would also be nice without needing to buy it from the guardian class, having to delete items every time that my inventory gets full is frustrating since i might not know what to delete because i need the items for crafting. I started the game week/s ago so i'm figuring out everything on my own and I enjoy it, the quests are a bit all over the place but overall, cool game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077881133', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 6479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6223, 'last_played': 1539201027}
review:
Okay, this one needs some work.

GoI Online is an excellent game. Alliance adds, on top of the PvP mode, a PvE play option. It adds some new content, in the form of new missions and Special Abilities, but the base gameplay is the same -- but the opponents are bots. And if you've played Online, you know that fighting bot captains isn't fun because they are dumb. It doesn't matter how many you have to fight at once, or if they add boss fights. The captains are still bots.

On top of that, playing PvE matches is a near necessity for advancing in the "overgame" (as I will call it; it has no official name as far as I know). On the surface, this third mode of play is the coolest mechanic ever -- a global, risk-style map that makes every game worthwhile, and adds a depth of strategy above the round-to-round combat. In practice, this discourages playing the better gamemode -- PvP -- in favor of MMO style grinding. Competitive MMO style grinding.

Consider what would happen if we replaced all the progress made by playing PvE with just a meter that automatically filled depending on what you targetted. The overgame now appears vividly hollow. Go back to how it is, and it is that, but with incentive to grind.

Only buy this version if you absolutely love the base game and are craving for more content or want to support the developers. GoIO deserves it.
developer_response:
Ohai!
As of next week there will be a Coffe Hour with a dev in discord again and I thought I should let you know. If you want you can bring all your ideas and thoughts and we will take time to consider, log, and potentially impliment them into DevApp! :)

All the best, and Happy New Year!

author: {'steamid': '76561198191225637', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1530340512}
review: I played this game in a bit with a friend and had some fun with it and actually won a game. The next day I decided to look at some reviews to see what others thought of the game. Most of it was positive but then when I saw the negative reviews that's when I started to get worried. I read reviews that said things of gaijin seeding stuff from your PC without permission, the launcher starting up when your PC boots up, and downloading gaijins other games without permission (that one I'm not sure about). I then uninstalled the game and doing other stuff to make sure. Call me dumb if you want, but i'm not the type of person to take risks. I would not recomend downloading this game until more stuff on this gets revealed. For now this is getting a negative review, but other than all that stuff I did enjoy what I played and it is a good game but again, I don't like taking risks.
developer_response: Hello Bucky, Gaijin Agent can be deactivated in the game launcher by a single click of a button and its only purpose is to update the game. We have notified all users that the game requires 3rd party software on the Steam store page and we are also asking whether users want to turn on auto-updates during the installation process. It is not harmful in any way. We have addressed these "concerns" in the game's discussion hub.

author: {'steamid': '76561198259338671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1703561745}
review:
I want to start by saying the art is beautiful, which is a big part of why I picked up the game in the first place.

Unfortunately, the art style was a major hindrance to enjoying the game as well. Trying to figure out what I was looking at at any given time was a bit headache inducing.

The UI was fiddly, and some of the game's mechanics were very obscure. I didn't find the puzzles particularly satisfying, either - many were quite simple, and the ones that weren't were a bit too abstract for my taste.

On top of that, the plot didn't grab me even after getting all the endings. Also, I have a low tolerance for certain tropes from 1970-90s sci-fi, and this game was full of them.

Loved the premise and the art, but the game wasn't worth it for me.
developer_response: Sorry you didn't enjoy it, and all of those are very legitimate points of criticism. (How they balance for different players is unique to the individual, of course.) Feel bad we let you down, but I'm glad you gave it a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066630000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1670809459}
review:
I recieved this game as a part of being apart owning a Tobii EyeX, and at first, I admit, I thought that it was a Telltales wanna-be, so I didn't get too far into the game.

However, fast forward to my 3D Game Art & Engines course where we're building fictional cities that are to appear as if they're on a stage.  The schedule has a day for some of the immersive technologies we can use to present our projects (Vive, Occulus, Tobii Eyetracking, etc), and I'm trying to decide on the game to show off the eye-tracking.  That's when it hits me: Knee Deep.

I remembered the game's theater quality and how it was perfect for the project.  Replaying it, I found myself realizing that while Telltales leaned on action, Knee Deep preferred the power of words and mystery and played to that advantage.  I went from showing it to a friend in class to doing a full-run through of the game in one night just for how the story sucked me in and didn't let go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198212541072', 'num_games_owned': 81, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 893, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1623280680}

review: Adventure games are not dead after all. The puzzles in this game are never tedious, but the difficulty does increase throughout gameplay. The narrative and characters are believable and intriguing, and the art-style and music fit together perfectly. Gritty cyberpunk post-apocalyptic story exploring what it means to be human (sort of).

author: {'steamid': '76561198069408973', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1621625812}
review: Before the Index update the game was at least playable. Motion sickness never really bugged me because I was at least heavily warned before purchasing the game that this is like the most nausea inducing game to date. But once the Index update came out my controllers are now floating several feet in front of me, the main menu is impressively even more buggy and laggy than before (I'm talking worse frame drop and lag than a overloaded VRChat world). In it's current state the game isn't worth purchasing unless you're okay gambling that they might fix these new "features" they added in the future.
developer_response:
if your controller is offset, please try doing these steps:

1) Make sure you don't have any additional gamepad plugged into your computer.
a) Restart Knuckles with game opened
b) THEN restart the game

2) Recalibrate knuckles without Detached turned on and then turn the game on

author: {'steamid': '76561197994005709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 92209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59081, 'last_played': 1689117877}
review:
Really hate to say this but game went down hill fast.  I would not recomend this game at this time. Few of the problems whirly  ships of death spinning out of control. Any one remember those when game came out. Well happens occasionally again. Pcu limits on items would go up down up down. Now server limits. They changed asteroids poof asteroids that you were farming are now gone and have to look for them again. Uranium missing off planets. Turned the hunt for resources into easter egg hunt be prepared to travel. The DLC i found was a nice touch would i buy just for the items yes. But im not goin to buy DLC for a game not goin to be able to play if they keep change things that are not broken. The achievements that were added wow how many times do you have to do them to get perfect game before someone else picks it up and have to do it again.

Just a few of the things i have noticed recently. I have about 950 hours of game time. But i wouldnt call this a multiplayer game unless you plan just 1 or 2 people playing around.
developer_response:
Hi Waldo,

Thank you for writing this review.

We really appreciate your feedback.

We are continuing to release free features for Space Engineers via updates, (Customizable LCD Screens, Replay Tool, Steam Badges. Steam Backgrounds, etc.) and optional paid DLC (the Decorative Pack), which is designed to not split our community. For more information please see Marek Rosa's blog: https://blog.marekrosa.org/2019/04/space-engineers-customizable-lcd.html

We are also continuing to optimize Space Engineers and fix numerous bugs in the game.

If you are experiencing any issues, please message us via our support site: https://support.keenswh.com/spaceengineers/general and we'll be happy to assist you.

Kind regards,

Keen Software House

author: {'steamid': '76561198048321172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 64806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59081, 'last_played': 1605314434}
review: I am close to 1,000 hours in and just realized I never commented on Elite Dangerous here!  I suppose, knowing that I have spent 984 hours over the span of about 3 years, experiencing Elite Dangerous in VR - first on the original Vive and more recently on the Index, you can guess that I like it!  For me, this is the best thing in VR.  I get as much action as I want from  combat roles, and the zen of exploration and mining. This space sim can be absolutely mind blowing at times.  Yes - you will need to endure a bit of a learning curve but it is very much worth it!   I am sure others will comment on "grind," but it is what you make of it and grind is easily avoidable if you just pace yourself and switch roles from time to time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968545232', 'num_games_owned': 738, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1373191808}
review: Great game. Would have been a classic in the point and click era. Themes are akin to Beneath a Steel Sky, but the puzzles are far more logical. Characters are vibrant and likable (although one in particular may be somewhat verbose). Writing is fantastic, and makes it another gem from Wadjet Eye's offerings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203053631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 8983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7951, 'last_played': 1662829504}
review:
This has got to be one of the best games I own and even after 2 years the company are still adding content. I played all the Original Dungeon Keeper games but this version certainly keeps me entertained for many hours. 

The producers have look after and debugged every version and dlc and how many games can you say have been supported this well, and not left to die.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131405796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3294, 'last_played': 1688935055}
review:
I wanted this game to be a huge success. The guys did a good job to revive the DG series but unfortunately they did not capture the spirit. 
The game is not well polished and I did not enjoy the campaign at all. I am very sad to give a negative review... as Dungeon Keeper I was my first PC game.
developer_response:
Hi George.Spil,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2017. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since release:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. One of these is completely free for you!
- New Game Modes
- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate
- Entirely new Skirmish AI

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561198011555731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1481602319}
review: Very entertaining game.  The throw, slow, shoot mechanic is extremely addictive and watching bullets fall in slow motion while pounding music plays gets the adrenaline pumping.  The visual style of the game is a cool sci-fi aesthetic and it's a minor but engaging addition to be able to see player arms move with the controllers in game.  There's not a lot of content here, but what is there is polished and seems very replayable.
developer_response:
Thank you for recognizing our polish. :) It's something we really strive for here at First Contact. 

We have a lot of plans for new content and will be releasing additional content over the coming months and our goal is to meet (or exceed!) players expectations in terms of replayability and awesome content. 

Thanks for taking the time to review our game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198083520771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1561253509}
review:
It was a really nice concept and I've played it at first launch. They then did some "improvements" but that was mostly transforming the game into an ipad/tablet version. It has a mobile game UI now and is not really intuitive. I got stuck in the forced-tutorial being ordered to do something that is not visible anywhere. And I didn't get the chance to skip the tutorial. Therefore I was stuck in something that maybe is a bug? because certainly i checked every menu, upgraded every building and was lost for more than 10 min skipping storms trying to see if that would be an event that has to be triggered later, idk. Nothing worked. So yeah, maybe buggy.. idk 

I mean, still appreciate they tried to do their gig. They just went the small-studio route of targeting mobile gamers since they're a pretty big market it seems. But for us PC gamers it is all in your face, the PC UX was not a priority clearly. I feel they should be marketing this on the Appstore instead of Steam. 
 
Other than that I would have honestly played this a lot more, the concept was simple and fun enough
developer_response:
Hey! 

Thank you for your review!

What was that issue with the tutorial? If it was during еhe sacrifice of the mage phase, than yes, there was a bug that appeared only on some systems and caused the button to disappear. I am sorry that you had this issue, and is already fixed in a 1.1 patch. Also, we do not give an option to skip the tutorial, because this way player would not know the core gameplay mechanic.

I must mention that our main priority was changing the game UI to feel less than a mobile UI and more like a pc one. That is why we got rid of panel in a top bottom part that looked like hp/energy in f2p games. We did simplify game windows, but this was made to get rid of useless space in them that appeared after we changed the core gameplay mechanic.

The changes to the gameplay were made to give player more control over the city and to raise replayability. The game now has dozens of new ways to complete it.

Our goal is to make a strategic roguelike experience for PC platforms, and right now we are not doing a mobile version, because it is not in our priority.

Hope you will give the game one more chance, perhaps with the next patch (ver. 1.3) that is going to be released in a few days!

author: {'steamid': '76561198071159010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1679718404}
review: SAVE YOUR MONEY. This game is hot garbage right now with the unbearable amount of bugs even after the Sept 1st update.  I was so anxious to play this game despite the comments about bugs that I went ahead and bought it, at full price even, because I saw they had recently done an update that fixed some bugs.  I didn't see any comments after that date so I tried my luck.  I am so upset that this game was released in this condition.  This game needs a lot of work to even begin to work properly.  I have tried everything to get around the bugs and have just decided this game is simply not playable until the developers do the right thing and get some real work done on fixing bugs.  The job system is completely broken and no matter what job I do, what character I create, the game breaks once it hits tier 2 of the job.  As a florist I went from watering flowers (beginning level) to CEO which was somehow job level 2 ??? and it didn't even tell me what I was to be doing at that point. I just stood around the store to find at the end of the day I made 5 coins as CEO as opposed to the 40 coins I made as flower waterer. Every job broke at job level 2.  On my last experiment as bartending I found that you can't quit some jobs, so you just have to be fired if you want to switch to another job. Your diary also does not keep the information for each job you have worked. One of the biggest issues I have found is with saves. It does something to the game when reloading saves. It showed lost information several times and this last time all of my saves suddenly did not show anything in my inventory anymore, poof gone.  No matter how many times I rebooted.  All my hard earned stuff was gone, FROM PREVIOUS SAVES! LIKE WHAT? This is just the beginning. The people you talk to on the streets only say one of three different things to you. Is this world some kind of lame hive mind?  Come on, there has to be more variety and realism.  I can't even tell people apart, how am I supposed to develop relationships when people are just speeding past me constantly saying the same things over and over. There is no immersion with the places of business such as the nightclub.  You go in and "dance" and you get out there to dance but you find that all your character does is stand there while your fun meter fills up and you quickly realize its also an empty night club.  I was expecting much more effort and immersion in those things as well as jobs. It should feel like a real simulation, a real exciting and maybe a bit scary experience in a new city climbing the ranks slowly, not just a jump to crafting your own stuff to make money and foregoing the job system laid out.  That is missing a huge part of the experience.  The game feels empty. You run around quickly trying to beat the clock while filling up your meters.  There is nothing fun or immersive about it.  So disappointed.  I will change my review to a positive one hopefully one day, but for now my blood pressure can't take anymore.  Please developers, a lot of people believe in your project.  Don't give up and please keep working on this game.
developer_response:
Hello depelocha, first of all we are very sorry you had such an experience.

We would be happy if you could provide us more feedback. Issues that are reported (and the ones we can replicate on our side) we do fix, and we thank each individual for pointing them out.

- Job System. Wahtever we try we can't replicate this bug, job level works on our end fine.
Could you send us your save game file, so we can see what happened on your end?

- We tried several other jobs and non-got broken at level 2. Did you play a particular Scenario or did you lay Free Play Mode?

- Quitting a job, if you go to any Newspaper stand and find your job there (that you are currently doing), there is a "QUITE JOB" button.

- NPC's conversations and depth of them are broken down into 5 tires, depending on your relationship level with the NPC, the conversation changes.

- Agree with you on the nightclub thing. Suggestions are welcomed at this point. :)

Please accept our apologies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109892814', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1597829908}
review: In the beginning i was stunned by it's graphics and then i started noticing major bugs in the missions, can't even progress farther on my first day now. Had to prepare medicine to heal my wounds, nope no can do, made medicine, health and psyche was full, still told me to go to fireplace and make medicine, wtf? Need to scrap a pile of trash to get resources? Nope no can do. If game's playable again, will give it two thumbs up even, game has a lot of potential, yes but getting really stuck on first hour in game... Ruins it completely for me.
developer_response: Hey mate! Yes, we did. We've added a lot of new stuff and a lot of fixes ... At the same time breaking the startup sequence. We didn't notice it because nobody touched it, so how could it break? We have already fixed the problem in the hotfix, I hope you will give us another chance.

review:
A strategy based on Ancient Egypt, it's a beautifully themed, and georgously looking little game for some hours of fun, it's the mini Ancient Egypt version of the Sid Meier's Civilization games. author: {'steamid': '76561198042493786', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1589655721}
review:
This game is fun, clever, and entertaining.

The solutions to the point-and-click puzzles genuinely make me smile. The platformer tasks are challenging but not frustrating. The gun is very pleasing to use and it's all I can do to not open fire on Ben most of the time (sorry Ben).

It's got good graphics and the feel of the animation is right. The music & effects are great. I've been very happy to launch this game when I've had a few hours of down time on the weekend to explore.  Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561197979890569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1650285172}
review:
Kickstarted this game, been looking forward to it being finished for some time. I chose not to play any Beta as I prefer to play the finished product...something that this 'released' game is not. Couldn't get past the first mission in the campaign because apparently building your dungeon how you like and not how it tells you to completely breaks it. Didn't get the rally spell so couldn't go further. Possesion is currently broken according to the tooltip. Selling a room also breaks the game and prevents you from building another. A shambles. Forget the people moaning, don't release your game until it's finished. 

I'd wait at least a few months before playing this, though honestly I can't see it being in a finished state for at least another 6 months.

Incidently, I completed both Dungeon Keeper 1 and 2 multiple times, I love this franchise. This game feels very much like them, the aestetic and narration is spot on. It's just not finished yet. When it is, I'm sure it will be fantastic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071371252', 'num_games_owned': 374, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1956, 'last_played': 1705119218}
review: Keep getting disconnected from the servers and not collecting the money from the end of events.
developer_response: Hello Sabellan! I'm sorry to hear that you have been experiencing disconnects in The Crew 2. Please complete our [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-US/faqs/000035320/Connectivity-Issues-in-The-Crew-2-On-PC-TC2/]connectivity troubleshooting guide[/url] in full. Doing so will ensure that your connection to the game's online services is not being interrupted and that it is completely optimized. Ultimately, this will help to lessen or resolve the disconnects you experience. However, if you experience further issues, please do not hesitate to reach out for additional assistance at support.ubi.com.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012854150', 'num_games_owned': 941, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1648997180}
review:
While it's a fun game and when more content is added I can see it being a definite recommendation, it's let down by awful UI and AI. 
One of the features the game touts is a unique system where villagers will build their own houses, while in theory this is cool and when it does work in game it looks really realistic, in practice it just leads to the builders half building 6 houses and people getting miserable because their house won't get built.
The UI is confusing and icons do not match up, in the needs column the faith icon is different to the faith icon which is produced from the church, making the wiki for the game necessary.
developer_response:
Hi willdapod,

Thank you for taking the time to write a review. 

We though you might like to know that the UI, it is undergoing a complete overhaul right now that will include many improvements to the UX. You can check out some teaser images of the current work in progress in the recent Devlog [url=https://steamcommunity.com/games/690830/announcements/detail/2745461157458184840]here[/url] as well as more in the recent article from [b][url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2020/08/14/foundations-updates-and-new-ui-will-make-it-the-city-builder-to-beat/]Rock Paper Shotgun[/url][/b]

Housing is currently still work in progress and will be improved as we further develop the game. There is however, a priority button on all buildings that you can use to prioritise the builders. Doing this on the houses will cut down on the time villagers are waiting for their houses to be built.

Thanks again and we hope you enjoy the further development of the game including the new UI when it lands.

Cheers
Ash

author: {'steamid': '76561197983977630', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2604, 'last_played': 1473624123}
review:
This is by far the most realistic tennis game I have ever played for PC or console. First thing, the learning curve is very steep, especially if you are coming from a game like Top Spin. The controls will feel very different at first and will take some time getting used to. The game is unforgiving when making mistakes. You may want to remap some of the buttons to make it easier or make the controls more like Top Spin/Virtua Tennis.

The campaign mode is extremely in depth. It is like a real tennis career starting from the bottom unlike other tennis games. You begin playing Futures tournaments and have to qualify for Challengers and Tour level just like real players. That alone makes it a good challenge and have a lasting appeal. Also, if you want real player names and real tournament names, mods are available for the game. If you a tennis fan, you will enjoy this game. Hopefully the developer will produce a quality sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198391690093', 'num_games_owned': 69, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2101, 'last_played': 1663707091}
review:
Fun, pretty relaxing game, which doesn't take itself seriously. The first half is basically Subnautica in space in an eastern european comedy version. The second half is a mixture of a spaceship shootemup and an adventure/walking simulator, with the main purpose of bringing you to locations and nicely tieing up the weird story.

Pros:
 - humor
 - ambience in space
 - relaxing gameplay (as long as you mind your oxigen level)
 - sounds, OST and voice acting is pretty good

Cons:
 - the pacing is strange. basebuilding in the first half is a complex minigame like in Subnautica, but totally optional, it is just there to enjoy it if you want. meanwhile the second half is quite different gameplay-wise, you barely need any crafting, just have to run through the story.

but in the end somehow this uneven pacing just strengthens the basic premise of lack of seriousness, so maybe this is not even a real Con, and then this is one of the best games I ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992135430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1676909987}
review:
Absolute junk.  I have tried 10 times at least to learn how all of this works but to no avail.  Controls are clunky and unresponsive making everything you do in this game hard work.  Tutorial is bugged  The graphics scale is all over the place so that if you select a module the ship is covered by the module control so you can't place or see your ships modules.

It doesn't feel like a game, more like a futile attempt at getting something to work as it should.  Also no immersion or atmosphere.
If your looking for a FTL clone look at Trigon.  That does things much better than this POS.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963905026', 'num_games_owned': 3643, 'num_reviews': 412, 'playtime_forever': 4887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1644622516}
review:
Free: gifted to me by a friend. 

Edit: I have since unlocked everything on the "skill trees" and beat all the bosses, and had fun doing it!  Recently (Jan, 2022) there was another free content update with some new bosses, so I paid to buy the DLCs.  The extra characters are....meh....but I think they deserve some money out of me for all the fun I've had.  Have not reached the new bosses yet but I'm working on it!  Original review follows:

Roguelite platformer/shooter with zillions of items and guns, and quite a few pets too. Shoot the badguys, and don't get hit by their shots.  It's nice that many enemies don't damage you on-contact, just from their actual attacks.  At the end of each stage there's a boss fight, and after several stages, there's a big boss called a manager.  So far I only beat the first one. 

5 types of 'currency' in the game:
-HP, which you can sometimes pay directly or indirectly to buy things or access new areas. Restore them by picking up full/half hearts. Moldy hearts may heal or harm you. 
-coins. Gain them as copper(1)/silver(5)/gold(10)/larger
-keys
-grenades / explosions, there are plenty of obstacles that will only disappear/open from explosions. 
-crystals, which you can think of as MP. They are used to power your RMB special ability. 
Some doors/chests can be opened for 3/2 crystals, or you can shoot them to turn them into a 'spiked' version that instead costs 0.5HP to open. 

On a run you can find big yellow coins, which go towards unlocking things on a skill tree including new characters.  Some of the skill-trees end in a one-time-use bonus that seems pretty dumb...the longest skill tree ends in double-jump (one-time-use), though you can sometimes get that, or even flight, from RNGesus during regular gameplay. 

There are several characters you can unlock in-gme (and more you can buy as DLC), they vary in health/shields/keys/grenades and their special abilities.  I like the black guy (default version) that lays landmines.  At the risk of hurting yourself, you effectively have infinite explosions.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983601366', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1652398166}
review:
Cossacks II is a game that I really like but it has some definite flaws that prevent it from being an all time classic. That said, there are not many games that simulate the the napoleonic wars so well. It certainly is more of an arcadey strategy game but it has a lot of elements of realism like morale, formations and intensive resource management.

First of all I would like to mention that the game has an incredible art style and that the 2d graphics hold up quite well. The units have detailed animations and spritework and coupled with the picturesque maps, it's quite a sight to behold. Although I do have a soft spot for 2d graphics. But having multiple lines of infrantry duking it out feels quite epic.

The game has an extensive campaign, a risk type of world domination mode, skirmish and multiplayer. The campaign is a good introduction but it is tough as nails, in general this game will make you go mad. You always seem outnumbered and resources are dwindling. Even on easy, the campaign is no joke. It's actually more frustrating and I could never finish it.

Skirmish mode provides you with map where you build your hometown, collect resources and then duke it out on the map. While trying to capture resource points. World domination adds an overworld map with various faction that fight over the control of europe. You also have a gamemode where you can replay massive historical battles, then you also got the multiplayer.

The gameplay mostly consists of moving around massive lines of infantry, adapting your formations to various circumstances. Formations are vital for success and also managing the morale of your units. Overall the formation based rts gameplay is quite enjoyable, albeit a bit chaotic at times. Most missions give you units and ressources, where you have to fufill certain objectives. Some missions have base building as well. The base building aspect of the game is a bit weak, gathering resources is a hassle most of the time. Therefore you can capture towns which automatically produce goods. 

My issue with the game itself is that there is no particular gamemode that is really appealing or offers that much replayability. 

The campaign is very frustrating and hard, also there are not many ways to actually fulfill your goals in different ways. Also the dialogues is done in such a boring way that you just want to skip to the gameplay right away. The historical battles are way to massive, it seems like the game is not made to handle such large amount of units to be honest. The player is always struggling to keep the frontline stable and the micromanaging feels like hell. The multiplayer is alright but due to the weak base building, I never particularly liked it. A shame also that you cannot play with a friend against the AI. 

The only decent game mode is the world domination, you pick a faction, gather resources and invade different regions. You spawn with a few regiments and have to conquer the map. This gameplay shines in this gameplay mode, where you can strategize and organise yourself before fighting on a map. Unfortunately, the tougher terrorities are so well defended that at that start of each round, you get rushed by tons of enemies. It's just tedious at some point.

All things considered, I want to like this game and I certainly do but it lacks kind of the rts elements from the first game with a bigger emphasis on the tactical aspect of the formations, still the tactical gameplay is not as refined as Total War games.

It's still worth picking up if you like historical rts games, lots of potential here.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979572304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 12456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 626, 'playtime_at_review': 7127, 'last_played': 1710226680}
review:
I keep seeing this game called the best modern Dungeon Keeper spinoff. I don't know what they're talking about, and it makes it sound like WFTO is the best of a bunch of failed open source remake attempts or something. DK1 was in 1997 and DK2 was in 1999, WFTO 2015, that's it. There are no other DK style games except maybe Evil Genius from Sierra, which plays similarly.

In it's current state it is vastly more polished and playable then Dungeon Keeper 1 or 2, and at least as much fun. If there had ever been a proper sequel by Bullfrog, I highly doubt it would have been nearly as good as WFTO has turned out to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202563105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4474, 'last_played': 1668459082}
review:
If you're a casual gamer looking for a game to play when you're bored, then go for it. Otherwise, I do not recommend.

I have followed this game company since early 2009. Playing their other games, primarily AQWorlds. I had high hopes for this game, testing it in every testing phase: pre-alpha, alpha, beta, etc. and the game hasn't changed. One bit. The combat is that of when it was first introduced: you target a monster, you spam skills 1, 2, 3, 4 and that's it. There's no missing, no dodging (besides the RNG calculator), it's like the game plays itself. Conclusion: combat is static and boring as all hell. The camera is the same; fix-locked onto your character with no smoothness to it. 

The graphics need a mass update to it. It's like playing a game from the PS1, only with higher anti-analysing and better resolution. 

Questing system isn't much better either (more below).

Want a new class? Takes a week doing a daily quest to collect class tokens and that's it. There's no farming for miscellaneous items or anything. It doesn't feel rewarding; as if you don't deserve the new class. 

Lastly, this game is ALL about cosmetics. As I mentioned in the combat above; you spam skills 1, 2, 3, 4 and that's it. Each class has 4 skills and a passive, and the combat being static, right? Well, that's where cosmetics come in to save the day? No... The majority of cosmetics you obtain through Dragon Coins (the premium currency). This game is a money grab if you want your PS1 rendered character to look good. 

If I had to sum up this game with one word: soulless. There's nothing to make it unique or stand-out from other games. There are much better options out there.
developer_response:
Hello. Thank you for being such a long time player and checking out our newest and first cross platform game!

We appreciate your honest feedback and always take any player feedback or constructive criticism to heart. The devs work very hard on a weekly basis to fix issues, release updates and to improve the game, which is a challenge as we are a small indie game studio.

The devs are working on updating combat, quests and improving graphics. You can always tweak your camera via the game settings. Besides the 3 base classes, any other classes are free to earn if you would like to learn their story, or if you do not want to wait, you can choose to purchase them outright. 

Cosmetics are completely optional and just for fun. They are the fastest thing to add to the game while the devs work on larger releases and updates to the game. We've also always had fun events with related item releases for holidays and such. 

We hope you continue to check out the game as it's growing - you can always check the Design Notes and Game Plan via AQ3D.com for updates.
