author: {'steamid': '76561198099542568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 14074, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13506, 'last_played': 1533845037}
review:
"Let's abandon this multiplayer once and for all."

It's becoming clear that when Keen Software House say they have been working on an "Overhaul of Multiplayer" the name they seem to give to every update that they have in fact been working on new trailers for the game.

Keen, next time before telling people your multiplayer is "working as intended" please log onto your own official servers where you will be bombarded with the following messages from your own performance monitoring.

Block issues -> Too many blocks
Block issues -> Too many grids

Other issues -> Scene too complex

Multiplayer -> Poor network quality
Multiplayer -> Scene too complex

Performance -> Simulation quality

Now Keen have disabled programmable blocks on these official servers, implemented a brutal cleanup that eats genuine buildings, limited rendering range to 3km (lowest a player can set there render range is 5km) and there are no mods installed. So I'm interested in what you plan to blame the issues on?

Keen, when you can play your own official multiplayer servers for a day without having to wait for long server pauses on save, crazy rubberbanding lag and the constant issue spam from your own performance measurement system in the top right. Then tell people its fixed!
developer_response:
Hi Richard,

Thank you for writing this review.

We're always happy to hear back from players, as we believe it helps us to create better games.

For more information why we have implemented safe and experimental mode, along with the current parameters for dedicated servers in Space Engineers, please see the following link:

https://blog.marekrosa.org/2018/07/space-engineers-multiplayer-overhaul.html

We're also continuing to improve Space Engineers via updates, such as our most recent one: 

https://steamcommunity.com/games/244850/announcements/detail/1702809986610067420

Kind regards,

Keen Software House

author: {'steamid': '76561197967343676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1573464693}
review: I wanted to like this sim so much, but the quad feels SOOOOO BAD!!  I could even get over the floaty aspect of it but this quad drifts TERRIBLY,  I fly HEAVY quads IRL and they come nowhere near the drifty levels of this sim.  0/10
developer_response:
Hi Castlebravo,

I'm sorry your experience wasn't as positive as you hoped. Some of our sim pilots, who have IRL drone experience come in with certain expectations and can feel let down by their initial flight time with the sim.

Experienced IRL pilots come in with expectations based around their personal drones and their first time with the Racer3 can be a bit jarring. The Racer3 is a heavy racing drone, that doesn't behave like consumer drones. You said you've flown heavy drones before. But I don't think you've flown a heavy drone like the Racer3. It's a beast of a drone, that weighs over 1000g with 6in props, that's built for only racing.

It takes a bit of getting used to, but once you've gotten the hang of it, you'll be tearing up the tracks with the best of them. A lot of our pilots, who've had bad first experiences like you have, once they've gotten used to how the Racer3 handles, have really come to enjoy flying it.

If I could ask you to please give the sim another shot, and maybe this time trying out one of the other drones available. Based on what you've said, I would recommend the Mifune. It's a great drone, that should be closer to what you've flown in the past. And it would be awesome to hear your thoughts on it.

Thank you so much for your feedback.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052279159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1524295892}
review:
The game runs horribly on a computer that runs all other games fluently. It freezes every few seconds what makes the game unplayable for me. Usual tricks to fix that on user side don't do a thing. That issue seems to be known since a while but nothing had been done to do something about it.
I was looking forward to buy and play this, but now I am completely disappointed.

I am gonna refund this
developer_response:
Hi Terodan,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review. Version 2.0 has brought massive changes to every aspect of the game, including new AI, great Performance and an improved interface.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since your review:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. One of these is completely free for you!
- New Game Modes
- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate
- Entirely new Skirmish AI

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

review: About Planetbase! The Devs spent a lot of time working on this game, a lot. Problem is this game is the digital equivalent to manic depression. If you like things in your life that disappoint you, that are utter wastes of time and electricity then this game is for you. The concept is brillant, the time spent on it's creation is respected, however this game presents the same pleasure one derives from a colonoscopy. I can only recommend this game to the most medicated of you gamers, so dose up before you purchase this title, you will need it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001119818', 'num_games_owned': 557, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1488223367}
review:
This is an adorable little game which unfortunately do not seem to work for me. My big fluffy santa hands are unable able to click "continue" or "play again" after I have finished the first few deliveries, and as such my game play is quite limited. 

Another problem is that even though the steam page claims the game only requires 2m x 1.5m play area, the game actually requires a larger play area, my guess being around 2.5m x 2m. Keep this in mind.

However, the game is very cute and I actually find myself feeling like Santa deep inside. It makes me find the generosity and love for children that I did not know I possesed. Delivering my first VR headset was a particular great moment.

Wait a few patches, snatch it on sale and be the worlds most loved person for a night.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026156692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1567018018}
review:
This game is very obviously alpha from the gameplay.

That being said, it has a lot of potential with very passionate developers behind it. Almost every single thing I could think of to suggest(and then some) is already on their design document apparently.

It's already fun to play for a few hours until it starts stuttering due to the hundred or so ships running around the solar system(alpha is alpha afterall) despite its early alpha state and the features to come make me very excited to see how this game develops.

I'm also very optimistc about it reaching completion. The developer is very active and responsive to player feedback, even if it's just to let me know that they are already aware of the issues I had with some of the GUI. So I feel confident to say that this game is not going to go the way of abandonware if they have anything to say about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198172675590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 72239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 804, 'last_played': 1707407443}
review:
I received this game from a friend as a gift.  I had been eyeing it for a while, but had kind of put it towards the bottom of my "to get" list.  I wish I had bought this sooner.  I am having such fun with this game that I can actually lose myself and suddenly six or seven hours have gone by...

The things I like about this game:

1.) The graphics and models are really great
2.) The levels are very cool and very detailed.
3.) The bow mechanics are really well done.
4.) Co-op multiplayer is a lot of fun if you can find an unlocked game (more on that later).
(EDIT): 5.) This is fantastic exercise.  I have actually started playing this with weights on my wrists.  

My complaints or things that I wish would improve (hopefully some of these will be addressed as development continues):

1.) I wish there were more playable levels other than the 3-4 that are already there.
2.) The equipment upgrades are neat, but pointless other than for cosmetics.  It would be nice if the equipment and bow upgrades actually did something to improve your character in some way --- let you take an extra axe before you die, decrease spell recharge time, increase arrow damage, give you additional skills, etc.  
3.) Leveling doesn't seem to do much other than give you an additional spell point and specify to other players how long you have been playing the game (I played a co-op with someone who was level 204 the other day).  
4.) As already mentioned, co-op is a blast provided you can find a game to play in.  Most people lock their games and I understand the reason for allowing people to lock games, so this may just be more of a complaint about the general anti-socialness of the community playing this game.  But, it's really annoying when all you see on co-op is a bunch of locked game when they all have room for 1-2 more people to join.  If you can find an open game, though, all the people playing are really fantastic, really nice, and this game is a great way to meet people.  
5.) When a multiplayer game ends, it takes FOREVER for the game to give you the option to restart the game, so if you do find a good group of people to play with, you immediately lose them at the end of the game as they go in search of other open games because it is faster to quit and rejoin multiplayer than it is to wait for someone to restart the game.  Be nice if this could be sped up A LOT.
6.) I have a problem getting my mic to work with this game.  I could easily see this one being on me and my computer, but I will mention it here since I am complaining. (EDIT): This was a HMD issue unrelated to the game that was fixed.
7.)  I wish there was an option to rotate the camera.  As I move to different towers, some of the towers are oriented such that they make me face in directions that are not as well covered by my VR sensors.  Did my best to re-setup my environment to fix this issue, but sometimes there is only so much you can do.  This would not have been an issue if there was an option to rotate the camera in the game.    
(EDIT): 8.) The devs on this game are terrible.  They are more interested in putting new features in the newer Quest version of this game than they are in actually finishing this game which has been around WAY longer.  That says these guys are more interested in a quick buck than doing a good job on what would be a solid game.  Game is great, devs not so much.  
(EDIT): 9). There is an un-godly long wait between waves, especially at the higher ones.  This has been an issue for months now (since the last "recent" update) with zero response or fixes from the devs.  Expect to be standing around for a bit once you get good at this game.  

Overall, great game!  Very fun, and very good exercise.  I would like to see some of the issues I mentioned be addressed/improved, but despite my complaints I think this game is solid and worth getting, even at full price. (Edit): Just expect to be constantly angered and disappointed by bad development practices from incompetent developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025091679', 'num_games_owned': 2330, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1657375823}
review:
It's a fun shooter influenced a lot by Half-Life Alyx (which is absolutely a good thing).

I love how you can scavenge a gun from a mission and take it apart.

I hate how I couldn't for the life of me find the menu button on Rift S. Still managed to get to the Social screen somehow. Playing as a party feels great, people help each other out, someone bought me a medkit even. Thank you, kind person.

It feels like it'll take forever and a half to unlock all of the weapon stuff, and that's actually nice as it adds a sense of progression.

As for the cons:

1. Just call the zombies "zombies" or "undead" or something. Alternatively, make enemies that aren't perfectly regular undead as seen in every videogame. As it stands, that's just confusing. I don't even remember the word NPC use to refer to the undead, it's "snowmen" or "freezeboi" or some such.

2. Some of the spawn locations could use tweaking, I've had enemies spawn in the walls and then vibe spastically due to the physics engine not knowing how to proceed.

To summarize, it's a good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012980505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1652587738}
review: super fun though sometimes u just get steamrolled lol, but overall multiplayer is super fun, and awesome

author: {'steamid': '76561198079492657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1531765456}
review:
I'll keep this review brief. I grew up with AdventureQuest; the nostalgia value is certainly here in abundance. The way it has been revisioned from a 2D, Microsoft Paint-esque visual to a full-scale 3D MMORPG is actually my favorite part about the game. There's a lot of good things about this game despite its early access state (open beta). There's also a lot that could be improved and even a few things that need to be scrapped. 

First: as a mobile game, it's actually awesome. Plays pretty well on my Nexus 6P - battery drain is surprisingly low and there are flexible graphics settings (could be improved). Combat and gameplay is fun on mobile, not as much on PC. The cross-platform does have its conveniences, though. 

Story is pretty standard AE. It doesn't blow your mind, but the humor is entertaining for some to most. A lot of the characters, particularly the ones who have had time over the years to be fleshed out and built around the AE staff they're based on are relatable and good characters overall. Didn't get too far into AQWorlds so I can't speak as to how well they write villains these days. From what I've seen in what the story offers currently, it's not so bad. One of the first characters I actually paid attention to and liked got killed immediately and is probably the only character that will happen to.

It 100% needs a Book of Lore like what AQW has. It's hard even for veteran players to keep up on whether or not things are completed. Things are pretty ambiguous and the main story is a bit disjointed once you finish a zone. A Book of Lore would fix all of that and give the developers a guide for future content in relation to player progression and main story cohesion.

Progression needs a lot of work. Classes have no depth beyond what abilities you immediately get when switching to them. For some, it's enough, but there's definitely room for more character choice and gameplay options here. Skill trees, ability upgrades, passives, etc. What I miss from other AE games that I don't get from this one is actually progressing in your class and earning ranks, titles, and abilities. I do hope they add it even if people will gripe about more things to grind. 

On that note, gear could use some work, too. For one, a character profile or equipment page. Inventory management, especially with equipment, is messy. It needs a page that shows each slot and any equipped cosmetic. Would be nice if that all didn't take up inventory space, too. 

Gear stats need more depth and relevance. I'd like personal player stats we can choose to upgrade like classic AQ. But equipment just providing basic Attack, Armor, Crit, Haste, Evasion, etc. is just boring. I get that they want people to just switch between classes at their discretion (it's a fine idea if implemented well) but this way is just too simple and takes away from player choice and meaningful gear grinding (if that's a thing).

That goes into my last major critique which is the UI. On PC, some of the elements have weird scaling. On mobile, screen space is hard to manage in any game, but this one could use some work. The inventory is mostly a big mess and it would be nice if the chat window and health bar were located somewhere else, although I can understand how frustrating it must be. If any developers read this, I'd suggest having some UI options available for people as every mobile device is different. 

AQ3D's Kickstarter page nailed the main point: it's a game that has a lot of potential. It's not even close to living up to it, though that's not to say it's a bad game, just that it has so much room to grow. In a market completely oversaturated with copy-pasted Asian MMORPGs, especially on mobile, this could be the game that topples it all and I hope it is. 

I'd recommend personally if only because I've actually been really enjoying my time with it on my phone. I'm really excited to see what they add later on, especially if they took the time to gather feedback and update classes according to it. If you didn't grow up with AE, they are the type of developers to literally put themselves into their games (I've met their NPCs and actual characters dozens of times in-game), be transparent about their plans and shortcomings, and keep pushing out content.

They seem to be spread a bit thin with how many games they have - it would be a tough call to pull the plug on older games, but I understand they're focusing heavily on AQ3D anyway. It's certainly far from a perfect game, even a great game, but it's a great time-killer on mobile and is like any AE game very social. 

Some of the negative reviews I've seen aren't totally fair. I'd just check it out on your phone if it seems interesting to you and make up your own mind, like I did. If you grew up with AQ, definitely try it out.

I'll recommend this even in its rough, incomplete stage because while it is fun and succeeds in some ways, it has a long way to go and every bit of feedback helps AE and I know they factor it all in.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984822255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 962, 'last_played': 1541724466}
review:
Disclaimer: I was a backer and translated the game to Brazilian Portuguese, so I have followed all the development.

This game is basicaly a one man endeavor, it is a 2d platformer with GREAT graphics. No, really, this guy must have had a lot of work implementing all the lighting effects that are top notch! Animations, sound and music are good. It is a tad short and some items and mechanics are not fully needed/fleshed out, but it is forgivable, because it is hard to cut things out. The exploration is a little hard, boss fights are nice.

The launch was a little shaky, with some bug that are being squashed daily. I found some, but nothing major. If there is one thing that I have to say that really annoyed me is that it uses frame skipping, and it doesn't work very well. I think this might be a little hard to implement in game maker, but this should be fixed. Even if at 95% of the game my graphics card can run it smoothly at 60fps, some scenes droped to a crawl, and I had to change the config midgame, since auto just seems to lock my gig at 30fps without any need.

So, I highly recommend the game!

PS: did I say the graphics are beautiful? There is even fluid mechanics on the smoke and fog! Very pretty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061597788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 688, 'last_played': 1594085952}
review: Got partway through this with my young son years ago, and either got stumped or lost interest. Finally came back to it recently, restarting from the beginning, and made it all the way through in a few sessions. An interesting and thoughtful perspective on the "fall of man" and the robot age. Voice acting was good (and entertaining). Some things were a little off base to figure out, but I did enjoy the puzzles which required some brain power instead of just clicking around all the time. I've got a little scratch pad of paper by my desk to help with some of the logic/number problems.
developer_response:
Sorry you got derailed when you played with your son. Point and clicks with my daughters is always a great joy. My elder provided the voice (and in fact the dialogue) for “strange robot, go away, go back to spooky place”! (She was two and half at the time.)

Glad you came back to it, though, and enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043285647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1606447594}
review:
PSA.

You cannot play this game without registering for a separate "Frontier Support" account. 

It is a pain to deal with.

I tried this game a year ago for 16min and gave up since the Thrustmaster HOTAS wasn't working well with my then Windows 7.  

Fast Forward to 2020, trying to re-install to see if the Thrustmaster works better with Windows 10, but somehow FRONTIER SUPPORT does not recognize my game/account as legitimate, cannot log-in after jumping through the hoops of email verification, which somehow you need to do twice : first two authenticate the email, then to get a code.    

friction
too-many steps
not working

I don't have the time or energy to spend hours on support for a $8 game, but I decided to test the water and check their Customer Support page :

"RESPONSE TIME: UP TO 7 DAYS.
We are experiencing higher than normal ticket volumes, and may not have capacity to answer queries within seven days. Please be assured, any tickets sent will be addressed in the shortest time possible."

Hard pass

don't make it so full of friction to play your game
don't force people to log-in into a separate system to play your game on Steam

hint : if you want fewer customer support tickets, put fewer hurdles in your customer's journey.

congrats for having swindled this user out of a few bucks.

double checking the developer name to make a mental note to not be fooled again : Frontier Development.

Edit : now this cancer of a game (game itself might be great, heard good things, but the process is terrible) displays errors as I try to uninstall it, and stays RUNNING even as I restart Steam, impossible to get rid of it, and it tallies that as "Game played".   my "in-game" time went from 16min to 50 minutes just trying to get rid of the damn thing, oh dear.  Great metric, big success, this user tripled his game time!
developer_response:
Hey Commander, 
sorry to hear about your experience. 

The response time is increased to up to 7 days due to high volume of traffic of tickets we've received recently. We still do our best to respond to everyone within 24 hours. 

In regards to your account not being recognized it is most likely that when you previously played Elite: Dangerous it is linked/redeemed with a different Frontier account. 

Could you please send a support ticket via: https://customersupport.frontier.co.uk/hc/en-us and if possible include the steam key so that we can locate that account for you. 

- Ikaros

author: {'steamid': '76561198347736883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1699991094}
review:
Unambiguously, I recommend this game.  From the programmer of Troubles of Middle Earth; another outstanding game from the mind of Dark God... a new engine written in C++, SDL, and Lua.  And amongst the few classic roguelikes that attempted to embed within itself a story we have the "Tales of Maj'Eyal".  Many races to choose from, many classes to choose between -- even for a given race/class combination; there are so many skills to choose between and many ways to craft a build.  Although... my advice to you should you play this game -- focus on expanding your options and your defences before you begin perfecting your offence.   "Low Defences" == "Dead Tune"

Unambiguously, I recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002640002', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 18996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7132, 'last_played': 1668369378}
review:
Update post Odyssy:
Still tedious, grindy and boring, but now with added bugs and more half-finished features...
Avoid like the plague if you're new...

Poor mission design.  Dull, lifeless planets.  Most content stuck behind needing a capital ship and/or a wing, but be prepared to grind for hours before being able to afford one.
The flight model is good and if you like flight sims and space sims then you will enjoy just plodding around space truckin' and ferrying passengers, but if you like excitement and combat (since you can only really have fun doing this after hours and hours of grinding), find something else to scratch that itch.  Also, most definitely not worth the full price seeing as you need the season pass/DLC to have anything to do in this game.
Shame really.  Frontier and Egosoft should team up and make us a space sim does it all.

EDIT:
Thanks very much for providing a link to the support page.  Appreciate that you guys still actively scan the reviews and offer support.  
I managed to fix the issue with a hard router reset (not the optimal fix but a standard turn it off and on again didnt work and i needed to do it in general as i had forgotten my admin password).  When the issue occurs again, I'll log a ticket via the link with the appropriate attachments.
Unfortunately, I still can't recommend it unless you have a group to play with.  Fun game with friends, a bit unforgiving and grindy if you fly solo.
developer_response:
Sorry to hear that you're seeing this error, it's possible that you're experiencing a local connection issue that we can help with, please send us a ticket via: https://support.frontier.co.uk/topic.php

-Vulcan

author: {'steamid': '76561198106570362', 'num_games_owned': 813, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1650823705}
review:
A horror escape room puzzle point and click. 

You, along with your wife, have been kidnapped and you have to escape the killer's "Funhouse". Each room poses a number of puzzles for you to complete in order to progress. 

I thought it was pretty well made considering it's a low budget indie. You can tell there was inspiration from the horror franchise SAW put into it.  The atmosphere and audio is well done. Puzzles are interesting but after the first few rooms they got a bit repetitive. Voice acting is pretty cringe. UI felt clunky and the animation when taking out your phone or matches is way too slow. It's like the protagonist is standing at the bottom of the ocean. If you're into achievements, it's easy to 100%.

All in all not great, but at least it's different. If you're a horror/puzzle fan I would recommend it but only at a heavy discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168823046', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1335, 'last_played': 1661696393}
review:
This review has been a long time coming and quite a sad one to make given my closeness with the team at one point.

Now this is gunna be a long one so a short TLDR; Don't get this untill it is complete if at all, its full of abandoned ideas, bugs and the Devs don't seem to know what the end result is themselves

I am Mouse, otherwise known as Miz and at one point was a Mod for the team in their discord, I spoke with individual devs quite a bit and had a lot of faith of the team to really knock this out of the park

Along with an exodus of other mods I am now banned from the discord for daring to have worries about the development of the game and voicing them (in DM's might I add) and was threatened to have my DM transcript with the Project lead posted if i made this negative review, hence why I held off on making this review untill a couple months later.

So lets talk about the game shall we?

At its base this is a simple enough premise, base building, unit production, kill zombies.
The core is certainly there and there's an enjoyable enough loop to give you a few hours of fun, for the price it is its reasonable, if we got for $ = 1 hour of fun ratio.... I doubt most people will get that however, not in its current form, theres only 1 map for the "main" game mode and the additional "Hoard" really is just more of the same.
My own hours are largely breaking and bug reporting. 
As always milage may vary

So whats wrong?

Now the main problems with the game are still the same as when i picked it up way back when, critical game breaking bugs, path-finding AI that couldn't find its way out of an unlocked room and the general feeling that the game isnt quite sure of what it wants to be.
Every run I had of the game has been met with the same issues, units that dont follow orders, zombies that spawn from nowhere and the invincible (by design) antagonist just.... breaking, not moving and by extension the zombies becoming pushovers. These problems were so persistent I found myself just telling people in the discord, who just bought the game that it was "Just Early access jank" but that was over a year ago, at what point do longstanding bugs be so baked in that being EA no longer excuse the fact they have not been fixed in so long?

The game also suffers from a severe identity problem, what started as a squad based game has become an open world game, sorta, its not /really/ open world and moeso, just, big map. Now they say that they plan on adding side missions to complete and a campaign but, thats still not open world, it just has 1 kinda big map, thats all and the performance on it is, frankly, awful to its counterparts.

Now at one point I had faith the team would deliver on a lot of its promises, they listened to what was being asked and could be found in the community discussing suggestions, good and bad, on feasibility and problems. Critical bugs were often fixed within the day, I saw community suggested units being added and new enemy types, it felt like progress was good and the team and community were on the similar rails.
Of late however this has changed drastically.

Behind the scenes
A lot seems to be hidden, features picked up and left halfway, abandoned features half in the game and requests for us moderators to stop talking about features because they are not being worked on.
Yeah, no announcement, just please stop talking about it

So lets start at the beginning, features.
Now while there is a roadmap for this game, this has been changed multiple times as the team couldnt keep up, COOP that was supposed to be added last year, that was a Patreon pledge that people paid for (now removed) was pushed back and back each time with a new promised date untill eventually a TBA was given. 
The zerg-like zombie Creep that was trailed, broke a few things then silently dropped. 
The ability for zombies to swim, hinted at so many times with exact details still unclear, then talked about no more
Zombies to climb buildings to skirt the cheese of roof camping, Gifs shown to see this in motion then... silently dropped
Factions, told they were "being worked on" despite them running on an old version of the game for months and months, for the mods to be told "Yeah we aint working on these right now please stop talking about it" and.... silently dropped.
A vehicle damage system, allowing drivers and pilots to be killed and vehicles to be recrewed, halfway completed then nothing.
The Evac system, its in, with a lot of old placeholders, in a strange limbo state

Now while its easy to say its a small team on public funding, ie they can only work on it when people buy the game, something i said for a long time myself, I have to look at what the team /has/ been working on.

A 1st person mode that was met with either "eh" or "we don't want this" that was worked on anyway, then dropped in exchange for a 3rd person anyway, that still nobody had asked for nor was on the roadmap.
Multiple redesigns of CERC units, just basic vanity while game breaking bugs still existed, also note these are going to get done /again/ because of the fact many of the civilian models are just assets and only the assault is actually a finished mesh
Map re-design after map redesign with more and more added just lagging the game more, while they couldnt get stable framerates on what they did have
Spin off books and Skins, now the skins I* think are fine, they asked the community what they wanted and they needed the funding, nothing wrong with these well aware of the minimal work required, but there are now more books than game modes, nor can i imagine they are cheap to make, also telling people to read a book if they want the game's story is uhhh, wild.
More game revamps than I can count, it really has had so many faces and i cannot tell you what its going to look like at the end

Which really is the crux of the problem, what actually is Cepheus Protocol (dont shorten that) trying to be? I once asked Dark this and got effectely they want to be be freeform, the ability to tackle any problem any way, to not be "gimicky." I respect that, but right now it has nothing at all, in fact its only unique feature is the Music and fact theres not really any base building RTS zombie games out there. 

After many months of hearing little to nothing, watching features be silently dropped i reached out to a team member I'd had prior discussions with about the game, wondering if they had ever considered gettting a community manger. A harmless question considering I'd been asked it myself a few times, I'd even had a few people volunteer to do the job part time for the guys and, as I was well trusted it seemed, they asked through me.
We had a short talk about the current state of the game  where we both agreed too many systems were half or "70% implimented" which lead to it feeling "all over the place" and as I was on the other side of the planet, I went to sleep.

I woke up to find myself removed as a moderator the the Lead dev, Dark, telling me he wouldnt have people with no faith in the project as a moderator (Also bare in mind I had been vocally critical of the game for around a year, before i was a of, my honesty is exactly why I was listened to) which sets a dangerous precedent of "yes men" in the discord. Also demanding that any criticism be levelled solely at him, as if discussing the game with other team members was complete taboo unless it was positive praise. 
After a back and forth on why I'd spoke to someone else, primarily Dark's self confessed inability to read everything (Everyone pings dark after all) I was banned completely from the discord, this within the same week 2 other mods were too.

So yes, I do not reccoemnd a game with 2 year old bugs, abandonded features and a Lead Dev unable to have any discussion unless positive or risk banning.
I'm sure there will be a comment left on this post, but I'll be leaving them disabled as I cba to give anymore time to this game or devs
Mouse out
developer_response:
You literally neglected the fact that the Operator was voted in by the community 
https://strawpoll.com/mpnbajKVYy5

As you mentioned we are a small team(5 devs) and we are doing the best we can with the limited resources available to us.  You also fail to highlight the successes we've had and only relegate us to the failures we've had.  I would invite anyone reading this review to check out our roadmap and research our news post for how much the game has developed/improved. Game design is iterative and we acknowledge our failures and learn from them as noted by earmarking a lot of time to audit the project further in the upcoming CERC/Doctrines roadmap card and submitting that audit to our community to add anything we missed to further refine and push the core game. 

Roadmap URL:
https://cepheusprotocol.notion.site/Cepheus-Protocol-31f1b25ce00148d6844825f4a0c0bc08

As you stated when we discussed this in DM's you professed to me that you can basically say whatever you want by stating  "Because im autistic as S%%@." That you can basically talk to myself or other developers however you'd like. Being a Moderator means you are an ambassador for the Discord/Community in question which means you have some amount of professionalism in how you conduct yourself.

As for the topic of the Moderations that did leave they were caught abusing their power, bragging to normal members and tagging developers after multiple warnings to stop for non-emergences.  

Why would we want Moderators to keep mentioning features that we weren't even sure we could fully implement and were waiting for Epic to implement features to better support them in the future. I addressed this multiple times to you on Discord, on AmA's on Youtube and on public channels that the Infection Growth, Infected climbing and Swimming were being delayed because rolling them out to the larger map would require more engine support and more resources which was earmarked and stated publicly to be broken up and tackled over the AI cards on the roadmap.... 

I looked and you never submitted any bug reports/save files. We can only fix the issues that users report and work with us on should it be a complex issue. Anyone researching the project can search our forums/discord and collaborate this and how we actively help and talk to everyone that posts. 

How you choose to conduct yourself is everything, This entire conversation  would have been completely different had you asked for a call/DMed me directly instead of  petitioning my developers behind my back and then they approaching me on how they felt uncomfortable on how you were talking about the project to them.  On numerous times i have sat in calls and on the public Discord talking to fans for hours hearing the bad and good watching them play taking notes and figuring out what we can do and what we can't to earmark for the future!

 Kenshi took 10 years, Project Zomboid +5?. We are working every day  to bring this game home and perfectly simulate a viral/zombie outbreak. And do remember we are in our 3rd year and have accomplished a lot! Do we have things to work on absolutely and we will continue to work on the game and with our community till the game is a gem!

Rome wasn't built in a day. after all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002567771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 1400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1167, 'last_played': 1448063331}
review:
I've been told this is out of date, and to be fair, it has been two months. So I've replayed it to see how much it actually changed, and how much of what I mentioned has actually been adressed.
Therefore, the following is an edited version from the original review, for the original review, please go to http://pastebin.com/xJqfjmhX or ask me directly for a copy. The review shown here is from 18 November, almost an exact two months after the first.

Planetbase is a great, if simple concept for a game. Yet flawed in its execution and sadly nowhere near fullfilling its potential.

While it has come a bit since release, it is still full of frustrating moments and flaws, sadly this taints what is otherwise an interesting game that looks fairly good and runs great even on subpar hardware.
Out of the flaws that were fixed, the most game-breaking were the first to go, with the nutrition system being slightly more forgiving through boosting how much basic meals your colonists can eat, and the AI being a bit more open to actually trying to do something that will lead to the colonists' survival, it still has issues.
You are still encouraged to not diversify your food supply, and colonists are still very robot-like in their methods. They have a habit of just standing around at random in your base, but at the least they seem to be willing to survive.
Sadly, They have any idea of prioritisation (And there are only VERY basic options to give them a priority, with only one button to prioritise a new construction over other constructions since my original review at release). Prioritising your workshops does just about nothing, as far as resources are concerned. You may have prioritised the spares factory so you can repair that solar panel that keeps the lights on, but your colonists prefer to put your materials into the bar construction that you have not prioritised, but also dont want to completely stop since there has already been a fair amount of resources hauled out there. Prioritisation remains an issue, as well as the limit as to your controls over what actually has the limited prioritisation you have access to - If there's a semiconductor foundry in the same room as your spares production, that will get the same priority as your spares if you prioritise the spares.

The second big flaw is in the interface and controls. You are very limited in how you can control the game, there are near no prioritisation buttons, you can not pause the game except by going to the menu, and there do not appear to be any graphics settings of note(Only 'ultra' 'high' 'medium' 'low', anti-aliasing and a resolution? Seriously?). There are no reliable ways to control or guide colonists, nor any way to prioritise for example your doctor making a medkit to treat the injured over hauling some vegetables to the trader. Nor can you tell when someone has just started work or when they're going to stop working. In general, there just is no structure to the base. Your crew just does what they feel like with no regard for the consequences while you have no way to tell them what to do.

The base itself is empty, and yet there is not enough room. Every single dome needs a long corridor that goes only from it to one other part of your base. There is no way to split from a corridor, and corridors need to have a minimum length, thus making sure you have long travel times no matter how you build. This of course means very little work gets done when you expand, with less and less getting done the more you build. Colonists do not interact with eachother either, and a majority of your base will be empty space where nothing fits or can be placed.

The nutrition system is still much the same, and works by loading a specific combination(One of multiple) into the meal maker machine to create nutritious meals. You give them 3 kinds of meat and 6 different kinds of vegetables? Doesn't matter. The game makes every kind of food ingredient into a generic 'basic meal' unless your unthinking colonists just happen to load the right combination of ingredients into the food making machine to make a nutritious meal. I've personally witnessed one food maker filled up with beef and only beef, and right next to it one filled up with only maize. Those two could have made burgers, nutritious delicious burgers, but instead I could do nothing but watch as the game turned them into generic 'basic meals'. A sad thing to see, for sure. But luckily no longer something that breaks your base as they can now hold out long enough for random chance to put together items well enough for a nutritious meal.
The problem remains though, with six slots in the meal maker, and most plants you grow growing in twos or threes you will not be able to make the meals consisting of three different ingredients unless you get very lucky.

This game needs a fair amount of work before I would consider it viable, and as much as I was looking foreward to it and was hoping to just relax, sit back and build myself a base, I found myself unable to do anything except fast foreward as my base stagnated and nothing got done. It's a good idea, and a good base for a game. But with the interface, options menu, and the AI as it is, I would not be able to recommend it.
developer_response:
[h1]Out of date review[/h1]

We would like to point out that this review is outdated, and the issues it mentions have been fixed in subsequent updates.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166869487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 426848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 42, 'playtime_at_review': 66717, 'last_played': 1712018745}
review:
I quit playing Naval Action in 2019, after enjoying the game for about 3 years, when trading was no longer profitable and building your own ship became prohibitive, IE; extremely expensive and time consuming. I recently attempted to rekindle my interest in the game (Aug 2020) to no avail. The game has become even more difficult to play.
The clan I was a member of doesn't even exist.
I appreciate the historical and technical accuracy the developers program into the game, but I play to relax, to enjoy myself for the brief period of time before having to kit up and breach doors.
Maybe I'll be back, probably not.
developer_response:
[b]1st problem:[/b] [u]A player enjoyed the game in the past but stopped to play when the game economy was changed. After an attempt to play again the game looks even more difficult.[/u]

Greetings Captain! Thank you for your feedback. The trading was completely overhauled from what it was in 2017 and now you have a lot more routes to trade - you can choose from short  but less profitable routes to long voyages with a large profit.

[b]2nd problem:[/b] [u]The player’s clan does not exist anymore.[/u]

There are a lot of active clans that constantly recruit players who will be happy to take you hunting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106001646', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1532623980}
review:
Fun to play, some cool character concepts (Ashani is my favorite). Costume designs/animations are a bit meh, but that can be fixed. Netcode/matchmatching is pretty solid too so I give credit on that.

F*cking absolute trash F2P model. Unlocking characters in a F2P? Sure. Unlocking 4 of 7 characters with no consistent means to earn in-game currency other than RNG loot drops that give you 5 pts each when each character costs 1000 pts? Yeah, no
developer_response:
Thank you for the review! We've been reading through every single piece of feedback and we're humbled by the outpouring of responses. We're happy that you like Ashani! She's super fast and exciting.

With regards to other cosmetics, it's just the beginning! We've got a ton more stuff in the pipeline :). What would you like to see for Ashani?

I'm also excited to share the recent steps we've made to address the F2P model.
 
- We now credit ALL players 1100 spectra when they join, so you can buy any character you want right off the bat. We also gave this to all existing players, so if you haven't spent yours yet, it's ready for you now.

- You can now try out ANY character in training mode. This was a key request from players who wanted to try out characters before picking one up.

In addition to the above, we're working on several new features to make the game fun and engaging right from the get go. This includes granting a character much earlier and giving more ways to earn spectra. We expect those to start coming online soon.

This is just the start. We entered Early Access so that we can work directly with you to make Icons ready for the world. You can read about the roadmap here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/684200/discussions/0/3160848559782811668/

Thanks again for the feedback. Please feel free to send any more ideas and thoughts our way. We're excited for what's in store.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982411398', 'num_games_owned': 920, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1690967985}
review:
Have played the game back and forth during early access and loved how it always got improved in one or another way, still had it's issues but you could see how much work and love they did put in to this game since every update always had a fix for something. Either optimization or lots of bug fixes. I joined the testing for the final update and knew this game was gonna work smooth once it got full released.

Here i am again back and playing the full release and can't say anything else than that i am in love with the game, you can see they have taken inspiration a little bit from the s.t.a.l.k.e.r games. That means the game is not only a good substitute to play while waiting for s.t.a.l.k.e.r 2 to come out, the game are also  just super enjoyable to spend time in since the whole base manage part and also have to manage so the characters you take in to your base wanna stay there. You don't need to play the stalker games to enjoy this, chernobylite will drag you in to a very interesting story while exploring for stuff.

What i do like with the game also is that it doesent hold your hands when you try find more clues about your wife, you have to explore to find information about her.

Atmosphere is amazing and you will most of the time have this creepy feeling while scavanging through buildings for resources.

I will not do a 1-10 thingy, i talk from own experience when i have played it and i know a review will not really tell people much more than what i think about the game, in the end if you are interested in the game. Buy it and give it a try, in my own opinion the game is worth every penny.

So do i recommend the game? Yes ofcourse i do, as long you like games like this, just don't expect it to be holding your hands to much

author: {'steamid': '76561198963807919', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 48043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 47949, 'last_played': 1711322882}
review:
While the game does have bugs, but what game dosent? and Cosmetic DLC (not gamepires fault. blame Jagx for that) i would absoley recommend this. blows DAYZ out of the water. i have bought every dlc to support gamepires to continue to make this great game

I started with DAYZ and i will never go back because of how good scum is. the devs seem to be really trying and caring what they are making here. the sounds. graphics and gameplay are so much better than dayz. the medical is in depth. and theres a variety of biomes. 

with the 1.0 full release coming out soon, i look forward to this even more. quests and NPC characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049326756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 7235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6165, 'last_played': 1615838214}
review:
It's a truly great game. Shame its DLC policy appears to be out of 2005, with functional blocks, some seemingly ripped straight from the workshop, hidden behind an admittedly low paywall. I'd love to update this review with a recommended if this changes.

Update: They've continued to release functional blocks behind paywalls, including the most powerful small grid cockpit.
developer_response:
Hi Ray Geetard,

Thank you for writing this review.

We really appreciate your feedback.

We are continuing to release free features for Space Engineers via updates, (Customizable LCD Screens, Replay Tool, Steam Badges. Steam Backgrounds, etc.) and optional paid DLC (the Decorative Pack), which is designed to not split our community. For more information please see Marek Rosa's blog: https://blog.marekrosa.org/2019/04/space-engineers-customizable-lcd.html

We are also continuing to optimize Space Engineers and fix numerous bugs in the game.

If you are experiencing any issues, please message us via our support site: https://support.keenswh.com/spaceengineers/general and we'll be happy to assist you.

Kind regards,

Keen Software House

author: {'steamid': '76561198240053774', 'num_games_owned': 32, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 11573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 696, 'last_played': 1679615439}
review:
I love all the Artix Entertainment games that has ever come out to date. I was waiting for the longest time for this game to come out because, it is a game changer for them. This is their first 3D game that they have made, and I love it. All of their previous games such AQworlds, and epicduel were are all in 2D. This is a great change and it also gives MMO players a variety. 

I would receommend anyone who wants to try this game out. People have different ups and down reviews about the game. But If you have played any of their passed games you will not be disapointed. They bring back many nostalgic memories, and now they are in 3D. You have to give them time to upgrade this game since they are only in 1.1. You have to give them credit because this is free 3D game too! 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198089494522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1303, 'last_played': 1678343247}
review:
I really enjoy strategic sims, things like this, Humankind, Littlewood, Kynseed, you know, casual/relaxed city building or resource management kinds of games. I picked this up while it was on sale and really look forward to how it grows until it fully releases. I haven't even tried mods yet because I'm admittedly lazy and not computer smart, but have been really enjoying getting used to managing supplies, though it can feel a little confusing at times. I think I hit the max for a few supplies as I could no longer assign workers for some productions, but I think it's a mix of still being in progress and my lack of gaming skills LOL.

TL;DR it's a really nice game so far, I'm eager to try modding and more playthroughs, and it's definitely satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198287475338', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1541870396}
review: Whoever wrote the jokes in this game is a b'soding genius! I have never played a funnier pnc adventure game than this before and I had played many, and watched at least a ton on youtube. This game, while not very high in pixel count, is the most entertaining 2d point and click adventure game I had played so far. Maybe because I can understand all the programming jokes. Those who cannot understand the jokes will enjoy the story.
developer_response:
Ha! Crispin is something of a divisive figure (some site called him a "tonal wrecking ball"), so I'm glad you enjoyed him and the jokes in general. Maybe you and I are just on the same nerd humor wavelength. :)

Thanks for leaving the kind review and for playing the game -- we're lucky to have such generous fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028911545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1435049134}
review:
Silly humour and neat story, really enjoyed it.

I'm not sure on their decision to making a game in this day and age for a 320x200 CRT screen though, and have to upscale it on you screen. Is it just trying to capture the look of old games for old times sake?
I assume the art would have been drawn at higher resolution to start with, why not keep it like that instead of downgrading it into pixels? The only reason games use to look like that was because that's all they were capable of.
Would have been nice to have the option to choose the original art of the downsampled pixel art.
Or is it some twisted joke +_+ since the game talks about the future and technology?

author: {'steamid': '76561198013925644', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1632644195}
review:
It's really sad that this game is now out of early access with how unpolished it is and unfinished. I am changing my review to not recommended. The early access tag gave me a lot of hope, but now i feel the company will just abandon this game and go onto the next. I love the RTS genre and i thought this was going to be the game to help bring it back, but there is just so much wrong with it i had fun playing with friends, but it ends up being frustrating and buggy.



OLD REVIEW(before early access ended):

Great idea. Really is. I really want this game to be good, but it needs too many things to be fixed as of this moment. Not just bugs, but fundamental game aspects. I played the demo last year and since then it has improved tremendously, but there are still really wonky aspects of the game. Such as the sound is quiet and loud at the same time at random. There is no good way to tell what is getting attacked especially if you are on the opposite of the surface/cave. 

It would be cool if the survival gamemode had goals? Like the starcraft mode Left 2 Die. It isn't much, but it's something to keep you going. Rather than senseless onslaught of buggy path finding enemies. 

Overall the game has promise and i love seeing an indie RTS with genre pushing mechanics. I have mixed feelings on the game as of now, but hopefully it improves drastically in time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027154101', 'num_games_owned': 1141, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1696039258}
review: A game that sat in my library for far longer than it ever deserved. After putting 6.9 hours into it in three days I've fallen head over heels in love with the bittersweet world of Primordia. From the bleak, deteriorating world full of wonder, to the sorrowful synthetic music, this game will pull at your heart and mind beckoning you to think.
developer_response: Glad you pulled it out of the slush pile and had such a good experience! It’s always gratifying to read such a fine review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969727318', 'num_games_owned': 2235, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2276, 'last_played': 1513365009}
review:
Disclaimer:  Steam does not have a neutral review rating.  Just recommended or not recommended.

I have completely rewritten the review so if some of the people in the comments section don't make sense this may be why.

Since I had a negative experience with the devs, I will leave the review as not recommended.  I will cover this below.

Wild Terra as it stands right now is an early access title.  It has been getting regular updates, usually small ones sprinkled with larger ones here and there.  The title has come a long way in the last 6 or so months before it hit Steam just in terms of character movement which has helped immensely.

I have only played on a PvE server so cannot vouch for the play on a PvP server.  The game is slow paced which I like.  I can sit back and relax while playing.  Game play consists of running around the map collecting resources for building up your dominion (what the game calls your base of operations).  Once you have your dominion built then you can work on expanding it and/or collecting resources to make into useful items needed for the extensive amount of recipes found in the game.  

While wandering the map you can find godsends, which come in the for of decomposed adventurers or crashed wagons.  Inside the godsends you can find items as well as recipe fragments.  The recipes you cannot make from the beginning of the game can be found in these godsends.  Each recipe requires a certain amount of fragments to be found before you can create that item.  From what I can tell it can take from 1 to I believe 4 or 5 fragments to unlock specific recipes.  It seems that once you do unlock a recipe that some recipes have a gold recipe that can be unlocked.  The crafting is deep in the game.

The Map:  This is the biggest issue I have with the game.  Everything is player driven (which isn't a bad thing).  There are no NPC cities or towns.  Everything on the map is one flat surface with trees, water, wild life, and resource nodes.  There is absolutely nothing that stands out that you could reference as to where you are in the world.  Once you have a dominion, you get a marker on the edge of the screen that you can use to get back, but that's it.

Player base:  This is where the game shines for the most part.  Most people in the global chat are very helpful and willing to help people out with questions and issues they have.  Some people leave a chest or storage outside for others to come along and rummage through for anything they may need.  During the Christmas event (before the devs lowered the cost) the stockings were hard to make because they needed a loom which unlocks from recipe fragments (found in godsends) and most weren't able to  make them.  One good person on the server would make the items you needed if you brought them the resources.

The devs:  I was wrongly banned from the Steam forums and it took a week before they realized I was wrongly banned and unbanned me.  The devs seem to just willingly ban anyone from their forums that speak bad about the game or the cash shop or in my case ban the wrong guy.  Instead of making a sticky at the top of the forums that lists exactly what is in the cash shop and opening it to discussion.  I feel everyone that is on the fence about the game has a right to know as much information on the game before they make a purchase.  So that brings up the next part.....

Cash Shop:  Once in the game, you can bring up the cash shop.  Inside you will find titles you can bestow on your character along the lines of Duke and Knight and a handful of others.  If you want a mount, you can pick from horses, deer, wolves, and bears.  If you want to dip into their premium  offering you can get a bonus for your character for a period of time based on how much you wish to spend.  I tried to see what the time length was for this review but the cash shop wouldn't come up for me at time of writing this review.  The premium is described (I wrote this down earlier when I was replying to someone) as:  Doubles chances to get rare items, gathering, building, and crafting speed.  As a PvE player this doesn't bother me in the least.  I don't care what the other guy is getting or what he is doing.  In a PvP setting I can see this as being an issue as the other guy is now pulling out double resources on some of the harder to find resource nodes in the world.  If the rare drop is (no clue what the actual drop rate is) 10% then the premium player is getting 20%.  

Due to how the premium is worded this is how I see it as working.  It could be double to getting rare items and an increase to gathering, building and crafting.  Even though an increase in rares can still be an advantage depending on the drop rate imposed in the game.

Is the game bad?  No and I feel I more than received my monies worth during my past and most likely future game play.  As an early access title the content is limited despite the large amount of items you can craft.  This is an issue that plagues many early access titles and is the bane of the whole ea system in general except for a few exclusions.

I do recommend Wild as the game itself, but you must realize what the game is and what it isn't.  It is not an action packed game full of dazzling sword play and fireballs whizzing inches from your face.  In fact there is no magic to speak of.

I do not recommend Wild Terra based on the actions of the developers.  They seem like they care about the game and are definitely actively working on it, but deleting posts in the Steam forums and banning is definitely not the way to go and sends off bad vibes to current customers and prospective customers.  They need to take the good with the bad, embrace it and use that feedback to allow the game to flourish. 

Verdict: Neutral.  If what you have read appeals to you and you can get past the developers then you can find a nice little time sink here.  If you're like me and try to answer questions for other people in the forums and just be an all around nice guy, then beware that you should probably not talk about the cash shop in any form at least until the devs smarten up and just embrace the contents they provide in the shop and not try to hide them.
developer_response: Hello. Accept my apologies, you were accidentally blocked. You have been unban on forums. Once again, sorry for the incident

author: {'steamid': '76561197961635953', 'num_games_owned': 1093, 'num_reviews': 230, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1525926077}
review:
I played it just long enough to leave a negative review. An ironically bad game is still bad. In Mad Sector's case, this game is ironic dog shit.

Here is a list of things I'd rather do than play this game:

[list]
    [*]Give a sponge bath to inmates in a maximum security prison.
    [*]Douse myself in honey and roll through an ants nest.
    [*]Be a background extra in a snuff film.
    [*]Drink bleach.
    [*]Watch someone else drink bleach.
    [*]Watch Madonna's filmography.
    [*]Bob for apples in a Piranha infested toilet bowl.
    [*]Get a Brazilian wax from an overweight, hairy man.
    [*]Give a Brazilian wax to an overweight, hairy man.
    [*]Stuff pocket change up my ass.
    [*]Snort Heroin.
[/list]

I hope the half dozen people who read this review get some kind of entertainment from it, because you won't find any with Mad Sector.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050537731', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1590112556}
review:
Installed, played 2 games, and uninstalled. It might be for you but definitely not me.

Lot of player lag, lot of movement lag, everything bumps or pushes you, player collision is honestly the worst in every way (the lag doesn't help), movement doesn't feel very nice (feels like everything is ice, jump height is too short and doesn't seem to follow the same 'hold to jump higher' platformer mechanic), The "Glitch Visual Effect" just seems to be a disadvantage than anything else, player skins give a clear advantage to some skins, visually hurts my eyes. . .

Honestly I could go on forever about what I didn't like so I'll say what I did like; It seems like a cool idea.

Yea that's about it. Having played the original Mario games front and back (what this game is trying to be) and they DO NOT feel like this. Unless they make massive changes to movement and overall visual design, I'm not picking it back up or spending any money on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073325163', 'num_games_owned': 591, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 22012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3327, 'last_played': 1699526093}
review:
I did a quick video review on this game: https://youtu.be/qDsYyhBfjUw
Text version of the video review below

After playing this game for quite some time I can fully recommend it. In a nutshell ACS is one of the deepest and richest Sandbox RPG games I've encountered so far. It has a knack towards base building but it's completely different to titles like Rimworld. It shares a similar base design, but ACS leans way heavier towards character development, world exploration and fantasy story telling.

Pros about this game are it's insane depth, a very cuddly and wholesome graphics style which also has a pretty high quality standard. On top of that it's moddable and therefore there's no ceiling to the content of the game. Everything makes sense, is very well fleshed out and offers hours and hours of interesting content if you are into Eastern Fantasy.

The Cons are: Steep learning curve as hell, a pretty clunky UI which is at times mildly infuriating and a translation which leads to misunderstandings and confusions at times. The third part is something I am pretty sure will be gone in a few months/years. Don't get me wrong, the translation is solid, but it's noticeable that there still needs work to be done.
The Learning curve is what I consider the heaviest Downside of the game. You really gotta dig deep into the game to actually enjoy it. But that's also a Pro - if you dislike shallow or too easy games in general

My summary: Absolute recommendation! 
Albeit it's quirks the game is one of the deepest and richest experiences I've had in 2020 and I don't think the devs will stop here. The game is moddable (translation work from Chinese takes some time though) so we are sure gonna see a lot more stuff in the coming years. 
If you have doubts - check out a few gameplay videos and decide for yourself if the gamestyle scratches your itch, cause the game sure is quite eccentric. But if you get past it's hard shell, it's an adorable simulator which gives you so much freedom of design and choices - it's awesome!

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198006518853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1601098131}
review:
Unfortunately, while the game is gorgeous, as many other reviews have stated Port Royale 4 drastically dumbs down gameplay mechanics to the point of borderline boredom. They've taken a complex trading sim series and made it a dull city builder series, where even the city building aspect is about as deep as a puddle.

The gameplay that is there is relatively well polished for the most part, but all of it leaves me wanting more.

I want more city building, bigger plots, more buildings, something more.

I want more complex trading. Automation can cut down on tedium, but the implementation leaves a lot to be desired. Setting it up still has a great deal of tedium, then you click go and never both to manage it again. 

Combat is turned based on a grid... and frankly, terribly boring. I really don't know what they were thinking. 

There are missions and treasure maps, and again, they're shallow without much depth in either system.

Fame and Fame Points and simple and allow you to unlock items on a Fame tree that are locked because... why? I'm not sure why I have to be famous to make a rope factory. Can anyone explain what fame has to do with rope factories? I get it when it comes to some of the larger vessels, but many of the buildings are just artificial gates to slow down your progress.

I haven't played a ton of the game, no, but until they manage to flesh out the game more I don't think I'll be playing it again. It's not a horrible game, but this is one I wish I had waited on the reviews before I purchased.  If you haven't played a Port Royale game, there may be something here for you. If you're a fan of the Port Royale series, you'll be disappointed.
developer_response:
Thank you for your detailed feedback.

Regarding the difficulty: Have you tried using higher difficulty settings in free play?
Especially with regional resources changed from „even distribution“ to „Regional distribution“ and trade routes from „with automation“ to „without automation“ make the game far more challenging and fun for experienced players. By default, the game settings are suited for beginners.

Please rest assured that the other topics you’ve raised will be discussed and taken into consideration for further improvements to the game.

Just like in previous games like "Railway Empire", we plan to work with the community for improvements and long-term support.

Please feel free to head on over to the official Port Royale 4 Community Hub to share your feedback and ideas.
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1024650/discussions/

Thank you in advance.
We hope that with your feedback we can improve the game further and that you will enjoy Port Royale 4 more.

-cheers

author: {'steamid': '76561197994540079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1608111468}
review:
I bought this because it claimed to be WMR compatible.   It is not.   A large number of us, based on the forum cannot launch the game.   It crashes immediately after the UE4 logo at start OR launches, but without any menu to start the game.     Unfortunately,  I can't get a refund because I waited too long for a response on the support forum and it was no longer eligible for a refund.  I am still waiting for a response weeks later, as are others.

Apparently it works well with occulus.  But simply does not work on WMR,  and by the developers post responses to others in the past, it sounds like they didn't have a WMR headset to test it,  so they should never, ever have indicated it was WMR compatible.

So if you have an occulus, it might be worth trying.   If not,  you are out of luck, and the developer doesn't appear keen on fixing the problems for WMR users.

So I have to give it a big old thumbs down.   I was scammed.   Would never have bought it if they were honest about WMR support.

This is sad.    I was very much looking forward to playing this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013115338', 'num_games_owned': 7447, 'num_reviews': 236, 'playtime_forever': 1433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1433, 'last_played': 1428962050}
review:
A fun point & click adventure developed by Wormwood Studios. This is their only commercial release to date but they did do two games for Indie Speed Run 2013 called Like a Raisin in the Sun and Salt. It takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where all the humans are gone and you play a robot named Horatio Nullbuilt.  You have a broken down ship that you live in and another robot breaks in shoots you and steals your power core. Now you are on a mission to get it back.

Gameplay:
	It plays just like a typical point & click adventure game. Finding objects to use and figure out puzzles to progress further in the game. Puzzles were a little challenging for me but were fun to figure out. They require some logic and can have multiple ways to figure them out. Choices you make in the game can change things later in the game. If you’ve played other adventure games then you’ll have no trouble playing this.

Story:
	It kept me interested and curious to dig deeper. It all starts out over a power core but there’s a deeper secret you can uncover if you make the right choices in the game. Great supporting cast which brought some comedy to the game. I really enjoyed the banter from Crispin your little sidekick throughout the game. There’s also seven different endings to the story if you care to see them all.

Visuals & Sound:
	It has retro style graphics with some great looking hand drawn rooms. They did a great job of showing you a dark and grim world. An easy to use interface, and great voice acting. You can also change it to text only if you are one who just wants to read it all.

Overall:
	Primordia was a fun and enjoyable game. The story was a little slow in the beginning but picks up a little ways in. I laughed at times and even felt a little sad at times. It’s well worth playing if you enjoy point & click adventure games or a good story and it won’t take you to long to beat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972270989', 'num_games_owned': 1144, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2748, 'last_played': 1705522239}
review: There is no better simulation of modern warfare on the market today. I'm not gonna lie - it requires an investment in time to understand the nuances. Once you do, what you will get out of this game is an intimate understanding of platform capability and a shitload of fun as you figure out how to counter threats, manage your forces and plan ahead. As you acquire mastery, there is a deep sense of satisfaction. The community has built a vast array of scenarios and there is a powerful mission editor if you want to make your own. The replayability is more or less endless. There is a database of thousands of platforms and this is updated regularly - if you ever wanted a toybox of platforms nirvana is at hand. The price tag is steep, but given the market is a relatively small niche of gamers, this is understandable. In my mind, it is worth every penny, and I feel I have only scratched the surface of basic competence after 45 hours - so thousands of hours are possible.  New features are added over time through patches. There is a professional version of the tool which armed forces use to train on! If you have any interest in modern warfare whatsoever you must have this. There are a few games I am grateful that exist - this is one of them.
