review:
Was an ok idle game.. they broke the crap out of the game today though... basically made game 100% pure idle.. no point in playing this game at all.. literally.. they changed how beer production works in the game.. so it went from getting thousands of beers while playing online to getting like 200 beers total for the day because your stuck doing offline crap gains.. great update to your game.. make it so no one wants to play actively online.
If you like mid evil graphics in rpg setting.. but actually do nothing and let it idle for months before you can do anything.. then sure try out this now broken game.
developer_response: RGoku i think you miss-understood the new system. Players get the same 3000 beers every day they used to take. Nothing changed on that. The difference is that the beers are now being brought to the game by the dragon instead of dropping by the enemies. The dragon brings more beers each time but with higher time intervals. The total output is still 3000 beers though.

developer_response:
Hello Anthelm,
the highest tier weapons you have mentioned are usually needed in high level Clan Wars competitions, one can play and enjoy the game with any combination of the lower tier weapons, it all depends on the build and fighting style, even entry level machine guns are quite effective in numbers. Also crafting your own parts and trading on the ingame market lets people obtain higher tier weapons without purchasing any packs, there is no need to spend money - Crossout is free to play and every part is available on the market in exchange for your resources and crafted parts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198275892818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1047, 'last_played': 1612412363}
review:
If this game was less grindy and every part above tier 1 wasn't locked behind a pay wall i would give this game a glowing review, The core mechanics  of this game are excellent, The customization and vehicular combat is awesome. 
i'd be more than happy to pay full price for this game but the way the market is set up and the microtransactions scream greedy business practices and i wont support that with my wallet. The fact that theres almost $1000 of DLC in this game plus a pay for every part plus a subscription tells me the developers are more interested in bleeding you dry than having a priority for your experience, Its a damn shame. 
Reminds me so much of mobile games that are based on creating money through addiction, theres even an energy system so you can only do certain things so much for resources.
developer_response:
Hello!
All parts that affect to the battle can be obtain in-game ways: as the rewards for leveling up or you can buy them on the in-game market. So you don't need to spend any real money to get a weapon, a cabin and so on.
Donate is just one of the ways to speed up the leveling up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036092004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1563765897}
developer_response:
Hi ZrEuRsGh,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2015. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since release:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. One of these are completely free for you!
- New Game Modes
- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate
- Entirely new Skirmish AI

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

review: this game is a high speed racing game right, but fps capped to 60 only, and cant get more, i tried everything, launch option also do nothing, why would developer cap the fps to 60 on a high speed racing game ? doesnt make any sense, once racing at crowded place, fps drop = collision :)
developer_response: Hello there, Shiga! Thank you for coming forward with this review and experience. I am sorry to see that you've been having an issue with your game's FPS dropping during gameplay, but I would be more than happy to better assist you. To get this resolved, let's try a few troubleshooting steps to locate the issue. For an issue like this, it could be that you need to update your drivers. Please go ahead and complete [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-us/faqs/000025947]these PC troubleshooting steps[/url] to do so. You may also be running into an issue with not having enough available RAM to maintain the game, which [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-GB/Faqs/000025721/Disabling-Background-Application/]disabling background applications[/url] can help with! If you continue to have issues, however, please feel free to [url=support.ubi.com/Cases/New]create a support ticket[/url] for additional support and we'll see you through it! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198047510458', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1705964951}
review:
I love the estetic of this game, but I believe there are some quality of life issues that completely ruin the game for me:
- Camera rotation doesn't rotate around the 3d position of our move
- The water system isn't intuitive, how do you use the water wheel?!
- The game feels awfully slow some times since you can only speed the game up to 2x speed.
- You can't attack camps that aren't your own with your godly powers, I don't want to ruin my own camp!
- I've only played early game, but it feels like your nuggets only fall in love and create baby nuggets if you "force" them with your godly powers. So it's micro managing to make sure each nugget is in a relationship.

These things just take the fun out of it for me, but that's just my opinion. I feel very restricted in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199162721696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 11079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10883, 'last_played': 1709420143}
review: This game has alot of things going for it, but the things that kills it for me is the confusion of the upper lvl quests that turn into numerous fetch quests that seems to be the running theme for this game. I can understand a certain lvl of content that must go into things but to get an item you desperately need for a pet quest or any quest on nulgath is insane. Just to get a diamond of nulgath..you have to do a fetch quest that turns into another fetch quest and AGIAN into multiple fetchs quests that ends with a monster that you have to beat that shows up rarely on a map..or even an item drop that is below 2% probalilty of EVEN dropping. A game is in my opinion suppose to be a fun getaway from the stresses of a person's real life...not turn it into a 10+ hour stressful grind fest with little directions on what to do and where to go for a item that barely even drops to begin with. That is what is killing the game for me. Maybe if the devs fix this..then i will return back to AQ3D..its got alot of potential..but wasted on such idiotic mechanics that shouldnt even be in this game.
developer_response: Thank you for your feedback, we appreciate it. The devs are working on improving the grind and updating quests in the future. Please keep checking the News and Game Plan via AQ3D.com for updates.

Our devs work hard to release weekly updates and fix bugs. We would love some clarification on what you meant about Mining Skills. 

If this is something you would like our team to add soon, we would be happy to hear your feedback. Our team enjoys working closely with players so we can make AQ3D fun for everyone! 

We have big goals for AQ3D and we would love for you to learn more about them via the News and Game Plan at AQ3D dot com.

review:
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38287655-Prof.Vaharrak/]Prof.Vaharrak's Curator Group - Almost 30 years of gaming experience at your service[/url]

It's an ok clicker defense.

You click on hands that approach a kid in bed for a time on each level.
You can collect spiders to buy upgrades and orbs to unleash special attacks against the approaching horrors.
Other obstacles show up later on.

It has other modes that add difficulty for a challenge and replayability.
Get it on a discount or a bundle and it's worth a couple quid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060745565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1671729249}
review:
I understand that the game is still in early access, however i have a big issue.

developer_response:
Hi CrazyGuardsman,

Thank you for taking the time to leave a review.

That is one beefy system and shouldn't be having any fps issues running the game. We haven't heard of any other players reporting similar issues so we would love to get some more information.

So that we an help you further please can you send a [url=https://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/help/4028644/windows-open-and-run-dxdiagexe]dxdiag[/url] report to support@polymorph.games.
Please could you also send in your foundation.log file which can be found here: \Documents\Polymorph Games\Foundation

These files will give us some basic information regarding your system as well as show any potential issues for your system. If you have refunded the game it would still be useful if you could send us these files so that we could investigate further.

Cheers
Ash

author: {'steamid': '76561198013513023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1703622824}
review:
What a mess..........

First of all Steam support was no help.
I ended up using Microsoft edge as a default web browser. DON'T USE MICROSOFT EDGE!!! It was a major part of my problems. It ends up blocking task bars and other things on the Frontier sites. 
I ended up using the Brave web browser, that worked WAY BETTER!!

Using Edge I could not setup an account. It would not accept my email or password. I even created several emails to see if I was doing something wrong. Nope, it was Microsoft Edge some how blocking things. I could not properly enter account information to be accepted/validated for Frontier because of this.

DON'T USE MICROSOFT EDGE WEB BROWSER!!!!

Once I used Brave and it worked way better! 
I was able to create a desktop shortcut for the game from inside Steam. Then launched the game with the desktop short cut. In the Elite dangerous window I clicked login, which brings you to the Frontier website. 
I clicked on "My Account" tab and selected dashboard. Which opens up a list on the left. Which you then need to select "Partner keys". This opens a window that allows you to click on a green area marked " Login using Steam". 
You then need to enter your Steam account name (not your player name!) and your Steam login password. 
You should receive an email with a validation code. You enter that code and enter Frontier's website. 
From this point you should be golden, and just a couple minutes from playing.

Honestly I spent over 25+ hours trying to get this to work. Only a family member who is more familiar with web browsers clued into what was wrong. I would never had known MICROSOFT EDGE was such a piece of garbage. I asked Steam for a refund before I found the solution and was denied since the game was running in the background (the login window I guess is considered "the game") and totalled just over 6 hours play time. Even though I never played a minute in game....

Needless to say Customer support/Steam is not in my good books

Good luck everyone.
See you (I hope) in the space ways
developer_response:
We had some issues with our integration with Steam over the weekend that unfortunately caused a few account creation problems. If you've not been able to resolve this, please do just raise a support ticket with us:
https://support.frontier.co.uk/topic.php
-Luna

author: {'steamid': '76561198835964710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 9256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4658, 'last_played': 1637689419}
review: some times it runs fine with no probs other times it runs fine with a lag spike here and there and most the time it runs fine and then crashes with no warning on any graphic setting
developer_response: Thanks for sharing your review of The Crew 2! I surely hope that I can help you with getting the game to launch properly. Since it's unclear of whether the game is crashing at launch or while in game, I'll try and give two scenarios! If you're finding that the game crashes at start up, please go ahead and make sure you have the game and the Uplay PC launcher installed to the same internal hard drive ( C: Drive being the best option)! If you're all good on that front, go ahead and complete [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-us/faqs/000025947]these PC troubleshooting steps[/url] and [url=https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=2037-QEUH-3335]verify your game files[/url] before trying to launch again. If you're finding that this happens in game, it could be that you needed to update your drivers ( which the PC troubleshooting link can help with ) or you may be having an issue with not having enough available RAM to maintain the game ( which [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-GB/Faqs/000025721/Disabling-Background-Application/]disabling background applications[/url] can help with that! If you continue to have issues, however, please feel free to [url=support.ubi.com/Cases/New]create a support ticket[/url] for additional support and we'll see you through it! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198072186199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1683456497}
review:
Good game with a lot potential. So far its very relaxing and cute. I mean bakery, baking and fresh bread, what is there not to like :D It gives good vibes. 

Pros:
- Easy to play and with decent pace.
- All the goods look great and make u want to actually leave your house and go to a real bakery.
- There is a lot of time to bake so no stress if u mess it up.
- Decent number of recipies and its fun that there are different steps to make it work. 
- Enough of different machines to make it enjoyable.
- Baking is somehow very satisfying in this game.
- On the second upgrade of the bakery, we get to use eggs and the recipe just says 240g for example so you dont know how many eggs it is exactly and need to count how many of the big (60g) or the small ones (45g) to use. It was a bit annoying but it didnt matter because with level 3 of bakery there is a machine that measures it for you. After struggling with that annoying step it was very satysfying to work for this upgrade. I liked that. Its smilar with other upgrades, They make a difference. 
- When the city was still open and it was possible to drive around it was quite eerie. It wasnt too dark but it wasnt a day either. Everything was foggy at the edge of the city and at that time of the day when its getting light outside but not quite there yet. No people around and only few cars. Loved that atmosphere. Now you get get glipses of it while looking through the window of the bakery and at some point you can look up, the ceiling is glassed (think it was lvl 2 of the bakery) and u see the night sky. Very cozy :) 

Cons: 
- Its still a bit buggy at time. After the fix where you didnt need to deliver the goods it was better. Had only one bigger problem and it was when i left the packed and ready crate, clicked on the door to deliver it but it said that there was nothing there, i relogged and it all vanished. Had to start a new day. 
- Its a bit easy :) Maybe too easy. The progress is too fast. Id like to work for it more. Maybe its possible for the devs to make a hard mode where we dont level up so fast and need to earn more money to upgrade? No 5000 gold or dollars at the start either. That would be great :) 

Additional info:
- After 5h of playing im already on lvl 20. Im not sure how many more levels and upgrades there are but im guessing maybe 5-10 more. I think i saw a vid on yt where a guy finished it at lvl 30. I wish there was more. In games like this its not only the baking that is satisfying but also reaching new goals. 
- I wish there was possibility to sell my own goods directly at the bakery. To have an additional room where ppl could come in and i could sell what i baked early in the morning. I wish there was rush to prepare as much as possible to sell more and maybe be able to upgrade for more space. I mean there is a lot of potential for future expansions.

For now i will definitely recommend it. Just be prepared that its a small game where you will most likely achieve almost everything pretty fast. Its still fun though.
developer_response: Hello. Thank you for playing Bakery Simulator. That's a nice review. We are happy that you've liked it. We try to listen to players' feedback and improve what we can. Just keep in mind this is rather a small indie game. Bigger changes/new content is more like DLC or a sequel. Cheers. Gaming Factory team.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965550884', 'num_games_owned': 436, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1532012191}
review:
[strike]This game uses an installer that is almost on the verge of malware. It does not come with an uninstaller so you will need to do some Reg Edits and folder deletion to get it to go away. Also without asking it torrents the game updates to others via your bandwidth. Gijin.net is not cool.[/strike]

Thanks for the respose on this. At the time I had this installed (A few versions ago) Gijin.net would not uninstall with your installer and had to be manually removed and the reason for this review. I am glad you have made steps to have it uninstall when the game gets uninstalled. Also at that time nothing in the install asked anything about auto-updates which is a good idea at time of install. Thanks for the update!

UPDATE: This review is based on a very different version of the game that exists today. Take from it what you will.
developer_response: Due to our player's feedback, we have made Gaijin.Net agent entirely optional during a Steam installation (now you can decide whether you want to use it, or not). Please note: Gaijin net agent is completely harmless and useful software, and not using it can lead to delays in updates, if Steam updates are switched off/or not effecient. We still recommend using our solution, it is essential to keep your game up-to-date to be able to play!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027446195', 'num_games_owned': 1779, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 5672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1703972638}
review:
Most fun prototyping, stunt driving, rock climbing, and crash test dummy simulator I've played in a long time; with a car editor, track editor, and a good deal of workshop content.

There's no real multiplayer, but it does leave ghosts for others to challenge/enjoy the show via track editing (make your own race track on any map; have your own high score board; or heck, a stunt show spot. Sorry to anyone's times I may have obliterated due to Gran Turismo experience. And speaking of Gran Turismo, the physics of this game are good enough to set time trials; we just need some race tracks now. And more tracks that make good use of stunts, and the crash physics overall.

Controller/gamepad recommended if you want to have better control over the throttle and brakes, and other conveniences to make driving a little more fun. Especially, after crashing a few times and racing a few tracks, practicing some drifting with all kinds of cars, including the classic Model-T, a tank, 787-B, the Batmobile, or an A-10 Warthog (making a different set of Brrrt noises).

UPDATE:
Can you beat my Reliant Robin track times? I left a few, here and there. I hope you know how to drift one. Crash Test Site has a good practice spot/track I left behind to get some practice in (slalom area). Have fun beating my times.
developer_response: Thanks for the review, I will release the beta version of the realtime multiplayer soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995200947', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1607221912}
review: This game might be fun if I could even play it. Bought and installed, but all I can play is the "demo". There isn't even an option to get the full game or even use the key steam gives me. Very confusing.
developer_response:
Steam stopped distributing keys for ED in April last year. If you have a key from a recent purchase, it can only have come from a third party site.
Provided the key is valid, you should be able to redeem it to your Frontier account here:  https://www.frontierstore.net/customer/accountpage/
If you do in fact have a non-key copy, see here:  https://customersupport.frontier.co.uk/hc/en-us/articles/360011815340-Link-your-Frontier-account-to-your-Steam-account-
-Luna

author: {'steamid': '76561198216800624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1627070524}
review:
This game isn't as good as it could be.
I played Adventure quest 2D a lot as a child and have always had a soft spot for the game. So when I saw that there was a 3D version I was really excited, but that excitement didn't last long. This game has potential to be so much more, because where it's at right now it can draw attention to it when they're are far more better titles to be spending you time on. The game is a bit on the childish side. Which I do get why that is but I think they could implement a bit more grindy and tough to stuff so it can appeal more to players. Also must say there a far to many cut scenes when handing in or taking a quest.

Pros:

-Nostalgia
AQ 3D is great to play for a while for the nostalgia alone. I don't think there are alot of players playing this that didn't earlier play another version of AQ. 

Cons:

-Micro transactions
And also please remove the micro transactions in the game, or at least the ones to buy classes. Just have a small fee to play the game and im sure it would be a far engagement from players. Because where the game is at the moment you can pretty much pay your way to the top, where otherwise you'd have to grind boring quests for quite a while. 

-Quests
MMORPG are suppose to be grindy, and alot of the grinding is often repeating the same thing over and over. But AQ's quests are just overall pretty meh. What they do is they give lots and lots of quests that a really simple to complete. So it might take while to complete them all since there are so many of them but there is no challenge what so ever. Also, just get rid of the cutscenes, or at least lower the amount. When you get so many quests there is no reason for there being so much dialogue between them all. 

-Classes
Some of the beginning classes have lie on different attack. There is not much variation at all.

-Pvp
This game isn't worth looking into if your playing it for the PVP aspects. Evasion stat is way to op which leads to it being very boring and infuriating.

Conclusion:

Good game. 
You should try it for the nostalgia and to just explore the AQ world but in 3D. Otherwise.. eh
developer_response:
Thank you so much for playing AQ3D and for your feedback! AQ3D is rated T for Teen but we do create games for players of all ages. As we now have players who have grown up with our original single player 2D Flash game AdventureQuest and our first multi player 2D Flash game AQWorlds, we created AQ3D for older players in mind as they are now adults, but also for those players who play on mobile devices too, since AQ3D is a cross platform game.  

The devs are constantly working on fixing issues and releasing updates/patches weekly. This has been a constant balance as an indie game company with a small staff. Please check out the Game Plan and Design Notes for updates - https://aq3d.com/news/ & https://aq3d.com/game-plan/. We hope you continue to check out AQ3D as it continues to grow and evolve!

It is literally a terrible world of warcraft.

developer_response:
Hello. AdventureQuest 3D is definitely not trying to be World of Warcraft - the AQ3D Team and the entirely of Artix Entertainment put together would be a drop of water in the ocean compared to WOW/Blizzard. We do appreciate the compliment though that you are trying to compare us to WOW. It has always been our goal to create a 3D game based on our original game AdventureQuest that was released in 2002. After years of issues with Flash, and then Flash dropping 3D support, we were able to create the current Unity cross platform version of the game. 

The devs are constantly working on fixing and improving issues and releasing updates/patches almost weekly. This has been a constant balance as an indie game company with a small staff. Please check out the Game Plan and Design Notes for updates - https://aq3d.com/news/ & https://aq3d.com/game-plan/.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087069131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1667250974}
review:
(Don't let my Steam hours fool you, I played AQ3D primarily through the Artix Launcher.)
The short of it? This sucks, dear God stay well away go play ESO or FF14 instead.
The long? Well here's some bullet points:
- The original tech demo for AQ3D was way WAY back in 2014. Which means at that point they had a playable build of the game and have been working at least an extra year on it beforehand. I'm making note of this because some reviews are saying "Oh it only 'just' left Early Access so I'll go easy on it!" when, no, this has been in development since 2013! Probably even earlier, who knows.
-Why did this have to be in 3D? I was expecting something akin to Runescape, you know, having tons of side activities that you can level up and really feel like you're living in the world itself. This is honest to God just AQWorlds but in 3D with zero changes.
-I don't think the developers know what they want to do. Infact I've seen developer streams where they openly mock how garbage the game is. On top of that, I swear every year they change the premise of the story. It's embarassing.
-No clue who their market is. Is it babies first MMO? No since there's too much payment shit (we'll get into that later). Is it an MMO for teens? No since the gameplay is far too simple. An MMO for adults? Nope, the writing is comparable to a Blues Clues episode. Because of this you'll experience horrendous mixed feelings throughout pretty much everything you do. I really can't explain it but it feels like you're playing Fortnite as a 20-something year old on the family TV while all your extended family are there. It feels cringey to play at all ages is what i'm getting at.
-The art is okay. The artists had to go from working in 2D Flash to modelling and texturing 3D models so I can't really blame the quality on account of this. That being said, outside of a few stand out environments and assets, this looks comparable to Wizard101 from 2008.
-MMO's are notorious for having grinds. Out of all of them i'd class AQWorlds as 'the' grindiest MMO of all time to such a point you feel compelled to bot out of necessity. So how does AQ3D alleviate this? By introducing more grinds of course! "Go kill X amount of enemies" is what 99.99% of the quests are like. AE if you're reading this please for the love of God hire a bloody game economist or playtest your questlines. This goes for AQW as well, in no corner of hell does anyone need to kill tens of thousands of enemies to complete a single quest (Legion Revenant). That's just stupid.
-"Oh you want that cool rare item?" *dangles a bag of coins. "How much you gonna pay for it?". AQ3D is the playground bully of egregious MMO payments. You'll be reminded to buy currency or the upgrade at every waking step, every time you open a shop, every time you open the damn menu. Again, this goes for AQW as well so clearly the devs never learn't from their mistakes.
Overall just don't play this. You have no reason to and there's already several other free MMO's that are far more fun and do far more unique things than AQ3D ever will.
developer_response:
Thank you for taking the time to check out our game. Our team values player feedback regarding our projects and would love to hear more from you. 

Our devs work hard to release weekly updates and fix bugs. 

We have big goals for AQ3D and we would love for you to learn more about them via the News and Game Plan at AQ3D dot com!

author: {'steamid': '76561197985987595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 100886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100211, 'last_played': 1643002555}
review:
The "Not Recommended" means just that here: The big red thumbs-down doesn't mean "this game is bad and I hate it". It means "this game often frustrates me and I can't recommend it to new players, because you might feel those same frustrations and then hate it since you haven't been with it since day one".

Maybe I'd call it unfinished, despite now being a 1.0, but I've gotten plenty of mileage out of SE, having played it on and off since its early days, and will most likely keep playing it unless it goes in a direction that some people are afraid of. The ingredients for something outstanding are all there, and unlike what some detractors might think, it's clear that thought and effort have gone into them. SE's unique Voxel deformation isn't just eye candy, but serves a practical function in identifying where your ship or building has taken damage. The building system doesn't give you many options in the form department as opposed to something like Avorion, but is solid when it comes to function, as your survival game is all about being an engineer - as the title implies - and devising solutions to solve the various problems you're faced with, such as streamlining your mining and logistics stream, optimizing production to ensure you'll have the materials you need to fulfill your building ambitions, or how to compartmentalize your ship to protect its crew from hull breaches.

The whole while, the game teases you with this sort of endgame of steamrolling your ship across the star system, crushing hapless AI pirates and plundering their remains, or the idea of a server with groups of players building their own interplanetary factions from the ground up and battling over resources. Unfortunately, due to technical issues with physics, performance, or multiplayer (after six years of attempts to fix them), and a general lack of features or the incompleteness of what's there, they just don't get put together in a way that lets this game meet its full potential.

The 1.0 feels less like a milestone and more like a letter of resignation. Like Keen just saying "alright, we give up trying to wrangle the physics engine into doing what we need it to do and keeping performance stable, so here's some new features". That's not a slight against the devs, I get where they're coming from. Their physics engine is clearly getting long in the tooth, and I don't think they could fix its limitations in ten years, let alone six. A 110m/s speed limit in space and randomly exploding rotors will just have to be an accepted inconvenience, I guess. However, some players are concerned that new features to flesh out the game will be come in the form of DLC, rather than updates. The first of these came in the form of "decorative" blocks, and additional cockpit variants. Granted, it cost four bucks, less than some cups of coffee where I'm from. Granted, it's all a bunch of non-functional blocks, save for the cockpits, and even then they just look different. Granted, the most dubious part - people without DLC being unable to interact with the blocks in multiplayer - would only be a problem if multiplayer was in any kind of playable state. And granted, the DLC was separate from the main update. However, it was taken as a bad sign, and some are worried that it might be the typically innocuous start of a trend.

Maybe the fear is unfounded. Maybe it'll be like when folks thought the game would become an Xbox One exclusive when the port was announced, or that it'd be abandoned in favor of Medieval Engineers when that was announced. Maybe someday we'll all look back on this and laugh at how silly we were being about it. Even still, that's not the issue. The issue is certain elements of the community, who can be found on the KSWH forums and Discord, who will call you an entitled ingrate for not wanting to embrace such an idea, should it come to pass. "You have concerns about the pace of SE's development? Who are you to talk? What have [i]you[/i] ever made in your life?" "You think this feature feels incomplete? Well why don't you just dip into the source code and finish it yourself, you brat?" "Oh, you wouldn't pay 30usd retroactively for every update in the game's development? So you think you can get away with just paying 20 dollars in 2014 and expecting everything after that for [i]free?![/i] Uninstall the game, you cretin." If I've ever had the misfortune of playing a game with a more egotistical, spiteful, and contemptuous lot, I can't remember it. Thankfully, as mentioned, multiplayer in Space Engineers is scarcely functional, so dealing with these people isn't required. However, any time I have the gall to check on the playerbase, I wish I could refund this game.

[b]In summary,[/b] SE is probably one of the best of its kind visually, and all the elements for something outstanding are there. Unfortunately, it suffers from technical issues that might be unfixable, unfinished features that might be kept behind a paywall, and an embarrassingly defensive player-base that will likely turn away anyone who values a community. If you're able to put up with those, and if our DLC-based fears aren't realized after all, you might be able to see why we've been sticking with it for so long despite so many frustrations. For some of us, the potential is still too enticing to completely let go of.
developer_response:
Hi, fifth smell.

We appreciate the time you took to write this review.

It is our belief that by incorporating your and other community feedback, we will make Space Engineers an even better game.

Please feel free to submit any feedback you may have forgotten or think of in the future here: https://support.keenswh.com/spaceengineers

Cheers,

Keen Software House

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2306, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1546580674}
review:
[b][i]Review copy provided by developer[/i][/b]

A unique look is all you need to get me into a game, and Das Geisterschiff had me right from the start. I was doubly interested to then find it a turn-based dungeon crawler in the vein of classic Wizardry or Grimrock. The cyberpunk stylings were just icing on the cake, forming a trifecta I thought would be a total delight. And I was wrong, tragically wrong, because inside that cake is just a tiny bit of fluff. All the style in the world won’t save your game if nothing happens in it, and after hours of wandering empty halls searching for invisible items I’m ready to blame my boredom on exactly that.

Turns out the future isn’t full of grim darkness, it’s actually so bright the surface of the Earth has been scorched clean. Everyone who didn’t get an atomic sunburn moved the party underground, where two dystopian megacorps now lord over the remaining populace. I guess they got bored down there because they’re stuck in a forever war and you’ve joined up with one of them as a mech pilot, taking on odd jobs to stick it to The Man for your own The Man. Your assignments will send you to all sorts of subterranean cities, tunnels, and ruins in search of data to steal or agents to kill, hopefully without wearing down your mech or exhausting you of ammo before that happens.

In gameplay terms, you have a grid map to scoot around one turn at a time in search of your objectives. There are doors blocking your progress that you can open, shoot, or bash to get past, and less frequently you’ll find doors to new areas. Maps can be quite winding and confusing, especially with the simplified graphics and few unique features of hallways. Occasionally you’ll be accosted by an enemy, which you’ll take turns popping with your weapons and scooting towards or away from tactically. More often you’ll come across mines to avoid or disarm, or force fields you need to lower somehow. Beyond that, you’ll find wall terminals and random notes that flesh out the story of what you’re doing and how fucked the world you’re doing it in is.

Before you ask what the titular Geisterschiff is, I will confess that I can’t tell you because I couldn’t get past the second mission. Right from the tutorial and the first mission, the problems that eventually derailed my adventure were apparent. You might have picked up that levels are tough to navigate with few landmarks and many doors, but there’s also no proper map aside from your tiny 5×5 grid on the HUD. That makes it hard enough to find your way around, but the game is rife with fruitless dead ends often behind locked doors that you need to waste valuable ammo or hitpoints to open by bashing them with your face. You’ll need to find items like keys and upgrades but these are literally invisible, requiring you to step into every square on the map to know you’ve found everything.

Combat is probably the most interesting part of the game, and because of that also the most damning because it almost never happens. When an enemy approaches, you have the option to attack while advancing, retreating, or holding your ground. You also have four different weapons with different effects on both enemy behavior and damage. Switching and reloading them takes turns, though, so you have to plan ahead a little. The mobility factor allows you to duck around corners to escape or launch ambushes, though at my early stage of the game I mostly just had to shoot until dead. The issue, as I mentioned, was that combat was incredibly rare. I faced perhaps two or three foes in the first level and less than a dozen in the second, and over the course of two hours that’s not much time spent strategizing. The rest of the time was searching for invisible keycards and quest objectives, and that got old real fast.

The last big issue with Das Geisterschiff is how thin most of the game systems are. You have stats but no way to influence them except by picking up invisible upgrades off the beaten path for +2 to a stat. You can only repair yourself at workshops, and there’s no way to recover ammo, and that’s about all the purported “survival horror” elements amount to. There are no complex interactions in the game, and no puzzles more complex than “find key for barrier” or “complete quest by going to place”, which makes wandering the empty halls even more of a barren experience. There’s simply not enough to do here except explore samey levels in the hope of progressing and maybe getting to fight something.

This is one of those games I really set out to love, one that sounded like a fresh and exciting experience I had been looking for. I love the style, I love the premise, and I love the mash-up of genres. And it could have been great, but all the contents feel utterly half-baked. Even the striking art direction suffers from having no actual animations for anything and a weird smattering of languages confusing the signage and level names. Das Geisterschiff is a bold foundation for a game with a cardboard cutout built atop of it, a hollow experience that only the most patient and invested players will get anything out of. But for me, there are too many games out there that give me a giant mech AND something to do with it, and I’m going to stick to those.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!
developer_response:
Would like to address several points in your review:

＞ ...the game is rife with fruitless dead ends often behind locked doors that you need to waste valuable ammo or hitpoints to open by bashing them with your face.

Unless the door is/was rendered inoperable, you can open it later after getting a higher access level card. Just having an option to destroy the door to bypass keyhunting doesn't mean it's meant to be used on every step.

＞ You’ll need to find items like keys and upgrades but these are literally invisible, requiring you to step into every square on the map to know you’ve found everything.

Not true. Keycards are marked with a circle w/ oscillating color to attract one's attention even from a few tiles away. Locations of upgrades are marked by a nondescript box.

＞ You have stats but no way to influence them except by picking up invisible upgrades off the beaten path for +2 to a stat.

While it may appear that way on the surface, the combat tutorial mentions several cases where and how the stats are affected. It may look like a minor thing, but it's important to know this to survive in the long run.
---
Honest feedback is always appreciated, but judging by the playtime, I can't shake off the feeling that you needed more time with the game, as DG was always designed as a slow burner. If you decide to give it another try, I'd suggest turning on the 'Always Run' option by pressing Caps Lock to make exploration faster.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971731154', 'num_games_owned': 885, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1668180805}
review:
As many other reviewers have mentioned, Shortest Trip To Earth is an homage to FTL in many ways, but it exceeds it in every way, including in difficulty. The developer obviously has a love for this game style, and like me, enjoys a challenging time failing over and over again until finally getting just the right combination to succeed (Which I still have yet to do). The art style and music are well composed; simple enough to easily see what's going on, and diverse enough to keep things interesting. There's very little narrative, but this is not the type of game you buy for the story. 

All in all, I'd rate this game a 6 out of 7. Adding more randomized encounters and including more choices as far as ship customization would make it even better, but it's a great game for what it is. Lastly, the price. I do feel like it is priced a bit high for this kind of game, which is why it remained on my wishlist until this past Steam Sale. I would have gladly paid 15-20 for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989383204', 'num_games_owned': 570, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 4880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1597963024}
review:
Hi Steam, Xira here. This game sucks, but it's not obvious until it's too late to refund. I shall tell you why!

Basically the entire premise of the game is flawed - it costs you threat (a bad thing that accumulates and ends in defeat) to attempt a mission which you have no real guidance on beforehand. So you are paying a deadly price to go in blind with a 'drone' or drones you design. You don't get unlimited chances - you get threat with each attempt. This would be fine if sending down a 2nd drone picked up where the first wore off (so you'd pay a price but eventually be able to complete anything by chipping away at it) ----

But no. You restart fresh but in a worse position every time you fail a mission. You perhaps know what how to tweak your drone to better survive the mission but that's largely irrelevant because you only get to carry/use X parts which you have to pray to RNGesus you get in time for them to be useful. 

This results in extremely tedious missions which are sometimes impossible and it's down to pure luck if you get bent over by the procedural generation gods too many times and fail a play through. I got a snake mission in my first galaxy that was literally impossible to complete with the parts I had at the time - One of the eggs was buried in the middle of the planet. And I discover this after trying the mission 3 times and carefully flying around up and down and patiently waiting for the big snake to go away so I can chip away at an egg. These missions are extremely tedious.

In general the RNG is tuned to be *hard* on easy. I give you a 1/20 chance of it being possible to win an easy play-through, 1/100 for a normal, and impossible for hard. Unless you have lotto-like luck it's likely you'll end up failing a couple of missions and ending up with too much threat and nowhere to dump it. Ded.

Also, the instant you lose a part you might as well quit that play-through. Losing a part is (generally) crippling to the drone, which is fatal to the mission, which makes parts with independent (and tiny) hit-points pointless. You can drag it out as long as you like tho...

Don't waste your time. I haven't seen a game this fundamentally flawed since Sunless Sea.
developer_response:
Hi Xira

Nimbatus is now finished and will exit Early Access soon.
We have done a lot of mission balancing in the past months to improve the difficulty curve of the game and have also reworked some missions and added new ones.
Would be awesome if you have time to take another look at the game!

Kind regards,
Philomena

author: {'steamid': '76561197997894370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1471246100}
review:
Edit: The stability issue hasn't been resolved, but it could be on my end. This game makes CPUs run HOT. Looking at my CPU core temps during gameplay, they went from ~50c to ~70c instantly, and climbed to ~90c over the course of several minutes, before crashing. So I probably have a cooling issue. I'll work on resolving that and see if it fixes the problem, then revisit this review once I can play more of the game. At this point I tentatively recommend WftO for people who meet the recommended specs AND have a really good cooling solution - my little case fans clearly aren't cutting it. /edit

I want to like War for the Overworld. I do. I probably could grow to like it, if it would let me play it. But between constant crashes and a gameplay style choice that just dosesn't work well for me, I'm left frustrated and disappointed. Sometimes you just can't go back to the way things were.

WftO has all the pieces to be a great spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper 2; one of my favorite games of all time. The voice acting is nostalgiariffic, and the UI tickles all the old neurons that have been left dormant since EA murdered the Dungeon Keeper franchise in its sleep, lo these many years ago. The dialogue is funny, the creatures are creative, the spells and traps make me feel just as evil and fiendish as their inspirations did in prior decades. That should be enough to put this game over the top, for me. But the devil's in the details.

I'm not a huge fan of the rushes in the campaign levels I've gotten to see, so far. This game seems to be a lot more about defending your half-built and shoddily repaired dungeon from increasingly dire and unavoidable enemy incursions than about actually building up your dungeon as you explore the level and probe the enemy's defenses. That might be good news for some fans, but it's not really what made DK2 fun for me, personally. There seems to be a lot less freedom in how you can tackle the campaign levels if you want to survive - which seems ironic, given the plethora of new options WftO gives to you. No matter what gadgets are at your disposal, you have to move fast, you have to focus on immediate survival over long-term planning, and you have to rush for whatever objective the stage gives you, over exploring. If that's how you already wanted to play, then great. But I miss the more methodical pace I remember from DK2.

But that's a minor complaint. I could get past it, and find a game I still enjoy, even with some caveats, if not for the fact that it crashes so much it's barely playable. I have restarted the fourth level four times, because the game simply refuses to remain functional long enough for me to beat it. I've had similar issues with other stages. Saving can be used to brute-force your way through a level while losing minimal amounts of progress over and over, but is that fun? If I have to restart, I want it to be because I lost, or because I want to try a new strategy, not because the game is so unstable I have to restart the game (or reboot my computer!) every 5 - 15 minutes.

Maybe I'm the only one with this problem. I can't imagine that after all this time, this degree of crashing is still a problem for eveyone who plays this game, or there's no way it'd have remotely positive reviews. But I can only speak from my own experience, and for me, the game is basically unplayable. I more than meet the recommended specs, for what it's worth.

I have waited so long (3+ years!) for WftO to become stable. But I honestly think it crashed less back in Early Access. I give up, for now. I'll let it simmer on the back burner of my library for another couple of years, I guess, and hope it's actually functional by the time I get back to it. In the meantime, I can't recommend it.
developer_response:
Hi Nightsong81,

Thanks for the review and deepest apologies for the experience you've had with crashes.

These days we would expect crashes to be rather rare and only in exceptional circumstances should they occur in Gameplay. I'd love to help you resolve your issues and get you back in the game without crashes but to do so I'll need you to submit a a bug report on our [url=https://brightrockgames.userecho.com/]bug tracker[/url] following our [url=http://brightrockgames.userecho.com/topics/118-how-to-submit-a-bug-ticket/]guidelines[/url].

You can also find troubleshooting advice for various crashes in our [url=http://brightrockgames.userecho.com/topics/1094-general-crash-troubleshooting/]knowledge base[/url]

As soon as we've got information from you we'll do our best to identify the cause of your crashes and get you back in the game as soon as possible! Don't rely on time to deploy fixes as without good reports we can't identify the cause in specific cases!

With regards to the "rushyness" of the original campaign, we definitely took a lot of feedback on board for Heart of Gold and we looked to making that campaign more open, pleasantly paced and methodical for our players. Once we've got you back up and running you might find that to your liking.

Cheers,

Lee

author: {'steamid': '76561197990572759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 851, 'last_played': 1497774275}
review:
Mission 1: Everything seems okay until evening. Not knowing that I need to have battery power at night leads the crew to freezing to death.

Mission 2: Got the batteries! I made it through the night! Only to starve the next day...

Mission 3: Batteries, check! Food, check! Meteorite dead center of the base killing three crew members, check...

Mission 7: What happened to my engineers?! 

Mission 12: I didn't lay this out right, I have no room to grow the battery farm next to the solar panels. And I question the legitimacy of those windmills.

Mission 14: Why is my power breaking down?! What the hell are spares??

Mission 23: Visitors! And they're paying me! 

Mission 24: Sure, you guys seem legit, you can land here and we'll give you food and rest. Why did you kill my engineer?!

Mission 25: Behold my monolith! 

Pros: Easy to get the hang of. Replayability. Nice art aesthetic. It's a fun game!

Cons: Not enough variance in the habitats. I'd like to build more different things.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977290622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1529292789}
review:
This game installed the Gaijin.net Agent which auto-opens in the task bar on start-up, gives zero option to not auto-open AND REMAINS ON THE COMPUTER AFTER DEINSTALLING THE GAME. This developer is not to be trusted! I wouldn't be suprised if it was using my system resources to mine for bitcoin or doing other nefarious activities.  Tell me why I need an agent constantly running in the background to check for updates for a game on steam when all other games update perfectly fine through the steam client.  

The game has no option to join a freind in squad or duo.  The graphics are nice, the gun play feels pretty good, and the idea is funny.  It would be nice if this was a game and not a scam.
developer_response: Due to our player's feedback, we have made Gaijin.Net agent entirely optional during a Steam installation (now you can decide whether you want to use it, or not). Please note: Gaijin net agent is completely harmless and useful software, and not using it can lead to delays in updates, if Steam updates are switched off/or not effecient. We still recommend using our solution, it is essential to keep your game up-to-date to be able to play!

author: {'steamid': '76561198083736752', 'num_games_owned': 526, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1596629786}
review:
[i]Roombo: First Blood[/i] is a short, gory, mindless, repetitive game where you fend off burglars from your home. At first glance, the concept seems interesting however once you touch and feel the product, you will be disappointed with the keyboard controls and camera. Even playing with the controller feels awkward. 

The "fun" factor is subjective. If you are:
[list]
    [*]A 0 IQ human, this will provide endless entertainment value for eternity. 
    [*]If you are somewhat sensible person, the endless repetition of defending the house becomes dull very, very quickly. 
    [*]If you are someone with high expectations and looking for a great adventure, look elsewhere.
[/list]

Despite all the efforts, Roombo: First Blood fails to offer [u]value[/u] to its consumer. In a couple of days, no one will remember this title or this developer at all. 

John Rambo would not approve of this.
developer_response:
Hey aruvin, 

Just letting you know we've just released an update with a non-tank control scheme. We'd really appreciate it if you gave it a try and let us know your thoughts. :)

https://store.steampowered.com/newshub/app/1004610/view/2716185857418881909

Cheers,
Winston

author: {'steamid': '76561198032411193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1694789108}
review:
A Phenomenal point and click adventure game! It's three strongest aspects are:
+writing, 
+art and design, 
+voice acting. (Truly excellent, I especially love Crispin's banter!)

Puzzles are mostly good, though sometimes I'm mashing everything together in my inventory. Crispin (your sidekick) is very helpful with little hints if you interact with him enough.

-the pixel hunting is not egregious here, but a button to highlight all hotspots could be a nice accessibility feature
(On a personal note, I wish I had remembered to use my map in the city to fast travel around, so here is your reminder)
 
Game length is about 4ish hours if you are moving quickly, but there is tons of fully voice acted optional dialogue which fleshes out the world, its characters and your playtime. 
I like the soundtrack a lot too, very atmospheric.

Again the English voice acting is just amazing, loved my time in Primordia!
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind words! The whole team poured our hearts into it—including the amazing voice actors (Abe Goldfarb was Crispin, and plays like 12 roles in our second game, Strangeland). I know the story wouldn’t have had the same impact without them and the art!

author: {'steamid': '76561197960527063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1541259729}
review:
Updated review
----

Picked this back up today and pleased to say a lot of my original issues have been resolved, so going to cover what's been fixed, and what still needs work (imo).

Frame-rate is now solid, not sure if it's my new rig (similar spec to the old one) or if the game has been optimised. But it no longer skips frames, and seems to hold up okay even on large playsets.

Physics are much better, when you throw lots of track pieces on top of each other, you are now able to pick an individual piece up and place it. When placing tracks it also doesn't bodge up existing track and disconnect random pieces you already had setup. It only seems to change existing track in order to complete the circuit which is spot on. So the issues I ran into before are gone, woot! 

Menu is still comedy size, I could understand if this was done for folks using older headsets with low resolutions but a setting to configure the distance from face would be great, as I'd like it a couple of feet further back so it doesn't consume my entire FOV.

Spent around 30 minutes just tinkering and found it a fun and relaxing experience. I couldn't figure out how to get the big red button track working, I sussed out how to connect it by dragging, but even when it was connected to a switchable track piece i couldn't figure out how to actually 'press' it, pressing the action button again just lets me wire it up to more things.

Going to change review to a recommendation.

Thanks!


Original review
-----

Loved the concept but found the execution too frustrating. 

The (new) physics are highly temperamental, sometimes I'll be slotting track pieces together with no probems. But occasionally it'll decide to become the dark souls of train games and everytime I slot a new piece of track in, it moves and disconnects the previous piece; making it impossible for me to ever make a completed circuit. 

I suspect it's trying to be helpful, and applying some degree of magetism to snap near-by parts together. But this has little regard for if the piece is already connected to something else or not. This also means if you throw a load of parts onto the ground at once to save going into the comedy-size menu, the parts all get a life of their own and refuse to be picked up.

My other complaint is the frame-rate. I have a pretty decent VR rig but for some reason this game just murders my graphics card. Even when you start a new game where it's just an empty void of nothing-ness the frame-rate will jump from 90fps to mid 20's then back up again without any explaination. I'm used to some Unity jank with my VR titles, but can't fathom why it's jumping around when there isn't a single track on the ground.

So suggestions to the developer would be:

- The menu is huge and clumbersome, it put imax cinemas to shame. Having to constantly open and close it because it takes up so much of my field of vision is very annoying. Please let me move it further away (holding the menu button then up/down on the sticks) and also have the menu button toggle it on and off, so I don't have to cramp my neck just to see and hit the close button.

- Sort out the physics, probably easier said than done, but having it moving and snap-completing pieces of track i've already put down is really annoying. Only the piece (or pieces) I'm holding should snap complete.

- Framerate, feel like there is something fundmentlly wrong/buggy here causing it to jump around so much regardless of if anything has even been built or on-screen. Hoping it can be fixed.
developer_response:
First of all, sorry for your poor experience. After your comment, we have tested the game but couldn't reproduce the problems you are describing.

About new physics: they are related to trains, we think your complaint is about the track snap system. We have tested the game with lots of extremely complex networks and never had a problem closing them since v1.3. Sometimes closing a circuit is a small puzzle challenge, but that is part of the fun of this game.

About frame rate: perhaps it is a problem with your system. Can you tell us which VR set you have? We have a computer with Oculus and a not-so-decent hardware (Oculus app even warns about our hardware doesn’t meet minimum requirements), but the game works flawlessly and at a decent framerate. We have tested it with a profiler, and the framerate seems ok. We are concerned about performance for a pleasant VR experience, and we made a lot of testing and put a lot of work and effort on this matter.

Let’s agree to disagree about the size of the menu :) . The menu can be moved holding the menu button. It is pretty easy and straightforward to get rid of it at any moment. The menu is designed to be easy to navigate and pick pieces as the game is designed for all range of ages, even 4 years old children can use it (we have tested it).

Of course we have a lot to improve, it’s a work-in-progress and we’re making changes hearing the community’s proposals. 

Cut us some slack and we hope you reconsider your review for future versions.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993879309', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1398846805}
review: This is one of the few early access games i've purchased that I do not in any way shape or form regret even a little. It is one of the greatest games I've ever played from the very beginning, and with regular updates coming out about every 2-3 weeks adding more and more features, it just keeps getting better and better. The community support is amazing, and the devs actually listen to the players, they learned a lot after their miner wars fiasco, and seem to have walked away from that much better game devs, because this is an amazing game that any fan of minecraft, space sims in general, blockland, legos, fans of any scifi universe you've ever thought you'd love to be in, or human beings in general will love. I've already purchased a copy for me and my wife, and several of our friends. I suggest you get it now at early access prices, because it's a steal. I can't see a game this amazing staying this cheap after it's launched.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991798166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 22070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3256, 'last_played': 1710790913}
review:
I can only recomend this game as more of an expeariment to watch TRUE Artificial Idiots (AI*) kill themselves. But for any thing other than that I would say don't waste your money. At the time of writing this the latest patch "Improves the AI's 'self preservation'". Does it really? 

First my workers ignored the "high prioity" set metal prossers with 3 ore a piece in them to make the steel needed to make more spare parts. When they finaly made the parts to fix the power producers.
I just watched as 3 wind turbines fail in the middle of the night 2 seconds before a sandstom (which could have changed the entire outcome if at least one had been fixed). The "AI*" right before that decided the solar pannals that where NOT EVEN BEING USED AT THE TIME where more of a prioity to repair.
This FAIL in proper "AI*" priorization caused all power to be lost and the O2 levels droped to zero killing every one.

The "AI*" in this game is a joke. The only way I could see this game is "What happens when the dumbest idiots try to populate a new planet".

Edit: After further game time the above still stands but with an exception. There is no build queue for the colonists (at least at the moment) so you are forced to build one thing at a time. Or it can end up being the total death of your settlement. If you like to place a bunch of buildings all at once, then you must have the resources to build them all at once. The AI in this game will try to build every structure at once. Unlike in some other 'city builder' games, where the AI focuses on constructing the set buildings in the order they are placed.

At the current time of writing this, that function is not in play. Though if you (the reader) can use the 'work around' and/or don't mind that 'rule', the game might be for you. 
I, do however find it a bit annoying and can not in good conscience recommend this title until that feature is a part of the game.
developer_response:
Hello there, thank you for your feedback,

We are always listening to the community and fixing any issues in the game.

You might want to have a look at our AI FAQ here:
steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=577310241#898896

This explains the behaviour of colonists in more detail, but if you think you've found a bug you can send us a savegame to "bugs at madrugaworks dot com" and we will investigate ASAP.
(Saves are in Documents/Planetbase/Saves)

Thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198304639488', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1559347879}
review:
The trailer is nothing like the game. Misleading. Graphics are not at all like the trailer.Also you need to PAY for all you see on the trailer,PLUS DLC since armor,planes,weapons,soldiers etc are pay-to-play.PLUS DLC.  First thing i realize upon playing is that there is no configuration menu. i mean, there IS one but it ONLY lets you choose the display at what resolution. Nothing else.

Second,i can't configure controls. I can't configure anything.No menu for it either.

I tried joining games, but there is NEVER enough players to begin a game. I need to play offline to even try the game out. And even that is screwed up because i discovered that, since i can't set aforementionned controls, i can't go prone behind fox holes(Said holes only being knee-deep).Or do anything! Can't even spawn bots to train or even try out the game's core concept!

Third: I do not believe one bit that there was 18 years of ACTIVE development on this game. If this game came out in 2001,then had 18 years of development,it's more than certain the game should be WAY better than this. Sound design would be better,models would not look like a playstation 2 game (Polygonal limitations of the console.No more excuses with even BASIC super cheap Integrated GPU's in processors of the last 5 years,nowadays IGPu's letting you play 1080p 60 fps in a lot of A-class games (CS:GO,Fortnite/PUBG,Overwatch even,etc.)). There is NO excuses on anything hardware-related.

And when it comes to grapical design... this game is LEGITIMATELY low quality in all it's aspects. no water(Or at least barely from gameplay footage i went to see to compensate for no players playing),barely any landscaping done,animations are really low quality,etc. you get it. If it's gonna appeal to 2019 players, it needs a serious workout.

There is not way in hell anyone would pay a SUBSCRIPTION for 15$ ***PER MONTH*** for a game like this. This game feels like a cash grab. With all the money they would have collected over 18 years from it's player base,considering it was never really free, they should have had the money to actually make the game WAY better than it is as of right now.

Good thing this game had free-access this month. Not worth the money investment,with all those EA-style cash grabbing schemes.I mean heck,even EA,***the company that abuses the shit out of DLC*** doesn't have 3/4 of it's game locked behind DLC! EVEN EA! I can't believe i'm saying that!

Anyway,game scores on metacritic are bs,subscription-based game ***with pay to play*** on top of it, WITH DLC on top of it is just the worst,and on top of that there is no player base with misleading trailer(Trailer shows stuff you need to PAY for,along with content you will never get to see in-game anyway due to before mentionned lack of players),and just so much more stuff that i just can't get into words.

If this game is to even be CONSIDERED to be sold/bought to/by ANYONE, it needs to stop the ***15$*** per month subscription (20$ per month for the "Premium" stuff),not make any excuses about hardware (SPECIALLY not in 2019,now that even low-spec computers can run A-class games easily),and actually put some heart in the development. And if budget allows it,get some graphics improvements. In 2019 a game that looks like this is not appealing to the public. And also, actually putting a graphical/audio/controller/keyboard setup menu is MANDATORY for ANY game. No excuses.


Will not play the game anymore. Nor think i will ever play it in the future if it keeps heading that way.
developer_response: All footage contained within our trailer was obtained by real in-game footage from Staff and players. All footage shows real players and actual game play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067964209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1700523916}
review:
EDIT: So since I reviewed this game, I have played many more hours of it, and the game has been updated many times.  I therefore want to update my review!

*The issue with the Lord's Manor and gold stocks has been resolved.  The game now has built-in early-game quests that lead you in a very natural progression to learn the game and set up your early economy.  The Lord's Manor is now one of the easiest buildings to unlock, and so the loss of gold is not an issue.  Also, there are a wide variety of quests and special events with varied benefits and negatives.

*There are now a number of helpful tools in the UI for managing villagers, which mostly eliminates the need for directly selecting them.  Villagers also will shift between houses on their own to optimize distance from their workplace/market/well/church, eliminating the issue where they would just build a house wherever there was room, and then be perpetually angry because it would take them all day to walk to work and back.

*Because of the way the game has evolved, having to click the X to close building menus is more of a benefit than a problem now.  It's often helpful to have multiple buildings open at once.

*Trade feels a little more natural now, including trade boons for completing quests helping that faction.  Still kind of wish for resources to be a bit more map-specific, but the game is so beautiful and streamlined and fun, I feel guilty even saying it.  Leaving my original post and first Edit up so you can see the progression as the game has evolved.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Overall, this game is one of the most fun and addictive I've played in recent years.  I had been craving a game with free-form building, and I took the chance on this one...and I was not disappointed!  If you enjoy free-form building (like the settlement-building in Fallout 4) you will not be disappointed.  If you're looking for a Medieval combat simulation with building as a central mechanic, this is not the game for you.  The most combat you get in this game is sending soldiers off to help defend the kingdom in exchange for money and land.

The game is still in development, so there are still some clunky elements--your villagers start to get stuck on building elements and each other once things get crowded, there are still some place-holder text lines, and that sort of thing.  But the game is beautiful, the monuments with their sticky elements are very user-friendly, and once you get the hang of the interface, the game is very easy to learn.

Now some details.

Things I love:
The overall concept is incredible.  There is something immensely satisfying about the way the villagers build their own housing.  The combination of free-form building and painted districting overlays is brilliant.  The villager animations are adorable.  Designing the monuments--especially later in the game when you have lots of component options--is very fun.  The difference between monuments and public buildings, which are unlocked by beautifying your city/gaining influence with a power faction and upgrading your villagers respectively, is a clever game mechanic.  The basic concepts of the game are similar to games like Age of Empires, where you build resource collecting buildings and assign villagers to that resource, which is very intuitive.  It's just a relaxing, immensely satisfying game.

Things I wish were different:
*You are limited to 500 gold at the beginning of the game, and it is only by unlocking the Lord's Manor that you gain the ability to raise your maximum capacity--a relatively difficult monument to unlock.  Meanwhile, the Wooden Keep is an early-unlock monument that opens up combat quests which give a 1000 gold reward.  The extra gold is lost, which in a game where your gold reserves fluctuate wildly, can be quite frustrating.  I wish there were either no limit, or a 1000 gold limit to start.
*Selecting villagers is very difficult as they are always moving, and you can't click-drag a select box to catch one or more.  This is alleviated somewhat by being able to assign idle villagers to buildings directly at the building, but there is still no way to assign Builders without clicking a villager directly.  I wish there were a population management screen where you could make villager assignments and track your population's needs and happiness.
*Selecting buildings opens up a very helpful window, but the only way to close it is by clicking an X.  I wish you could close the window by either right-clicking or by selecting the building again.
*The trade mechanic is relatively simple to learn, but it is currently highly tiered and immutable.  Trading refined resources is part of the economy built into the game, but I wish the resources you were able to trade was either randomized or variable, so that playing the game didn't feel like a trial and error experiment in learning which buildings to build in which order, but one in which you had to react to the resources you have available.
*I enjoy the quests, but there are only a few that keep popping up; many of which aren't possible to complete.  I look forward to more being available.

All in all, it's already a good game, if you're looking for what it has to offer.  I was, and it was the best game purchase I've made in ages!  But it's definitely obvious that it's a work in progress.  I can't wait to see what the end product will be!

Update:
I have now played the game for some 14 hours.  I take back some of my wishes--unlocking the Lord's Manor is not so hard as I had thought, once you learn the game, and having large quantities of gold is not nearly so useful as having large quantities of trade goods to sell to your villagers or other towns.  After spending more time with the game, I think making the trade mechanic more complex would make the game nearly impossible to play--you need to be able to sell certain goods and buy others in order to make the town viable.

I do think it's a worthwhile thought that perhaps the kinds of goods you can produce should depend on the terrain type chosen at the outset.  Like maybe wine and sheep for mountainous regions, grain and honey for the river, fish and dyes for the coast, etc.  And then the trade cities (and goods available/desired for trade) should be different depending on the terrain.  It felt weird growing grain essentially on a beach, and that I was well into the mid-game before I was able to build a fisherman's hut.  BUT, these are minor complaints/suggestions.  Still a freaking amazing game, the more I play it the more I love it.  It truly fills me with joy every time I open it up.
