author: {'steamid': '76561197970566201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1563661924}
review:
It’s just an okay game. Everything is done competently enough. But there is just not much there and not much reason to invest time in it beyond beating your own high score.
It’s a typical tower defense archery game. The graphics are on the realistic side but there are only a few types of enemy and the animations are all the same and less then inspiring in that you feel like you a shooting a tiny arrow into a large orc because of the weak hit animation. Yes, animation singular. Doesn’t matter where you hit them they are going to react the exactly the same way every time. Makes it feel very shallow and not exactly visceral. And that shallowness extends to the sound too. Just the same thing every time ad nauseum.
The only character progression is the unlocking of spells for your arrows. Your character does rank up with play but it doesn’t appear to have any affect on the power of your shots. You also earn gold that you can use to buy better looking equipment but again it’s just cosmetic. You can upgrade the spells but all that does is lower the cooldown time. Still it’s the only character progress you have so better than nothing I guess.
The bow handling is okay. The trajectory seems too flat and doesn’t seem to change enough with angle and range which makes it feel a bit unrealistic but it’s still fun. I don’t like how the arrows magically appear in your hand with the push of a button. I prefer the QuiVR scheme where you at least have to reach to your shoulder like you pulling an arrow from a quiver. But the ‘instant’ arrows are not unique to this game.
I’ve played the single player quite a bit and can reach the low 20’s by myself but the lack of progression has kept me from investing too much time or even checking out the multiplayer. If I want a one off experience I find Longbow to be more fun and frantic and the leaderboards work. And if I want to feel like I’m investing the time in my character I’ll play QuiVR as at least there is better equipment to unlock and the gameplay itself has more variety and depth. 
Bottom line is that’s it's too shallow to reccomend when there are better options out there.
developer_response:
Thank you for your opinion and some suggestions.

Comments like this tell us what to focus on so we can improve in the future.

We hope that someday you will come back and try the game once again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198800662709', 'num_games_owned': 899, 'num_reviews': 338, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1651581566}
review:

Watch my 20 Minutes playthrough here - https://youtu.be/TsddcYQEoQU

Bakery Simulator is a unique simulation game that lets you control everything happening in your bakery. Each order you complete helps to unlock more recipes, bakery machines, and ingredients for creating new, more complicated recipes. This is the most fun I’ve had with a game in a very long time, and I’m still finding cool things after hours of gameplay. If you’re looking for a fun sim that’s unlike any other out there (and even better when played baked out), then check out Bakery Simulator today!
developer_response: Thank you for the feedback and video. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198098994867', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5473, 'last_played': 1704924656}
review:
Game is great but I cannot recommend it until puppet spawns are fixed, they spawn in front of you (bombers too). Also, if your PC doesn't render properly, you're going to fall off the map, your vehicle [b]will disappear[/b] with all of your items inside (happened twice, uninstalled on second one).

Other than that the game is gold for me aside from some minor inconveniences.
developer_response: Hi there Fever! We're sorry to see that the issues you've experienced soured your time with the game, especially since you, overall, like it. We're looking into ways to improve these puppet spawns so that they don't spawn directly in front of the player. As for the rendering issue, we'd like to kindly ask you to send us report with a detailed description of what happened before you fell of the map via https://support.scumgame.com/ so we can try to replicate and fix it. We'd be most grateful for that. We'd like you to know that the team here is hard at work on completing the game and preparing for its eventual exit out of Early access, meaning that we are working on fixing as many bugs as we can and polishing the overall experience of the game, as well as adding additional content features. All that being said, we hope that you'll give the game another chance once we get there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119711690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1560495394}
review:
Creepy, but intriguing little game. It pays to be a little bit selfish in this story. Also had to try 3 times to get that one particular bad ending, which in turn forced me to explore choices I normally wouldn't have. 

An overall interesting experience. Would love to see more in future.

Oh, and please add a "Skip" function. After the 5th run, I really don't need to be reading the text over and over.
developer_response:
Hi there and thanks a lot for your review! 

In the next months, we will have some big changes coming to the game: for now, I can just anticipate that a whole "Skip" mechanic will be added. This way, hopefully, making multiple runs will get easier. 

Again, thanks for your feedback, it's really important for us.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995110569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1622399339}
review:
This game is 100x better than the Store page here makes it look. How the HELL did I miss out on this for so long?

At the ending credits I was waiting to see the name of the Marketing people so I could talk shit about them 
 here specifically, and of course there weren't any.  Your publishers did you all dirty on the marketing.

This game is what happens when you put all of your talent everything except Marketing.  If this game were a Dungeons & Dragons character, it rolled a 15 for every stat except Marketing, which rolled a 2.

The world building and environment art are outstanding. The voice acting is great. The narrative is decent. The core game loop is great, 

My only feedback are a few things:
- Fire your publisher and get a better one if you haven't already because their marketing team failed _miserably_ on this
- The character art improvements of the new game you announced recently is perfect, so I won't talk shit about the character art in this game because you all obviously already know
- If I make it to the destination before the dialogue finishes, you guys should have some voice lines to interrupt and say "alright we're here" so that we can skip the conversation and continue.  That speed boost upgrade (which I loved) made me have to spin in circles for a few minutes sometimes, which is not fun from a game design perspective
- Many of the choices I made during the story ended up having no pay off or consequences at the end, and so some of those minor story arcs seemed like a waste of time in hindsight

Little things that I especially liked:
- The video game console was great, one of the timed missions started while I was in the middle of a high score run and so I failed it
- The surprise ending gift was great... I just need a button to interact with my friend!
- Letting me free roam around the city and explore after the story is finished is great!

author: {'steamid': '76561197990162989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1360742400}
review:
Good point and click adventure, in some ways it's a bit like Beneath a Steel Sky. It's like the classic point and click adventures and doesn't dumb itself down either, so you can get stuck figuring out exactly what the hell you're supposed to do, exactly how these games should be. 

If you do get stuck, you can speak to your sidekick for clues without giving too much away.

review: this game works ok on my laptop (low fps) but not my desktop. It always selects the integrated GPU (even if I disable it bios) then I have to restart the whole pc because all the other games also want to use the integrated card! I have wasted allot of time with "support" who dont even read what I write properly (very frustrating) I have to repeat myself again and again. Uninstalled due to it not functioning, a regrettable purchase still remains :(
developer_response:
Hello Nyangau! I'm truly sorry to hear that The Crew 2 is not working properly on your PC. I also apologize if our support team has not provided the desired assistance! Please comment your case number below for me. I would be glad to review it further.

You can also reach out to our team on [url=facebook.com/UbisoftSupport]Facebook[/url] or [url=twitter.com/UbisoftSupport]Twitter[/url]. They may be able to provide the necessary assistance to get this resolved!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031404282', 'num_games_owned': 2376, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1476598691}
review:
TLDR: Only fun for the first hour or 2, then it's totally worthless

This game may feel like fun in the beginning, but then you realize that there is only one scenario to play and that's it..no modes, no campaign, no multiplayer..nothing

Also it's insanely difficult to win this one scenario even on the easiest settings..you will need to memorize what happens through out the game and pre-plan the next time based on stuff that hasn't happened yet, and in the end it will still be difficult!

Edit: So after the patch the game seems better, at least now one has the option to play an actual easy difficulty and finish the game without too much complex god-like strategy skills and memorization for what lies ahead. Normally I hate easy difficulties and like a good challenge, but in this case it felt way too hard on the easy difficulty and for the wrong reasons, and there isn't a clear way to know you'r not doiing well until the end of that game so it can be frustrating at that point.

Anyway, I realize I was a bit too harsh on tha game before, I probably expected too much of a 9$ game. And above all, the developers response have been awesome, and I value this almost as much as a good game. I wish them well, it's a good first try (if it is) and maybe we'll get better games from them in the future.

A note to the developer tho: yes I am from Egypt and I love storytelling in games, but it needs to be a bit less subtle to grab my attention, needs to play a bigger part somehow..it didn't really connect with me in the game.

I'm changing this to a positive review, for 9 bucks and a few hours, I did have some good fun even if it didn't last forever, but I guess that's fair :)
developer_response:
Hello and thanks for the review. The negative review is of course bad for us, but it helps to make the game better and better. We read your comments and just released the 1.0.1 update – which we made as easy as possible for all novice players. They now can play in a training mode and after the historic campaign they can continue to play.

About mods – we're working on Steam Workshop now and when it will be ready, we give the players all the game scripts so they can create their own mods.

Recommended game time is 3-4 hours, during this period, the game will tell you about the ancient history of your country (You're from Cairo, right?), what technologies were discovered by the Egyptians thousands of years ago and will shows you where people lived and what difficulties they have met.

Hi TheLastPepe,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2015. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since release:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. Two of these are completely free for you!

- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561198003069918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2131, 'last_played': 1422238977}
review:
I stumbled across Primordia some years ago, and it couldn't have been a better coincidence on my part. The game has been one of my personal favorites for quite a while now. I always try to find an excuse to gift it to friends who haven't played it yet so I can get them in on it, too. I admit, I'm a little biased. It just so happens the game rolled a lot of my interests together into one experience. Apocalypse fiction? Fascinating art style? Haunting, moody sci-fi? Sad robots? [i]I'm in.[/i]

In all seriousness, though, I think it's a beautifully put together game. The love everyone at Wormwood poured into it really shines through. The deep melancholy of the soundtrack and haunting art style build such a solid atmosphere. I loved picking around the ruins of the world and unraveling the full story bit by bit with each puzzle solved, or item examined. I loved the characters, the personalities they exuded in their dialogue, and all the idiosyncrasies of their cobbled together robot society I was exploring. I loved my jaded, weary, hermit of a protagonist who was still lonely enough to build himself a friend. I love Horatio Nullbuilt v5, my favorite robot.

Primordia is one of those games that I'll be thinking about forever. It makes me wish it had a bigger fandom so I could find more excuses to talk about it all the time. It's just a lovely little thing that I'm really happy to have found.
developer_response: Thank you for the kind words, beautiful review, and support over the years. We’re very lucky to have fans like you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088213112', 'num_games_owned': 1213, 'num_reviews': 257, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1586713560}
review:
The interface is too obscure for me. Sometimes your microphone shows some countdown, no idea what that means. Sometimes you get some audio fragments, not sure when and how. You get attacked by dark orbs which are sometimes invisible (or almost invisible?). If you shoot them, some stuff happens, but I'm not sure weather they're taking damage or not. I understand there are two kinds of ammo, but I don't even get which kind of ammo I'm shooting: lets say there are two stones and then lots of nails in the pipeline, the gun won't stop shooting stones. I guess. You find some recordings you can tinker with. By accident I found a hidden message. No idea how and why, Hell, I did not even find out how to leave this recording menu expect for going to the game's menu via ESC and back.
And a fair warning: As a non-native speaker you'll have a hard time. Understanding words in the static his hard to impossible, and one of the narrators (Bobby) has such a faint voice (without subtitles) that it's hard to get anything he says.
Obscurity and mystery are fine, but the interface and the basic mechanics must be clear. A pity, the game had an unconventional and promising appeal.
developer_response:
Hey there, sorry about the experience. Just wanted to give you an answer to the things you find unclear. 

The countdown on the mic shows your distance in metres from the thing the mic is currently picking up. It can be used to find spots of interest, or orbs to shoot.

After shooting an orb, it disappears and you will record audio. The audio can then be analyzed with your recorder.

You will see what kinds of ammo you have in your pipeline. When loading it's filled from left to right, hence the next ammo going out is on the far right on the UI.

Hidden messages are found when you adjust the playback in different speeds.

You exit the recorder by pressing Q, or use 4 to toggle.

Thanks for the feedback about Bobby's voice. 

Feel free to mail me at bugs@stroboskop.com if you have any questions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008697465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 7175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4692, 'last_played': 1631530585}
review: I got the EE editions of the original BG games in anticipation for the upcoming BG3, since Larian's D:OS2 done and turned out to be the best game I ever played. NGL when I launched BG1 it took me a single floor of the Tutorial tavern and about 20 minutes to let the game go for no less than 2 years. I've stuffed 2 PoE's, Dragon Age, NWN2, both KoTORs and other titles inbetween to come back around and I was finally gripped. Dated graphics and complicated systems were welcome this time around, and beyond - an exciting story waiting to be unveiled, and me still on Chapter 7 and almost through with the Durlag's Tower never hesitating to recommend this classic gem to you as a 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068919027', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1396488613}
review:
So first things first, i did not finish this game. I liked it, but there came a time when i said enough was enough. I gave up on the game not because it's broken, no because the stories bad, and not because it's a bad game. I stopped because i couldn't stand some design choices made by the developer. If you don't have a problem with some of the issues i have with this game, then it might be a better game then i let on.

This game is good, the stories a bit so-so (i am not a sci-fi fan, so this may not be the case for you), but there is a depth to the world that makes exploration satisfying. For an adventure game (and a sci-fi), it's not bad. Adventure games are usually sold based on their stroy, or their atmosphere and world; this one falls squarely with the interesting world brand of adventure games. It takes a serious stance to its story, so if you wanted another monkey island-ish adventure game, keep looking. The visuals are solid, and what humor there is (mainly in the form of referenceses, such as the crowbar) isn't very satisfying, but it's harmless. 

Where the game lost me is its choice on puzzle design. There comes a time when you have to do some tasks, like convince 2 robots to stop arguing. The problem i have with it is they don't give you the information for long, so you either have to write it down or memorize it. Only after writing it down can you try to solve the riddle. It's a bit backwards, where you have to work around outdated, missing, or omited mechanics to get to the puzzle before you've even had a chance to ponder it. There is a device that records important pieces of information, but what it deems as important can be hit or miss sometimes (such as the robot diologue riddles, where the riddles aren't written down). 

The game also does a very poor job of giving hints if your stuck. This problem, and a few others, are indicitive of the genre. One such problem is having puzzles where you have to guess at what the developer wanted you to use to progress. An example would be ruining soup in some adventure game, where you have mud, shoe polish, and a rat. Only one will ruin the soup, despite all of them being viable in a realist sense. 

In the end, this is an adventure game, so replayability is already low. I'd rather not waste my time reruning the same diologue trees over and over, which is what i found i had to do for the robot riddle puzzles. If I couldn't write fast enough (cus memorizing the jargen and name drops was not easy), i would have to guess and restart. There are i believe 5 riddles or so, so having to restart from the 4th on can be annoying to say the least. At this point, the game felt more like work then fun, so i gave up on it. I didn't want to put in that much effort for what i felt was not enough in return. 

You are expected to bring a lot to the table to get through the game. Good memory, write stuff down, and replay the same section over if you experiment. You will find that trying to force your way through diologue puzzles is very time consuming. If you get stuck and fall back on this, you might feel inticed to cheat (as i was). When i feel like i have to resort to a walkthrough to make progress, the game begins to feels like a chore. It's not fun when you have to use a walkthrough for an adventure game, because relying on it really takes you out of the world. Personally, i call it quits at that point, as i did here

To reiterate, this is not a bad game. It's a game with a vision that i fell outside of. If you played a lot of old-school adventure games, or you're a sci-fi fan, you might find a lot to like. If you find you didn't like older adventure games (or Daedelic's brand of adventure games, like The Dark Eye or Memoria), or you gravitate towards newer games like the Telltale brand of adventure games, this game may not be to you're liking.

If an old-school sci-fi adventure game with some of the problems of older games, as well a bit unforgiving approach to game design (in that you will solve problems for yourself, without more help then the developer deems nessassary) sound good to you, then this might be a game you will enjoy.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If anyone should wonder why the developer of the game commented on this review (i was very suprised about it, personally), it's because he questioned some of my reasons for quiting, as well as questioning why i would post a review of a game i played so little of. After being initially pissed, i thought a lot about the review and realized how many assuptions i had taken as fact. I heavily edited the review after i thought about it, namely because the initial review didn't convey what i wanted it to; this game was not for me, for the reasons listed above, but it might be the game for you depending on your tastes. 

The developer didn't harrass me (though initially i thought he had), and i am changing this review because i feel like it. Mark was a decent guy, and he responded more calmly and professionally then i thought he would. I made the changes i did because i was initially wrong, the developer earned my respect, and i had gone back over the review and found it unsatisfactory. If you think this makes my review less reliable, then so be it. You have been informed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084324200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1571536528}
review:
I bought this game as part of a bundle with the much more realised EpiStory (which has some great graphics to boot). The multiplayer is completely dead, but it could be a bit of fun with friends. However, this game has some huuuuuuge balancing problems. 

There are a few game modes where typing speed isn't sooo important, but if one player can type at 100wpm and one player types at a max of 55wpm, there's no question who is going to win - even if the 55wpm player is, say, better at coming up with words in 'Creativity' mode or has faster instincts. There is one mode where typing speed isn't a significant factor but can still decide matches - Reflection. It's variant, Tug, is still largely decided by typing speed. I just don't see any way this can be much fun with the lack of balance. 

Competition against the AI falls into two categories: way too slow, or impossibly quick, to the point where it is impossible to do things earlier than the AI. It isn't all that much fun even when the AI does match you because the match feels empty.

Typeracer is, unfortunately, way more fun.

I played it for about an hour and I don't think I'll ever touch it again. It definitely isn't worth the $2, and I'll go into exactly why with some more brutal comments as this review draws to an end.

TypeFighters is a poor realisation of a great - but largely impractical - idea. A game that uses typing as its main game mechanic? That's so cool! Typeracer is great and all, but it's not that much fun when the only game element is competing for the top 20 scores of the hour. It's just a singleplayer typing test where the results are compared against other people, and the closest it comes is to 5 people doing the same typing test at the same time. That's *almost* like competitive gameplay, but it's still way too separate. Typeracer is an ego trip - I've wanted a multiplayer typing game where there is both skill and speed involved for a long time. TypeFighters is the exact kind of game I wanted to love, but it's just gets boring too fast.

There are a bunch of modes, but once you've played them a few times, you've played them to death. There's some definite creativity here - I particularly like Tug & Reflection. If only they worked practically. Much like TypeRacer, the competition is still too separate because of the disparate typing speeds between players. It's just too imbalanced for it to be any fun, and there's no depth in the singleplayer to make it worth buying.

This game is very barren.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072479584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3652, 'last_played': 1539583687}
review:
Here are some things I had learn and play this game.  They should upgrade and fixed these thing.
1# graphics: are good, need to polish some egdes on textures , weapons, armors and props. 7/10
2# control mechanisms: are minor good, if there were a setting that allow free control of your character's movement with out 
     clipping your character to go to the target this will help a lot.( example: I lock on to an enemy and activate his/her move 
     automatically goes to that target to do the action, instead the setting will allow free control of your character and not 
     allow your character to move automatically when I activate the move if I am trying to dodge incoming area attack.) The 
     lock on also should be fix, because when I was playing My Mage, I locking on to coggweller enemy next to crispy 
     skeleton enemy. I fired at the coggweller dealing amount of damage until some reason on my 7th strike of my move set 
     it started to attack the crispy skeleton even though it wasn't in combat with me and the coggweller was still alive at 
     42% health and attacking me. I was using my keybored numbers to use my actions. This need to be fix or we will pull in 
     unwanted enemies while in combat. 5/10
3# players and characters exsprestions: are not so good, but I seen worst. As much ability to sit in chairs and not the ability 
     to sit down on ground or any where eles this should be a thing. Make up some dance move this isn't ( MJ or 
     Headbanging), also is a loop and not one action move its minor cringey. Not alot of exsprestions in face. They don't 
     even blink and blinking is some thing you should do. The thisg thats is a problem is 2D Adventure Quest Worlds has 
     some blinking at least this and this  Doesn't have blinking even for Blue Flying Eye beast in Greenguard heartwood 
     Forest. Animation of enemies or even players should have this in there animation. Its alot of work animating walking and 
     fighting, but blinking why not? When you talk to a random character you are up in there faces and not once they blink.
     Last thing is seeing face changing to sad, mad, scared, happy or even silly while they do action in the story or player 
     activating them. Its upseting story have animation while talking but can't tel if they are mad or excited for there friend 
     dying in the story line. this is minor exsprestion in storyline. 3/10
4# lack of skills: good, but still waiting. As much for skills, there aren't enough skills to unlock or even none to begin with 
     only classes which doesn't help if you class can't heal with a skill or have a cool move to reduce even more damage. 
     there is only 5 move set that is kinda sad do to  a good amount of RPG quest games online is doing, But if you can give 
     us abilities to unlock if we level Up. 4/10
5# Changing texture on weapon: good and still going up. If you have the time to Changing texture on new armor with the 
      same 3d mesh why not do it for the weapons, I keep seeing the color change but texture of it not changing. (exmple: 
      brought my self a new sword, but they texture is still the same and not seeing anything different only the color change 
      to dark green even my old sword was light green.) 4/10

There are alot of things this game should be upgrading and fix, but only the people who played this game and people who want to make this game even better can only do it. 

Only supporting this game or even other games will help games to grow. Negative comments like ( THIS GAME SUCK, this game gave me aids, this game is crappy or a waist of time playing this don't play it) will not make it better.
Game Developer need real comments that also can help them to make games fun. We might play games for a living or for fun, but they are working making games for us to play. They give us  free to play to try games out and if we want to upgrade our accounts we pay extra, but behind the scene help them to live and slowly upgrade the game.

So is this game good? A good game is hard to tell in other people perspective if they play it. The reason why, we are all different and have different taste in games. what makes a good game is supporting the game developer and there work.

for me I still play it, but still being Upgraded.
developer_response: Hello! Thank you so much for your review. AdventureQuest 3D is inspired by our original games AdventureQuest and DragonFable and is very different from AQWorlds. The devs are constantly working on fixing and improving issues and releasing updates/patches almost weekly. This has been a constant balance as an indie game company with a small staff.  We also have a Game Plan posted here that is updated every Monday - https://aq3d.com/game-plan/. We very much appreciate your feedback!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051297137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 36259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1705771064}
review:
Beware: shady company that will take your cash and leave you hanging.

I ordered Horizons after previously owning the base game (not connected to Steam). The product actication key was already used, meaning the game can't be launched and just continously requests an update.

Checked to see if anyone else had this problem and saw plenty of examples, not a lot of resolutions. I contacted Frontier support, they didn't help and insisted there was no problem. Hard to tell how common this is: astonishingly diehard fanboys attack anyone making a complaint over official or most third party forums.

Steam, as always, was excellent and refunded the DLC cost after a few days. Lesson learned. Too bad Frontier will be keeping the cash from when I first bought the base game. 

It really looks E:D had the potential to be the definitive space opera game. Persistent bugs, laggy servers and now incredibly terrible support put it in an untimely grave.



Edit 11/15/2021: Tried the game again since the dlc is free and automatically installed now.  The engineers, which are mandatory for setting up a competitive ship, are heavily bugged with two of them being apparently impossible to unlock.  I LOVED this game when it released, so its astonishing that the devs could mess it up as bad as they have.

Edit 4/3/2023.  Why on earth did I try to play this again.  Now the automatically installed Horizons dlc will get you stuck in an updating loop, meaning the launcher never actually loads the game.  There is, as always, no support from Frontier.  Please do not buy a Frontier product, they are scammers.
developer_response:
Hello,

If you've experienced issues in accessing a purchase of the Horizons Season Pass, we would be happy to help you locate this. Please do contact us via support ticket with your order number and account details, and we'll look to get you fixed up as soon as possible. 

https://support.frontier.co.uk/login.php?page=contact

Thanks!

- CMDR Atlas
Frontier Support Wing

author: {'steamid': '76561198160485301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 226641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1457, 'playtime_at_review': 76319, 'last_played': 1710565551}
review:
This product is not a game.

This is a spaceship art program.
If you've always wanted to build spaceships with a limited, almost-satisfying array of shapes, this is the game for you.

But there is no gameplay here.  The self-proclaimed "survival" mode amounts to simply asphyxiating eternally because you can't find ice, then getting angry after 8 hours of asphyxiating because you can't find iron, so you can't build anything.
If you like painting?  This is gonna be your new heaven.
If you wanted to play a game?  Don't buy this game.

When I bought the game, many years ago, I paid $25 for the potential for a game.
I was cheated.  This is no game.  This is an art program.  An art program in the same way that Microsoft paint is an art program.

I wanted this game to be a tactical space-combat simulator.
What I got was Garry's Mod, but in space.

TLDR: If you want to build spaceships, buy the game.  If not, don't.
developer_response:
Hello, ZDuke.

Thank you very much for writing this review. We really appreciate your feedback and all of the other comments we receive from our awesome community.

We encourage you to submit any additional feedback here: https://support.keenswh.com/spaceengineers

Thanks again for your detailed feedback.

Kind regards,

Keen Software House

author: {'steamid': '76561198872277458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1606008418}
review: I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son Tim, who is 36 now. My son got this game for Festivus in 2021 from his uncle Frank, so we installed it on his Macintosh and he started playing. By the end of the first day he had 29 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends playing bum darts or just watching Xhamster. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to join him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died in a hot noodle accident. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside of our bunker. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories. it was truly “a Festivus for the rest of us”

author: {'steamid': '76561198049382433', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 30699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16891, 'last_played': 1711121061}
review:
This is not much of a recommend or not recommend, but more of a simple review that should help both the developers and players gauge things that could be improved as well as determine whether or not to play this.

To start off, never treat this game like a serious competitor to great titles like The Elder Scrolls Online or Final Fantasy 14. While those two, for example, do require some time investment to enjoy all that they have to offer, AdventureQuest 3D is more or less a time-killer. You're not playing the game to be completely serious, but because you have free time and this game is conveniently easy on computers and free, and as such, occupy that niche perfectly.

The Artix Entertainment brand of games have never been serious and have been good at being there when there's time to kill, and this game is no other. Much like their flash games, AQ3D maintains the trademark of constantly updating content every week, with no end in sight. Whether this is off-putting is independent to the player. 

The active story, as this review is written, accompanies the main player as a champion for Death itself, with Death's key stolen by a Voidking known as Vane. Your goal is to reach Vane, take the key back, and return it to it's rightful owner. Reusing their iconic characters from previous games, from Faith to Dage, from Rayst to Zhoom, their returns may hype you up or incite cries of repetitiveness. That is independently dependent on the player experience and not the majority.

The gameplay is about as cookie-cutter as standing RPGs can get. If you've even played a standard MMO before, AQ3D's gameplay is literally the basics. They can be forgiven for that as well as their graphics, given that they're mostly known for their 2D expertise, and are slowly improving on their art in a 3D space. Eventually, we can expect high quality art for many items in the future, given they break the mold and work on improving and improving as time goes on.

As with all free games, they will have a cash shop. It's inevitable, and telling any developer to not have one is like telling them to not make money off providing a free service. My only recommendation regarding DragonCoins, Guardian upgrades, and anything else that costs real money is to avoid aggressively marketing them. In this era of gaming, it can be considered predatory and desperate, and the majority of games with microtransactions are already being boycotted for being aggressive with them. It would be the perfect opportunity to innovate and be the leader in a new, less aggressive means of making the money to afford the salaries of the hard-working folks helping with updates, as well as ensure the servers remain affordable. It will also unite the paying customer and the free-to-play playerbase together, instead of dividing them simply because one can spend money whilst the other can't afford to.

All in all, whoever reads this review can decide by themselves on whether AdventureQuest 3D is worth playing. It's a niche game for those with time to spare, and remains on the same podium competing with other games that do not require a massive time investment. While the game does provide some speciality treatment for paying customers as perks and it can dissuade those trying out for free, it is just another RPG that managed to avoid being the cash cow that has ruined games like Wizard101, games that require excessive financial and time investment to catch up.

One question before I end the review: Thinking of giving this game a try or passing on it? Time's a wasting.
developer_response:
Hello. Thank you for your review. We appreciate your feedback!

AQ3D is not pay to win - none of the items that can make your character stronger are sold for money or micro-currency. There are thousands of items you can gain for free and from playing the game. The game is free to play and we do offer different items and packages you can purchase to help support the game, but the devs always make sure there are plenty of items you can earn for free or purchase from gold. Only cosmetic items are offered for micro-currency which are just the items that make you look different but have no affect on your character strength. 

We are sorry that some of our players can be jerks, this is something that is always going to be a reality in a MMO. You can always ignore and report players in game. We have a party system and a friend system where you can meet other players and player with other people you know who can help you in game. We are also working on guilds. 

Those players how pledged via our Kickstarter are the ones who helped make this game exist. We wanted to make sure these players were rewarded appropriately in game which is why special in game items, features and such were offered. None of the rewards provided are 'pay to win.' 

The devs are constantly working on fixing and improving issues and releasing updates/patches almost weekly. This has been a constant balance as an indie game company with a small staff.  We also have a Game Plan posted here that is updated every Monday - https://aq3d.com/game-plan/. 

We hope you continue to check out the games' progress in the future, especially once the devs are able to add more content and the game is officially released.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985722163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 691, 'last_played': 1462692118}
review:
Overall: Very hard to review as parts are excellent but other parts are very frustrating. Too much irritation in its current state to recommend, I simply don't want to play it that much. Please note every negative review has huge downvotes no matter how reasoned or fair it is, the community here has some pretty hostile elements (although plenty of good people as well).

So the GOOD:

Fun combat, good customisation, great look and feel, satisfying feeling to winning a battle. Nicely polished story and cutscenes, good acting, and a lot of care and attention has been put into it.

The BAD:

All of which is set against the mission design which is very disappointing by comparison. The moment that it isnt a fleet vs fleet battle the influence of random chance becomes much too high. Playing a planetary bombardment mission? The locations randomly spawn too far away with too little time to get there even though you positioned in the middle to give yourself the best chance, no chance of winning the mission. Assasination missions where your ships don't even fire a shot before the enemy has escaped and you fail the mission. Escort missions where one time the enemies are nowhere near you and its a walkover, and the next time they are all over you and there is no chance of victory. Data stealing missions which are really poor. 

Judging this game as fleet vs fleet combat only then its a good recommendation, some balance issues but thats understandable.

Judging this game on the campaign where you lose missions without any chance of success and there are big penalties to progressing the campaign from that point on, its highly frustrating having so much be random with the player skill not being able to mitigate, I don't enjoy playing it at all. I like hard but fair games, difficult isn't the problem, its the lack of correlation between player effort/skill/strategy and the results you get.

So overall its a negative, too much of the game is not fun to play and has not been designed well enough, which is really unnecessary as the core mechanics of spaceships fighting each other is excellent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000245352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 8815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1564, 'last_played': 1643338971}
review: Build a colony to survive in space, avoid starvation, loss of power, or the other fears of dying in space.  Build up your colony before you can build and maintain a meteor laser, and watch meteors destroy your production building.  Encounter a windstorm or solar flares and watch your last engineer die as they try to fix your last solar panel producing power for what little is left of your colony(or if you forgot to build a security center)....   Haven't made it too far, but the game really does remind me of the game "banished" in a space format.  It's easy and fun, you just have to figure out how the AI builds as close as it can first if you are laying out construction everywhere and just go from there... When i got this game there was a lot of love for it on release day, and a day after there's alot of hate.  But I for one am hooked on it... it's simple to grasp and fun, perfect recipe for a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071613043', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2042, 'last_played': 1645886366}
review:
Well... This game is unfair. I know and understand RNG but this is way too unfair. I have almost 200 hours in darkest dungeon and I have never felt as frustrated. 
A random dice roll between 1-100 is not how you design a game. This isnt about probability, this is just pure luck. My player with 60 ball control gets dispossesed by a defender with 30 defence just because I rolled a 1 and he rolled a 15. Not once, but time and time again. I have played almost full 5 seasons hoping it will get better once my players improve but no it doesnt get better. Even with an easy RNG setting it still feels extrmeley frustrating.  
On top of that the player progression is extrmely slow. 
I dont mind games with RNG mechanics but in this one I feel my strategy has no implication as my players dice roll is mostly unfair. 
It seems more luck that strategy. 

I really want to like this game but cant.
The devs should study the RNG mechanics of Darkest Dungeon and Xcom in detail so that it feels more strategy and less luck. Maybe introduce the critical chance concept or a skill set based dice roll instead of a random dice roll. The RNG mechanics need work
developer_response:
Hey! I regret you fill disappointed. But from your review, I feel (maybe wrongly) that you don't use the skills often enough in your tactics. 

Your usual attributes are only a basic layer of the tactics. But you should combine them with skills and other advanced technics (like crossing) to make your team shine.

For example, when you combine a midfielder with the Long pass and a universal forward with Cannon Shot - you will see how many there are possibilities to score. Just learn how to use Cannon Shot. Same with other skills and mechanics,

You can ask on the forum (https://steamcommunity.com/app/375530/discussions/) - other experienced players will gladly help. Or just read their tips.

Hope you will give the game another chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042275652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1696447177}
review:
While it's agreeable that the game is fairly buggy in some areas, once you get the hang of it, it's a great time-sink. It may look simple at first, but as you keep making more and more swords, with different designs, and you ACTUALLY get better at it, something kind of pushes you to keep going, to make more swords and to become the best blacksmith in the realm!

However, if you're looking for a simple game that will take you by the hand through every step of the process, you're in for a surprise. The tutorial works to an extent, giving you a gist of what you need to do to forge your own sword at first, but unfortunately, it is not as helpful as it should be. I struggled at first a little to learn how to temper a sword and to learn damascus patterns, etc. 

But if you're patient enough to experiment, or to look up the answers to your doubts, this game is a great time sink.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087730263', 'num_games_owned': 925, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1674546663}
review:
I can understand those that don't like this game or get super frustrated, I love this game and got very frustrated and lost. I don't like these types of games but this one clicks so well with me, the story and voice acting along with a world that feels desolate yet full of life and activity.

I highly recommend this game but for those frustrated with adventure games maybe just watch a youtube playthrough instead.
developer_response: It's true -- we feel like complex puzzles and inventory puzzles are a big part of what makes an adventure game, but many players find those things frustrating, and probably should skip Primordia if so. :)  There are other more purely narrative adventures (sometimes unfairly criticized as "walking simulators") out there like Unavowed for players more interested in just watching a story unfold without puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051939071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1531591646}
review:
TL;DR: the moneymaking schemes from Wavedash seems suspicious and that annoys me

I was really excited for icons combat arena, and i was surprised to see it was free on its "official release" (open beta), and its even marketed as a free platform fighter https://i.imgur.com/2mqRWn8.png, however, of the seven characters, three are playable, as it turns out, the game actually costs $25 USD and that's how you unlock "all current and future characters". Another thing to be found on the store is essentially a deluxe edition at $40 USD, you get a beta skin and a beta icon, as well as 5 portal packs. What are portal packs? I have no idea, the game doesn't directly tell you on the store page but I'm making an assumption that they are more or less loot boxes. You can buy these portal packs at a minimum of 2 for $3, at most 55 for $50, and looking further into the store it seems you can get player selection cursors, player icons, skins/alt colors, emotes, voice lines, sprays, victory poses, and platforms that you spawn on when you lose a stock. Along with the loot system is an in game currency system where you can use "Spectra" to unlock the mentioned loot drops, it appears loot drops have rarities; common, uncommon, and legendary. I'm sure its possible to earn the IGC and lootboxes through playing online, so I tried two quick play sessions, and was correct in my assumption of getting a lootbox through leveling up and im probably also right on getting Spectra through duplicate drops. This ludicrous system of loot drops seemed immediately familiar to me when i first saw it and instantly reminded me of Blizzard's system of loot drops in games such as Overwatch and Heroes of the Storm. It becomes more apparent when the icons and sprays mimic Overwatch's types of icons and sprays, "cute sprays", "8-bit sprays", and minimalistic icons are apparent, obviously these are just art styles, and are probably (maybe) coincidental, but the comparisons are there, and still equally worrying. It should be noted that I never closely followed the games development (I did heavily at first, through the announcement of Ashani and Kidd, but dropped off from there, likely because I forgot about it), so if all of this was previously announced then I wouldn't know but it was a big, dissapointing, surprise to me.

Now, onto the ACTUAL gameplay and again, as I was limited to three of seven characters, I can only really talk about those fighters, I havent had much time to play these characters much as of wirting this review since I felt the above paragraph was important to write as soon as possible, though so far it feels about how a platform fighter should feel, for the most part, the game is in open beta so I'll give Wavedash a chance to fix things such as netcode being inconsistant, a weird input buffer that makes the game feel stiff, and odd stage design that makes recovering feel weird, maybe im just bad at the game though :~) ;

Ashani - A pretty close take on C.Falcon, she has a neat meter build mechanic that improves her neutral special, it loses charge over time unless it's maxxed out which makes her style of play "mandatorily  agressive," and I think is a nice addition of the C.Falcon archtype, my perfered character of the three to use, she also has a very cool design and i think i love her

Kidd - A close take on Melee Fox/Falco, he has a slow fox laser, a "heavy" phantasm, a short shine (of which can be jump canceled and can be multishined), and more or less has Fox's recovery with the active hitbox and slow startup, but long distance. Because of his slower lasers, its difficult to do even one shorthop laser but thats okay. His design is kinda odd to look at but its still refreshing nevertheless 

Xana - A definitely unique take on Ganondorf (Brawl/Sm4sh), mostly, surprisingly, a grapple character, which is interesting to see in this sort of fighting game, she has a counter grab, a side special grab, and an "up/down" recovery, her neutral special is a lariat, which can be used for stage control. Her design is very much like Zarya's from Overwatch, but she's an alien, its still a good design, just seems a bit lazy to me.

Universal mechanics- Directional air dodging (Melee style), sheild/rolling/spot dodging, and directional influence are all immediately and obviously found in the game, which is to be expected in a platform fighter inspired by melee, you can wavedash, you can waveland, but ledge canceling, while probably would be useless in this game, isn't obviously present, which is fine, most if not all aerial moves are relatively lagless and can be SHFF'd easily, L-canceling isnt in the game which is also fine, it shouldn't be a neccessary mechanic, I think its better off not in the game as long as the aerials arent as laggy as they are in Melee, so I don't miss the lack of L-canceling, something similar to an extended dash dance can be done, and dash dancing in general is easy to use, there is a new, unique mechanic in this game which i can only describe as an advancing guard, using special while sheilding, the player can push away opponents at the cost of their "sheild life", the push away isnt too significant, and I think it could use a bit of reworking, as it is also sorta hard to do anything afterwards, aside from jumping away (it is possible to jump oos, I should add)

Overall some hit/hurtboxes could use some tweeking, its possible to get weird reverse hitboxes on some characters but I expect as much from an open beta game

Finally, the game's art direction is pretty good in my opinion, some effects could use some work (such as Kidd's jet smoke), but that comes down to subjective opinion.

I'd say to give this game a chance, if it werent for the very poor practices with lootboxes and the method of unlocking what I assumed to be the begining roster, if you want to main Ashani, Kidd, or Xana, then go for it, hopefully youll be able to play the game for free, forever, but for someone like me who wanted to try Weishan or Zhurong, I would rather have to pay for the game upfront, than have to look at these characters behind a lock screen each time i want to play the game, if the closed beta had access to these characters why dosent the open beta have access to them? 

I hope to see improvements to these money making schemes but I doubt I will, I'll probably play here and there and then completely drop the game when Smash Ultimate comes out, overall I'm dissapointed in this first look at the game. I would definitely pay full price for this game if lootboxes were removed, access to all characters were available (aside from a few DLC characters), and unlocking things such as skins and emotes were obtained through more than just paying for them and playing QP forever. I understand this game can technically be completely be F2P, but this method of trying to acheive that kinda sucks a lot.
developer_response:
This review is TREMENDOUSLY helpful. Thank you for taking the time to write it in such detail!

Reading through, it looks like your concerns primarily sit with the F2P system. Is that correct? We're hearing this loud and clear from the community, and Early Access is about evolving until the F2P system is exactly right.

For now, based on community feedback we are working on these areas:

[b]- Earning spectra[/b]: We will be adding several more ways to add spectra, so you can earn it directly through playing. We want players to see faster, better progress towards the specific items they want in the shop.
[b]-Unlocking a character faster[/b]: In the next few weeks, we will have new tools for the designers to add character unlocks to different milestones in the game, like an early levelup
[b]-Adding ways to try out characters[/b]: Adding tech to give players more ways to try out a character before buying one, such as in training mode. (The feature here may change, but that's an example of how we're thinking about it based on your concerns.)

Some of these may take some time, but you'll see the first efforts of this coming online soon.

Thanks again for writing this. If you have any additional thoughts, please let us know.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078266523', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1558126851}
review:
This game installs an app that runs in the backgrounds and continuously checks for updates to the game. It autostarts with the system and does NOT uninstall when you uninstall the game. In fact there is NO uninstaller for this program AT ALL. You have to manually disable it in autostart then locate and delete it in your appdata folder. It completely disgusting. 
Oh, also the game is a bland pay to win arena shooter with cars that handle bad and extremely uninteresting design. 
My main reason for getting the game was that I figured it'd be fun to customize cars. But the rate at which you get parts - and how incredibly boring those parts you get are - made that very much not worth it. 
This game is not worth the time or effort. Leave this page and dont think about this game again.
developer_response: Hello Mint Boa! Players can disable the autostart app in the beginning and it won't activate again. The way the vehicle handle depends on their construction, weight and other qualities like the type of chassis selected for the build. The parts available to player vary and can be unlocked, got in the battle, crafted from other parts or bought on the ingame market or in packs. So the variety grow with the player's progress in the game and the number of parts and decorations one can use grows with the player's level too, so they become flashier and more versatile when one leaves the first few levels. We keep adding parts and decorations to the game to give players a wider variety of possible building elements and some of the player's creations are really awe inspiring. They can be seen in the game Exhibition where players can store and showcase their vehicles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198429756732', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 4099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 13, 'playtime_at_review': 1627, 'last_played': 1711689441}
review:
Surprisingly, this game has an active community, and they're very welcoming. The dev are is active in implementing regular updates. The game has a decent player base (played on SEA). I often see other players around. It's playable for both party and solo. The gameplay is not too complex for an MMO in general, it's pretty balance, I like it personally. The combat is decent for a cross-platform game, and I feel comfortable playing it on both PC and mobile. As for the story, I never take it too seriously. It doesn't matter since I still can enjoy the combat. Graphic isn't a big deal for me. There are many repetitive quests in each zone, but I can still enjoy them to get better gears. And of course, it's f2p friendly.

Additionally, this game has 4 class for starter. You can unlock new a lot of class after it such, ranger, necromancer, pirate, ninja, more. You can freely change classes whenever you want.

It's just alright imo. Definitely worth to try.
developer_response: Hey there, thank you so much for your 53+ hours of time spent in-game. We really appreciate you taking the time to reach out to us and leave us a review. Thanks again for your detailed, thoughtful review! Thanks again for taking the time to contact our team. Battle On!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035059251', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1526252128}
review:
I purchased this game a few years ago because I was really excited about a new version of Dungeon Keeper. I have tried playing multiple times and every time I run into some game-halting bug. Each time I try playing, I ending up stopping to wait for the bugs to get fixed. When I first started the game was in early access so I decided to cut them some slack. But now it's the full version of the game and I still can't play because of these bugs that basically make gameplay impossible.

I really want to like this game. It's a fun concept and the devs have obviously done a ton of work on it and made an almost-great product. But the focus seems to be entirely on adding content rather than making sure the existing content works. It doesn't matter how great your graphics are, how many levels you have, and how many different rooms and spells and monsters you've thrown into the mix. If people can't play because of bugs, your game is bad.
developer_response:
Hi Flopperz,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2015. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

Most importantly the performance and stability of the game has been now greatly improved after thousands of man-hours of development from our two-man code team. 

There is also now the second expansion, the Crucible survival mode, that was free for all! 

If you've not tried the game for a while now might be a great time for you to jump in and see how far we've come since release! We'd love to hear what you think now.

Cheers,
Cian

review: This review will echo some of the other reviews out there. The idea of this game is really cool, the videos in the steam store look great. The mini games are really too simple and not really pertaining to baking and should really be done away with. The new delivery driving system is really ghetto (GTA 1/2) with really touchy controls, really not cool and not enjoyable. This game has a lot of potential but at this time I cannot recommend it. If the devs make some changes to these issues then I'll happily re-review.
developer_response: Thank youi for playing Bakery Simulator. We are sad you didn't like it. Bakery Simulator is more of casual and relaxing baking simulation game. For this reason driving and minigames can feel too simple. We would like to know what are those issues you are mentioning. Just to let you know, the driving part can be skipped. Which mini games you didn't like? If you like to talk more with us and the community, here is our discord: https://discord.com/invite/kYpZmkBAgc. There are many players sharing with their suggestions and feedback about Bakery Simulator. Hopefully, one day you can come back and have fun with the game. Cheers. Gaming Factory team.

author: {'steamid': '76561198342023712', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 88, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1712432447}
review:
Been using PowerBeats since it's early stages for a couple of years now on my Quest 2. Just recently purchased the steam version to support the developers. Great workout tool, makes cardio fun and not tedious.  The steam version is pretty much the same as the quest store one, with a little sharper graphics of course.  The only thing the quest version has over this is the ability to use passthrough.
    My favorite thing about PowerBeats is that you can easily use your own custom music through mp3 or flac.  No conversion required as with other games, just point PowerBeats to your music folder. The generator also does a good job with your custom songs. That's important to me, because the music never gets stale and I can work out to songs I know and love.  Definitely recommend this whether you're already into fitness or just starting out and looking into VR to get fit.
developer_response:
Thank you so much for your thoughtful review and for supporting PowerBeatsVR through both the Quest 2 and Steam platforms! We're thrilled to hear that the app has become a valuable tool in making your cardio workouts enjoyable and that you appreciate the sharper graphics on Steam, along with the unique feature set of each version.

The ability to use custom music without the need for conversion is indeed one of the highlights of PowerBeatsVR, and we're glad it enhances your workout experience by allowing you to exercise to your favorite tunes. It's fantastic to know that the music generator meets your expectations with custom songs, keeping your sessions fresh and motivating.

Your recommendation for both fitness enthusiasts and beginners looking to get into shape through VR is greatly appreciated. We're committed to continuously improving the app and providing an engaging and effective workout experience for all users.

If you have any suggestions, ideas, or specific feedback on how we can make PowerBeatsVR even better, please don't hesitate to share. Your input is invaluable as we strive to evolve and tailor the app to our community's needs.

Thank you once again for your support and for being part of the PowerBeatsVR community. Keep moving and grooving!

author: {'steamid': '76561198280509481', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1588185748}
review:
Welcome yo the "Litova's Honest Reviews"
Today I decided to start reviewing the games that I have tested or played enough to tell about me experience.
Weeeeellll.......
This game isn't the one I would recommend.
Here are some reasons why:
     a)
        Combat system is really bland. "Uncooked" as I would say... To put it nicely... NOT FUN.  Just spam 1 or other three keys without even thinking and trying and you will come out a winner. That's it. 
     b)
        Skill Trees are non-existent in this game. Spawn in -> Choose class-> Five or six abilities till the end of the game. Nothing more. If the game did persuade you in expanding your skills and abilities it would have become a lot more interesting.
     c)
        Farming is an esential element in any MMO RPG. This game is an example of a poorly executed one. Farming is not fun at all and in a mix with a bad combat system is almost fatal for the gameplay. 
     d)
        Quest are all repetative as HELL. Kill some mobs->Bring them back->kill some mobs->Bring them back->Talk to someone->Come back-> REPEAT. The most "CREATIVE" one was to water flowers by cliking on them. It was also not fun
      e)
        Graphics are ofcourse a problem. A game that young having graphics of a game of the start of the previous decade is not just dissgraceful, but also sad.
       VERDICT:
         The game is still in an "Early Access" mode, where things can and ofcourse will change and the game is quite promissing in it's way. But the problems are currently overwhelmingly fatal and are a big threat to the project, that is  really immportant for people, who grew on this developer's games (Adventure Quest World) and who do fill nostalgic about this game.
developer_response: Thank you so much for your review! The devs are constantly working on fixing and improving issues and releasing updates/patches almost weekly. This has been a constant balance as an indie game company with a small staff. The devs are focusing on the grinding, adding class skills, improving combat, quests, etc. We also have a Game Plan posted here that is updated every Monday - https://aq3d.com/game-plan/.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054759713', 'num_games_owned': 1323, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1574195626}
review:
Note: I received a review key from PCGamingWiki for the purpose of reviewing the PC port. 

Edit: The game now supports framerates higher than 30fps. Thanks, devs!

I haven't played much of it, but from what I've played, I mostly like it. It's like something you'd find on the PS2, but with slightly better graphics. I hear it's a bit short, and the season pass is definitely not worth $30, but overall, I think it's fine, and mostly doesn't deserve the large amount of negative reviews from Chinese players (although I can understand their frustration given that Monkey King is a rather famous IP there). The reason I say mostly is that the PC port is pretty bad. Despite running on Unreal Engine 4, the game is locked at 30fps, and for a game running on that engine, and being an action platformer and all, it's not ideal. There is also zero graphics options whatsoever besides resolution and brightness/gamma, and while there is forced temporal anti-aliasing, it could have done better in that department. Also, the English voice acting is kinda bad, so choose another language for the voice acting.

review:
A brilliant game that has me coming back to it time and time again...

Unfortunately, I like to play with my friends, which is where the game falls flat on its face. Although this game is more stable in multiplayer than it's ever been, it still has MASSIVE issues.

If you can grab for cheap and you can forgive the bugs then go for it. Otherwise avoid. If you are planning on starting on a planet with friends and exploring the star system, well.. you should probably give up on that idea now. Once you get big rovers, and large ships going.. with biggish bases, things go downhill fast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002512132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1648445830}
review:
If you think this review is too long, you're not going to like the game.

For this review, I'm not going to focus too much on the gameplay, since it's not really the focus of the game itself.  I'll just say that this game is somewhere between a visual novel and a choose-your-own-adventure game.  There's only one save file and you have no control over when it saves, you have three lives to lose, and once you lose them, your only option is to start a new game (though you can start from the beginning of any of the game's three acts that you have previously reached--though from a new state, not with the same attributes you had before).  It's honestly not what I would call "fun" in and of itself, but it [i]does[/i] add more weight to the decisions you make, and since you're always making new decisions, that makes the overall game stronger.

(Some early-game advice, if you want it: Although it's probably possible to beat the game on your first playthrough, [i]you[/i] are not going to accomplish that.  Rather than make your initial goal to be to reach the end of the game, instead, make your first goal be to reach the milestones that give you bonuses on future playthroughs: Focus on hunting one type of animal per area until you learn the animal's "way", and focus on completing the harder, longer sidequests to earn the tarot cards.  Once you've died a few times, you'll also know what choices NOT to make on future playthroughs.)

I'm also not going to focus on the game's writing, since you have no idea what I consider good writing or whether it matches your own preferences.  I can say that the writing is poetic, describing a pre-civilization world that [i]would[/i] look familiar to us, except it's being described using terms that the narrative never outright explains, but expects us to pick up through the context of how those words are used.  And I think that's neat, but I don't really have enough background with this type of story to say whether it pulls off this style of writing better than other stories of its type.

Rather, I'm going to focus on this game's philosophy, since the game is nothing BUT philosophy from beginning to end.

Growing up, I was interested in philosophy because I was interested in ethics.  I wanted to make sure that I was doing the right thing, as much as it was within my capacity to do so, and philosophy helps make it clear that just because something [i]feels[/i] right in your gut, it may have indirect or long-term consequences that you don't immediately see.  Same thing for things that initially feel wrong--sometimes there's good reasons to be doing something that appear wrong on the surface, or maybe sometimes you have to choose between two evils and it's better to know which one at least leads down a path with good potential.  The more I learned about ideas like this, the more I felt like I was coming to a better understanding of what "true morality" was.

But the more I followed people who approached the same lines of thought, the more I started noticing something.  Once you have a full enough understanding of philosophy, you can use words to justify literally any action you can take, no matter what it is.  Not everything is a virtue, but there are enough virtues that are commonly accepted [i]as[/i] virtues that you can boil any decision down to a conflict between two or more of those virtues, at which point you can always say "Well, who am I to say which of these virtues is the most valuable one?"  In other words, it started feeling to me like philosophy was really just an exercise in arguing yourself into inaction as the "wisest, most reasoned" path.  Not to mention that looking at things this way basically also made true morality inaccessible to anybody who wasn't intelligent/considerate/resourceful enough to look at things from all angles like this.  I lost my taste for this way of thinking about things.

I bring this up because Golden Treasure is ENTIRELY "view the world from all possible angles, from the vantage point of any value system you could possibly have," but I love it.

Although I don't know that I'd say that this game addresses my issues with this line of thought in a direct sense, I think it does acknowledge them in spirit.  It doesn't send the message that inaction is a viable path, because there are moments where you're forced to choose between multiple opposing, but equally good, philosophies, or else die--but at the same time, it also doesn't judge you for choosing death.

It also doesn't try to frame things as if every decision is equally good, because even though it's exploring lots of different ideas, it clearly frames SOME of those ideas as being more beneficial or harmful than others.  But at the same time, it acknowledges that it's the right of every living being to fight for its own values, and to me that implies that even though the game is fighting for its own values, you're more than justified to fight back against whatever those values are.  (This is perhaps highlighted by the fact that human beings are basically portrayed as the main antagonists of the game, albeit with the level of nuance that you would expect from the type of story I'm describing.)

I think what's special to me about Golden Treasure: The Great Green is that it represents what it was that I wanted philosophy to be.  Morality may be an inherently paradoxical concept, but I still want to be able to explore the beauty inherent within it.  When I feel constrained by pursuing the objectives of my own life, I want to know that there are other ways of living that I may never have even considered--and that even if I never get the chance to experience them, that at least someone else is, or will.  I want to be able to believe that all life has value and a place in the world, even the life that I, in my current state, with my current values, see as immoral.  I don't know that I have the strength/weakness necessary to truly believe that, but just the idea that it's a possibility helps me move forward.

If most or all of this applies to you as well, I definitely recommend the game.  For the other 99% of you, just download the demo.  I don't know, make your own judgment, I'm not your mom.
developer_response:
MC Buffalo... Thank you.

Not everything you had to say was to my benefit, perhaps, and yet I feel as if you have truly seen my art, and to have one's art truly seen is to be truly, deeply happy.

-Ludwig
