author: {'steamid': '76561197988300205', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1437863349}
review:
Does not work at all for me on my Mac Pro desktop.  (A "Macbook Pro" is a laptop, a "Mac Pro" is a desktop.)

I just get a black screen and the audio.

The developers said in January that they were working on a fix.  It's July.  That must be a very difficult fix!  Given that other games using Unity work fine, I assume they don't plan to fix it, since it won't affect future sales at all...

Oh well.  It was a promising game, too.
developer_response:
Hi Plambert,

Sorry to hear about the issues you've been facing. 

I've had a look around our forums and I've found another report of someone suffering from issues on Mac OSX, we are investigating but we're not aware of any wide reaching issues with the OS X build.

If you'd like to have your issue investigated as well as it appears to be related please post the information requested in [url=https://forum.subterraneangames.com/threads/please-read-how-to-report-a-bug.4689/]this thread[/url] in the recent [url=https://forum.subterraneangames.com/threads/game-will-not-launch-on-mac.8630/]bug thread[/url]

It's quite possible with regards to the fixes promised in January that those were made and resolved the vast majority of issues but some corner cases still remain. The more information we get on these the better we can address them.

Truly sorry for the inconvenience and we appreciate your help in resolving this issue.

Cheers,

Lee

author: {'steamid': '76561198918814196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1643870822}
review: ran like shit, and ive played the most recent and intensive games on max setting running fine
developer_response:
Hi solstice003! I'm sorry to hear that you've been experiencing poor performance in The Crew 2. I can understand how frustrating this would be.  First off, please ensure that your PC meets [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-us/help/the-crew-2/connectivity-and-performance/article/system-requirements-for-the-crew-2/000063461]system requirements[/url] for the game. If it's looking good there, let's address the performance drops. I recommend completing the steps in our dedicated [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-gb/help/the-crew-2/connectivity-and-performance/article/improving-game-performance/000063456]performance guide[/url] along with the in-article-linked [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-gb/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/troubleshooting-technical-issues-on-pc/000061047]basic pc troubleshooting steps[/url]. If you continue having issues and have two GPUs on your computer, please double check that the game is using your main GPU instead of an integrated GPU as this could certainly cause a slow down/stutters/drops in FPS. 

Should the issue persist, I encourage you to reach out to our team on the [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-gb/help/contact#en-GB]Support Portal[/url] and provide your [url=https://support.ubisoft.com/en-US/Article/000061449]system files[/url] so that the technical team can further look into this with you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198201368746', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1678374703}
review:
Thee entire prologue available at the moment is a conditional training of the player in all the basic mechanics of the game. 
First, they explain to us how to check the documents, then they show us where to rest, how to cut tires and seats in search of contraband, where to put criminals, and so on. 
After completing the training, all this seems very obvious and understandable, but the player would definitely not be able to guess the many gameplay features on his own, so the training deserves special praise. 
Moreover, you need to understand that the checkpoint post is not everything that is implemented in this simulator. 
We’ll also have to travel by car, catch villains, and even shoot from a pistol.

The most important thing, of course, is to find the smugglers who want to trick you and smuggle something across the border that cannot be smuggled. 
To prevent this, the player needs to inspect the documents of the citizen and his transport. 
These are two completely different processes, which are connected with each other. 
First, the player must take the person’s passport and other documents, starting to verify the data with each other. 
It is necessary to verify the name and surname in all provided documents, compare the expiry date of the passport with today, compare the stamp and background of the passport with the official data for a specific country.

All the necessary data for comparison is available in the border guard’s notebook – there are indicated all the parameters that need to be paid attention to when evaluating the documents, there is a list of all currently available countries and all the data we need are indicated – what stamps can be, what passport colors are used in this country.
Accordingly, if a person has one country indicated, and builds a seal from another, then it is worth taking a closer look at it and, of course, not letting it cross the border.
There are actually many such subtleties, but in an hour you will understand them at a glance.

It is important to clarify that our border guard has a stamina parameter, which is spent every time you compare parameters in documents using mouse clicks. 
However if you recheck everything several times or miss the mark, then by the end of the working day your endurance will end, and you will have to compare names, document numbers and seals by yourself, by eye.
However, this is even more interesting – there is no sense of casualness.
Moreover, it makes no sense, for example, to spend stamina comparing names or passport numbers – they can be compared by eye in a couple of seconds, it is better to spend energy on something important or not spend it at all.

Don’t forget about transport
After checking the documents, it is worth opening the form and putting crosses in those points that did not agree, and then proceed to inspect the car.
Open all the doors and trunk, look under the hood, run through the cabin looking for suspicious things.
Here you can even unload everything from the trunk, inspect and compare with the import invoice, banning the entry of the truck if it contains prohibited items or goods.
Of course, you can not only inspect the interior for contraband, but also open seats, upholstery or tires in search of something prohibited.
Everyone shouldn’t cut tires in a row – they will be fined if you just spoil a person’s property.

To find a smuggler, you need to study the latest news reports, plus examine the list of suspects at a special stand. 
If, for example, there is a suspicion that contraband will be brought in today on such and such a car, then such a car should be inspected especially carefully.
By cutting the seats and tires of the car, I was able to find contraband in the form of cigarettes, alcohol, packs of money and even drugs.
For this, a citizen who tried to bring all this good to the country was sent to a temporary detention facility, and everything confiscated was thrown into a warehouse.
Oh yes, you can still close your eyes to the violations of the citizen and take a bribe, letting him into the country, or you can put an innocent person in prison.
That is, the developers thought of the possibility of a bad guard, who in a bad mood puts everyone in a row.

Life outside the checkpoint
Surprisingly, the gameplay of the simulator during the inspection of documents and cars at the checkpoint does not end – the game has already implemented a fairly large map.
The player has the function of delivering prisoners from a temporary detention facility to a prison, plus we ourselves deliver all the seized illegal to the state warehouse, receiving good monetary rewards for both these actions.
For example, after the surrender of all the contraband and two prisoners, more than a thousand dollars fell into my account, which I then went and safely spent on tools.
Yes, in a communist country, the guard buys himself tools for opening the cabin, tires and other containers in search of contraband, so the gamer will have to periodically go to the merchant and buy everything he needs.
This is a very interesting process, since you need to look at the map constantly, while turning on the flashing lights and not crashing into everyone.
In addition, there are situations when attackers simply hit the gases, breaking through the barrier – in such situations we can sit in a “loaf” and overtake the criminal, crashing into him at full speed.
It’s an insanely fun process, in fact.

Conclusion
At the moment, I can confidently say that I liked comparing documents at the checkpoint, looking for inconsistencies and putting a red stamp in a passport, and the process of assessing a car, inspecting it and opening it are quite exciting activities.
developer_response: Thank you! We really appreciate such elaborate reviews. We are glad you enjoy Contraband Police :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198962878768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 95613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86316, 'last_played': 1699873785}
review:
By far the most additive game I've even played. Almost 4 months playing at the time of this review and even with bugs etc I still give this game a 10/10. With the addition of mods SE can be anything you want it to be. i'm currently working on a world/scenario that tells the story of the Stargate franchise after Universe including characters from SG1. This game allows me to utilize designs and mods by players around the world to tell an amazing finally.

The game is as easy (after the learning curve) or as difficult as you want it to be. From (god mode) creative to Armageddon you will surely die over and over and all in between. I'll continue to support Keen in every update in hopes the game gets even better and who knows maybe one day SE 2.

Cheers,

The Epic Beard

author: {'steamid': '76561198144336332', 'num_games_owned': 49, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 13763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2882, 'last_played': 1710102743}
review:
I highly suggest playing this game if you were a fan of AQW (Adventure Quest Worlds). I played this game back in 2016 when it first came out and there were a lot of issues and bugs with the game. The team has since made a lot of progress toward perfecting the game and graphics. Some of the graphics still need work but the game brings back a wave of nostalgia if you are an AQW player. There are still minor bugs and issues but I assume as the game moves from Early Access to being fully released that these issues will be resolved.

This game does not feel pay to win as AQW does, you can buy two packages and they are not subscription-based like AQW. I bought the $50 package and the $5 starter bundle and have been enjoying the game with the additional cosmetic items.
developer_response:
Hey there, thank you so much for taking the time to share your thoughts with our team. We really appreciate your kind words and detailed feedback regarding AQ3D and AQW. We are so honored to receive such a kindhearted review from you so we wanted to take the time to thank you for reaching out! 

We are so glad to hear that you've been enjoying the cosmetics and items in-game, as our team works hard to create items that make our game fun for everyone. We try to keep core items out of paid bundles, that way everyone can level up and play our games without having to pay. That said, we are happy that you like your cosmetic items! Our team appreciates your support, because although it is optional, it does mean a lot to us here at the Secret Underground Lab. 

Again, we want to keep our game as fair as possible for all players, so that people can return to Battleon whenever they want without paying to unlock items or features. Our team is glad you enjoy the direction of AQ3D- we hope it has been as fun for you to play as it is for us to develop! 

While we're still working on some aspects of the gameplay, we would love to invite you to AQ3D dot com, where you can learn where the game is headed via the News and Game Plan. Until then, we hope to see you again in-game soon! 

Battle On!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972624697', 'num_games_owned': 893, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 685, 'last_played': 1476586739}
review:
A brilliant point & click adventure game. Engaging story, great voice acting, interesting characters, and a perfect balance of difficulty with the puzzles.

Many memorable characters from this game, and the writing at critical points is top notch. The antagonist and the setting are very well done.

The palette is pretty much brown, blue, and grey. Perhaps more color would have been nice, but I really can't criticize when the artwork is so beautiful. The graphics are otherwise retro-style and very well done.

If you are a fan of classic adventure games, I can't recommend this enough. I love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994827422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 10004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4273, 'last_played': 1661030307}
review:
Intersting but kinda flawed too, economy is rubbish and the rng drives me up the wall.

This game might work if you pick a top team from the start, but if you're like me and like to start from the bottom division, you'll find the game is pretty much broken. It's impossible to build a team that will take you from the lower divisions to the upper divisions because the economic system flat out makes that impossible. Having said that it's also almost impossible not to succeed since once again the economic and club building systems rely on nothing more than playing a lot of matches. eventually, no matter what division you are in, you will have enough to get to top division, but it's just a grind, grind, grind and nothing you do can change that.

An example of the stupid economy is you can literally only have 80 000 fans. wtf.

Edit: The developer response: "You're just not good enough" - lol.
developer_response:
I'm sorry you feel that the only way to develop your club is grind. But that's not completely true.

If you know how to use skills, how to perform crosses, how to use strong sides of different classes (for example, wing forwards with high Control allow to score easy goals), you can win even stronger teams.

Experienced players ask us to make the game even harder because they easily rice from league to league and there's not enough challenge for them. That's because they know use skills a lot to gain +1 bonus action, score with crosses etc.

If you give the game another chance, you should concentrate on using skills. Also, change the formation according to every opponent. This way you can promote with lower level footballers what makes it cheaper for you so you can maintain contracts. In any case, you can ask anything on the forum, we I or our experienced players can help with some suggestions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078889483', 'num_games_owned': 271, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1694837494}

Hello! 

The game doesn't require you to install the EGS launcher. It doesn't boot through Epic. It needs to install Epic Online Services that are needed for us to provide cloud saving, matchmaking etc.

Many well-known games use EOS such as Hades and Risk of Rain 2, or Disco Elysium.

https://steamdb.info/tech/SDK/EpicOnlineServices/

Read more about EOS here: https://dev.epicgames.com/docs/epic-online-services

author: {'steamid': '76561198060833735', 'num_games_owned': 102, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1706298016}
review:
I enjoy the concept of this game and how it's tangentially related to "Papers, Please", but it just overstays its welcome. The gameplay loop is just so repetitive and the rare moments of not inspecting cars for contraband are the worst part of the game. The faux pressure of a timer on every mission is frustrating, and the rare times when the missions aren't just fetch quests they're frustratingly difficult because of the clunky controls. 
Driving anywhere is also a chore with the unresponsive vehicles and CRAZY map layout. Also, no minimap is fine, but it makes traveling difficult. 

I like the game well enough as a time waster and will play it until I'm done with the campaign, but I would not recommend someone purchase it at full price.
developer_response:
Hello, thank you for playing!

Thanks for your feedback. We're sorry the game didn't fully meet your expectations. We're working on new updates, we're gonna improve visual fidelity of the game and we have other improvements in store. We hope you will consider coming back in the future.

If there's anything else you'd like to add, feel free to leave a comment.

Kind regards

Thank you for your feedback.  As a solo dev who relies a lot on feedback, I offer you a free early access copy of SATS - Small Arms Training simulator - so you can give more feedback prior to public release.  

This game is motion controller only and we do not expect the controls problems some have stated.  This game is designed for touch/vive and I would love to personally welcome you as the sole creator of my 4 published games to have a stab at the SATS - DLC - for free well in advance of public distribution to aid in QA and bug testing. As A solo developer who went it alone with failed crowd funding I would appreciate what feedback you have to offer.   This game is down to VR controller usage.  I will PM you personally over the coming days to see if you have the right equipment and to offer you a unique- pre-release beta test.

Thanks for playing,

Shaun Williams  (AKA MAG studios) as an incoming friend request.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035743156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1498958843}
review: Awesome game. Very good characters developmend and interesting story.I bought it on steam sales, i would probably give 5 bucks or a little more, but not 10bucks. Only con: you might stuck at some point because it's not clear what to do next but this happens with all the "point and click" games so it is ok

author: {'steamid': '76561198043825929', 'num_games_owned': 2612, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1418682970}
review:
Primordia is the third Wadjet Eye P&C adventure I finished. 

I liked the other two (Gemini Rue; Resonance) for their mature stories, so it is only natural that I would like Primordia as well. But what a nice surprise to say that this game is even better!

Resonance tried cool stuff with the character switching, but I found it confusing at times. I was stuck multiple times in Gemini Rue (which obviously could be me being stupid) and think that the game sometimes had no direction to push the player to.

Primordia is just a pleasant ride from start to finish. Some of the code puzzles are a bit hard, but never frustrating. The story is just great. I loved the dark and gloomy tones and the sarcastic MC. Set in a dying world the game throws all kind of grey moral choices at the player.

Preach the Gospel of Man, fellow robots!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045390257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1669305090}
review:
My computer isn't high end, but not terrible... using a GTX 1070 and i5 7400 (only 3gzh quad core). I can still run almost anything at least on medium settings and games like FO4 on ultra without issues. I can't run WFTO well at all. Load times are ridiculous--no game should take 3 minutes to load. I've spent more time finding bug fixes than I have playing. Gameplay itself is less friendly than Dungeons III, which I really enjoyed. 

Editing review and may edit again. Developer is one of the few who actively responds in forums. Some of the issues I've had are experienced by others--longer initial boot times and (if I understood correctly) some texture issues on the initial load screen). The GPU error message I got is also possibly a glitch as my GPU was running the game. Thinking of picking it up again during the next sale and will update the recommendation after a few more hours of playtime. Tentatively don't recommend. Too risky to pay full price for me right now. TBD.
developer_response:
Hi Brithking,

I believed I responded to you on the forums as well but I'm going to repost my response here in hopes that it helps.

We'd certainly expect a GTX 1070 to easily run the game at full settings so that's truly surprising.

We run GTX 1080s (and I had a 780ti at home) in the office and have no issue maxing out 1440p at 60fps under almost all circumstances.

I'd love to get a look into what performance issues were occuring for you and see the crash logs for the aforementioned "Freeze and die". Did you try installing the game on a different drive? 

Additionally A few weeks ago we had someone with serious issues with load times and performance both of which were traced back to his Pagefile being on a failing hard drive. Once he moved that all issues were resolved. This user was also reporting load times in the minutes.

If you still have the game installed then I'd love to get my hands on the latest output log or crash logs from the game, as well as a copy of your dxidag. You can email them to me at support@brightrockgames.com.

You can find instructions on how to get those files here: https://support.brightrockgames.com/knowledge-bases/2/articles/118-how-to-submit-a-bug-ticket

Sorry once more and hope I can at least provide some clarity on what happened here.

- Lee

author: {'steamid': '76561198082949496', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1538616520}
review: Autistic flying, this game would be far better if the hub followed your mouse, so W could be more than forward. Because as it stands, you cant rotate your drone at all, A/D go left or right, its just a horrible control system. Complete trash, and I cant say about the rest of the game because I cant get past the ancient trash controls.
developer_response:
[edit]
Hi Snerpes

We're close to the launch and we're checking old reviews to see if we fixed all problems which got reported.

We added new tutorials, one separate for building and one for how to play the new survival mode.

You still have to build the drone yourself and set the keymappings to your liking, that did not change (we focus on building instead of more arcady action). But we added tutorials to make the learning curve more acceptable. If you play the game again, please let us know if we improved that :)

cheers,
Markus



-------
Hi Snerpes

Please note that the controls are completly built by yourself.
Depending on where you place the thrusters, how you rotate them (using the mouse wheel) and which keys you assign, the drone is controlled differently.
Using a directional sensor, you can even build a drone that follows your mouse cursor!

Please try it out and let me know if this info helped you :)

Cheers,
Philomena

author: {'steamid': '76561198090910713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1700328933}
review: It's a good game so far. It doesn't quite have the feeling I was looking for, but hopefully it will all get polished up near release. In particular, I'd like to see more life to the environment - wandering npcs, more random events, occasional dialogue boxes from npcs, etc. Currently, it feels like I just run from one static npc to the next and read paragraphs of text. Don't get me wrong, I like the writing and storytelling, but I'd like the city to feel more alive (possibly add more interactive environment objects for more lore and setting). Fallout had wandering alcoholics, npcs that would argue and fight with eachother, and that's all I'd like to see more of in this game if its something they decide to add.
developer_response: Thank you for the positive review despite your concerns. There will be more interactions and civilian animations (people walking, fixing things, cooking, etc). We do want the town to look more alive.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979669370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 3426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1709777899}
review:

Why ? This game have no content, no gameplay, it have several insane grinding mechanics and you will get full of it after a few hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250544676', 'num_games_owned': 3682, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1590242558}
review:
Eh.....this feels daft reviewing a demo of an early access game, as it's even "earlier" than most games launched under this condition. But it's some feedback for the developers at least, it's free to try, and this might entice someone to watch for future updates, so.....

I've given it a positive overall, as it has potential. To be blunt though: they released this demo too early and it has left a somewhat stunted first impression. Sound glitches, graphics glitches, a mouse cursor that refuses to disappear and annoyingly flickers all the time, other irritating game play issues, and totally crashing my pc, are some of the things they really ought to have fixed before releasing this taster.

Those are the negatives, and, yes, they will no doubt get fixed in time, but some of my issues with it aren't technical ones. Due to it crashing I can't say just how well they've realised certain elements of the game: it's described as a metroidvania, but my limited time with it didn't show anything along those lines. So for now I'm only treating it as an action game.

In that regard...it's okay. It plays smoothly and responsively, and has mild stealth elements, which I suppose are a relatively fresh addition for the genre. Having said that...this is no Mark Of The Ninja, as the enemies can be a bit too twitchy for it to work consistently, and other aspects go against it. 

It's a flip screen game, so what you don't want to be doing is going to jump on an enemy and unleash "death from above", only to find that instead the game jumps you out of the current screen briefly before you fall back down again...which alerts the guard who has been reset to his previously facing direction, and now shoots you.....

It will require a pretty fundamental change to how they display the game  for this to work better. Which is a bit crap anyway - why the hell do you still have flip screen games in 2020? It suggests a bad grasp of the Unity engine when you're using a technique that was technologically necessary 30 years ago, but sure as heck isn't in this day and age. 

This stealth mechanic doesn't make the game unique, and it's certainly not unique as an action game, so they're going to have to improve this clunky aspect of it if they hoped it would make it stand out. Right now it's no better than Blasphemous, Dead Cells, Dark Light, The Messenger and about a bazillion other games, but it plays worse than those - which is going to be obvious as it's fairly incomplete, and they're finished games (or more advanced in their development)

The graphics are alright, but there's better looking games. It's lacking any music, which somewhat undermines the impact of the game play. Combat is slick enough, though missing a bit of oomph due to the absence of any score to emphasise it. Dark Light plays just as well, but has a superb soundtrack that makes it stand out when compared to this. 

(EDIT: This does have music, but it's fairly quiet in the overall volume of the game, and more ambient than exciting / intense / menacing etc. Which undermines the relatively capable level of the action) 

Storywise it's well told, and has a surprisingly decent voiceover and animated cutscenes.

It has the potential to be a decent game, but based on my brief time with this demo (bearing in mind it was short due to it crashing - it might have some mindblowing game play I missed) a lot of work needs to be put into it for me to recommend it as essential. Right now I'd say Dark Light has it well beaten for being a game I'm excited for.

If you found this review to be helpful, then I have a curator page where you might discover some hidden gems, or see some stinky clunkers to avoid.

https://steamcommunity.com/groups/The_dull_games_reviewer
developer_response: Thank you for this lenghty constructive review. I really appreciate that. Happy to say the full game will be remade from scratch upon release because with this concept demo I learned a lot of things. A lot. Optimization for example. Sorry for crashing your computer. Did you say there was no music ? I heard music. Didn't you ?

author: {'steamid': '76561197972395973', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1625427151}
review:
Update (December 31, 2018) - I would like to say that the developer is very responsive and passionate about making video games. I was able to make it past the troublesome spot. Reminds me of the Souls series, unforgiving but, rewarding once you master the area.

Normally, I would not write reviews on games but I feel this could be a great game if more constructive critism is offered. Please, please fix the issue of getting stuck. I cannot get past the first thirty seconds as I keep getting stuck.

My suggestion would be to start out "easy" / tutorial of sorts that gets progressively more difficult. This is so the player can get used to how hard it can be to control the vehicle.

Otherwise, keep up the work as releasing a game is better than not finishing one... I know. :(

I would recommend others to play the game as we can make it great. Note to developer - Offer a demo of a first level. Else, I would not recommend it until it is more polished.
developer_response:
Demo of the first level is already in the store. Work on the game is in progress and at the moment a major update is being made in which: maps will be changed, a menu will be added, saving(possibly) a couple of transition maps and more.
About getting stuck in real life on the car, too, you can get stuck and the game was conceived difficult.
For more information\questions, you can write to me in private messages: https://steamcommunity.com/id/SystemVC/

author: {'steamid': '76561198935612793', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 68728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 67, 'playtime_at_review': 60005, 'last_played': 1712021449}
review: This game is the best for creative minds with destructive tendencies. Fun to play solo but much better with friends. Start of  game you start out with bad parts but the drive to get more and customize is what keeps me going. You’re matched with people with the same power score range, meaning you are put against people with the level of parts you have. Mid game you’ll probably get a pack, and they have great sales if you wait long enough and the battle pass seasons are completely reasonable and enjoyable to play through. Every now and again Gaijin releases a special mode for a limited time to diversify gameplay, eg. Operation Red Light, Big Chase, etc. Highly recommend for those who are willing to spend some hours to get better parts and just enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040098483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1594823924}
review:
I enjoyed this game for about the first 8 or so runs. Not so much any more. First of all, if you've played Binding of Isaac-- congratulations! This game is basically just trying to be Binding of Isaac. I'm not saying that in a disparaging "every roguelite is Binding of Isaac," I'm saying it in a "this game literally rips entire concepts from it without changing them." Seriously, the main differentiating feature in this game is that it's a 2D platformer rather than a 2D top down game, as well as some objectively bad mechanics stapled on top.

You start with a few characters, all of whom have different starting healths, grenades (this game's equivalent to bombs), keys, etc. as well as some having unique gimmicks. Interestingly, the only two starting characters with any playstyle variety happen to be the two that are offered as DLC on day 1! Isn't that interesting? One of them has what is functionally a double jump, and the other can eventually fly. Objectively stronger than the base 2 characters who have... nothing unique whatsoever. Progression in this game works as follows: you go into the starting level, you wander around killing enemies, collecting grenades and keys, and go into a treasure room which gives you a free upgrade item. You can then potentially find a store, some challenge rooms, etc. to get more items. You then fight a boss and after winning you can either continue to go back and explore the area or head down to the next level. This is all sounding remarkably similar to another game, isn't it? 

I'll jump into a few differences. In Isaac, you basically have 1 attack for every single character with no differences: firing tears. Your attacks get different properties as you pick up passive items. In NA, instead, the way your attack works depends primarily on the weapon you pick up-- sort of like Gungeon. Different attack patterns, bullet shapes, etc. Sure, half of them are variations on "slowly charge up a laser" but some of them are interesting. Then you have the passive items which impact how your bullets work. Many of which are basically the same as in Isaac, but to be honest they aren't unique to either game, just kind of standard stuff like piercing, explosive, poison, fire, etc. The weapons also have active abilities-- so instead of having a separate item tied to a use key like in Isaac, instead whenever you right click with a given weapon you will consume some charge and use the ability. Now, in Isaac, this charge was given whenever you changed rooms, however in NA, you get it randomly from drops of purple crystals, which can drop in 1, 2, or 4 clumps. Or they might not drop at all, hamstringing you with RNG.

But that's not even the worst of it, since you probably don't want to use those crystals anyway, since you need them to buy your way into certain doors, as well as use certain chests, and an interactable pillar-thing. Whenever you spend crystals in this way, you'll build up a meter in the bottom right-- it's called wisdom, but that doesn't matter. Basically it's a meter that will give you a free item from a set of 2 items: it's the Angel room from Isaac. You get charge for these meter by avoiding damage as well as cashing in the crystals. The issue is that the amount of charge you get for avoiding damage is completely pitiful, and the actual uses for crystals don't always show up, meaning you won't get access to the room entirely by virtue of RNG. And, yes, like the angel and devil rooms in Isaac, there is a counterpart. The counterpart is acquired by, whenever you see a crystal cash-in-thing, damage it first, and then run into it to damage yourself and fill the meter. So kind of the opposite of how you'd want to get it in Isaac. You then can choose to sacrifice one of your heart containers and then get access to 1 of 3 items. So, yeah, basically a devil room. I don't honestly mind this, because I liked that mechanic in Isaac-- however there's a huge difference here. In Isaac, the angel and devil rooms had unique, powerful items that made it incredibly worthwhile to play perfectly in order to get even better benefits and abilities. In NA, they're just regular treasure rooms. You don't even get to *see* what you're going to get if you sacrifice health in the devil room equivalent, so you can't make an educated risk, it's just pure RNG. And I guess now that I've brought it up a few times, let's get into the RNG elements, shall we? Because I'll list a few examples of things that they added to the genre that really add to the "difficulty" of the game.

In Isaac, slot machines were little interactables in a room that you could fire off some of your extra coins into and potentially get rewarded. In NA, they are *doors*. You spend 5 coins sort of like you'd spend a key, and you have a *chance* of opening the door and going to whatever is behind it. That's kind of annoying, but it's not awful... except when you realize that they also took the mechanic from Isaac where after a random number of uses the machine will just break. You'd think that would mean that the door would break and you could open it with like a bomb or something-- no, it's just locked shut forever now. [Edit] As of the experimental branch at the time of writing, the devs have made it so that when a slot machine door explodes, it opens. Good change.

Pets in this game are literally just the followers from Isaac; they either follow behind you in a conga line or they spin around your character and block shots and the like. The ones following you attack enemies or do something else. Many of them are basically identical to ones from Isaac, but we've already stomped that into the dirt anyway. In Isaac, you pick them up like any other passive item. In NA, you instead have another random pickup-- eggs. This causes little easter egg looking things to follow behind your character, where after a few screens and the like they eventually hatch into a follower. Except when they don't. Yeah, the eggs can sometimes just not give you anything. Which, you know what, that's fine, it's a little RNG thing that might give you a little bonus but it's basically just a powerup, since they can be killed and disappear, unlike in Isaac. Except... many are hindrances. [Edit] Originally at this point in the review, I went into how many of the pets ended up being basically worse than useless and harmed the player. The devs have actually made a new version of the egg pickup that explicitly contains these questionably useful and potentially dangerous pets. This is a good change, and removes most of my issues with the pet mechanic.

[Edit] The devs have already started to address a lot of the problems many users have with the game. I respect that. I'm glad to see that they're already moving ahead with quality of life improvements and rebalancing some of the more questionable aspects. Something else I couldn't get into in the original review due to character limits was the lack of enemy variety. Apparently many of the enemy varieties were actually locked behind the upgrade tree in the game, but have now been changed to be based on the final bosses. So that should mean overall much more variety in the game, which is also a good change. I still don't think the game is worth its current asking price in terms of quality, but judging by how fast the devs respond to community feedback, I'd say in a month or so I might come back and re-assess this review.
developer_response:
Hey there,

Thanks for the review! We are taking in all the feedback from launch and have just made live an optional experimental branch with many of the most requested features and changes added. 

Here’s a few that are addressed that were in your feedback:

On pets, the Vibrant Ball is now out of the game whilst we rework it, several of the other trouble pets (Peter the cat, Grabber, Jack, Dr.Blue) have a new ‘naughty’ egg system where you need to manually pick them up like an item.

On RNG issues, the slot machine opens once it explodes, Wisdom progress is only 50% reset if you have some violence, the first shop has a 50% sale and you can now see item names.

We’ve increased the time the item description stays on the screen when you pick them up. Plus, we’ve lowered the god coin cost of the upgrade tree.

A big one on screen clutter is that enemy bullets/attacks will be in front of the players attacks to make the game more readable.

These aren’t exhaustive and we’ll be working hard to make sure that lots of other common suggestions are considered. We’re committed to making the game the best it can be! 

You can see the full list and how to get it here: https://steamcommunity.com/games/788100/announcements/detail/2753339286193349786

On your points about similarities, we have been compared a lot to several of the popular proceeding roguelites and whilst it isn’t a copy, it does stand on the foundations of other roguelites sharing a lot of common mechanics in the genre. We do feel we have brought our own unique mechanics and twists like the potential item synergies that combine with weapons and your characters, the progression tree, the mini-games, the way all items stack visually, the Manager system, advanced pet system and neon theme.

We hope you’ll give the game another try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052665407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1657945270}
review:
EDIT: I finally got the xbox one gamepad (for PC) to work, but only after disabling controller input (in steam settings).  It seemed to be causing a conflict in the controls.  Several hours lost figuring out how to make it work.  To the devs-- does it really have to be this difficult? I mean, it's on steam, so you kinda have to make stuff like this work seamlessly with the platform, especially since controls make or break this game.  I never have to do this finagling with my other games on steam. Anyway, after getting the gamepad to work, it is also recommended to spend some time mapping controls to the buttons.  

When playing the game itself expect a steep learning curve when it comes to flying your ship, but that's just a matter of patience, and is part of the experience in playing these kind of space sim games.  It is highly recommended  to take the tutorial to learn to fly.  It's still not enough though, and you will likely need to consult some guides online in order to understand how to fly more smoothly in the game.  

I found Horizons more interesting than Odyssey (you can launch either version from the starting window) since horizons was about the ship flying and odyssey is more about the on foot shooting.  No Man's Sky seems to handle the transition between ship and on foot mode much more smoothly, but that's just a nitpick.

Overall, the game really could benefit from doing a more thorough job guiding players, as I can see the steep learning curve discouraging some players from spending more time in the game., and as I said, they need to make it so that the controls just work-- whether it's a gamepad, keyborad/mouse, flight stick, etc..  Clearly a lot of work has gone into the game, and there's a lot of potential, and if they just make it more accessible, then it would give Starfield, No Man's Sky, etc. a run for their money.  Maybe offer players a choice to have a more arcade style flying mode as an option, and players can choose whether to have it more sim-like or more like No Man's Sky.  I tend to prefer the more sim-like experience, but I also play No Man's Sky and that is fun in it's on way because the mechanics are more simple and straightforward, and encourages exploration.  All that being said, if you can get past the issues, the game will provide some hours of fun for sure.
developer_response:
Hello CMDR, controllers are definitely support by Elite Dangerous! Please contact us at https://customersupport.frontier.co.uk/hc/en-us/requests/new and we'll troubleshoot this for you. 
- Vostok

author: {'steamid': '76561198070616040', 'num_games_owned': 505, 'num_reviews': 270, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1553296596}
review:
I can remember playing AQ 10 years ago and the servers were so full that you had to wait to play the singleplayer:)
I think you should have used all that time and money to update/upgrade the turn based style AQ into a full f2p game on steam with more MMO elements.
You would have won our hearts again.....and we would have surely used a subscription system here too or payments for cosmetic items or to found guilds or claim other buffs.

The game as it is....has no magic, no charm, feels like an early alpha indie game. 
I played a bit in the begining and some now but it just has that grinding feeling with nostalgia.

Please make AQ a turn based MMO on steam, this 3d project is too ambitious and unspired to have any lasting effects.
You know that most of the positive reviews are from soft hearted AQ players, i wanted to do the same...but you are killing AQ here.
PS: i will always love the AQ universe and the game with the mechs even if i don't play them anymore
developer_response: Thank you so much for your review and feedback! It is always a honor when a legacy players tries out a new game! AdventureQuest 3D is inspired by our original games AdventureQuest and DragonFable. Since the original AdventureQuest, we have released multiple other games including our first MMO AdventureQuest Worlds that was released 10 years ago. It has always been our dream to create a 3D MMO and first started creating AQ3D in 2012, before Flash decided to drop support on its new 3D program, so we were forced to learn Unity 3D then opened the Tech Demo for AQWorlds Members in November 2014. The headway we make on AQ3D, which is our first cross platform game, will help us work on improving our older 2D games and make them cross platform as well! The devs are constantly working on fixing and improving issues and releasing updates/patches almost weekly. This has been a constant balance as an indie game company with a small staff.  We also have a Game Plan posted here that is updated every Monday - https://aq3d.com/game-plan/.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005162720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1571385332}
review:
Had to sit at the menu for 5 minutes to write this review. I was at 4 minutes, and reinstalled the game a third time to sit idle another 1 min to meet the minimum to post a review. Ty Steam.

Anyways...

Same old story. Early access title, looks beautiful on the outside, but rushed out of the gate too early. Cant even get past the loading screen and I get a 'fatal error'. 

"Unreal Engine is exiting due to D3D device being lost."
System restarts, doesnt work. 
Disabling of various software, doesnt work. 
Reinstall game, doesnt work. 

Avoid this like the plague, and all these titles that have 0 game testing before release. Wont collect dust in my Steam library like so many others, so I have requested refund. Tired of being essentially a game tester for our current lazy industry.

-Check this game out 6 months from now after it has been properly tested, but for now AVOID IT like Chernobyl.-
developer_response: We're sorry that you weren't able to play our game. We know the problem you are talking about, it seems to us that it is not on our side and we try to work with graphics card manufacturers to fix it. I hope that when you want to give us a second chance, the game will be much better!

Hi scwMortise,

author: {'steamid': '76561198321782660', 'num_games_owned': 587, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1690522091}
review: The game is confusing, there's so many places and it's hard to know where to go to get somewhere, and it also feels pay to win. There's a cap on inventory space so I would go search for a bank or something to deposit my loot and not know how to get there. The game has a ton of items and I wouldn't know where to get them, and I'd think of selling items but then not know if I'll know where to get them later on if I ever want them again.
developer_response:
Hi Kevin, thank you for your review and feedback! We are sorry to hear the game has been confusing for you. AQ3D is free to play and is not pay to win. Any upgrades are completely optional and not needed to play the game. 

Please make sure you go through the tutorial (and don't skip!) and then you can do all the quests and explore BattleOn and beyond. You can also check out other adventures in the Game Menu and ask other players for help and group up with them if you'd like. You can also submit a ticket to Artix Support via artix.com/contact if you have any questions or issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062353010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 25172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4949, 'last_played': 1679226031}
review:
So, I spent more time playing this game in the hope that it would change my opinion of it. Mostly because I did play the 2D Flash version years ago.

Has my view of the game improved somewhat? Yes, surprisingly it has.
Would I still recommend it for other players? Depends on what kind of game you expect to find. If a fun little time-waster is what you are seeking, then yes. If you want a MMORPG with fleshed out combat mechanics, that require meticulous strategy between players, then no.

Okay so let go over the positives of the game.
-Impressive looking level design, that have a nostalgic feel to those that played the 2D Flash versions. Only in 3D.
-Classes are actually diverse enough, with some excelling against certain enemies than others.
-Quirky humour that did bring a chuckle out of me.
-Mini-games that are pretty diverse, some of which are surprisingly fun to play.
-Plenty of challenging secrets for players to discover, with some requiring help from others. This is a game that is more fun to play with others.

Not every game is perfect, even the most pristine MMO's on the market have their negatives. AdventureQuest 3D unfortunately has a lot of them.
-Crafting is tedious in places, where it doesn't allow multiple items of the same type to be queued. Only one at a time.
-Character movement can be janky, which makes some parkour runs harder than necessary.
-A lack of audio in cutscenes, such as dialogue, sound effects, music. The only thing I hear is the level music in the background, which at times doesn't fit with the scene very well.
-Some quests that feel more like a chore instead of something fun to do.
-Connectivity issues, despite having a decent internet connection at home.
-Combat can be broken at times, especially the Silence and Stun status effect which are exactly the same. Plus some enemies don't have resistances to certain elements (like fire type enemies takes just the same amount of damage from a fire spell as from a non-fire type enemy)
-Weapons and armours that have little diversity in terms of statistics. Would be nice to have some which provide magical bonuses, such as elemental effects like fire, water, holy magic, etc.
-Some quests and dungeons have game breaking bugs, which requires the player to reset progress at times. (Can be very frustrating for someone to lose progress, with the time lost being a few minutes or, if you are really unlucky, hours!)

Overall I still maintain that this game does have potential. I even upgraded my account to Dragon Guardian to help support the game and I do applaud the developers for what they accomplished so far. With more polishing of the game mechanics and taking out what doesn't work, this could one day be something more. I hope to one day change this review again, maybe even recommend it to other players.

Until then, this is a above mediocre game that has its moments but still falls short of the mark.
developer_response: Hi there. Thank you so much for all of your feedback, we really appreciate meaningful, informative and constructive feedback like this! The AQ3D Team are planning to update and tweak crafting and combat in the future. They also finally have an amazing musician who has already worked on music for other releases and events and is working on filling any gaps where music and sound effects are missing. As an indie game studio with weekly releases, sometimes improvements can get bottle necked, but the team has a ton of additions and improvements coming soon!

author: {'steamid': '76561198077927569', 'num_games_owned': 698, 'num_reviews': 173, 'playtime_forever': 4505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1710242778}
review:
This game is pretty good, you can make some really nice villages and the "forbidden" zones are awesome to play around with as you can make some neat paths etc. The devs seem to be putting more time/work into the project now as updates seem to be coming out a bit more often. 

As others have said, the game sorta stagnates towards the end as there is no real end game and you pretty much just expand until you get bored. However it's a pretty sweet ride up until then and I've restarted a few times.

If I had to pick one thing to improve it would be talk about some of the systems in the game, such as how you won't get immigrants if you have too many unemployed people despite being at ~95% happiness.
developer_response:
H Fazure,

Thank you for taking the time to leave a review.

The game is still in Early Access and we have much more to come in development so we understand your later points. We will be adding more narrative, gameplay and polish as we further develop the game.

We are also working on a new UI and improved UX that will help explain things in game more clearly, which may be what is causing some of your issues.

- We are unaware of any bugs with the monastery. The most likely cause for not being able to concede villagers is that you either do not have a dorm for them to live in or you don't have any unemployed men. You need both to be able to recruit monks.

- Some resources will deplete. Fishing spots are one of these so too many fishing huts might mean that there is no fish available from time to time. We are unaware of any issues affecting resources. 

- Villagers need housing zones within 150m of their workplaces but will travel any distance to get water, food and visit a church. There are no hard limits to needs fulfilling. This can affect their efficiency if they have to walk to far so managing these needs can be a priority,
There is a priority button for building projects as you say but we will look at the mechanics for this as we further improve the game.

If you are still having issues with any of the above then please could you send your save file to support@polymorph.games so that we can investigate further.

Cheers
Ash

author: {'steamid': '76561198004342461', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1665876953}
review:
I like this game a lot, the idea's great and it pretty much reminds me of Prototype but you play as the people tasked with stopping Mercer. However--
It's Early Access, and with that comes the bugs. It crashes occasionally, the friendly AI - soldiers/units are kinda dumb and will often swap from running to walking randomly, never walk in formation, and will sometimes choose to charge head-first despite me giving them a movement command to retreat. I'll certainly be playing the game continuously though, and I expect I'll probably change this review if the bugs are fixed, the AI recieves some updates, or if something else is added to the game that makes it MORE worthwhile, because it's already quite fun regardless.
developer_response:
Great to hear your enjoying the game.

 Can you drop your crash information to us on our Discord crash reporting channel? We can fix these kind of crashes typically within 24 hours or less. Otherwise we don't know or can't fix these kind of issues  since the crash reports just go to Epic Games not us.

As for the other issues you should reach out on Discord I would like to talk about the other bugs you encountered 

-Dark Project Director

author: {'steamid': '76561198069026008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1474416519}
review:
So I had some reservations about this game when I started playing it but the dev is super respectful and fixed the bugs within a few days.  For that alone I would change my review.  

About the game itself....The "heroes" made me laugh quite a bit and for the price I would certainly purchase it again.   I really liked the break-up between multiple characters as well as the point system.  Having given it some thought, the potion and item system is also pretty innovative and forces you to change your typical attack, magic, attack, magic thought process in most rpg's.

Thumbs up!  I already own another of the dev's games and am looking forward to it.
developer_response:
Hey Bastion,

I'm sorry you had to play the game right in between two updates. Our previous update created a bug with Steam Achievements & Battle Retry. We just pushed an update fix for them a few minutes ago. Could you please consider changing your review into a Thumbs Up, considering we've fixed these issues so quickly?

Thanks! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561199013566137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 112304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53515, 'last_played': 1706582050}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000550428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1624829994}
review: So I keep getting stuck and cant move and have to restart levels over and over again. Seems like a pretty basic bug to not have fixed. Looks like a lot of people in the forum were having it too. Don't recommend buying this at all...hard to play a game where you can't move in it.
developer_response:
First of all, sorry for your troubles, please use the forum or contact us via info@decayoflogos.com

What you're saying is not exactly accurate; there have been a few input issues since our launch that have since been corrected. Your experience is really one in thousands, we could use every available detail to possibly replicate and correct this on our side.

There are a couple of posts about input related issues but they are not all the same issue, what you're describing is not common. One of the last input issues we handled of a user reporting no input turned out to be caused by an old Joystick plugged into the computer in addition to his controller, or when playing with keyboard; all the input was coming from there.

There could be a variety of problems happening; we would recommend starting by checking which USB devices you have plugged in, there could be something happening there.

Please get in touch, we'd appreciate it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198968825468', 'num_games_owned': 171, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 100883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21640, 'last_played': 1710543526}
review:
It's hard to get into, there's a lot of downtime, and you pretty much need to seek advice from others who have played the game for a while. For the love of God, use the community tool websites like inara.cz to find things that you're looking for, don't be stubborn like me and go, "I don't need 'em" for the first hundred-fifty hours. Don't buy Odyssey, and try not to get hung up on the fact that the developers are getting lazy, there's plenty of the game here if you have the patience for it. Still not a letter of acceptance for you to slack though, FDev.

The spectacle is fantastic, and makes it all worth it. The universe is thoroughly-crafted for what isn't just automatically-generated. Combat is often tense, and exploration is the main meat of the game- it feels so special when you fly out really far from civilized space and start finding systems that have no one's name on them- because they'll have yours if you can return and cash in your data.

Making money for a good ship, as well as collecting materials and unlocking engineers for tuning said ship is tedious, I won't honey my words here. But if you can get past it to put together a good ship for whatever you're after, the whole galaxy becomes your oyster.

This game reminds me a bit of fishing, but in space. I have enjoyed this game for over three hundred hours. I will continue to enjoy it for more.

P.S. Don't fly in open play unless you're willing to get blown to pieces by a no-life flying a maxed-out Fer-De-Lance. I lost 7 million credits pretty early on that way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044802802', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 11443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4264, 'last_played': 1619316975}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043989302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1654226065}
review: After almost 10 years I've come back to this game for a restart/refresher and boy can I say it still is one of the most impressive point/click games I've seen. The art is incredible and the universe is something you wish you could explore more and more of. Can we also applaud the soundtrack? Yeah, let's do that. One more thing, the voices for the characters all fit so well and it makes you really love them and their own unique personalities. Please pick up this game if you like point/click adventure types.
developer_response:
So glad you enjoyed it! There is a bit more in the universe available on Primordia-Game.com (spin off story, art, poem, etc.). 

We recently released our second adventure, Strangeland, which is quite different but which you might also enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026604342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 13089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1481, 'last_played': 1708912124}
review: Fun for a couple of hours, but once you figure out how to be successful it loses its charm.
developer_response:
Hello there,

The game should be very stable, if it crashes this is usually a driver issue, possible solutions are:

- Update your video card drivers.
- Run the game in DX9: In the Steam Library, right click the game and go to Properties. Click the SET LAUNCH OPTIONS... button, then type -force-d3d9 popup dialog.


Regards.
Martino.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041156939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 9060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9060, 'last_played': 1422208320}

author: {'steamid': '76561198145290113', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1536989249}
review: Let me know whenever someone makes a mod that kills 70% of the realism that 70% of the players would appreciate. Honestly, its too much. Its like trying to live your life as an adult with your grandma constantly nagging in you in your back seat. "Dont forget to stay hydrated, oh wait, I noticed that you have a scrape on your knee, you should probably have that looked at, speaking of which how are your potassium levels..". I played this for a very short bit when it was first released a few years ago, and with so much of the game leaning on the boring aspect of the apocalyptic dystopi , survival. It just kills the fun factor. There seems to be a huge disconnect with game devs and customers. It seems so simple to us, we want something well rounded. Base building without having to have an engineering degree, staying alive by eating random non rotten food, not having to make sure my blood sugar levels are okay or not. It seems like the people who make these games (which we all have really high hopes) are made by fringe gamers. They have extreme takes on existing titles instead of expanding on a fun, great working formula. Its not what you want, its what the customers want. And the customers want something straight forward, easy learning curve and that has longevity. Daz Mod had the perfect basic layout, and yet everyone else since than has to add their own wacky twist that nobody asked for. Its like the loudest voices are never the majority. Hopefully a future game dev is reading this and will finally understand and make something F U N!
developer_response:
Hi there He11 Hammer! 

First of all, thank you for taking the time to write such an extensive review.

The realism you speak of was actually one of the draws of the game that led me to it, as a gamer first. It's a difficult thing to balance out in game dev, while still having the fun factor to it. The whole metabolism system you mentioned is still a main draw for players, and no other game has one like it, we're proud of that one. Still, it gets tested out thoroughly with every new feature and has seen QOL changes to it numerous times.
One of our top priorities is to balance out features so that they complement each other, that's why we depend on valuable player feedback up to the 1.0 release and beyond.

With the 0.95 update released, we're getting close to the polish phase where we'll seriously revisit all features in need of rebalancing and tune the hell out of them. 
But, these tiny improvements actually happen on a daily basis, through in-office communication and playtesting of the game.

While I do agree that a great existing formula is a good basis, we wanted to make our own special take on the whole genre and leave our own mark. 
We also believe that a game has to be fun, it's one of our top priorities and while it's also true that it's impossible to please everyone, our goal is to make the game more accessible to newcomers which is why we've added the CODEX in 0.95. A tutorial system which explains in-depth the features of SCUM.
A CODEX that will be also be expanded with 1.0 and beyond. 
We hope you'll give the game another chance and perhaps change your mind.
Have a good one!

author: {'steamid': '76561199230003694', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1659596209}
review: This is my very first steam review and I'm honored for this to be the first game I review, because this game is incredible! I haven't had genuine enjoyment in a game in quite some time. The concept is so simple yet executed in the best way possible. This MMO doesn't need a deep progression system or a convoluted skill tree to be entertaining because it does all of that through it's humoring dialogue and overall calm and collected gameplay, and to top it all off it's free, which means that there is no reason NOT to play it. This MMO can also be played on mobile devices so you can access it anywhere with a connection instantly. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes RPG's or to anyone who just wants to have a fun and humorous experience. I am greatly looking forward to what the developers have in store for this game as well as any games they would be making in the future.
developer_response:
Hey there, we're honored that you picked AQ3D as your first Steam review! Wow, we are absolutely so stoked that you left us such a kindhearted, thoughtful review. 

Your review made our day here at the Secret Underground Lab and we wanted to let you know that reading feedback directly from our players helps our team tremendously! We are so appreciative that you took the time to both play our game and write out such a lovely review for us here at Artix Entertainment.

We hope you continue to stick around in game for all of the wacky, fun events we have in store in the future! We are hard at work on this game and some other titles, so we hope you enjoy what you see from our team. 

You can learn more about our upcoming projects at artix dot com and AQ2D dot com. You can also learn more about AQ3D at AQ3D dot com.

Again, thank you so much for taking the time to share your thoughts with our team! We hope to see you in-game soon. 

Until then, have a great day and Battle On!

author: {'steamid': '76561198151417106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1505934734}
review: It's... Meh. Not Much fun. And the Tutorial is Taking FOREVER to Learn.
developer_response:
Our game play cannot be judged on the tutorial experience Jack. I would strongly advise completing your tutorials and then logging in to the main game. Graphics is definitely not our appeal but our game can hold up. It's the sheer awe of hundreds of players in a single battle zone duking it out. If you don't give it the proper chance to experience that, you'll miss out on a lot.

The tutorial is a necessary evil and I can understand you perhaps are not interested. If we don't teach you some basics, you will be completely lost by the time you enter the actual Campaign. 

My hope is, you try it out some more. This game has been around since 2001, there is a reason. Give it a proper chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058135852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 820, 'last_played': 1501412829}
review:
I agree 'Football Tactics' is turn-based, but I don't think the word strategy really describes this game.  It is very difficult to build a coherent strategy when you only have 3 available actions every time it becomes your turn. (Moving a player one square counts as an action.) because of this every game plays out in the same way.

- Get the ball
- Pass to striker
- Shoot from outside box

The AI also plays with this same strategy. If it fails, try it again next turn. The game introduced  a few special skills that your players can learn. But often it feels very limited in terms of which skills which player can learn.

Player improvements are incredibly simplistic and within about 30 minutes I'd noticed a flaw in tthe club improvements.

This game may improve, but it would require a radical redesign of the basic gameplay in order to do so.

author: {'steamid': '76561199088722209', 'num_games_owned': 1, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1707879579}
review: I really want to love this game--and, it almost has everything, but 95% of the gameplay is you just staring at a pointless loading circle as, I guess for the sake of 'realism,' it takes over a minute to do basic tasks like crafting items and cutting down a tree. Some of the zombies are so fast that they cant be outrun, especially in hordes. If you get an infection, you have to travel to a pharmacy and even then theres no guarantee itll stop.
developer_response: Hi Tripwilder! We're sorry to see that the game did not live up to your expectations. However, there are things that might need to be clarified in this regard. Your character in SCUM has points allocated to different skills, which then influence their interactions with the environment. In this specific example, the speed of chopping down a tree is influenced by the level of your SURVIVAL skill and by the tool you are using, i.e. a real ax is much more efficient than a stone ax. Incidentally, crafting speed is also influenced by survival. That being said, if you want to be faster with these things, please make sure to create a character with a greater level of survival.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004282046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1574804550}
review:
Game is nothing like Stellaris, but it has design problems like Stellaris did at launch.

I think this game is a great effort, and I didnt experience bugs, but quality is lacking in areas besides production values.

As someone who wanted to like this game, I can't recommend it until the underlying design itself receives more polish.  The choice to use a full 3d map doesn't really seem to have paid off well.  Too many things are in the game that don't improve it, including UI buttons, mechanics, ships, technologies, etc.

Too many gameplay mechanics do not add to the experience, I believe these are things that seemed like good ideas but as currently implemented they detract from some combination of fun or intuitive-ness of the rules.  Not enough tools to deal with organizational challenges.  And the UI definitely has issues, a large amount of real estate sometimes is claimed to display very little information (though some windows are better designed than others)

I played on a harder difficulty and on my second game, I researched the first ship upgrade and took out a loan to buy 2, the AI players were no longer competitive after that (not that I would have understood why I was being out-competed with the current design) and I blew through a surprising amount of the tech tree with only two not-upgraded research stations.

This is a game about interstellar expansion and I felt like I had seen most things after a few of Jupiter's moons were colonized.  Like Stellaris it seems like this game launched without a vision for how the player would proceed through to the endgame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075073720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 780, 'last_played': 1618601626}
review: Hello.  This is the second review I have made for this product.  I voluntarily deleted the first because of some terribly vile comments that do not belong on this kind of platform.  This is a review for potential buyers of Colony Ship.  There are many good aspects to this game and I feel it shows great promise.  It has an interesting theme and story setting.  It also has some striking if simple graphics. At this time I say it is a poor purchase because of the value of play vs the cost.  In my opinion there is only a few hours of game play currently available.  Unless you want to play the first chapter over and over with different builds.  This brings me to the build options.  The game claims a variable system but I found that to be untrue.  If playing a Charisma/ Intelligence build it becomes formulaic and predictable.  Also, I do not feel you can actually get away without having some offensive capabilities.  I feel the combat system is erratic.  Cover, movement, and weapon stats are so completely unworkable that most fights are repeated over and over to achieve a positive result.  It is a combat grind.  Save, fight, save fight, until you win.  I do not find that enjoyable. Some have made the arguments that the game is meant to be a serious challenge and also that this is the nature of an ea game.  I actually agree with the second part except that of all ea titles I have this is the absolute bottom of the barrel in play ability.  I find it functionally unworkable in it's current form.  I have also questioned the way some of their developers communicate with their own customers.  I felt they came off rude and entitled but I understand they are a very small company (some said 3 people) so they may be very sensitive to criticism.  You would think it would motivate them to act in the opposite in an effort to cultivate more buyers.  As I said before I think it is currently a BAD purchase but it has GREAT potential to be an epic game.  Sadly I have turned off comments because of some of the things said by super fans.  I wish you all the best and happy gaming.  Months later and it is still going downhill fast.  I think my earlier hope that they would turn it into something good was wrong.  Its just terrible.
developer_response:
