author: {'steamid': '76561198039413776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1535266518}
review:
I will start off by saying that I'm of two minds about this game in its current state. On one hand, I do like supporting devs whose games I enjoy, especially indie devs because the road can be really tough. On the other hand, there is not enough content (an hour at my reading speed) to justify its current price to me. 

The art style is unique and really gorgeous. The sound effects are very atmospheric. The backgrounds have a lot of little details that give them depth and vibrancy. What you see in the preview images is what you get – you have no save function, you cannot hide the text window, the amount of text window space seems disproportionate to the amount of text. 

What you don’t see – you cannot adjust text speed, there is no text history or going backwards if you click too quickly, switching between scenes (ie, when the auto-save function kicks in) can leave you with a black screen that requires reloading to progress (happened quite often for me for some reason but no one else seems to have mentioned it), so you end up replaying portions carefully when you finally realize that no amount of waiting is going to start a new scene.

I know this is Early Access so these are not recommendation killers for me. I am glad to support Pink Potion in this endeavour and I hope to see it become really successful; the game looks wonderful visually, the writing is intriguing and immersive such that I can identify with Jeong. 

However, and this is why I’m not 100% comfortable in recommending the game in its current state, there isn’t much content for the price that you pay. I feel like the current release is more suited as a demo, and even then, I’ve played demos longer than this current released episode. I also haven’t felt the non-immediate effects of my choices, so I look forward to seeing them come back to bite my shiny bum. If content is [i]not[/i] the main criteria that you look for, like me, this game is very much worth a try. Or maybe you'd simply like to support a budding dev. :)

I will, of course, be updating this review when I have the chance to experience more content (along with the new price point), which sounds like it will be soon. \o/
developer_response:
Hey Gievre and thanks for the detailed review, below are some developer comments:

UPDATE: Since your review, another chapter has been added to Yakuza Kiss and it triples the previous build game content. Further chapters will be released as soon as they are ready.

PRICE: As Yakuza Kiss is in Early Access, you are not paying simply for the content that is currently available - you get the entire game, including all future content (which will be substantial). We wish to reward early adopters and supporters and the current price is only a fraction of what the game will cost once it's completed.

SAVE SYSTEM: Currently the game utilizes an autosave system which is similar to what's been used in e.g. Tell Tale adventure games. Since we've had a lot of requests for a manual save system, that is in the works.

TEXT SPEED: You can adjust the text readout speed in the game options (options/game/text character speed). There is now also an autoread function that you can activate and you no longer have to click manually to progress.

BLACK SCREEN: We've had no previous bug reports of this issue, but we'll look into it. Could you please let me know if you still have this issue in our current 0.2 build?

I'd like to underline the fact that our team is very tiny and this project is pushing us to the very edge, but we're making it because we love what we do and we're hoping that players will see that and support us. We're in Early Access because we wish to develop the game together with players so it's essential that we know which features people wish to see in the final game. Feedback that is detailed and well-argued (such as in this review) really helps us, so please send us more of your thoughts via twitter, email or Steam forums.

twitter: https://twitter.com/PinkPotionGames
website: http://www.pinkpotiongames.com
email: info@pinkpotiongames.com
steam forums: https://steamcommunity.com/app/847950/discussions/ 

<3: Pink Potion team

author: {'steamid': '76561198145483815', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1621637703}
review:
This game is great in terms of creating robots, but the issue with it, is that it lacks a goal and this is why I will give it a bad review.
You have to create a goal yourself with repetitive objectives that are always or almost always the same, and there's a moment where you hit the point of "your robot does everything", this means: Why creating a robot with complex mechanics when your shitty bot does the job without any problems ?

Slap a few weapons on it, eventually make a robot that has a magnet or drills with storage for mining and boom you're basically done. I've tried unlocking a few items that can make things a bit more funny logic gates and pistons and blocks that drop a missile and shit like that but the issue is that you finish the campain too fast and too easily with only a few chances to find those blocks that can help you make cooler bots that do different things. And like I said: you can have a correct bot that does everything in a few quests by unlocking stronger weapons that literally destroy the world.

And even worse than that, even if you get the opportunity to use those blocks and logic gates, I'm pretty sure that you will probably be better off using the typical weapons and drills bots than some massive bot with crazy stuff on it.

I discovered this game thanks to Lathland, and back then I remember the campain being way more interesting, I believe they changed it to ... this but why ?

author: {'steamid': '76561198164802869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1707509599}
review: I am a bit disappointed in the current state of this game. I understand it is early access, but for a "multi-level building" tycoon, this lacks the #1 mechanic necessary for that. You can currently only build one floor, despite the advertisements showcasing very large, multi-story luxurious hotels. With only being able to manage one floor, on one map, you run out of space somewhat quickly. Everything soon feels cramped and untidy. This makes it lack the satisfaction you get from creating something aesthetically pleasing, because it eventually becomes a hoard of strung out rooms across a green field. I don't believe I would have been as disappointed in the current state if I didn't feel like I have been mislead into thinking there was more currently here. After looking in to the road map, I was quite disappointed to see that stairs and additional stories to the buildings isn't a high priority to the devs. The game has great potential, and I hope this gets added soon.
developer_response:
Hey,
Thanks for the review/feedback! its really important for us in gauging what people want. 
We are sorry to hear you are disappointed with the state of the game. I can assure you that multi-level building is one of our highest priority features to have implemented. It is where it is on the roadmap because from all of our community feedback it was determined that duplicating rooms was of a higher priority to our fans. 
We are aiming to have a content update every 1-2 months so features like multi-level building are not too far away.
I hope you give the game another try when we add these features and if there is anything else you think is missing or should be added, feel free to share them on our steam discussion board or on our discord.

Thanks again for your feedback, hope you have a nice day!

author: {'steamid': '76561198120385323', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 25561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6195, 'last_played': 1624566025}
review:
I cannot possibly recommend this game to anyone.

I've played 426 frustrating hours of this game. I enjoyed some aspects of gameplay, but the majority of it has been terrible. Crafting is a NIGHTMARE (As explained in the below paragraph), Pay-to-win is a serious problem, and the story ends really badly. (In what would seem like the very middle of the story, with no proper ending, no more story stuff shows up. A bad guy is revealed, he escapes, and we don't go after him. BAD ending.) After a long time (I think more than half a year, but I logged in once 3 months ago to check if anything got better, so Steam can't tell me.) of not playing Crossout, I've realized that I've actually been happier rather than frustrated.

If you don't want to read my experience with this game, skip this paragraph to get to the details.
I used to love this game. It was absolutely amazing the first time I played, thinking of what I could make in the future. Eventually, I discovered that to make the vehicles I would want to make, it would take an absurd amount of money and time. Throughout the game I always played solo, so I never got a Clan, which is required for Relics. (Also, many of the vehicles I wanted to make wouldn't be possible at all, because the parts required don't exist. I once designed a faction to remedy this, hoping that I might be able to get the attention of developers and get at least some of the part concepts into the game. (I think that at this time it was naive to think this.)) Even though I discovered most things I wanted to build were nigh-impossible (w/o paying money), I decided to carry on playing in the hopes I could actually make something fun anyway. I was *mostly* wrong. ("mostly" because I paid for two season passes: Doomsday Cars (because I had just started playing, so I was excited about it,) and The Syndicate. (Because of drifting wheels, a cabin to go with them, and the Kaiju weapon.)) After the Doomsday Cars season, I had a decent cabin (Cohort) to make a semi-decent vehicle. In PvP, I still got annihilated almost every time. Halfway through The Syndicate season, I decided that I would abandon the game after I finished the season pass. It was increasingly clear that the devs would never improve crafting, grinding, or anything else for the free-to-play players. (In fact, in the next season pass, they decided that Legendary stuff from that season could only be crafted during the season, making almost no-one able to get the legendary parts after the season without paying real money.) So I finally abandoned the game when the next season was announced.

For the sake of the math I already had done, here's a list of reasons I don't like Crossout: (Most of this I haven't edited at all.)

1) As rarities are sorted into Common (white), Rare (Blue), Special (cyan), Epic (Purple), Legendary (Yellow-orange), and Relic (Deep orange); there is a very steep increase in material cost in crafting Blue items. White items cost around 50 scrap and 10 copper, Blue items take around 700 scrap and 100 copper. Scrap is a very widely used resource, so you don't always have a lot. I typically have around 200 on average.
2) Crafting time is ridiculous. White items are crafted instantly. Blue are around 15 minutes. Cyan is 2 hours, Purple is 6 hours, legendary is 21 hours, and Relics are 5 days. This is just the time you have to wait after spending the materials!
3) To craft a Relic, you need 2 legendaries, which requires a total of 6 Epics (3 per L.), then 18 Specials (3 per E.), 36 Rares (2 per S.), and finally 72 commons (2 per R.). Each of these crafting tiers also requires a number of materials, making crafting something of a higher tier require sacrificing a number of items whose combined use is far more effective than the one higher-tier item. Based on if you only had to make the same item of each tier, you would need the following materials: 27,260 scrap, 10,312 copper, 3,000 wires, 1,300 plastic, 2,500 electronics, 2,500 batteries, 600 Uranium, and 243 hours of crafting time.
4) You obtain around 20 scrap for pvp victories, 15-ish copper for easy raids, 30-ish copper or plastic for normal raids, around 10 to 20 wires or batteries depending on the pvp mode selected, and almost nothing for "Adventure" mode. I've been unable to do others, as I can't survive hard raids (electronics or copper), and I don't have a clan for Clan Battles (Uranium, only source).
Using this information, it takes around 1,363 PvP wins in Get the Scrap Metal, around 688 easy raid wins for copper, 44 normal raid victories for plastic, 150 Get the Wires wins, 125 Get the Batteries wins, and an amount of wins that is unknown to me of Hard raids for electronics, and Clan battles for Uranium. You have to pay 500 in-game coins to make a clan. I have never been able to make 100 coins without a season pass in my 200 hours of gameplay.

Now here are some GOOD things about Crossout:
1) The vehicle builder is fun and effective to make interesting combat and interesting vehicles, if you can get enough parts.
2) Combat is usually fair between teams, the vehicle's total power score determining who you fight. (Although sometimes its hard when people come in with a powerful weapon on the bare minimum of a car.)
3) There is a semi-decent story.
4) The "Adventure" mode's map is really big, so you have plenty of places to go.
5) There are plenty of options for factions, even if some take forever to unlock. (It's taken 200 hours to get Nomads to level 10 and unlock the Dawn's Children, and get them to level 4.)

EDIT: I've realized that most Legendaries cost 5-7 Epics. I've done enough math, so I'm not gonna bother with rewriting the math. Just know that Relics are impossibly difficult to obtain.

Thanks for reading my review of Crossout. Crossout is a decent game with some incredibly obvious mistakes that make it hard to play. If these mistakes were corrected, and I actually do hope they are, then Crossout would be an amazing game. For a specific list of things that need fixing: Nightmarish crafting needs balance, free-to-play players need some form of means to beat pay-to-win players, the story needs an actual ending, and Relics shouldn't need Clans to access. I do hope this game gets to a playable state for free-to-play players, I would enjoy playing this game if it did.
developer_response:
Hello.
All parts that affect to the battle can be obtain in-game ways: as the rewards for leveling up or you can buy them on the in-game market. So you don't need to spend any real money to buy a weapon, a cabin and so on.
Speaking of grinding: paying attention to weekend specials can make that easier - free workbenches rental and cheaper fusions do help save lots of coins.

author: {'steamid': '76561198180439931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 849, 'last_played': 1677913254}
review:
Where Strangeland, Wormwood studio's OTHER masterpiece, is my personal favorite game in this genre, Primordia touched my heart no less than its successor did. Where Strangeland excels in telling its incredible narrative through the harrowing winds of a tempestuous madness, Primordia excels in delivering an equally provocative narrative through characters, worldpieces, and subtle messages told along the way that reveal a far darker, more sinister background to this bleak and dilapidated landfill we once dubbed Earth.

First off, I need to get this off my chest because I've waited nearly 3 years to say this: Primordia's aesthetic is jaw-droppingly, tear-jerkingly gorgeous to me. I sat for hours in the Unniic just listening to Metromind preach of the grandeur of her City of Glass and Light, and I wish I could go back to make those hours an eternity. Every dusty, broken-down heap, gilded with the faint remnants of a false life, flickering with the melancholy flakes of a binary will that inches to survive; it all was just so haphazardly beautiful to me that it lingered in my psyche for years to come. I think it goes without saying, but the art direction that these games receive is some of the best in the indie industry.

There are a TON of things I'd love to talk about in this review, but I just don't have the time, so I'll limit it to this: Primordia is the first game I've ever played to make me truly question if the antagonist is truly a villain or not. Metromind is a character masterclass on how to truly maroon your audience in the limbo of their own morality. And don't mishear me: other video game antagonists, such as Gwyn, Lord of Cinder from Dark Souls or The Pale King from Hollow Knight, make it perfectly clear that they are morally grey; that have done equally good and bad things and that characterizing them as hero or villain is, at best, shortsighted and foolish. But halfway through her monologues at the peak of the tower, I was seriously questioning whether or not Metromind was truly unjust in both her actions and her ideals, and if I was the fool all along. She's characterized by many to be an authority-hungry power-junky, but if she really wanted to hoard power, she would never have created a city where robots could thrive and never worry about energy usage. She bans religion, and the act of leaving the city, but the robots she cares for just don't know any better. They don't understand that if they leave the city, they'll likely perish in the dunes, or if they worship Man, then they will become preaching slaves to ideals that staunch the act of progress; the very ideal that Metropol runs off of. Every action she took had me question what would truly be the best course of action if NOT that: Either steal the power-sources from outside the dunes and neutralize any hostility in your way, or let Metropol slowly bleed out without the means to provide for its citizens. Either usurp the regents and adjudicators that once held the city together, or let all perish in the wake of your humility. Either stop Horatio and Crispin from taking what's theirs, or let them have it so they can die in silence amidst the nil. It's SOOO interesting, and lingered in my system years after I had completed the game. Because of that ALONE, this game enters my top 10 favorites, and I don't feel a shred of doubt saying that.

Where other mechanical medias focus so much on the age-old, beaten-to-death question, "What does it mean to be Human[?]", Primordia pushes far past that to the point of no return; to a world where we had our chance, and failed, and naught but the scattered shrapnel of that failure remains in our wake, asking us with sorrow, "What remains of Humanity when we are gone?" I can think of few other games that left me staring dead at the screen when it was all over, begging in my mind to relive it all again, if only to die once more. 

...This game costs $10 btw.
developer_response: Wonderful review. Thank you so much (for both of them)!

author: {'steamid': '76561198444333184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 81938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 73, 'playtime_at_review': 80487, 'last_played': 1712153662}
review:
SCUM is realistic take on survival mechanics, That has both impressed and frustrated me since its early access release. While the game's attention to detail and innovative features are admirable, it's essential to address two significant issues: poor frame rates and the impact of overly detailed "jiggle physics" on the female character models.

One of the main concerns for me revolves around SCUM's performance in terms of frame rates. The game's demanding graphics and physics simulations can strain even high-end gaming systems, resulting in sub-optimal frame rates. This issue can severely hinder the overall gaming experience, causing frustration and detracting from the immersive survival atmosphere that SCUM aims to create. This notable in the latest release which along with low frame rates suffers from late object drawing.

To address the frame rate concerns, the developers could consider additional game optimisation. This might involve refining resource-intensive graphical elements, tweaking the rendering pipeline, or providing additional graphics settings to allow players to tailor the game to their hardware capabilities. Frequent updates have been forthcoming from the developer so there is ample opportunity to roll out improvements.


While SCUM strives for realism in its character models, the implementation of overly detailed "jiggle physics" on female characters can contribute to distracting and unrealistic visuals, particularly during intense gameplay moments.

To address this concern, the developers might consider implementing an option in the settings menu that allows players to adjust or disable the jiggle physics effect to their own tastes and system capabilities. Providing players with the ability to customise their gaming experience in this manner would strike a balance between realism and player preference, ensuring a more inclusive and enjoyable environment for all players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198984427717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 985, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1710999966}
review: The game is pretty good, has decent immersion and I like the spaceflight. Everything is done pretty well. Really my only complaints are some bugs that can be worked around and also the flight tutorial, which has the 3rd drone sometimes leaving the training area for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198267515320', 'num_games_owned': 385, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 3372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3196, 'last_played': 1622987246}
review:
SE is a fun game, once you get a hang of it. It just sometimes feels empty... Aside from constructing, there is not much you can do. I also play Empyrion and I love the fact that there are NPCs that attack you, NPC villages to explore, etc. There is actually stuff to do... like in SE I feel like I built that super cool base or ship, just to show it off, since there is nothing really to do with it. 

Still it is a great game. I love how physics work and the detail put into it. For example that resources need conveyors and tubes to be transported instead of just appearing in some storage... Things like that are awesome and if you like construction and building in a space style, than SE is definitely the right game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154638656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 5659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4519, 'last_played': 1666496956}
review:
So the game itself is good but the devs are so stupid they have forced you to use a two-step verification system that forces you to use an email even when you use steam but the system doesn't pick up the fact that your using steam and freaks out so the system itself is bugged and it blocks alot of the content that the game actually has if this system stays in the game then i can see this game die within a year. I just hope the devs look at this and removes it coz it was a dumb move to do in the first place. 

Hot tip for any dev: Don't force people to do things like this, It actually annoys us and then we stop playing.
developer_response:
Hello K1ngsGam1ng!

We are really sorry to inconvenience you and other players with being insistent about the 2-step authentification, but it's really the best way to protect you from phishing scams and other ways of  someone getting an unauthorized access to your accounts. Such cases bring a lot of frustration and stress to players instead of having fun, and we'd really like to help people avoid such situations as the 2020 is full of stress for everyone and everywhere as it is, so we think relatively small inconveniences to activate the protection and avoid the extra stress are worth it.
The system does recognize it when you play via Steam. However, if you activated the 2 step authentification and encountered some unexpected block after it, we would really appreciate it if you could elaborate and let us know more about it so we could fix it. Maybe you could make a bug report and show our developers some screenshots to get to the gist of this phenomenon?

author: {'steamid': '76561198000167056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1454389062}
review:
I'm trying my hardest to have fun here but it just doesn't have the same magic as the originals did, which I played immeditely before starting WFTO

They tried to make the narrator humerous like the older games but they seem to have flandarized him and made him more cartoonishly evil than something actually menacing. 

The designs of the campaign levels I've played as well as some of the sandbox/skirmish levels felt very restrictive, so I never really felt like I was having fun building the dungeons. In DK2 I felt like I was slowly creeping out and corrupting the land, my dungeon growing organically.

WOTF ends up feeling more like a standard RTS than a base-building/management sim that I liked in Dungeon Keeper. It's not terrible, but it's also not what I was looking for.
developer_response:
Hi Ikarrus,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2015. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since release:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. One of these are completely free for you!
- New Game Modes
- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate
- Entirely new Skirmish AI

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561198040337092', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 67464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61360, 'last_played': 1688070075}
review:
Just say no! Messy as it has always been. If you have spare week to get decent spawn near must have ores, engines are still total crap ad I need literaly hundreds of then for any bigger ship, I wont even mention mulltiplayer as it was so bad that I even do not play it anymore. 
Anyway this is just my opinion. 

PS. New color scheme for ores are also nightmare.

Edit: And yea Keen, you had plenty of time to "help me", now I am rewriting my opinion just to warn people of your game, but some people like to suffer, so choice is on them :)

Edit 30.06.2022: I must edit my review as I play it again so despite all it's fallbacks, I guess it is very nice and enjoyable to play, once I change my building aproach. I will still say that engines are crappy with their poor power, which requires whole nacelles and half of ship overed in engines to make it fly decently, but that is engineering problem to solve right? Anyway, I will say positive and low DLC price is nice bonus.

Edit 13.2.2023: I decided to try and play again to see if any of stuff i hated in game got fixed or at least eased if that is possible. So in short nope. New bugs, along with old ones. My game crashes and tart spinning in circles almost every 2-3 plays. Engines are still ginormous but they still can't power ship even if they want to. What ever design I try without mods I need at least 1/2 up to even 2/3 of my ship to be engines. Nope i am done...again. I even am not sure what I was expecting i guess.
Edit: 23.6.2023. I tried to play again due to pure boredom. So i said to myself if I accept fact that all above is as is, will i be able to play? Well answer is as expected...no. I made small bump with atmospheric engine during docking and whole engine exploded and disintergated. Lovely. And I already spend too much time on this garbage.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989722747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1501105994}
review:
Ok, I know I put NO but I do also recommend this game.  As EVERYONE is saying the AI is...potato at best. Let me explain.

1. People will stand idle for days at a time.  Need your biologists to maintain plants? nah they're gonna hang in this tunnel and O2 generator for awhile.  Need your Medic to use a "medical supply" on a injured colonist? nah they're gonna sleep, eat, cross the entire map to take ore to the metal processor INSTEAD OF HEALING THE WORKER WHO FRANKLY IS WAAAAY MORE IMPORTANT.
2. Everything is suicidal - Oh sandstorms here that hurts our health and incapacitates robots? well our omnipresent lord and master hasnt built a control center to put a yellow alert up so LETS GO OUSIDE! *dies/KOs*
3.  Food disappears super suddenly because you cant really tell how much food is needed to feed people - For example 10ish people with a small biodome making food and you have a surplus of 40+ vegetables.  11 people? HAHA everyone gets to starve now! Prioritizing doesnt help either as that doesnt effect production time just keeping the growing plants healthy.
4. Power dissapears all to quickly at night unless you've somehow managed to mass produce STUPID amounts of Backup batteries.  Solar power doesnt work at night (duh) and I can accept that, but wind is SOOOO underpowered.  Right before nighttime the wind never fails to stop...completely and then the batteries drain at uberspeed, especially when you have just gotten a start in expanding.  5 buidings OK at night 6? Yeah...well good luck with that.  Again you could just place more solar and generators during the day but it takes DAYS for the AI to get around to building Metal from ore.
5.  Prioritizing anything is luck at best.  Need starch (for plastic) well unless you happen to have extra resourses laying around for a med or large biodone then you have to sacrifice food.  Need Medical plants? yup same deal you sacrifice food and starch (for plastic).

Now the AI...it just doesnt seem to want to work with you.  you can have recources available and people will just loiter forever.  The only thing I see to fix it is to unprioritize everything, stop building, and wait for every loose item to be gathered and taken to its home.  Then AND ONLY THEN will a medic heal a person or a engineer/robot go build a building.  Heck the builder robot routinly does the carry robots job while the carry robot just idles around.  It seems like the AIs prioritizing is alittle off deeming gathering over healing or expansion. 

So why do I also recommend it? Now maybe this is just because of the finicy AI but mistakes are punished.  Your building an outpost ona distant planet you cant just be given everyhting super easy, though a few extra resources in the colony craft woudnt be harmful.  The models are pretty nice if a little lacking in variety.  The game doesnt slog along, once you start you (logicaly) only have a short while to get oxygen, water and food going. Though itd be nice if either you had more food or people didnt have black holes for necessities.  The core mecanics are there and the game has good foundations, its just a wait to see how they do with newer content. 

Improvement wise there needs to be some more movement of parts.  Sure the solar panels turn and wind turbines turn but oxygen? nah static movement, water? nope? food? nope, just spits out veggies and such occasionally.  Rooms are just that, rooms theres nothing amazing about them to make you zoom in and marvel at whats happening.  I just watch the resources and when theres enough I build a building.  Which is bad as im not LOOKING at the game, just teh charts and resource monitors, the game could have been a top down or ASCII game for the amount of time ive looked at things.  Rooms should be specialized when you build them imo, biodome? select food, startch, or medical plants and then upgrade it over 4 levels 1/4 full, 2/4 full etc and have it fill with various things.  Have some airducks that have little streamers blowing to show air is present, have the med bay bed perform diagnostics on a injured person.  have water spriklers in the biodome.  This would need some more balancing to make it not game wrecking but showers and toilets as apparently hygene isnt important in space. maybe mine more then ore like precious metals to trade.  Theres so much room for improvement but I think that the resources need a major overhaul first as anything gets added to this game and it might make everything break.  Especially since everything is based on 2 singular things, metal and bioplastic, the amount needed just to get stuff rolling is crazy even if its just 1 or 2 of each.

Still, idk, I like this game but I know that its only...20% if that.  The base game is there but is in need of balancing and additional things to do as honestly the game relies alittle to much on luck atm.  Also once the AI gets tweaked im sure this will get much better.  Heres to hoping the gtame isnt just dropped by the producers.  

Id give this a 5.5-6/10.  Playable and just fun enough to not drive you insane.
developer_response:
Hi there,

Thank you for your feedback.

We've made many AI improvements since launch over these months.

Maybe you would consider getting the latest version and playing the game again.

Regards.
Martino.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012610173', 'num_games_owned': 853, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 132702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6, 'playtime_at_review': 80235, 'last_played': 1711556097}
review: 1337 hours, I can't believe it... the meme-level playtime I spent in this game is only matched by the meme-level amount of times I re-did this review. Elite is a space sim that requires a bit more imagination by players, as the upgrade-loop you have in most games does not totally apply here. Sure you can go and upgrade your ship and get better stuff and shoot things or earn billions with trading, exploration or mining apart from combat, but what makes Elite so great is the actual experience. There's a plethora of player groups, squadron and role play communities that simply are in for the fun. Saving players who ran out of fuel mid-transit, killing evildoers or robbing players when a trading event is on is as fun as doing the more traditional stuff. It has a 1:1 scale galaxy, a very well done flight model, insanely good sound design and every venue of gameplay except piracy is profitable. They even made the DLC-content free, so everyone can land on planets now and have SRV-races on a 0.2g planet. So you go out there, explore, shoot, trade, and do your thing. Meet other players, make some friends, and wait for space legs so we can explore, shoot and meet some more. This game has accompanied over a long time and while there are some issues in terms of balancing, connection and economy I always felt like having a good time. Plus, if you die in this game, it's your fault, pick your fights and slow down in the mail slot. o7

author: {'steamid': '76561198040735864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 894, 'last_played': 1587909404}
review:
This game is a cross between Endless Legends and Space. One of the biggest problem with this game is its maps. It is procedurally generated and in many instances, it is not actually playable due to haphazard generation of mountain tiles; which also makes city development extremely difficult.

Another big problem is the load time and initialization time of the game; one has to wait for a long time to load a game. The unit roster and combat mechanics is OK and immersing enough.

The technology tree is without much depth, in fact compared to other 4X games, it is almost non existent in terms of the aspects it covers. The game apparently has all the required components for an engaging game-play but the components are somehow not meshed together properly or are in a very rudimentary stage.

Another big problem is the city management screen; the map in this screen can be zoomed in and out but not moved. This becomes a tremendous problem as city development in this game largely tend to be lopsided and seem to be extended in one direction due to the mountain issue mentioned above.

I found the game very strange in that at micro level it has every thing (exploration, resource management, map, tech tree, combat), yet at macro level (overall game level) it does not have the depth, game-play, tactics and it feel very empty.

Since the game is in EA, hope is that developers would correct some of the flaws. At this point it is not worth investing money in the game, one should wait or all together skip this title.

One thing does need to be mentioned and highlighted. The developers have done a fantastic job in terms of the stability of the game. It is rock solid and has not crashed or become slow for once in my entire play-through. This in itself is a major achievement; given that many of the  'big' titles have not achieved this kind of stability many years into release.
developer_response:
Hello!
Since this review was posted we've released new updates which include new content, so we hope you can give the game another try and hopefully have a great time.
Note: you can destroy/flatten mountain tiles using the terraforming module. Cheers!

author: {'steamid': '76561197990427994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 16630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14990, 'last_played': 1702956799}
review:
Short review-
buy it on sale 10-15 dollars, especially if you are ok with rust, and like zomboid. If you can't make it past the initial huge learning curve you won't waste too much money.


Longer review-
Recommending was a toss up. There is so much potential it is insane, and I do ultimately enjoy it, but there is a lot to unpack. 

Scum is the love child of Rust and Project Zomboid. Like Zomboid it has a steep learning curve. Very steep. If you are learning on your own, I estimate 50 hours if you have limited similar experiences to really have a grasp on how to survive, assuming you are learning most of the game and not skipping things.

Like Rust there is raiding and pvp, but it heavily depends on the server. Make no mistake 60 people on 1 server at once is a lot. Once you have the basics down, you can largely simplify the game if you please. You can sustain yourself on a simple diet, and you don't have to build or farm, and making money becomes easier. Many players live off of stashes they place in world and are baseless.

The way I see it the devs care about the game, but not about the players. This deserves further explanation. There are basically 0 quality of life features. If you want basic wood arrows, you need to cut sticks into small stick, then craft each arrow. Find a box of nails? Have fun right clicking and then left clicking remove nail for the next few minutes. That isn't fun, it is work. 

To add insult to injury there used to be faster ways to do it, like being able to craft a nail with the required material being a box of them, but that was removed for some reason. It is a simple recipe, it wouldn't take an hour to code it in from scratch, and if you just used a form it would take minutes. 

To make things a little more aggravating you need dozens if not hundreds of nails, bolts and bobby pins, which means you are unpacking for an hour of two if you do it all at once. Again, this is work, not fun. Further, your first base will likely be made with primitive gear, which means a simple 2x2 can take hours. 

Not very much is intuitive either, so it can be VERY frustrating. There are even keyboard commands that arent shown on the keybindings, which should piss anyone off. Because of this the game ultimately feels like the devs don't respect the players time which explains why the game is on life support.

In my experience official servers are more toxic than Rust official. The main reason is feuding. Some people hold grudges in rust, but the reality is that in rust there is usually such a high pop that are all doing the same thing, that people forget because in 30 minutes it happened again 2-3 times. Sometimes it goes further but I have yet to hear about long time players holding a grudge more than a day or two without a specific reason, like racism etc. Scum servers have to be smaller, so people will try to punish you specifically often. While this can be fun if it is a friendly competition, most people who are new don't want to deal with that. Ever have someone find all your bases and only raid you and constantly hunt for specifically you, before you were really established? I have it sucks, and there was literally nothing I could do. I was prim, and he had rifles. Why? apparently I built my first base too close to him, but I had no idea where he was. Maybe 2 hours in on my first time loading.

The actual gameplay is great, the animations are really good, plenty of things to do if you just want to learn playing solo. I do find the shooting to be the most accurate to real life than in any game I have ever played, with there being a bullet rise before drop, windage etc. So sniping can be really complicated compared to most other games, and in one case I hit a friend in the head with a shot at over a grid away. Unfortunately most servers wont have draw distance that high, but hey that happened and it was awesome. The hunting is incredibly hard, and the best way I can describe it is like spot and stalk irl, which isn't practiced a lot, and is quite difficult, harder than irl to be honest. Anyone who hunts knows hunting is not easy either. The fishing is fun. PVP is fast, as in incredibly fast. 1-2 shots and it is likely over, and even if you win, you could still die from the injury or infection. That is why server pops can not be too high.  

The game can be very fun after the learning curve, and there are many people who are helpful, and nice (relatively speaking, don't ask where their base is and they wont say goodnight). The online tutorials are ok, but until you figure it out do yourself a favor and start on a pve server. The game is immensely different than any other I have found, and you will need time to acclimate to it

author: {'steamid': '76561198070168327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1667867167}
review: I think that the game is a great concept and I've really enjoyed my time I've spent playing it. The biggest downside for me is there is this awful bug where if you zoom in too much on an angle or something the camera will orient itself straight down like a top down game, and it messes up the artwork in the game and I really don't enjoy it. (There's also no way to orient your camera out of this unless you open a previous save, which can be a problem sometimes.) Otherwise it needs some work, so I wouldn't recommend buying it yet, but if it's on sale and farther along production I'd totally recommend this game!
developer_response:
Hi castironcassim,

Thank you for taking the time to write a review. As an indie developer all feedback is important to us.

Camera controls will be improved during development however we aren't aware of a bug that causes the camera to get stuck in a top down view. Assuming the mouse wheel does not function for you to zoom out you could try opening up a villager or building window and use the crosshairs (focus) button to see if that rectifies the issue for you.

We would be interested to get more information from you regarding the bug if you would be happy to send a bug report to support@polymorph.games

Cheers
Ash

author: {'steamid': '76561198141451349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 13501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 552, 'last_played': 1588539218}
review:
After series of patches it happened what I worried about - developer dumbed down physics.  Right after the release the game was quite challanging as the feedback from tyles was more realistic and it was easier to crash.

Last upgrades showed that Milestone dont want to keep the game realistic, and prefer to focus on more arcadish game play. Its sad because if someone want  more realism the game starts to get boring after some time. Bikes are very stable, the feedback of tyres is very high and also you can press the brake in full lean and bike will not instantly crash...

What I like about game:
-great onboard experience
-pitobards
-tyre compound simulation
-multiplayer lobbies
-helmet, number, back patch customisation
-MotoE!

What I dislike:
-arcadish physics with big amount of feedback and grip
-lack of option to lock onboard in online races
-no ride through penalty
-no damage to the bike

In general MotoGP19 is a huge step forward comparing to all previous games.
developer_response: Hi KG_03, thanks for your review. You talked about broken dashboards in some bikes, in order to fix them, could you tell us which bikes have this problem? Thanks again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016025867', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 224105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163681, 'last_played': 1695445721}
review:
I usually don't write reviews, but her it goes.
5 years playing and participating with the community to help creating this game, giving feedback, suggestions, ideas, bug reports, and all that stuff you do when you enter an Early Access project. Maybe some of you knows that I have been making tons of videos of Space Engineers. Although, my channel was terminated recently, due to some community violations BS, that some people suspect it was a network inside job conspiracy theory.
Anyways... There was glorious, impressive moments, amusement, but also rage, disappointing, delusions, etc. You can't have everything. But since I am not an MP kind of guy, at least in this type of games. I didn't feel that part of the community rage, I know it was bad though. So, I only played and enjoyed very much the Creative and Survival since the beginning, of course always wanting to have more stuff and things to ask Devs to add to the game, but as I said, we can't expect them to add everything we ask for, right?
The Survival mode for sure needs a revamp, I know you can add tons of mods or play a custom scenario. But a core new feature would be 100 times better, and for some reason I preffer the game Vanilla as possible. I love mods of course, an also think some of them should be in the game core as essential. 
Even the Creative mode needs improvements, in the way that there is a few blocks that seems to be missing. Particulary corners blocks, mechanical blocks, and perhaps a few aesthetic blocks. Again, "there is amod for that". I know dooooh!
But know, the MP part, which I repeat I am not particulary interested in, it has been Updated. A massive marathonic work from Keen to fix the MP once and for all. of course, I tried it, and I just... it blowed my mind. 30-40-60 people in one server, all together, almost no lag, no desync, no rubberbanding. I mean, if you compare this New Multiplayer from 2-3 years ago, this is for sure a huge improvement, it even makes me want to join MP or Coop servers now.
Anywas, ending this text wall, now. 
TL;DR do not expect a very rich Survival solo game (unless the surprise us with a New Survival Overhaul Soon(tm)), or a mega massive online space battle. The game is very hardware demanding, since it have phiycs and stuff. But don't be afraid to search the workshop, there are great mods there that will make this experience way more enjoyable, and game modes, custom scenarios, other people's creations as well.
developer_response:
SpetS, thank you very much for this review and the feedback. 

Our team is working hard to make the Space Engineers a perfect game and it wouldn't be possible without our community. 

Thank you again and enjoy playing Space Engineers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198344616766', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1690173700}
review:
This game is freaking awesome. I've played a bit of it... about 72 minutes of it and just bought it on march 9th. Never heard of this game. Saw it was 12% off and saw the trailer... I was like "Dude this seems like a remastered version of papers please" but it's more than just checking documents, you check cargo, go on police chases. Transport criminals and the things they tried smuggling. It's a bit confusing to know what to do specifically because I didn't know why I was getting deducted money for letting people in when they seemingly looked good to go but that's the thing with the game. At least they should implement a small thing where it tells you what made them not approvable but it's whatever. I would hands down recommend this game to anyone that likes that dystopian, border guard lifestyle.

Edit: Just looking at it now, they do have an audit system where they tell you what the problem was if inspection was incorrectly carried out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198232122804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1692570632}
review:
I bought it when it was on sale and i wish i just used that money for a different racing game. The PVE is stupid easy when you get the hand of it and never gets harder. I would win every race by a long shot and its never challenging or fun anymore. The PVP is ok and playable, but its still not great. The race constantly stops in the middle due to host migrations and people lagging, and even though you are playing with other people it isn't satisfying. 

If you are thinking about buying it, i would recommend that you go look at other racing games before hand because you will most likely find something wayy better, but overall it does work and isn't unplayable.
developer_response: Hi TheRugBug! I'm very sorry to hear that you experience lag in PVP races in The Crew 2. To improve your gameplay experience when racing, I'd suggest completing our [url=support.ubi.com/en-US/faqs/000035320/Connectivity-Issues-in-The-Crew-2-On-PC-TC2/]connectivity guide[/url] for The Crew 2 in full. This will ensure your connection to the game's online services is optimized, which should help to reduce any lag you may experience. You can always reach out to our support team at support.ubi.com for further assistance if needed!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048316188', 'num_games_owned': 84, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1577895302}
review:
This game is a lot of fun even with the litte content it has so far. The "story" (so far) is pretty linear and can be completed relatively quickly, but you miss out on a lot of things to explore and possibly improve if you only focus on that. At first whenever you go on a spacewalk there is this constant pressure of time and running out of air, but later on you can travel quite far with oxygen refill points you can build and some suit upgrades.
 
The only thing that annyoed me a bit was the somewhat arbitrary cold spots and the very low durability of tools you are basically constantly running back to craft new tools or run with half the inventory taken up by spare tools to at least get a few things done in one run. 

It's definitely worth picking up for the price and already announced chapters still to come. Can't wait to continue this hilarious adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048683516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 10728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2689, 'last_played': 1511573905}
review:
A lot of the bad reviews are beause of the shennanigans pulled with the horizons expansion - lots of people had loads of time and community content completely wiped as a result.
I, however, was fortunate enough not to be affected by this, as I never bought horizons until after it had its conversion to DLC.

My time with the game so far has been very enjoyable - it definitely takes a lot of learning to get into this game, but there are some helpful tutorials to get you going. They by no means cover everything, and time, effort and research are needed to get a proper understanding of the game, but are a good start.

I love the beauty and scale of this game, and the variety in terms of ships. I haven't played long enough to judge every aspect of the game, as this game is truly massive with so much being possible, but haven't found anything yet that has made me even consider setting this game down, despite a lot of the complaints it recieves.

I recommend this game to anyone who is willing and able to put a lot of time into it - this isn't something you can just dip into and out of, it requires dedication and time to properly make the most of it. I can definitely see myself sinking many many more hours into this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025315297', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2193, 'last_played': 1649908396}
review:
There's a paradox in this game that is one half of the game being dailies and artificial caps on everything while the other half wants you to grind endlessly for whatever reason it can come up with.

Want a class? Do a daily for about 8 days to unlock it.
Want a cosmetic set? Do a daily for like a dozen or so days to unlock one part of the set of 8 equipment.

Want some event items? Pray to RNGesus and keep killing what was supposed to be some important boss multiple times in a row.
Want to level up? Grind about 5 times more than the usual normalcy of MMOs (and I'm talking about Runescape/Everquest [and no I'm not talking about maxing things, I'm talking about leveling up combat]).
Want to continue the plot? Do the same exact "Kill X, Y times to collect A/B/C/D/E/F/G/H/I/J/etc." mission with a blurb or two to justify needing to kill the same exact monster again instead of just killing it beforehand and gathering more than one bear ass from the same corpse before going back to the bear ass fetishist to get the same bear ass again.

The fun part is you can make grinding fun, like in horde games like PoE/BDO or make the rpg combat reactive like in ESO/TSW/Neverwinter/Dragon Age Origins (even if it doesn't outweigh the pain of the grind at least have SOMETHING entertaining about your games other than lore puns), but the daily limit, the spawn rates of both monsters AND items, and the merge shop just makes this MMO less of a game and more of a chore.

I paid 50 bucks to be entertained, not to do chores. 
Speaking of, 50 bucks packs in a "beta" spanning years is a huge warning sign. Still kicking my own ass over that decision.

I would say I expected more from Artix Entertainment, but this was apparently just a downhill saga in a downhill slope of their history of having absolutely no idea how games work.
developer_response:
Thank you for your review and feedback. 

Dailies are a small part of the game and optional and there are no artificial caps. Caps are in place to keep the game fair and balanced. Any 'grinding' is also optional and the devs are reworking many quests to lessen the grind. 

If a player does want a different class than the base classes, that is also optional and they can choose to work to earn it (and learn about the class) or can pay DCs outright. 

There are some items in the game that are random drops and are a challenge to get. This is another optional feature of the game, as items can be obtained in multiple ways.

AQ3D is free to play, and purchasing any packages are also completely optional. You don't need to pay $50 to be entertained and what players want to do or have it the game is their choice. The game is in Open Beta and any rewards Guardians receive are all available except the Guardian Tower features which are in progress. The devs just posted this update about the Nature Guardian Tower on May 11th - https://aq3d.com/news/art_sneek_peek/.

The devs are constantly working on fixing and improving issues and releasing updates/patches weekly. This has been a constant balance as an indie game company with a small staff. Please check out the Game Plan and Design Notes for updates - https://aq3d.com/news/ & https://aq3d.com/game-plan/.

AQ3D is definitely not like other MMOs - our company has never played by the normal 'rules' of creating games - we like taking risks, doing crazy events and releases and love using puns. We are definitely not everyone's cup of tea, but will continue to release fun, exciting, wacky and memorable content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010305509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1635618534}
review:
Saw this game had to play it, got a Subnautica (In space) vibe off of it.

First of all this game is f&*cking hilarious, it's a game that doesn't take itself too serious, the jokes just keep on coming. Made my entire experience very entertaining.

GamePlay - 5/5 plays alot like Subnautica. Air is your survival gauge, run out and you're losing health until dead. You can unlock an ugrade later on to give you an extra 30% time, helps a long way. They also offer other upgrades to your suit. Pay close attention to your controls I completely missed ALT  and the Shift's button's function.

Story - 4/5 The story is a plus, it's not oscar worthy but man is it entertaining. Chick-Chick...Chicken!
You can beat this in about 1-2 hours after you understand the resources and where to find them. 

Can't wait till they finish the story, it's relatively short (So far) but pretty hilarious,

author: {'steamid': '76561198083387045', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 24705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19470, 'last_played': 1682111907}
review:
This game is, honestly not very interesting after a while if you're playing by yourself

BUT

If you manage to get yourself into a squadron, or you're in a gaming clan, playing with friends is hundreds of hours worth of fun (and still counting)

You are essentially free to do whatever you want with no restrictions on what you can do (within the confines of the games abilities)

wanna be a trader? make your billions trading.... home system under attack by aliens? swap that refinery for a shield generator and dive into the battle!

No skill-sytstems or levelling to limit your characters gameplay to one specific path! :D 

just... make sure you slow down BEFORE you hit your friend's expensive ship, knocking out his shield and him into an asteroid -_-

author: {'steamid': '76561198045516664', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1535501115}
review:
[quote]Edit Saturday, November 3, 2018:
As a Monomyth developer posted below this review, this game has changed a lot since it's release and since I wrote this review. While I do not currently have time to give the game another shot due to classes, keep in mind that the review below is not an accurate reflection of the current version of Need to Know.
[/quote]

So I tried to like this game, I really did, and I was one of the ones who followed the hype from the first trailer release in the Kickstarter campaign. I really looked forward to the Papers, Please -eqsue surveillance game that the trailers advertised. Holding out to release (remember, no pre-orders!), however, revealed some key flaws that the game has.

[h1]Lack of Tutorial[/h1]
The lack of a tutorial is my primary issue with Need to Know. With almost zero instruction given, the player has no clue on how to progress, how to use the different tools provided in-game, and what distinguishes a subject between a "safe" individual and a threat. Players are expected to know beforehand what all the tools do and how to use them effectively, and  with the game not arming the players with that knowledge, I and many others were left confused as to what to do almost constantly.

[h1]User Interface[/h1]
The current user interface is extremely similar to the user interface that was advertised throughout the developer cycle. While it seems to be extremely sleek and inviting, don't let its looks fool you. The UI was another primary issue with Need to Know. In practice, the UI was sluggish and huge on-screen, with every single element in each window being blown up unnecessarily. Everything except any back or close indicators, which took minutes to find on several occasions. In the beginning of the game, it even took me about 10 minutes to figure out how to begin the first mission! 

[h1]Final Evidence is not consistent with Evidence Requirements[/h1]
At the beginning of each mission, you are given specific key evidence to look out for while analyzing individuals. Several times, the evidence the game wanted me to find were inconsistent with the requirements it gave me. This meant I often “missed” evidence which was never actually listed as a requirement.

[h1]Inconsistent Results after Missions[/h1]
As part of the story, you need to build up your agency's trust in you by successfully analyzing, identifying key elements a suspect might exhibit, and eventually classifying the subject as safe or a threat. These trust points given, however, were often inconsistent. Successfully classify and identify all pieces of evidence in a mission? Have 15 trust points! Missed one piece of evidence? There goes 30 points!

[h1]Inconsistent Dialogue[/h1]
Have a bad day and lose a lot of trust points? Doesn't matter, your boss will let you know what a great job you did today!

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
While many people (such as myself) disregard the bug warnings in games and play them anyway only to still have a positive experience, let me tell you that it is not the case with this game. Throughout playing, I experienced numerous bugs, some of which were game breaking or needed a restart. For example, after losing in the prologue (why is that even possible?) and making a new profile the game glitched out and showed two different points in the story, progressing through them simultaneously, requiring a full restart of the game and clearing out the old profile and creating a new profile. Notifications on your in-game phone often appear and disappear in under a second, not giving you enough time to read what it says. You can’t even change the wallpaper.

[h1]In Conclusion[/h1]
In its current state, I cannot recommend Need to Know. The game has vital problems that it needs to solve, problems so important that it makes you wonder if Monomyth Games even play-tested all the features in-game before the final release, in despite of several beta versions being released to Kickstarter backers in the previous months. The game feels like a rushed beta version, even though the game was delayed by a month. Should Monomyth Games fix these key issues, I would gladly re-purchase the game for another shot at Need to Know.
developer_response:
Hi, we’re glad you followed Need to Know so closely, and are sorry that it disappointed you upon release. We appreciated your thorough, clear review, and have since worked hard to address many of the issues you raised.

[h1]Lack of Tutorial[/h1]
Tutorials are now in place for key points in the game, particularly in the opening sequences. Gameplay is now also more clearly directed, and will continue to improve.

[h1]User Interface[/h1]
Our UI scaling now sets all windows much smaller as a default, and allows you to adjust the size with a slider to fit your preferences, which helps to minimize visual clutter. We can see how the interface was initially confusing, but with the new tutorials and more visual guidance, you should find that this issue has been heavily remedied.

[h1]Final Evidence is not consistent with Evidence Requirements[/h1]
Thanks to our helpful, enthusiastic community, we’ve corrected the vast majority of these inconsistencies. Although some may still be lurking around, they should now be negligible, and we’re working to root them out as soon as they’re reported. 

[h1]Inconsistent Results after Missions[/h1]
Although the Department of Liberty is an unforgiving organization that does not tolerate mistakes, we understand that the point deductions may have been harsh (particularly when coupled with unclear gameplay). We’ve rebalanced the Compliance system, so that you won’t be punished as heavily for errors. 

[h1]Inconsistent Dialogue[/h1]
We agree that this issue would have been immersion-breaking! Since release, we’ve expanded dialogue branches in most post-mission conversations so that NPCs now react more accurately to your performance. Your boss will no longer pat you on the back for a terrible work performance. 

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
We have fixed major, game-breaking bugs and addressed a host of minor issues that made the experience far more burdensome than it needed to be. The glitches you experienced should now be long-gone, and you can no longer be booted from the Department after the opening interview sequence. Though it was possible to re-load the game at this point, this was not clear enough, resulting in some players replaying the entire intro, which would have been irritating.
Also, you can change your phone wallpaper, and we’ll soon be adding a much larger range!

You and other reviewers are right in pointing out the game’s flaws on release, and we appreciate that you managed to be constructively critical without any malice. Since launch though, we’ve worked very hard to correct these problems, and in the future, will continue to make the game richer and more complex. For example, we’re currently implementing financial pressures, and more choice-based outcomes for home missions.

If you do get a chance to try the game again, and you encounter any issues you'd like to let us know about, you can head over to the Steam discussions or our Trello board [url=https://trello.com/b/ABG1gSZb/need-to-know-bugs-feature-requests]here[/url], and we'll fix it as soon as we can!

We really hope you give Need to Know another shot, and that your second experience is much more closely aligned with your expectations. Thanks for your time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011768105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 4300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2615, 'last_played': 1699657007}
review:
This one is a rare gem.

In the end, it comes down to a relaxing gameplay loop of you vs physics. The game does not tell you much about how things work, yet it also tells you everything in the details. It's just so many details and systems that it is very intimidating at start.
Don't expect clear health bars or exact states of everything. And that is really cool the way it is, after all you spectate the ship from a drone far away - with all the sensor interference and whatnot.
It is this unknown that drags one in and this captures the look and feel of a space mining operation very well.

On one side, the game is rather simple and easy. You fly around, shoot rocks, collect cargo, get back to base, repair, upgrade, repeat.
On the other hand, it can be beautifully difficult if you run full speed into the fields or follow some of the quest lines.

The game gets really frequent updates, the demo was just patched to be basically a full version so you can donate the cash to people who need it more in these times.
Huge respect for the one man show the dev is pulling off here.

I spent quite some time with the game and loved it.

Early access communication (discord, streams) and updates are exemplary.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020981093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1552420789}
review: After spending several frustrating hours at this game, I am now inclined to say to save your money. There are several key elements to this game that are missing, under developed, or just plain broken. The tutorial is vastly under developed, the issues present make everything maddeningly frustrating, and I shouldn't have to spend hours reading through outdated forums trying to pick apart what works and what doesnt. Save your money, this is a concept and needs a lot more work before it should have been released.
developer_response:
Thanks for review.
Indeed, some aspects may have serious bugs or flaws. But definitely not "everything".

This is a complex game with many complex features, so it is not an easy task to create a comfortable user interface and tutorial for each aspect of the game.
But we are constantly working on improvements of usability and fixing the most critical bugs. Currently there is not so many of them actually. Earlier the game was really bugged, but now we are fixed most of critical bugs. The rest of them will be solved pretty soon.

Information in this Guide is pretty up-to-date
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=557510735

Also if you will have any issues, feel free to contact with us in the Discord chat:
https://discordapp.com/invite/celestialcommand
We are answering to everyone and in many cases reply almost instant.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999926754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1618121318}
review:
I don't know. Some people are going to like it just because it has the crafting element. It was pitched to me as "like subnautica but in space", which sounded appealing to me because I loved subnautica. But I found myself floating around the same space over and over again without any real sense of exploration. The game tries very hard to be funny, but it just isn't. Yet its intrusive jokes just keep right on coming, every five seconds, completely confident in themselves, but still not funny. At times I could barely concentrate on what I was doing because the unfunny comedy man would not stop talking to me. It got to a point where I was just kinda boringly floating around space looking for material that I couldn't find anywhere. I looked it up in the guide and that wasn't helping. I floated around, slowly, tediously, for like two hours trying to find one mat. I was gonna just google it but then I decided I'll probably just play something else.

Aaaaalmost good game with overconfident not-funny jokes / 10

review:
Fantastic concept and I reeeeally want to love this game.

Unfortunately the AI needs some major work, just the fact that bots go idle when I have had a second O2 plant waiting to be constructed for about ten minutes and then people start dying.. Regards.
Martino.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098401282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1618457081}
review:
I have bought some excellent and fully working professional games for £10. This isn't one of those.
It's amateurish, undocumented and somewhat childish.
"You are starving". Really? You start playing and suddenly you're starving. Not hungry, nor in need of food. Starving.

The standard of graphics with it's faceless characters shows from the beginning that it starts as badly as it means to go on.
'Planeshift' is better than this, and it's free.
developer_response:
Thank you for your feedback, sorry to hear you do not like the game, i will take on board what you have said about the messaging about hunger etc and look to implement asap. 

As for the graphics, you were clearly aware of the level of graphics for the game as they are displayed on the video and all other screenshots, however in the future with further investment there will be additional graphics being released.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013414847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 1449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 911, 'last_played': 1616245364}
review:
Wow, this game is a unique experience. I absolutely love it.

You start with being alone on an outpost, barely functioning, jsut after your spaceship (capsul) crashed. That sense of danger and loneliness there, supported by the great music in this game, was very intense for me. I like being alone; so that´s probably one reason why I love this game. 

Aside from managing and expanding your base (energy, food, housing etc.) you go outside, exploring Titan with your rover or on foot; gathering data, ressources and information. You spend it on research and  supplies. You find people to connect and trade with; like a Chineese base, a trader from a free enterprise, your home crew and some more. 

You got to develope your charakter, RPG style, and have to decide on which abilities you spend your xps; for you can´t level em all to max during one play-through; and each skill provides you with the means to complete the quests for one of the factions; each delivering a different ending.

Not going on here for longer, since other players wrote it down in way better English already. 

Just want to point out it´s been programmed by but one person and he did a phantastic job on this. Would not want to have missed this game. One of the few in recent years that managed to make me thrilled to play on the next day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049840197', 'num_games_owned': 484, 'num_reviews': 382, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1588996596}
review:
Idk if you all can see Dev replies but I can and this one from three months ago is. Well, kinda bullshit really. "Everything you're asking for is in the works! If you look at our track record with games like DUSK and AMID EVIL you know we're going to make MAXIMUM Action just as complete and polished as our other games. Hope you'll be back for future updates!" ~El Oshcuro August 7th 2019

Since then not a single feature I noted as missing has been added and not a single update for Maximum Action has happened. But the devs did announce a new game to add to the pile of stuff their developing. Behavior like this is why I detest Early Access game design. If you want a good example of how it should look go look at Postal 4 or Overgrowth. Games were the dev team was commited to them and focused all there efforts on a single game. They also published frequent updates and in the case of Overgrowth have a  400+ video youtube playlist showcasing every single build of the game. I wouldn't buy this game again and I certainly would not recommend that you buy it either. At this point it seems like the devs have abandoned Maximum Action in favour of their more popular titles Amid Evil and Dusk. 

Original review:

As with most early access games I can barely call it a game. Yes theres mechanics, levels too, and some of them can be quite fun but a "Game" is something that can be won or lost, and often theirs a progression from start to end.

Maximum Action doesn't really have this, no high score boards or story, no unlocks. No progression at all. You start with full acess to everything and it makes the game feel empty. Like cheating for a full weapon set and unlimited money in GTA. It makes the whole game feel completely uninteresting and I have no reason to bother playing it. No achievements, levels, weapons or skins to unlock.

Maximum Action seems to be banking on user generated content but unless your game has a huge fanbase you're not going to get far banking on the modding/steam workshop scene to carry your game. Always the games with the largest workshops/modding scenes have been games like Left 4 Dead or Skyrim. Games that were around LONG before the workshop was a thing and almost everyone who has a PC has played them. 

Maybe this game might be worth it if its on sale. But for 20 bucks I find myself hesitant to recommend it.  

Overall buy with caution and know what your getting into, like most Early Access games its not worth it and probably wont ever be.

May 8th 2020: Still none of the content I asked for is here, we have one new level though. So yeah the game is pretty much abandoned and left to rot in Early Access. Rest in peace Maximum Action.
developer_response: Everything you're asking for is in the works! If you look at our track record with games like DUSK and AMID EVIL you know we're going to make MAXIMUM Action just as complete and polished as our other games. Hope you'll be back for future updates!

Hey there, thank you so much for your positive review! We appreciate you taking the time to play our game!

Wow, thank you so much for your awesome review and years of support for our games! Our team really appreciates your support and we are so stoked that you decided to reach out to us today! We are happy to hear that you've had a positive experience in-game and are so thankful you decided to pick up AQ3D today!

Thanks so much for your support of the original AQ and AQW titles. Our team works hard to continue to update those game, all while updating AQ3D, as well. Our team is actually working on a cross-platform port of AQW right now; you can learn more about it at AQ2D dot com. You can also find out about it here on Steam by searing "AdventureQuest Worlds: Unity."

We are so thankful for all of our players, so we appreciate you taking the time to reach out!

Please check out AQ3D dot com to learn more about our game!

Battle On!
