author: {'steamid': '76561197982150547', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1647842585}
review:
I played this game way, way, way back in the day. I'm talking, 2011, 2012. In those days, I was hooked and could not get enough of it. I stayed up all night, fighting for a city, waiting for the High Command to put an AO on a new town we could attack, paradrop on, et cetera. Plus it was one of the few games you could play Infantry, Paratrooper, Tank commander, AA/ATG gunner, Navy, AND Air force, all going on at the same time. Made for fantastic battles i'll never forget!

However, the game has died down over the years. It's common for that to happen to old games. Older games fade out, new ones fade in. In most cases, older games like this would open it all up for free. There aren't nearly enough people playing anymore to warrant a subscription this day and age.. On top of that, DLC?!?! Seriously?! If I don't want to shell out money for a monthly subscription, I have to PAY to be able to play as a paratrooper or fighter pilot?!! That's ridiculous.. And honestly, greedy on the developer's part.
I loved the community, but with all that's happened to this game. I will not be returning anytime soon. I loved it back in the golden days, but now, it's a laughable excuse for a paid product that has almost no players, is P2W and requires DLC to play roles that were FREE in the past. 
I predict this game will die out in the next year or two. If it hasn't already...
developer_response:
The subscription model that we have is the single reason for our almost 20 year existence. WWII Online has a server base that it has to operate to provide services, remember: it's configured to operate as an MMO, because it is the first MMO FPS ever created. The game is in a consistent state of development, in fact, we just released our first 64-bit compatible client. 

We are not a standard Free to Play game where we offer micro-transactions or advertisements to make monies in that way. So subscriptions and DLC is what we have to offer, plus a perpetual Free Play subscription. And the Free Play subscription is no strings attached, 100% free. That's a fair deal.

In terms of calling our development studio, "greedy," I think you should get to know us a little better because we're extraordinarily community-centric and are actively engaged with our community and more transparent than pretty much any other studio I've ever seen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058684368', 'num_games_owned': 71, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 100039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86880, 'last_played': 1701679347}
review: One of the best hard sci-fi space sims out there. Its beauty, complexity, and freedom are only matched by its unforgiving approach to death and its steep learning curve. That being said, Frontier has put a lot of effort into making the game more welcoming for new players, and it's come a long way from its initial release. Grab a cargo ship and a few escorts and go asteroid mining, arm yourself to the teeth with lasers and railguns and go kill some pirates (or, if you're feeling lucky, traders too), or just max out your FSD range and go explore the infinite - the galaxy is yours to do what you please. Definitely recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023385226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 17063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6445, 'last_played': 1657757660}
review:
I'm over 100 hours, probably 200 but Steam doesn't record offline hours. The survival mode is pretty well fleshed out, and some of the stuff missing was added in the economy update some time ago. What seems like a pretty substantial amount of time in-game is still a drop in the bucket. Making new vehicles that aren't just flying bricks is still the most difficult part. I've spent days to weeks working on new designs, only to step back and realize that this new style is still blockish in one dimension or another. It's fun.

I started out in survival, and that was interesting. Having to farm for ore with meager supplies, slowly building a small fort to create more advanced parts. Then having to branch out and search for cobalt, gold, and other things. If you want to get started in this game, you'll need to spend several hours watching videos on YouTube that further explain some of the mechanics of the game, but you could just hop in and learn as you go.

Klang, the God of this game's physics, is known destroyer of complicated machinery, typically involving Merge blocks, rotors, and pistons. Expect to meet this god as you learn your way through the game. Some of the physics of the blocks are weird, not allowing you build in certain ways. Also, forget about building round things without spending hours working around the limitations of the blocks. Otherwise, build what you want.

Tons of good stuff on the workshop to download. Ship, planet, base blueprints and then the tons of mods that add thrusters, doors, scripts to manage turrets, and tons of other stuff. I recommend the Smart Solar Panel mod, that adds rotors that track the sun and follows it accordingly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970627863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1631460803}
review:

Hi!

Please contact us at support@wenklystudio.com to clarify the issue. Please also send me the Player.log file. You can get it by following these steps:

1. Try to reproduce this problem.
2. Close the application
3. Go to C:\Users\%username%\AppData\LocalLow\WenklyStudio\Elven Assassin
4. Copy the Player.log file and send it to us as an attachment.

It will allow us to verify what the problem is and find a solution.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031191380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 16033, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8191, 'last_played': 1711221410}
review:
If you're a big fan of Spaceship Simulators, and would enjoy a game with literally a whole Galaxy to explore (though the vast majority of systems are currently uninhabited, but there is still a huge amount of occupied space, and exploring the unoccupied space can be quite enjoyable.), then you will probably enjoy this game. 

There's also quite a fun trade system, and the PVE system can be fun as well; however, I haven't played around with that as much.

There is a PVP system as well, but I can't speak to that as I've yet to play in the Open World.

I really enjoy that you can play in a Solo mode, and still be connected to the servers with the galaxy changing around you based on what other players are doing, and can still participate in online events and change the galaxy yourself. Essentially you just can't see other players. You can also play with a private group, all the same stuff, but can only see the people in your group. Or you can play in the Open World and see every player doing the same.

This setup is great for people like me who don't enjoy PVP, though I might prefer if you could simply join in the Open World and disable PVP.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015623875', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 28595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22323, 'last_played': 1516583912}
review:
This game,

Absolutely beautiful historical ships, incredible sailing simulation, so satisfying to broadside a trader and take everything they ever loved and sell it cheap back at port like garbage. 

You've probably guessed that i'm a pirate. I have been 3 different nations and as of now I like the Pirates community the best. There are a lot of wonderful people in this game and it always feels like im sitting down with a bunch of friends at a table to play cards less than it feels like im playing with people thousands of miles away.

I'll be playing this game for years to come. Truly a gem.

Good devs, good community, fun gameplay, tons of more content seen every couple weeks and lots more to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093427334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1357, 'last_played': 1705975859}
review: I really have enjoyed this game till the recent update. An explosive puppet plus 6-7 other puppets spawned directly on top of me when i was in my inventory. This update delivered broken spawning mechanics with no motivation to continue when you die. Giving your audience no hope to get anywhere, broken zombie stamina, puppets and mechs have wall hax, so discouraging, arguably unplayble right now. I hope the devs see the recent outrage of the community and try to change it. its sad
developer_response:
Hi Tyrant! 

First of all, thank you for writing this review, for your support, and for your honest feedback!  
Yes, the team is aware of the horde spawning issues and is working diligently on producing a fix. 
Your voice and the voices of the community have been heard. Please be patient as we are a small team and still in early access, but we're working as hard as we can to improve the game as much as possible. We'll be entering our polishing phase fairly soon where we'll revisit all the features in need of fine-tuning or rebalancing and address those issues.
We hope you revisit the game and perhaps change your mind! 
Have a great day!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004463741', 'num_games_owned': 1264, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1561670088}
review:
So, Ubisoft, when are you killing this one? If any of you bought the first game, feel free to follow the steps on this website: https://www.stopkillinggames.com

Probably won't change a thing, but maybe it'll raise some awareness...

TL;DR: Game is fun, solid 7.5/10... but crashes for no reason every few minutes and I wasn't able to find a fix... this being an apparently common issue...

After being surprised by how enjoyable the first game was, I was expecting alot from its sequel!
The fact planes and boats were being introduced surprised me! The looked more "colorful" and less "edgy" (without the whole drama story "must avenge brother" from the first one).
And from what I was able to play... they delivered!
But... that's the problem... "what I was able to play"...
The game kept crashing with no error messages. Just dropped to desktop for no reason.
I spent some time looking for a fix... but all I found were people having the same issue and replies from others stating "I'm having the same problem. Help!" and others from devs telling us "to send them a ticket".
From all the similar posts I saw online, I'm guessing the "tickets" didn't help at all...
Such a shame too... because the game is amazing. Not perfect, but good! Solid 7.5/10! 
But the crashes pretty much ruined it for me :/
developer_response:
Hey there! We are sorry to hear about your issues with The Crew. Please try [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-us/faqs/000025947]these PC troubleshooting steps[/url] if you have not done so already. Additionally, we suggest [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-GB/Faqs/000025721/Disabling-Background-Application/]disabling background applications[/url] and [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-GB/F//aqs/000025662/Run-applications-with-administrator-rights/]running Uplay and the game as an Admin[/url] on your PC. 

If you continue to have issues after these steps, please submit your [url=https://support.ubi.com/en-US/Faqs/Details/kA030000000emSbCAI?name=how-to-submit-dxdiag-and-msinfo-files]MSINFO and dxdiag files[/url] for further assistance. Please also include a list of what troubleshooting steps you've done at this point. Hope this helps!

author: {'steamid': '76561197990248547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1591520603}
review:
Absolutely outstanding idea,,, unfortunately the complete opposite for execution!
graphics are old as hell which would be fine if gameplay actually countered it. 
spent 91 minutes playing and must have spent 80 trying to find out how to fly, when i got into the air the controls just dont match what my input was and the aircraft kept barrel rolling into the ground.
the last 11 minutes was spent running across the map looking for people to shoot which failed as there was no one around that i could see.
if this game was remastered with decent controls and maybe a bigger player base  then it would be epic

Hi anantiyn,

Thanks for taking the time to leave a review. We are sorry to hear you have been experiencing some crashing. 

We would love to help resolve any issues you may be experiencing. When a crash occurs there should be an error report tool pop-up. Please could you add your email address in the "Provide additional information" section and send in the report.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074612679', 'num_games_owned': 6110, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1661530660}
review: Makesure you set to twin stick shooter config for best experience
developer_response:
We're sorry to hear it. This review was written just hours prior to the relaunch of the game, which among other improvements changes the default movement scheme (from "relative" to "screen absolute" IE "twin stick" or "arcade), and changes the default game speed to 80% instead of 100%. We hope you'll consider taking a look at the game in a few hours with the improvements of Up-Armored Edition. The short, too-text heavy tutorial levels have also been completely replaced, we think new players will vastly prefer the amended campaign.

Please note that so that existing customers do not have their settings over-written, if you already own the game, you will have to change your settings manually.

Again, the new settings:
-both movement schemes from "relative" to "screen absolute"
-game speed set to 80% (easier/better tuned for controllers)

author: {'steamid': '76561197990082800', 'num_games_owned': 768, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1228, 'last_played': 1624875240}
review: The easiest way to describe The Crew 2 is to compare it to Forza Horizon. Where Horizon is Quality over Quantity, The Crew 2 is the opposite offering a massive open world map and a ridiculous amount of vehicle types including cars, motorcycles, boats, planes, hovercraft, helicopters, monster trucks and much more. While Forza Horizon is certainly a better game and a more refined experience, The Crew 2 is well worth playing and has some great ideas of it's own. Just skip the cutscenes lest you vomit pure monster energy. Yeah it's one of THOSE stories.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972555541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3113, 'last_played': 1627475193}
review:
One of those games where you can be hours and hours into it, only to have everything go wrong, everyone die and your sect burn to the ground, but you learn something with that and do something a bit better the next run.

Like learning to not build nice and Feng Shui pleasing, until you have the strength to protect your stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012897416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1129, 'last_played': 1533683834}
review:
A great concept for a game with incredible potential for growth and further development marred with an ocean of boneheaded implementations of modern monetization tendencies. The dreaded lootboxes return in one of their worst incarnations yet, where to even begin earning any sort of in-game currency you need to unbox repeats of many useless and undesirable items not unlike sprays from a game such as CS:GO as well as basic features from other platform fighters (Like Taunts and voice lines).

Even though it feels like the devs have some idea of how to design satisfying gameplay, and as a veteran of Project M I can appreciate many of their design decisions in regards to the gameplay, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game while it is filled with such a greedy money-grabbing monetization scheme.
developer_response:
Thank you for the review! We've been reading through every single piece of feedback and we're humbled by the outpouring of responses. We're so glad you enjoy our gameplay. It's only going to improve from here!

I'm also excited to share the recent steps we've made to address your feedback.
 
- We now credit ALL players 1100 spectra when they join, so you can buy any character you want right off the bat. We also gave this to all existing players, so if you haven't spent yours yet, it's ready for you now.

- You can now try out ANY character in training mode. This was a key request from players who wanted to try out characters before picking one up.

In addition to the above, we're working on several new features to make the game fun and engaging right from the get go. This includes granting a character much earlier and giving more ways to earn spectra. We expect those to start coming online soon.

This is just the start. We entered Early Access so that we can work directly with you to make Icons ready for the world. You can read about the roadmap here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/684200/discussions/0/3160848559782811668/

Thanks again for the feedback. Please feel free to send any more ideas and thoughts our way. We're excited for what's in store.

author: {'steamid': '76561198850931511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1665373650}

author: {'steamid': '76561198039581501', 'num_games_owned': 1087, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1449072341}
review:
Taking in consideration that the Foresight was created by indie developers is quite obvious that the didn't have an big budget to use.

The game has 3 factions, each one has different units design and the factions way of playing/base building is different from one to another.
The narration is ok in my opinion I don't understand why the other people are complaining.
The graphics look old indeed but that's for you to judge if it's a bad thing, I personally like it. Old games are one of the best in the RTS genre. :)
The game doesn't necessarily bring so many new things to the RTS genre, it's however different but still alike with other Real Time Strategy games regarding the resource gathering, units battle, units production population  etc...
The multiplayer sadly is not as I expected, you need to request the IP of your friend in order to play and if you don't have a friend, multiplayer is not an option for you.

I recommend this game if you look forward for diversity in the RTS genre but if you are looking for a game that offers a good story that makes your tears drop (like SC2 did for me), a good competitive level gameplay and intense multiplayer, you should go search for other games.
developer_response:
Hi Sergui, this is a response to your video on youtube. I'm not sure if it's appropriate to share my thoughts but I'm sincerely grateful for their feedback and yours as well. I do hope that they could at least take another look. The game is evolved over the last few months - I won't say it's a totally different game but it's definitely more streamlined thanks to community feedback.

Please feel free to copy and paste the response below onto your youtube video. Thanks!!!

Dear all,

I'm the developer for Foresight RTS. I've seen your comments. Regardless of whether if you like Foresight or not, I thank you all for taking a look. Yes, there had been issues with the game due to our lack of experience in the field. But we're catching up, listening to feedback, improving the game and adjusting the price to the best we could. More improvements, bug fixes and contents will be coming in the near future.

Despite being marked as release, Foresight is still developed like an early access title. We're still listening to your feedback and will implement the necessary changes to improve the game further. We will do whatever we can to make it better for you guys to play.

Our main game website is here www.foresightrts.com - here the information on all the faction can be found.

Please allow me to summary what Foresight really is:
1) Automation - Enough of all those typical RTS chores. Let Foresight do it for you intelligently and reasonably. Leave build orders and production management behind; Foresight will automatically choose the lightest load for ship queues (unless you specify otherwise)
2) Fleets - Nope these aren't unit groups. Fleets are created with officers who will help craft the fleet's composition of ships and requests to move, attack, defend and so on. They talk to you. You make the decision and ultimately, the responsibility.
3) Strategic Relevance - I'm not saying that NO RTS games do that. But we've designed Foresight to reward players who think strategically. Think of flank attacks, rear attacks, ambushes, blitzkreig, defensive battles, counter-attacks ... You're rewarded by design when you execute these battle plans successfully.

No, there isn't any silver bullet units that will crush your opponents. Building the largest ships simply won't do. You need to have the right combination to counter various potential threats. Fighters are nimble, but bombers will really do the damage if you're not careful.

Have a closer look, I'd say. If it's still bad, we're all ears to hear your feedback and suggestions for improvement. :)

Regards,
Foresight Team

author: {'steamid': '76561198000399213', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 6862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2184, 'last_played': 1687994967}
review: Needs a bit more work - the game is very slow progressing - unless you have a ton of free time this game will not be for you.  Maybe add a couple more speeds to help speed up the game.
developer_response:
Hi Majere,

Thanks for taking the time to leave a review. 

Sadly due to the complexity of the game, adding more game speeds is not a viable option due to limitations of PC equipment. However, after listening to player feedback we have released the 1.9.0.35 patch on November 9 that addresses a number of balancing issues slowing down the start of a game.

These changes should improve the speed of the game and result in less waiting around for the player. Furthermore we have released another patch to address, amongst other things, builder's efficiency which should help to improve the speed which buildings are built.

We will continue to monitor feedback and tweak and improve as we continue to develop the game. With these tweaks and improvements, hopefully we can earn a positive review in the future.

Thanks again
The Polymorph Games Team

author: {'steamid': '76561198027579055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1445190312}
review:
I want to like this game. It's cool to play, even if I fail. However, it's not cool if your crew is a bunch of braindead electric ants. Let me explain.

I had a night when there was absolutely no wind, and I didn't have enough electricity to make it through the night. How could I have? The game tells to build wind power. Why should I build it if I can't last the night even with it? Well, thanks to the power outage, people didn't sleep or eat or anything. What kind of a human being requires electricity to sleep anyway? If that wasn't enough, I already had a shortage of food and other materials. I could've really used people who did their fricking tasks. But instead they wanted to sleep. All at once. Because of that, nothing got built. Absolutely everything collapsed because of this.

Don't get me wrong, I like a game with challenge, but this is bullsh*t. The difficulty comes mostly from RNG and bad AI. That's kinda weak. The crew needs like 10 minutes to make a single piece of metal. From mining the ore to hauling it to base to somebody bothering to process it. I kinda liked the game until I hit the wall of nothing getting done because everything went in a snail's pace. I had to tend to every need of the crew while waiting for more metal to be processed, but that just meant I had to build more stuff and get more crew. Unfortunately, this meant I had to build even more because they couldn't survive with what I had already built.

Is every game of this a snowball rolling down to the depths of hell? Is this what this game is about? I get it, it's hard to make resources but it's a fricking meat grinder.

If possible, I'd like there to be a patch of some kind to make it easier to mine metal. Because frankly, it sucks right now. I hate it because it could be a really great game, especially with some kind of objectives instead of a sandbox. If you read this, creators, please make it so that I can play it without feeling like poop is running out of my hem. Thank you.
developer_response:
Hello there! We noticed this review is quite old, and the game has been updated quite a bit since you wrote it.
We'd appreciate it if you'd try the latest version (1.0.7), to see if the improvements make you change your mind about Planetbase.
We've made AI improvements, gameplay tweaks, fixed many issues and added some new features too.

Thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053788131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1487733022}
review:
[h1]OVERVIEW[/h1]
The Last Dogma is a first person exploration / action game from one-man-band indie developer, Sasha Darko.

In the Last Dogma you play Sebastian, a tough-guy ATF agent working in Serbia (or is it Russia? I'm not quite sure). The story doesn't make a whole lot of sense, though, so I'm happy to be told that I misunderstood.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The Last Dogma's graphics fall over a large range. From a creative, but minimalist, 'meta room' in the tutorial, complete with labelled objects and development texture maps, to the in-game forest of the first level, and the great, super-bright glowing of the second (or third?) level, I was really quite impressed with some of them. Smoke and other special effects are very good, too. Character models fall fairly solidly in the middle ground. And then some of the level geometry and textures are eye-bleedingly bad: I gave myself a headache from squinting at some of the glaring reddish textures inside some of the buildings; noticed quite a few examples of terrain not fitting together, leaving holes in the level geometry; and just found myself confused with some of the later levels.

Options are equally confusing, with three resolutions available: HD, HD-Ready, and FULL HD. Similarly, detail levels make no sense: True, Medium, and Pentium 486.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
Sound effects are pretty good. Volumes seem to be properly normalised and nothing stands out as being out of place.

The game includes voices for the main characters, and these range in quality. The narrator voice sounds professional and is the best of the lot, while some of the others, including Sebastian, aren't that great. But all are much better than I had expected after reading some other reviews.

The title theme is an ambient sort-of slightly chilling score, which I found fit the game quite well. There are sections of the game with similarly minimalistic tunes and background noises that are also well done.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The Last Dogma is a first-person action/adventure game with some light combat. It's set in a weird alternate-history Eastern Europe, full of cults, cannibals, and weird demon-god-thingies. Sounds confusing? Yeah, it is.

The tutorial introduces you to the basics in a somewhat humorous way, with a dead-pan narrator and a single room set up like a development test. It's a nice start. The game then throws you straight into its weirdness, though, with a comic-style introduction and a nice forest scene. WASD and mouse control movement and combat, as you'd expect, and the handful of remaining keys are easy to remember.

Each level is moderate in size, but there's not that much to do. You walk around, talk to the few NPCs, sometimes biff a few baddies, and try to find the exit to the next level. There's no map, but the levels are fairly empty, so you shouldn't be stuck looking for the exit for too long. There aren't any puzzles, or that much to see. I guess some might stick it in the genre of 'walking simulator', and wouldn't be far wrong.

The story is a bit ridiculous and hard to understand. It's confusing enough, in fact, that the developer posted story spoilers on the game's web site, although that seemed to be down at the time that I tried to connect, leaving me still in the dark. It's creative in some ways, but feels quite immature, jumping all over the place in a way that feels very forced. To top it off, the writing itself is of fairly poor quality, and could definitely use another proofreading pass, or seven.

You can't skip the tutorial, and when only Chapter 1 has been unlocked the chapter select option doesn't work, forcing you to start again (and sit through the tutorial again, too). I also found the game crashed when minimising and restoring on a couple of occasions, so I've now seen the tutorial four times.

The game really suffers from lack of polish and attention to detail, too. From the tutorial that incorrectly names the game ("The Last Disbeliever") in the opening lines, to the subtitles that don't match the spoken words, the poor grammar, and the terrain meshes that have holes in them and cause you to get stuck, The Last Dogma feels like it should still be in beta.

[h1]PROS AND CONS[/h1]
Pros:
+ Graphics are well done on some levels
+ Music and sound are pretty good
+ Voiceovers
+ Steam Achievements and Trading Cards

Cons:
- Nonsensical story that may offend and is not written well
- Lack of general polish
- Achievements don't seem to work (I completed the game with the 'perfect' ending and didn't get the "You've completed the main campaign." achievement)

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
The Last Dogma is a bit of a confusing mess. Given the lack of that much to actually do, the bugs, the nonsensical story, and the general lack of polish, it's hard to recommend. But it's a shame; it's definitely creative, and some of the graphics and sound are really rather good.

I'm really on the the fence with this one. I think it's a thumbs down, but only just. Still, if it seems like your sort of thing, and you don't mind your games a bit 'raw', by all means pick it up when it's next on sale.
[h1]4/10[/h1]
developer_response:
Thanks for the honest and unbiased negative review, I wish Steam had more of these. 

There are some details to clarify and (indeed) misunderstood things to explain. And something to confirm, too.


[b]About story[/b]
The game can look pure nonsense on the surface until you start looking deeper. It's not like everything will be clear, it's just won't look entirely absurd. I'm not trying to say there's something “super smart” underneath, I just wanted to write a completely unique story in a most unconventional way, no tired tropes and cliches, so the sacrifices were made and many traditional elements were thrown out. 
Some things are never explained for the sake of realistic storytelling (yes, in a surreal game), some things are cryptic just for the sake/fun of it and some references are so obscure that perhaps only 5-10 players in the world will understand them. For example, referencing some obscure Japanese adventure game (which was only released in EU/Japan on Sega Saturn or maybe even didn't have such luxury to be translated) is a pretty usual thing for me in that matter. Playing Sacred Line (a freeware game on which The Last Dogma is based on, available here as a free DLC) will also help to understand some minor details.

In many ways the game is similar to movie Southland Tales, I even put the name of the movie right above the logo. Both are chaotic in nature and absurd on the surface and both got very negative reviews because of that. I ended up writing a developer commentary with some explanations about the story as an extra bonus, but some people on Steam just take as an insult and developer's inability to provide a coherent storytelling.Which was never the intention.
Speaking of that commentary, you wrote the review about the same time the game website which had it was shutdown after four years of existing. I've already re-uploaded the commentary: http://sashadarko.com/the-last-dogma-developer-commentary/

[b]Missing textures and bad level geometry[/b]

You probably mean The Red Desert level. There's an “red light” effect which I added to make it the location more surreal and haunting. I tested the level many times and honestly have no problem with it whatsoever, this is also the first time I read it's “eye bleeding” to somebody.
There are indeed some problems with terrain geometry on Desert level and most of them tied to default Unity terrain engine, which is known among developers for being extremely poor and only allowing to create terrains which look like the 90s/early 2000s 3D games. There's an advanced solution (i.e. plugin) to create better terrains but it cost something around 150-200$ and I couldn't afford it.

HD = 720p, HD-Ready = 768p, Full HD = 1080p. Not sure how it's confusing, although...it's probably an European thing and Americans don't see these labels on US monitor/TV boxes.
True = The way the game is supposed to look, Medium = Medium (literally), Pentium 486 = A somewhat standard joke which means “Old hardware” and in the game context it means “Low settings”. I could name it “Potato” like some other developers do these days, but I have a somewhat nostalgia for old computers so it's named that way. 


[b]About Achievements[/b]
There is no Steam Achievements feature listed in the Steam features and there never were any Steam achievements (which is important). There are two in-game achievements, both of which are jokes which make fun of the Achievements system itself and will never “unlock”.
These two Steam achievements you mean were recently made public on Steam for the matter of testing (no other way to do this). But then I found out that the Unity version I used to make the game (4.2) won't allow me to implement Steamworks without updating the engine to 4.6.1. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Yes, there are no puzzles. I'm not a fan of  puzzles which have nothing to do with common logic (like King's Quest puzzles), something like HOG mini-games wouldn't make any sense being in the game and they would be a stupid and unnecessary cliché. I wouldn't mind to add some physics-based puzzles, but there are so many games with physics puzzles out there so it's practically impossible to create something new on that front. 

The game had two proofreaders, but only before the game was released. There were many changes in the story and dialogues after release, some parts were rewritten entirely. I suspect these new additions are the ones you mean. If you'll tell me where to look, I'll start looking. I'm obviously not a Native speaker and my native language is entirely different, but my English had improved significantly over years. 

There's might be some problem with Chapter Select, indeed. It seems it occurred after the last update, I'll look into it.
“The Last Disbeliever” is not a mistake, it was the game title right from the start and voice actor was given the lines which mentioned it. The name of the website and early promo videos also reflect that. It was some time before release when “Disbeliever” was changed to “Dogma”. The reason is simple, it's just sounds better and also helped to make the logo look better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198809374121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 9638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 750, 'last_played': 1700939498}
review: Waste of money. Here's why I think that: The concept is nice, cars boats and planes racing all over America. It sounds good on paper but as the game really plays, the map is quantity over quality, in exchange for such a large map they had the game essentially looking like a mobile game. Another issue is the races are just boring roadtrips if they aren't just within a single city. That's all fine and dandy except when you consider the handling is very barebones and the sense of speed is basically nonexistent, plus the soundtrack isn't really the best so you're really just in for an incredibly boring, incredibly long ride. I have never fallen asleep playing games unless I was really comfortable but this game had me snoring while standing up, that's not what you want out of a video game. Another thing this game offers is vehicles. Personally I only really care about the cars and let me tell you, the car list is pretty solid. A good amount of tuner, muscle, and supercars. They even have a good selection of bikes and even a hovercraft if that tickles your fancy. The game also has customization which is where the fun ends for me. I do want to say that the customization isn't so bad, and it almost isn't. But it's mainly just splitter kits and tacky spoilers, alot of the better customized cars coming with some pretty ugly body kits that make Need for Speed Underground 2 look more considerable. If I had to say, I'd recommend just buying Forza Horizon, you'll have more fun with that mess than you will here. But if you want a real recommendation, despite the fandom calling it essentially one of the worst games ever, Need for Speed Unbound is a great game. Significantly better customization, more unique handling between cars, a banger soundtrack, colorful artstyle, beautiful city to go along with the stunning graphics, and the single player story is more interesting than whatever The Crew 2 has to offer. This game feels like a cheap yet incredibly overpriced Forza clone and it's not worth your time or money. I already wasted mine and have taken too long to get my refund, I just hope you can spare your wallet or save the money for something better. Maybe Motorfest will be better at least, I really do hope for the best for that game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075964929', 'num_games_owned': 795, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1636381315}
review:
There were a lot of good moments in the first few chapters but then the whole game turns on its head. It got a lot more boring sadly.
I had my struggles in the first few chapters, things that annoyed me or pissed me off, however the gameplay was enjoyable enough for me to continue. Especially after the introduction of upgrades for some of the tools (not all of them) and ways to traverse space..

Spoiler though:
You end up just leaving all that progress behind. Cool space car gone, cool vaccum scooter gone, your bases gone.

In the later chapters you are stuck in your space ship, only being able to exit it in select areas to shoot some things and going back and forth to craft some stuff thats required to continue. Then you go back to your moving prison and yeah. 

I do not recommend the game because of how the devs just threw it all away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140677599', 'num_games_owned': 1828, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1545528829}
review:
The Emulator does a few things right. The atmosphere is pretty good. The sound design is alright. Some of the level design is pretty good. But...the enemy and it's AI are extremely frustrating. It was so frustrating that I started the game intending to do at least 2 episodes on my channel but ended up only doing 1 because I just couldn't get through enough of the game to warrant a 2nd episode. The enemy will randomly appear out of nowhere and start stabbing you. If you aren't near a hiding spot or just happen to be close to it when it spawns, you're basically done. On top of that, there doesn't appear to be a way to heal yourself so you just run around with an increasingly "Red" screen making it very, very difficult to see. You appear to be able to sort of "cheese" the AI by running into some of the rooms but it doesn't always work properly and I had a difficult time getting some of the doors to close. I'm not sure what was up with the hitboxes but it seemed like I'd be looking right at the door and it just wasn't registering my inputs. 

I'd say if you like these kinds of cheaply made atmospheric horror games then you'll probably like this one. For me personally, I enjoyed some of it but not enough of it to warrant a recommend from me. Your mileage may vary since this one is kind of a toss-up. If we had a middle option I think that's probably where I'd settle on this game but since it's either recommend or not recommend, I have to say I don't recommend it. But it is free so it doesn't hurt anything to give it a try if you want to see what it's like. 

Here's the one episode I was able to upload to my channel if you want to see the game in action:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=krp4nECi8UE
developer_response:
Hello, I just wanted to address that while it may seem like it, the enemy should never truly appear out of no where. He emulates a variety of objects and is triggered based off of proximity, line of sight, and sometimes sound. Also, interactions are indicated by the text in the middle of the screen, so if the text shows then the interact button should always work. Hope you'll give the game another go!

1/4/19 EDIT: We have addressed a number of things with our recent update, we hope you'll give the game another shot :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198133251638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 306670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1531, 'playtime_at_review': 3076, 'last_played': 1712437358}
review:
Before going into why I cannot recommend this game, let me point out that there are a couple of positive aspects to Illyriad.  First, for a MMO, the game's community is exceedingly welcoming to newcomers.  Many of the established players are willing to answer basic questions in the chat, and even provide early game resource donations.  The game world is suitably large and there is a strategic depth to the game that requires classic "guns vs. butter" decision making.

Those things said, there are two components of the game that prevent a recommendation.

There is absolutely a P2W aspect to the game.  It's not overbearing, but it is there.  There are time gates to facets of the game; things such as building construction, resource gathering, trade and others all occur in real time.  If you want to avoid the wait, you can "rush" the completion of these tasks by spending Prestige (the in game currency that is available for purchase).  

Of course, one can play the game in such a way that rushing construction and so forth doesn't make too big of a difference.  If you are of the mind that you simply wanrt to develop a network of varied cities, conduct research, gather resources and so forth without engaging in the PvP, you can certainly do so (so long as one of your more established neighbors doesn't get itchy and decide you are a prime target).  However, that brings up the second critical flaw.

As you constuct your initial city, you will be able to research certain technologies that allow for varied buildings and units.  This is all worthwhile as it forms the foundations of what your city can produce.  However, once you have progressed enough to settle a second city (and start thinking about the new tenor this city will possess) you are met with the fact that you have to start all research over again.  In other words, even though you researched the Militia technology in the first city (a necessity), you have to research it again in your new city.  Seeing as the object of the game is to create and foster an integrated kingdom, this mechanic makes absolutely no sense and is unnecessarily frustrating.

In the end, if you are looking to engage in the social aspect of a MMO, Illyriad is probably as good a choice as any other.  However, if you are looking for a game that provides a sense of progression and proportionate reward for effort, this game will likely disappoint.
developer_response:
Thanks for the detailed feedback, we really appreciate well thought out critiques.  

We'd like to see if you've revised your thoughts on Illyriad as you've become a far more experienced player since posting your review.  

Thank you again for your evaluation.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992040071', 'num_games_owned': 507, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1523760965}
review:
played over the free weekend, both with a freind and on my own.

i can say as a single player experience its kind of... meh? you get infinite pauses, so you can micromanage your 2 (or 3 survivors, depending on how long you've played or if your lucky enough to find one passed out somewhere.) survivors to go to every building systematically, sharing their inventory through magical bag of holding, so one person looting a can of beans can teleport it to the other who can cook it up at the stove theyre sitting in front of...

i got to the end in single player, 'challenge mode', no problem... and then i was confused, the game tells me that in order to get a 'good end' i have to do something, and its not going to tell me what that is. oh well. (i'm being intentionally vague here, obviously.) i end up getting the 'second bad ending' because i didnt have the option to choose anything else... not having the required supplies despite having emptied out every single building for all of its resources along the way to the end, all 3 of my characters maxed out on their 'needs' with no particular health problems... they all died in an explosion because i didnt find the macguffin.

moving on to multiplayer....

i'm sure the devs know of this by now but there is an absolutely gamebreaking bug that occurs during online play in which randomly, while playing, the game will pop up a screen saying 'there is a problem with the internet connection, reloading the last save'. thats all well and good... but when your last autosave loads up you check your inventory to find that half of it has magically dissapeared... and more often than not includes valuble items like medkits and gas cans.... and i've seen it said many times over many reviews, this can break a run from 'we might just make it' to 'oh god lets just restart'... in my most promising run this ended with me and a freind on the 5th sector, i was passed out from a cold in a building we had designated as the 'eat sleep and warm up' building... all my freind had to do was find some wood to get me up, i had an adrenaline shot for him for when he went down, but you cant pass items to people when your down and they cant pick things off your body... i sat there as he looted buildings but he couldnt find any coal or wood... i HAD coal on me at one point in time, but a save deleted that... i HAD 3 medkits but they dissapeared as well, otherwise we both would have been in good health in a heated building, and then ran to the end to get the same ending i experienced in singleplayer... as neither of us had any equipment left regardless.

.... its frustrating, and of course i'm just telling my own personal experience with the game, it might have worked perfectly fine for someone doing a LAN in the same building, or perhaps online with a stronger internet connection...

and a last bit of gripe i suppose is scavenging... in singleplayer there are little events that sometimes happen when your looking around... aparently that was removed for co-op? i dont understand why.... as  it can give you an interesting boost or hinderance depending on your luck.... like poking the alien artifacts, either good or bad can come of it, and if your doing poorly, you might just consider that chance... things couldnt be worse... could they? there were also a few buildings that... for some reason were simply empty.... this is assumedly a base that was well used and full of people while they were researching what went on prior to the games events, there is very little reason for an entire building, locked doors and blockades and all... to have nothing but 2 boards sitting around in it.


alien monsters need more aggressive tactics as well as variety... as they are you can more or less literally run past/ignore them entirely, and they die slowly over time regardless so by the time they might be a threat to you they've already dissapeared.

i like this game and i want to see it do better, will probably check back in a few months to see if the bugs have been worked out, might even change my review then! my freind bought the game... he'll either buy it for me too or pressure me into buying it later to re-play it with him.
developer_response:
1. Launch Steam client and go to Library.
2. In your library, right-click on Distrust and chose "PROPERTIES".
3. On the "PROPERTIES" window go to "LOCAL FILES" tab and select "BROWSE LOCAL FILES...".
4. The Explorer window will appear and you will see a folder with game files.
5. Inside that folder you will find "Logs" and "Distrust_Data" folders.
6. If the game ever crashed, there may also be a folder (or folders) with crash report, it will be named something like "2017-08-23-153045".
7. Inside "Distrust_Data" folder you will find "output_log.txt" file.
8. Press Win-R, type "dxdiag" in the opened window and click "OK".
9. In the opened window (DirectX Diagnostic Tool) click "Save All Information..." and save "DxDiag.txt" file. 
10. Zip "Logs" folder, folders with crash reports, "output_log.txt" file and "DxDiag.txt" file in one archive and send it to support@distrust.info.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147041593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1487410679}
review: Very disappointing , minions not interested at all, why bother
developer_response:
Hi swanseaclarke,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2017. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

We'd love to know what you think of the game and the new stuff, here are some features we've added since release:

- Map Editor & Workshop Support with full scripting to create custom campaigns
- Overhauled Main Campaign
- Four Expansions with dozens of new features each. One of these is completely free for you!
- New Game Modes
- Improvements across the board to the core game.
- Aesthetic Improvements
- Vastly improved framerate
- Entirely new Skirmish AI

Looking forward to hearing what you think,

Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561197964066812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1652039012}
review:
"This game is awesome" would be a sufficient thing to say...

Since I laid my evil pawns on dungeon keeper during the starting age of gaming I have always missed a game like this! Some pitiful "wannabes" can be seen during the way from that time to now. None has even come close to awaken the child within me who always has been crying for the real feeling of a dungeon keeper game.
These guys have been working hard and in my opinion they have done everything they set out as goals during the kickstarter campaign. 

So to get some real numbers for you guys who like it, here it comes !

+ Good and worthy successor of the dungeon keeper game
+ Good atmosphere
+ RTS-game without to much micro on resources
+ You can "kinda" pick your own pace in the game
+ You can feel the evilness growing !
+ NO KITTY CATS

- Don't really feels polished at the tutorial levels
- The lore behind the campaign falls a bit short
- Optimization is a bit behind for the release of the game

I WOULD TELL EVERYONE TO BUY THIS GAME IF YOU MISS A DUNGEON KEEPER GAME

author: {'steamid': '76561198972520994', 'num_games_owned': 44, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5467, 'playtime_at_review': 3814, 'last_played': 1712499553}
review:
Looks like DayZ has some serious competition.
The graphics are absolutely incredible and the world is very expansive and interesting not only that but the puppets are very challenging and the gun play is amazing to say the least.
However, many issues need to be fixed such as glitches, laggy servers and unreliable combat system ( melee ) and especially the instance where your hair is gone as soon as you put on a helmet or a hat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198275240678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1630485672}
review:
this is THE SINGLE MOST pay to win game on steam .

pluss , queue for 20 damn minutes b4 gave up and logged out . no queue should EVER go over 1 or 2 minutes in a game that has bots to fill the slots.

rubbish, pure rubish
developer_response:
Hello 32bit4ever!
Players face bots filling slots on both sides in the beginning - bots act as training wheels of sorts to allow the players to hone their skills and define their favored fighting range and tactics, after the first few levels bots are replaced by real players.
Crossout is a free to play game, purchasing packs can save some time otherwise spent on earning resources, crafting new parts and unlocking structural parts in Factions, but packs don't make the player who purchased them superior in battles as victories strongly depend on skill, tactics and teamplay.
 The 20 minute queue you have described is an absolute anomaly as queues are 1-2 minutes long at maximum. Unfortunately such anomalies happen sometimes when a player gets into a queue, loses their queue spot on the server side due to connection issues, but on the client side the counter continues ticking. Apologies for that and we'll do our best to eliminate such a discrepancy. Meanwhile if waiting in the queue gets suspiciously longish, we recommend to reenter the queue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080815637', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1517870316}
review: This is a nice little puzzle game to load up to waste a bit of time and challenge yourself with.  It has a nice progression and difficulty curve and allows you to drop in and out at the level you last attempted.  My issues with the game come from the lack of audio controls within the game, only on or off, and there is no option to exit the game completely.  Feels like a mobile port that has had little thought put in to PC UI in this regard, but for the price it's not a bad purchase.
developer_response:
Hi there and thank you for your honest review. I definitely will be adding your suggestions to the next version and I agree with having an exit button and also possibly a slider for both music and sound.

Keep tuned for the new version soon.

Thanks again!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045692513', 'num_games_owned': 1410, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1436413228}
review:
Knee Deep is an episodic murder mystery game following three protagonists who come together to solve the murders happening in their hometown of Cypress Knee. The setting is set on a stage and it's really surprising the first time when you see the buildings and environment being built right in front of your very own eyes. You as the player have some control over the three main characters of the play. I say some because I felt as though some of the selections that were given felt forced on me. 

Anyways, there are choices you can make (in a form of news reports that you can send to your editor/boss), that will determine how other non-playable actors will react to you.  Now, since there’s only one act, I am not sure how much of an impact my decisions will have on future acts so that is to be determined. I will update as more acts are added.

The characters are quirky, albeit strange at times but they all have unique personalities that set them apart from each other. I mean it’s not every day someone asks you to feed a raw chicken wearing a diaper to an alligator. (However, if this is an everyday occurrence to you, please call me.) Some of the dialogues are funny and the story is engaging. I believe it took me about 3.5 hours to complete the first act so it’s not too long. 

I would recommend this game, especially since the price dropped to $9.99. The developers are pretty responsive to their players. 

I’m not much for scoring but I suppose I would rate the first act a 7/10.

For your viewing pleasure, I uploaded my playthrough of this game on YouTube. 

[url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLI0KAbZpUbEGliZlaTbNcUoY2x6tY0F2s] Knee Deep Playlist [/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198036332774', 'num_games_owned': 434, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1651607897}
review:
I really did want to like this game, it's been on my wishlist for over a year now. I was expecting something like Cooking Simulator but oh how wrong I was.

It doesn't feel like there is any sort of challenge to the actual baking parts. When you complete a recipe it doesn't feel like you've achieved anything. I played for about 1 1/2 hours and got 11 out of 50 achievements which should tell you all you need to know.

Secondly the driving aspect is completely out of place and feels like a whole separate (bad) game which was just shoehorned in because they'd developed it and they were going to use it gosh darn it, even if all the pre-release reviews slated it. 

I've got a refund because I just can't see it improving.
developer_response: Thanks for the feedback, we are sorry that you didn't like the game. We are currently working on patches which will make game more playable. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198030905262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1651635767}
review:
If you don't count the silly driving mini-game, then the first two hours of my three hours of game play were extremely fun. Sadly, by the third hour, everything in the game was starting to break. I couldn't use the divider rounder because the red tray wouldn't let me place it. The large divider and rounder spat my dough all over the floor when I connected them. I felt like I was in a realistic kitchen where all of the equipment is old and busted.

That being said - I really enjoyed the baking portion of the game while it was working properly. It is a really fun idea and I love that you can customize your bakery as well. I look forward to seeing some things get polished up so I can come back to it again later.

P.S. Please take out the driving part. Please. <3
developer_response: Thanks for the opinion, when you press 'H' in the game you have instructions for the all machines in the game. The red tray should be placed inside the machine, after you choose the shape. ;) At the moment we gather all the feedback from the players so we can discuss fixes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035971134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1558126740}
review:
This is the best free game I tried in the past few years. Easy and fun to play. No pay2win jerking. Smooth controls (though target reticle needs to be improved).

It also has your character (well, in fact, it is hovercraft) progression with upgrades, level ups, and all that jazz.

Most of all this is far cry from most so-called free games, just grab it and play. Solid and quite polished, so, best recommended!

Get it, I dare you!
developer_response: Oh, thank you so much for such a warm review. Love you 3000

author: {'steamid': '76561198042883662', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1704061141}
review: Definitely  not recommended. The crafting system is stupid hard and tedious down to you need to craft a rope to make an ax which is bullshit if you have been a boy scout. The enemies are lack luster and offer no challenge. The biggest challenge in this game is finding food
developer_response:
Hi Halcyon! 

Thank you for your feedback, we appreciate it. 
Could you go into a little more detail? After the last update and the crafting rework, the reception to crafting was stellar and people love it! 
I have to say, since the last update we've heard very few people say that enemies offer no challenge. Have you gone to a village/city and triggered the horde? 
Have you gone to an abandoned bunker and try to outwit Razors and Mr. Brenner? 
Higher the risk, higher the reward :) 
We'll be entering the polishing phase of the development process fairly soon, that's when we'll revisit every feature and tweak it/balance it out as much we can!
In any case, we hope you revisit the game and perhaps change your mind.
Have a good one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198073827224', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 922, 'last_played': 1559357238}
review:
- No tutorial, if you're one of those people who needs constant reminders to do something in a game, this game isn't for you.
- Monastery... Coming soon!
- Can't make glass, it's still not in-game.
- You can't do anything with Hide.
- Trading isn't that good, need to find a better balance than that.
- No late game benefit... yet.

Positive review
Coming soon!
developer_response:
Hey Legacy,

Thanks for the review and feedback! 

Since you posted this review we have released many bug fixes and recently added the Wine Production chain. This is part of the Monastery monument which is now in the game and much further developed.

Hide (Leather) is still not fully complete but you can now sell it to the trader. Glass also will be implemented in future updates but can be bought via trade until that time.

Your comments about trading are interesting and during development we will be looking at improvements and listening to community feedback.

There is a help menu (?) in game that explains a few of the game mechanics but we also understand the need for a tutorial which we will look at as we further develop the game.

Thank you again for the feedback and we hope we will be able to earn a positive review in the future.
Cheers
Ash

author: {'steamid': '76561198044486396', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 4257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2144, 'last_played': 1591530693}
review:
In short:
You can barely interact with anything. There is not enough content. Haven't noticed any update. The game is way too simple. Once you complete the initial tutorial the game has nothing more to offer.

How do I spend most of the game time?
- The speed of the game is almost always at maximum, yet still have the bored feeling of having to wait for way too long (half an hour?!) for anything to happen.
- Turning on or off structures to reduce electricity usage.
- I can even ignore emergencies as I can't really interact with them and a redundantly built base just survives anything.
- Counting the pixels between dorm room bunk beds when placing them in order to be able to achieve 100% bunk bed count per dorm room - pretty annoying and boring.
- Interface for colonist hiring should have a disable colonist type option as I have been setting one type to 100% so many times to avoid random spawning, it would be easier to block the ones that I don't need actually.
- Sometimes I want to see the base, but can't. The camera is way too restricted. You can only have a hint of the nice sky above your planet as the game doesn't let you to change the view angle at all.

How are the challenge missions?
They turned off most of the game features and made you wait even more. The challenge is about patiently waiting to stockpile the resource needed to win. Very boring.

How is building?
Way too restrictive. You can't have separate bases on the same map, it has to be a single supercomplex. Half of the buildings can have only one entrance - otherwise will loose its purpose - making layout planning too annoying. Also buildings have to have a giant gap - distance between buildings is very restricted, taking any creativity out of the layout planning. The variety of buildings are way too low, some of them are even redundantly useless as the 2 types of recreational rooms can be substituted by the tv in a diner.

AI bug for biologists:
Biologists are not prioritized during starvation, making it a chain reaction. So if you don't have enough biologists or a meteor hits them and don't act fast by hiring biologists before the stockpiled food runs out, your entire colony dies out slowly, you wont be able to hire new colony members (biologists) once the starvation hits in as low morale prevents colonist ships from landing - in the meanwhile the few remaining biologists will work on producing food for others until they stupidly starve to death. Trading for food might save you if it's not a megabase over 100 colonists, but ironically trading ships always randomly don't bring the stuff you might need - there is no option to call for help or anything.

Trading?
The way trading works is just highly unprobable. In a real world scenario a trader wouldn't land on your planet unless he is absolutely sure that you will trade with him. They just land with a bunch of useless material so many times and its about WAITING for the right trader to come. Or spending your resources on another landing pad, so you can WAIT LESS.

The game is terribly overpriced. I would only recommend it to anyone under 1$.
You can get AAA games with 100000x more content for less.

Room for improvement?
Certainly yes, the core idea is great. Is there any developer reading these?
- different weapon types (machinegun, flamethrower) that can only be used by professional soldiers
- native Aliens on the planet randomly attacking you in lategame would give a thrill; they could even enter the base via creating an opening on any room with their acid and leaking oxygen from that room until you repair it.
- points of interests on the planet that you have to visit with your ships, kill aliens or humans, claim loot, level up, etc
- raid/attack/capture/enslave other colonies, interact with other colonies, setup regular trades with other colonies
- campaign of conquering hostile planets with multiple bases to support establishing colonies on more hostile environments (ex: trading with your own other colonies go at a better rate, you can get limited stuff for half of the price, etc)
- buildings that regulate heat of very cool or hot planets giving a new dimension of problems to be solved...
- terraforming tools/buildings to actually have a GOAL, making the planet hospitable
- buildings that are for glory should attract better paying visitors
- recreational buildings should attract better paying visitors
- new luxury buildings for even better paying visitors
- underground buildings to be protected from meteors & save space and more creative base building
- direct orders for people or first person control of them (fight intruders in first person)
- different mineable/tradeable minerals
- trader ship building & managing your own traders
- more needs for colonists (ex: bladder - fixed by bathroom, social - fixed by chatroom talk with relatives on home planet, etc...)
- unusable bot recycling to save all those precious materials
- more bot types to eventually replace all colonist functionality (biologist, medic, combat & mechanical robots)
- ability to order colonists for money
- have traders with better prices time to time as they are extremely overpriced
- being able to sell bots to traders, this one is pretty much the most annoying thing that you can only buy them at ridiculous price but can't sell them at all... what?! no trader wants a droid?! are you serious or just trying to annoy the hell out of your players?

Music:
Some people complain about the music - I actually do enjoyed the music a lot, but I ended up turning it off as it is a neverending repetition. But this is a minor thing, I don't expect games to have complete OST's, anyone can put on some background music for their own liking...

In overall I'm very sad that a good idea is sinking in the toilet for the lack of content.
And yeah, it has decent graphics - that doesn't help being the game terribly boring.
developer_response:
Hi there,

Thank you for your feedback, we always read customer reviews and try to improve the game besed upon them, at this stage we won't add anything dramatic to it, but we are working on a new update and will release a few fixes.


Just to reply to your points:

> The speed of the game is almost always at maximum, yet still have the bored feeling of having to wait for way too long (half an hour?!) for anything to happen.

If things are proceeding slow, it means your base might not be not optimal, you could try to improve the troughput of your producion chains and make sure things run more smoothly. I've played the game for more than 600 hours and can barely cope with the game at max speed on the easiest planet: If you find yourself waiting around, you might want to try to increase the output of Ore, Metal and Bioplastic in your colony, by redesigning it so it is more efficient.


> Turning on or off structures to reduce electricity usage.

You can do this in one go in the grids panel, you can use the shortcut to do this with one key press + one mouse click.


> I can even ignore emergencies as I can't really interact with them and a redundantly built base just survives anything.

Yes, that would be the idea, build your base correctly and things handle themselves.


> Counting the pixels between dorm room bunk beds when placing them in order to be able to achieve 100% bunk bed count per dorm room - pretty annoying and boring.

Surely one bed more or less in a Dorm os not going to make a massive difference? Just make another dorm and build more beds there.


> Interface for colonist hiring should have a disable colonist type option as I have been setting one type to 100% so many times to avoid random spawning, it would be easier to block the ones that I don't need actually.

There is no need to do this, the percentages in this screen are the desired percentages in your colony, not the percentages of people arriving. So just choose your desired percentages and the game will automatically bring as many people of a particular specialization as required.


> Sometimes I want to see the base, but can't. The camera is way too restricted. You can only have a hint of the nice sky above your planet as the game doesn't let you to change the view angle at all.

There are some mods that allow you to do this, it's just not in the main game as the sky is not detailed enough to be shown fully. You can still see your whole base by putting the camera on top of a hill a bit far from it.


> How are the challenge missions?
> They turned off most of the game features and made you wait even more. The challenge is about patiently waiting to stockpile the resource needed to win. Very boring.

Most of the challenges (except for the last one), can be completed very quickly if you follow the right strategy, waiting for a long time is just one way of completing them ;)


> AI bug for biologists:
> Biologists are not prioritized during starvation, making it a chain reaction

The idea here would be redundancy, if you have a few scatered domes with separate groups of biologists in the this should never happen.


> Trading?
> The way trading works is just highly unprobable. In a real world scenario a trader wouldn't land on your planet unless he is absolutely sure that you will trade with him.

I will give you that, but this is a game, and if we followed a 100% realistic pattern with everything it probably wouldn't be that much fun :)


Thanks again for your feedback and ideas.


Kind Regards.
Martiño.

developer_response: Thank you for taking the time to review our game. AQ3D is the 3rd iteration of the AdventureQuest series - all 3 games - the original classic AdventureQuest, our first MMO AQWorlds, and now our first cross platform MMO AQ3D - are all very different and separate games, and all 3 have (and continue to have) weekly releases. You can read more here - https://www.artix.com/posts/adventurequest_legacy/. We created the Artix Game Launcher so players can continue to play AdventureQuest and AQWorlds once Flash is no longer supported as of next year. There is a new version of AQWorlds for mobile in development currently. We hope you continue to check AQ3D.com for updates under the Design Notes and Game Plan. The developers work very hard to release new content weekly, fix issues and improve the game, and will do so for years to come! Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561199177851558', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1680360296}

developer_response: Hey there, Maybe Plazzify. My apologies for any misunderstanding caused by the free week! The game, itself, was not free, but rather the gametime you could spend during promotional days of July 7-July 13 were. We have further [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/article/000102387]details[/url] about what the free week entailed if you are interested in reviewing that. Sometimes we offer giveaways of the standard version of the game, but I am not able to predict when that may occur. Please note that any progress you made in the game will transfer over to your owned title should you wish to purchase it. I am very sorry for any confusion caused.

review: In a strange way, Primordia makes me feel like I'm playing Beneath a Steel Sky for the first time.  The world is beautifully worn without feeling desolate.  It's fun to get lost in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055717378', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 11466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10864, 'last_played': 1607930484}
review:
This game would be perfect if it weren't for two things: 
1. If parts didn't require hundreds of hours of grinding to unlock unless you pay for them (And the price is exorbitant. You could easily drop a few hundred dollars just to have shiny/fun parts)
2. If the fact that the higher end parts had an incredible imbalance that was masked only by the fact its so expensive to get your hands on them, in terms of hours or money. 

Devs are just too greedy and too lazy to make this game shine, which is a massive shame, because it could truly be revolutionary.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035788970', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 13471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2597, 'last_played': 1710946651}
review:
As soon as I got the game it was hard at first as it is a very in depth game with a lot of mechanics to it and a lot of thought put into how things work in the game. I would for sure tell anyone to look into how to play the game a bit before jumping right into it with little to no knowledge like I did. 

Now after about 40 hours in I can confidently say that this game is one of the best if not the best survival game i have ever player honestly. I cannot wait for the full release of the game or for more updates and patches. Sure it has some bugs and crashes here and there a few times but you can always get right back to what you were doing and carry on as they continue to finish the game :) 

Amazing game can not wait to see what they do next as the game is developed :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198324966096', 'num_games_owned': 963, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1636824409}
review: Just can't get into it. Its a bit clunky, feels a bit empty too. Just gets boring very fast.
developer_response:
I regret you didn't have fun in the first half an hour but FTG is a very deep strategy that uncovers slowly. There are so many tactical elements to learn and use so it can't be done even in 5-10 hours. Therefore, at the start of the campaign, we place the player in the Amateur league where he can start learning basics, and then go slowly higher and higher where he will be able to learn more.

For example, you can start the game directly in Premier league. For that, you can enable Sandbox mode at the campaign creation stage and choose the first team in your country. You will see that there are a lot of skills, classes etc. But it will be very hard to play for you because until you learned all the tactical mechanics, you can't successfully manage Premier league club.

Hope you will give the change to the game.
Have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198123822014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1551529361}
review:
This is a good combat simulation from the WW2.
Both on the basis where you can customize your own aircraft, to your own wishes.
and you also learn something nice about history.

The flight mode is also done nicely, feels like if you are really part of an air platoon. and not all enemies only come for you.

The only thing I found less was in the aviation fashion that the ground surface was kept quite simple, trees that grow in the river weining variation.
but this was also the only thing I could find.

Korom I think this game is definitely worth a 8/10.
take the time to walk through the assignments, then it goes almost by itself.
And the bicycle idea is super thought.

Super game
