author: {'steamid': '76561198184414090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 559146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 829, 'playtime_at_review': 266563, 'last_played': 1712433126}
review:
over 4.4k hours played, loved the game even with it's small anoyances.
But now they add in 2 step veryfication even tho i use steam to play it.
And because i used to play war thunder i already had a gaijin account making this whole process needlessly complicated.
I am hoping technical support can now fix this for me as it is an requirement to fully experience the game now all a sudden.

Other then that it's a fun game with extremely pricey parts you can buy for real money, it is how ever not pay to win. If you don't want to pay (and even if you do) the grind is real. Expect to put in a lot of hours to get to where you want to be.

Also expect every weapon you get to get nerfed soon after, there is a reason you want that weapon, it's because it's powerfull at that moment.

Lot of good people in the game, but ofcourse also some that are just toxic.
The building system is awkward still not having mirrored building and modules that are odd sizes.
In the end most players use nearly the same looking builds because of that.

There are also some weapons that you can hardly play without using hovers.
And then there is the annihalator drone that 3/4th of the builds can't do anything against.

So sadly at this moment i can not recommend playing this.



2022 update :
After a lot more hours of addictive playing they just changed the codrivers with which they destroyed littlerly 99% of my builds, and they added a legendary artillery cannon that can 1 shoot you.
Player count is dropped so much they are evevn working on joining console and pc players together to keep the game going to milk it for a bit longer.

Please people do not spend anything on this game.
developer_response:
Hello TeKKie!
Thank you for the thorough feedback, I'd like to answer about some of the issues you have described.
First and foremost, we apologize for the inconvenience with the 2 step authentification, but we think it is vital for keeping your accounts safe from phishing frauds etc. Please contact our tech support if something in the process of setting it up seems confounding, we'll be glad to help.
Speaking of the game: yes, you are right, it is free to play and purchasing packs won't guarantee wins as players need skills in the battles to win. As for the grind, please pay attention to the weekend specials: they can feature free workbench rentals or discounted upgrades, when you need only one identical item to upgrade your part. Also trawling the market for good deals proves to be a good way to get something cheaper.
We rebalance the game not only by diminishing some characteristics, but also by upping them and do this to make the playing field more variable in builds and weapons without everyone going for the same narrow meta. I hope you understand this, we believe it is way more fun when people have wildly different weapons of choice on the battlefield.
Please report toxic people via the ingame report button or on our game forum, we look through the reports constantly and deal with the people who break rules.
I hope you'll be happy to hear the mirroring building feature is in the works and will be introduced in one of the future updates. As for odd sizes of modules - could you please elaborate on that? Which modules and what could be changed about this size? The dev team takes such criticisms into consideration and rework different parts, but we'd appreciate more information to work with.

developer_response:
Hi Running Rampant,

We are sorry to hear that you felt you had come to the end of a game.

Foundation is in essence a sandbox game where the player makes there own goals to some extent. So there is no real endgame. That being said we will continue to add more content as well as more diverse and in depth narrative events and missions that will punctuate the gameplay.

In time we hope we can earn a positive review.

Cheers
Ash

author: {'steamid': '76561198393948712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3534, 'last_played': 1633386909}
review:
The concept is fun... but it is a pay to win game.  Just swipe your credit card and you will win. I am playing free... trying to level up a machine gun and a shotty... get matched with lasers, guided rockets and drones. I do not see how one would ever be able to flatten the curve. It seems you will always be out gunned if you do not pay money to win. Not only do you have to grind.... they force you to log off by limiting how much resources you can farm, and put a 12 hour lockout on gaining that resource. They also limit how much xp you can get after 8 hours and you must log off for 8 hours to get the'boosted'  xp again. Then I found out recently if you just decide to sit down and grind thru it... they jack up the que wait times on you, to frustrate you, and make you log off. I am talking 15 min wait times to get into a battle.... you win, kill 4 people and get no resources and 100 or so xp. The entire game... is built around making you pay money. You don't want long ques? pay money. You need resources? Pay money. You don't want to loose 7 times before you 
finally get a win? Pay money. If you want to win... get ready to spend money.
developer_response:
Hello!
All parts that affect to the battle can be obtain in-game ways: as the rewards for leveling up or you can buy them on the in-game market. So you don't need to spend any real money to buy a weapon, a cabin and so on.
Speaking of boosting XP: all players get it at 12 pm UTC regardless of spending money.

review:

At the beginning it was a bad, a really bad game, that was trying to copy Dungeon Keeper. Now, after two years from early access on Kickstarter, it is awesome and finally as good (almost) as The Dungeon Keeper. If you liked DK, you will definitely enjoy this one as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078793705', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1861, 'last_played': 1650765286}
review:
The game is still filled with bugs with the 1.0 release. The most frustrating issues are unbeatable levels due to the semi-random level design. Some of the level pieces simply do not fit together, rendering the levels impossible to complete.

EDIT for the dev response:

The two main bugs I had to deal with playing this game last night:
1. Weapon not firing. I ran into this one a few times. It appears to resolve itself when you pick up another weapon. But there were times where I could not locate any other weapons to fix the bug (do to being unable to fire) and had to reset the run.

2. Enemies appearing behind the walls. This MAY not be a bug technically, but it feels like one. I had multiple instances where I could not find enemies that I could clearly hear. That's normally not a big deal, as the only consequence is that you will miss out on the end-level bonus. However, I had to deal with a red orb that endlessly generates exploding green orbs around the player until it is killed. I dashed through the entire level multiple times looking for it, could never find it. A slow, miserable death for that level. Again, maybe not a bug, maybe just really poor design?

3. Level design in general: Perhaps the issue is not the procedural generation creating literally impossible variations (that was simply my guess, dev says it's ABSOLUTELY FALSE, so alright). A few times, I found myself trapped in the levels with no clear exit. This IS due to the procedural design. The pieces may technically fit together, but the variations do not present a visual language that the player can consistently interpret for navigation. The map does help to an extent, but the game starts introducing verticality and alternative zones (e.g. under sewer gates), which makes the map less useful. There were times where instead of running through the entire level looking for what I missed for the 20th time, I just restarted the level to save time. Was it a bug? Or is it simply bad design? I will let the dev decide.

I have enjoyed the game to an extent, and love the very creative concepts employed. However, the end experience was simply too frustrating for me to recommend.
developer_response: I'm sorry you didn't enjoy the game, but this is absolutely false.

author: {'steamid': '76561198440534287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1511898654}

author: {'steamid': '76561198048996374', 'num_games_owned': 773, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1668364373}
review:
At first I found that it was not playable for me because of my Intel 11th Gen CPU. No, this is not the fault of Intel or Windows, it is the fault of the developers. The developers have known about the problem for several years and have done nothing. But okay, there is a "temporary" hotfix to work around this bug. This made it possible for me to start the game.

But now I can't play the game at all, because every few minutes the game crashes with a LowLevelFatalError. There is no way to fix this error or continue playing the game. All the things I tried did not lead to any success. 

The developer is no longer active. I can only warn against buying the game.
developer_response:
Hi there!

We’re now looking into the crashing issue, and it’d be a great help if you could send your DxDiag file to info@breathedge.com.

How to get it:

1) Press the Win + R keys to bring up the Run command
2) In the "Run" command box, type in "dxdiag" (without quotes)
3) Press Enter
4) Once the DirectX Diagnostic Tool appears, click on the Save All Information button at the bottom
5) Save the file

Thanks in advance!

author: {'steamid': '76561197964097180', 'num_games_owned': 756, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1577146560}
review:
Was having a great time with this game until it informed me that I was out of gas. Oh, some sort of gameplay mechanism perhaps? No. Hiding the ability to play behind "fuel" is low and a guaranteed way to get an uninstall then bad review. I almost never write reviews but fealt this had to be done.
 
Remove the play gate. There's plenty of DLC for people to support the game. From the 40 minutes I got out of the game it seems you could really use the player base.

EDIT: After being corrected by the developer's response I went back in to spend some more time with Crossout. While I wouldn't say there is a "lot" to do without gas, there is enough. I found that as I leveled up I was provided increasingly more gas to the point where I no longer found it to be a hard limit. I even saw my gas get refilled automatically from certain circumstances (level up, event actions, etc).

The core mechanics of this game are a ton of fun. There are matchmaking scenarios where you will be massively outgunned, but I did not find them to be completely game-breaking.

Changing my rating to recommend this game. Now excuse me I was gifted some DLC so need to go change some stuff up on my rig.
developer_response:
Hello and thank you for the feedback! Regarding the fuel in the game: there are several modes in the game and only one requires fuel - raids, the PvE mode. 
Fuel for raids is automatically replenished daily, but if you run out of that daily stock, you can get more fuel by participating in the PvP mode - missions, but you'll have to install a fuel barrel or a fuel tank on your vehicle to bring fuel back from the battle. Fuel barrels and tanks are explosive when hit by an enemy, so hiding them behind some armor would be a viable engineering decision.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024975130', 'num_games_owned': 1096, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1534153883}
review:
i got this game using my saved up tokens on chrono.gg .  I really enjoy this and am surprised it is not more popular.  First level or two were mundane, but it soon picked up and clicked in my head what the game was.  It is slightly forgiving at the start but soon tactics become vital.  

I only turned it on to see if worked, next thing I know 90 minutes had passed. I only hit it off because my daughter needed to go to bed.  I actually prefer this to Plants v Zombies (which people compare it to) as you are constantly planning, where in PvZ you just spam shooting plants. 

This is better than many AAA or indie darling games in my games list. Certainly worth a buy.  

Just edited, because I realised I never mentioned how good the writing is.  Well, it is very funny without being obnoxious like some games try.  A bit zany without going full Jack Septiceye.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042871777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 856, 'last_played': 1539191784}
review:
I have'nt as of yet put a serious amount of time into playing war for the overworld. That being said, as a big fan of dungeon keeper 2 which i spent many hours playing i think Brightrock Games have done a fantastic job putting this together and I can only give my praise. 

War for the overworld plays and feels very much like dungeon keeper 2 did in my opinion, which can't have been an easy task. Of course it does'nt quite possess the magical charm of DK2 visually, and particularly in the sound department. For example; the little touches on DK2 such as the sound when you claim ground, the beating of the dungeon heart, the battle music etc...but its still very good and enjoyable and unique in its own way.

They clearly had a lot of passion developing this and doing their up most best to make it feel as close to the bullfrog series as possible. But they have included some nice extra's to make things a little more in depth which can only be appreciated. 

I find it very sad that some people feel the need to give this game such a bad review. Some serious grafting has clearly gone into this and seeing as bullfrog never gifted us with dungeon keeper 3, this is a welcomed addition in my eyes. 

Many thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027684454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1576744543}
review: 3 years and this is all they got done. WOw.
developer_response:
Hello. AQ3D is still in Open Beta and is adding more feature releases  before going live. It takes an enormous amount of time, staff and resources to create a MMO from scratch. Our small but mighty team of developers create, plan, develop, program, 3D model, write and test the game in house - we don't have any outside help (except for our amazing team offsite!), so it will take time to build the world of Lore within AQ3D but we feel we have so far created a wonderful, fun, engaging, and entertaining game - that has weekly releases and will continue to be developed for years to come!

AQ3D is definitely not like other MMOs - our company has never played by the normal 'rules' of creating games - we like taking risks, doing crazy events and releases and love using puns. We are definitely not everyone's cup of tea, but will continue to release fun, exciting, wacky and memorable content. And the fact we have weekly releases - and continue to grow, develop and evolve the game along with player suggestions and feedback. 

The devs are constantly working on fixing and improving issues and releasing updates/patches weekly, which is a challenge as an indie game studio. Please check out the Game Plan and Design Notes - https://aq3d.com/news/ & https://aq3d.com/game-plan/.

review: This is the type of game that falls under classifications; "point and click", "puzzle solving", but for about 95% of my playthrough, I was engaged and immersed. Even to where at one moment I stopped and found myself wishing it was a movie instead. It's a sarcastic drama, that deals with heavy topics, causing you to stop, think and problem solve. author: {'steamid': '76561198169038599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1267, 'last_played': 1610405242}
review:
Imagine a game like Minecraft. Except that the graphics and gameplay are 10 times better with a physics enginge and the ability to build spaceships and engage in epic starship battles with your friends. That is space engineers. You can build almost anything you could possibly imagine and explore the seemingly endless asteroids and planets. I cannot recommend this game enough; if you don't already have it, buy it. 

~9/10

P.S. You can download other people's creations from the steam workshop and submit your own. The creativity is endless! Also, the developers come out with an update almost every Thursday to keep the game fresh and exciting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982718107', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1514641254}
review:
The idea of this game is great!
Haven't played the single player, bought this only for the coop.

Played about 2 hours, the first of which was okay (we had a disconnect and then I had to wait for the game to unfreeze for some reason).
The second hour was a mess...
Five disconnects, the games not syncing properly - I was doing one thing, while my friend was like in another game (we were playing coop together...)
He clears a door, I go to that same door, and IT'S BLOCKED... I could see him walk through the damn blocked door.

I have high hopes that the devs will make som serious adjustments to the coop, and hopefully me and my friend will be back for a session in the future.

At the current state, I strongly advise you to skip this game, if you're looking for a coop experience.

The coop is BROKEN.
developer_response:
1. Launch Steam client and go to Library.
2. In your library, right-click on Distrust and chose "PROPERTIES".
3. On the "PROPERTIES" window go to "LOCAL FILES" tab and select "BROWSE LOCAL FILES...".
4. The Explorer window will appear and you will see a folder with game files.
5. Inside that folder you will find "Logs" and "Distrust_Data" folders.
6. If the game ever crashed, there may also be a folder (or folders) with crash report, it will be named something like "2017-08-23-153045".
7. Inside "Distrust_Data" folder you will find "output_log.txt" file.
8. Press Win-R, type "dxdiag" in the opened window and click "OK".
9. In the opened window (DirectX Diagnostic Tool) click "Save All Information..." and save "DxDiag.txt" file. 
10. Zip "Logs" folder, folders with crash reports, "output_log.txt" file and "DxDiag.txt" file in one archive and send it to support@distrust.info.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017663146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1581566228}
review:
Played on the Index, using keyboard/mouse, gamepad, & knuckles.

I felt like I was fighting with this game almost every step of the way. I started off with a look at the [b]options[/b] which were pretty [b]minimal[/b], the game has a few graphical tweaks with a res "booster" (which I like, especially when the game ignores your SteamVR SS settings.) I left things at default which were high with base 100% res scale. The only gameplay options are toggle on/off for screen shake and pitch invert.

The game [b]looks very dated[/b], which is only made worse by the fact that it [b]runs poorly[/b] too. I had some stutters, it spent most of its time at 60fps (was set to 120Hz which it clearly was unable for) and even a few freezes. On my second session, I tried at 90Hz and it did at least spend most of its time there, but the odd stutter and rare freeze still happened. 9700k/2080ti/32gb/ssd.

First up, I went into test flight, which I thought would be an ok place to start - it wasnt. As I looked around my cockpit, about 10 seconds in I started to get flashing covering the right half of my screen as if I was being shot or hitting an invisible world barrier (I was still in the hangar!), ship died, started again. This time I thrust immediately out of the hangar, but as I got to the mouth, I have no idea how, but my ship acted like I hit something (I was as clear as I could be, having flown straight forward the short ~20 meters to the exit) and my ship spun and exploded. Take 3, I got out of the hangar and was blasted down in about 20 seconds. Ok, not the place to start!

Next, I went to basic tutorial, its almost entirely dialog driven with next to no visual ques. Its not uncommon for 2 messages to be playing at once. A bug that I thought was so annoying I stopped to look up if anyone reported it and if it might be fixed - found threads on it dated 2017 (pancake version), so I wouldnt hold my breath on that one :/ There is a good list of tutorials, I did just a few.

I then tested out how the game works with different controls. The short answer is terrible. It supports a range of input devices, but if you dont use a gamepad, enjoy having to bind everything. On keyboard/mouse, only WASD is set, not a single other key seemed to do anything, while its nice that you can rebind, it seems criminal to not have a basic profile for different methods setup, I dont mind tweaking things, but having to set a key for everything?! The knuckles (/Index controllers) were strange, pressing right on the right thumbstick selected things on the menu, and in game it had dual functions, so while you want to pitch down you kept getting spammed the scan function, or rotating right you were spammed with the matching speed function. Thats not even the worst part!! When you tried to rotate, you were jerked usually 5-10 degrees in *either* the direction you were trying to turn to, or the opposite (before then rotating correctly), so if you wanted to subtly turn 30 degrees and did so by touching the stick a few times - grab yo nausea medication.

The gamepad worked fine and things were mapped nicely. It is the input I would recommend anyway since the motion controllers are not tracked and only act as a gamepad anyway.

Finally, I gave the campaign a go. After a short video which is shown on a small floating screen (I dont mind this honestly, I would rather when devs are porting a game from pancake to VR to put the time in pretty much anywhere else than try redo cutscenes) and mission briefing while sat in VR, I was on my way. It started to feel a little like fun :O I managed to fly out of the hangar without exploding (noice!) and was given instructions to escort some ships. No problem! It was a pretty sleepy affair, after a few minutes I was told there was a ship(/blip) lurking around some asteroid and it was go time! Kinda. There was 1 ship, which took me a minute and a half to find (probably my fault, as I had no idea I could scan a near target - no controls are shown and I didnt get down through the tutorials, so maybe its in there somewhere), easy kill, on with the mission. 2 minutes of more sleepy flight and we arrive at what I am assuming was the destination because everyone kept flying around it. I must absolutely suck, because I couldnt see what I had to do for the life of me. I genuinely spent 10 minutes looking around the station, looping around it and scanning, flying to where I thought the game wanted me to go, flying next to each of the container ships... nothing happened. Got annoyed, started to fire at the ships! Was given out to (fairly lightly tbh!) Destroyed 1 of 3, no warnings or HUD changes happened, so I started to fire at the second! I figured at this point if I cant complete this mission I am going to fail it in style. As I fired at the 2nd ship I got a message which sounded like my shields were depleted? Dont know how or why, but I was no longer able to fire or fly! I could look around, but not thrust, or roll, or ..... I gave up!

So, I even failed at failing! What a perfect way to end!

After that experience, I just cant recommend this game.

[i]Game was received free as part of the curator connect program via the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/HTCVIVEVR]VIVEVR[/url] group (which is not just for VIVE users!)[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198035598764', 'num_games_owned': 34, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 30965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4578, 'last_played': 1710389967}
review:
low spec, like wow, familiar mmo mechanics, throw back for old heads, fun for kids.

Edit: i see complaints about how the game is a grind fest and how all the money is going towards devs making cosmetics... I like this game because it reminds me of WoW or Runescape, or even diablo from when i was a child.. and its simple enough that it allows my kids and younger family members to play, and i can play with them, way better than them unsupervised on fortnite... it gave my kids a taste of what i used to experience and the wonder i felt exploring worlds in similar games from my hay day, 20+ years go...

again, great game, simple... easy to pick up for kids, allows me to experience it with a younger generation, and allows them to enjoy what i used to enjoy. The overall cartoony, fun themes make it a winner for me because i can play it casually or in a competative fashion as well.

I also like the fact that I can hand my kid my cellphone and he can play with me rather than he using my office with my gaming machine and my business machines...especially in a remote work situation...

I personally do not invest in the gaurdian thing, I am too casual for that, but i have purchased crystals for the little ones... its not any worse then the kids begging for robux or vbucks.. the f2p is fine for me and there is a lot they offer. and the kiddo can even earn free crystals by watching ads on the mobile app version of the game... 

9/10
developer_response: Thank you so much! We are honored that you have chosen to play our game and be a part of AdventureQuest 3D's fun, wonderful journey! We appreciate your kind words and review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198020456739', 'num_games_owned': 768, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1703434663}
review:
Posted Dec 24th after the update for Dec 14th to improve combat glitches:
I played the first stage all the way through with 2 different characters, halfway through on my second play through my weapon again wouldn't fire even tho this has been listed as fixed. This time it started working again after using an ability (previously even though this was listed as how to fix it while being stuck unable to attack, it hadn't worked for me). 

Posted Nov 27th:
Wanted to give this a fair shot but could not. In the first room after killing about 7 mobs my attack button would no longer work and either would my change weapon button. I could still do everything else so I was killing things with my abilities and waiting for my cooldowns to come back. Looked online and apparently there are a bunch of known issues like this and honestly I'm just not willing to play something where the main core feature doesn't work sometimes especially since it's not early access. If this was fixed I'd be willing to give it another shot.
developer_response:
Hey there Fryu! We just released a massive patch where we reworked abilities, movement, and all other actions:

https://steamcommunity.com/games/363860/announcements/detail/6864112816152092535

Among other fixes, it fixes the issue of getting stuck with your weapon.

Please try it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085138563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1704678021}
review:
It's a really relaxing game. It's a lot like Anno but on a smaller scale, much smaller scale. Beautiful artwork and graphics. Simple mechanics, but they will keep you engaged. I don't know if this is still work in progress, but the one thing the game significantly lacks is the absence of any real challenge. Also, there is absolutely no way to intereact with other NPCs, or players in the network, which could have had made trade interesting. 

A huge shout out to the ambiance sounds. It's one of the best and most realistic.

In short, the scope of the game is really really small. But if you just want to sit back, listening to birds chirping or a storm passing, over your tiny city, before heading out in search of the next resource and plans on how to utilize those resources to make your citizens happy, you could give it a shot.
developer_response:
Hi Kingmaker,

Thanks for taking the time to leave a review. We do indeed plan to add more challenges to the game before the full release. We also plan more depth alongside more and deeper missions/quests.

There is still much more to come for the game and we hope you enjoy the development and improvements.

Also, great to hear you are enjoying the sound design!

Cheers
Ash

author: {'steamid': '76561197970977129', 'num_games_owned': 2160, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1533181894}
review:
The dulcet tones of solemn russian man's voice sets the tone for an adventure of a lifetime. Beset by fog on all sides, a car lazily drifts down a field of planks wedged between the solid rock of the cliffs of FATE! One wrong move and the car will become stuck, no way to escape. Is this the end of the game, did it bug out? Or are you meant to sit and contemplate your own existence?

You be the judge 

10/10 a game for teh thinking man (or woman)

review:

We hope you check Hunter's Arena again in a few patches. We will make sure to improve! Thank you :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198081678832', 'num_games_owned': 78, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1456508602}
review:
+ a nice concept
+ works well and seamessly

- seems like a fun survival game before (very swiftly) turning into a grindy simcity in an alien planet
- resolution sometimes locks into the lowest possible, can't change
- building placement very limited
- interior placement very limited
- feels like a mobile game
- AI is primitive and buggy. After a while most of the time people start idling.
developer_response:
Hello there, thank you for your feedback,

We are always listening to the community and fixing any issues in the game.

You might want to have a look at our AI FAQ here:
steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=577310241#898896

This explains the behaviour of colonists in more detail, but if you think you've found a bug you can send us a savegame to "bugs at madrugaworks dot com" and we will investigate ASAP.
(Saves are in Documents/Planetbase/Saves)

Thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197976708362', 'num_games_owned': 554, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 6563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6485, 'last_played': 1700804261}
review:
Spawned in, built some basics, headed off to town.  Got a pistol, ammo, magazine, shotgun etc. at police station.  Loaded up my pistol clip with 45 ACP, put in into my pistol.  Put pistol on hotbar.  Loaded shotgun, put it in the 2 slot.  
A few minutes I come across 5+ puppets that aggro me.  No problem, I hit a few with bow and arrow and pull out the shotgun.  It drops to the ground.  I run around the shotgun trying to grab it while 5 puppets pound on me.  I bail, leave the shotgun and switch to my pistol.  But the pistol is no longer in my hot bar slot.  
I have to manually equip it from my inventory.
Still alive, thank god for the pistol.  Aim down sights, pull the trigger and ... nothing. click click.  As I am running away I realize the pistol clip has literally disappeared along with all the ammo.
This is pretty much a typical experience for me on Scum.  
Then you die and respawn randomly and have to run 1 to 2 hours in real time to get back to your body/base.  Unless it's night then traveling generally ends in death unless you are really prepared.  
Until the developers finally fix all the bugs, network performance issues, poor respawn mechanics, this game is more aggravating then it is fun.
It has a ton of potential but so far these bugs continue to plague every server I visit.  Disappearing items are super frequent.
developer_response: Hi there Alpha ∞ Omega! We're sorry to see that you've experienced a bug that severely undermined your time in the game and we'd like to thank you for the extensive review. The bug you've mentioned is known and we're working to fix it, along with a host of other known issues that are present and we'll aim to get those ironed out once we fully release the game. Until then, we'd like to kindly ask you for more patience and express our hope that you'll give the game another chance eventually.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120285564', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 538, 'last_played': 1564429978}
review: Honestly, I had fun playing this game. The core mechanics are fun, and it's nice to watch the civ grow. However, this game is riddled with bugs that make it unplayable, and they can happen at any time. Most of these bugs involve the AI of the "nuggets" that forces them in some case to do nothing and slowly starve to death, or sometimes they just stop drinking water no matter how many wells you put down. I would wait for a full release to fix these bugs before purchasing, as even though they may not happen to everyone, it's very annoying when they happen to you.
developer_response:
Hi Reach, 
Thank you for your feedback. I sincerely sorry that you had to deal with some of the bugs. We are working as fast as possible to resolve them and with each patch we are polishing the game more and more. Currently we are reworking our pathfinding system and certain AI priority requests in order to resolve the majority of the issues that are connected to the nuggets not doing anything or starving to death. Once the system is reworked, all those issues that you described will be resolved. 

I hope, after we introduce the new pathfinding system, you will give the Universim one more try and see for yourself how majority of issues with the nuggets will be resolved. 

In any case, thank you a lot for your feedback and support. We value your opinion and we will do our best to make your experience better with each patch that we introduce. 

Sincerely,
Sasha

author: {'steamid': '76561199522389454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1707577151}
review: this game is NOT launching i tried every single method and still not working
developer_response:
Hey there lauraisdaboss, and I'm so sorry that The Crew 2 was not launching for you. It looks like you've had some gameplay since your review so I'm now glad to see that you've been able to play successfully! I will leave some troubleshooting below incase you ever encounter any other launching issues or crashing issues with the game, but for now I hope you are enjoying the game. Also, if you did not know, our next installment of The Crew franchise will be The Crew Motorfest and there are currently [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-us/game/the-crew/motorfest/closed-beta]closed beta registrations[/url] if you are interested in testing the game out! 

And as mentioned, here are some troubleshooting steps that you can do if you ever encounter any technical difficulties with the game in the future. 
- Complete the steps on our guide [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-gb/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/troubleshooting-technical-issues-on-pc/000061047]here[/url]
- Have the game installed on the same drive as both Steam and Ubisoft Connect
- If the game will not launch, clear the cache in [url=https://help.steampowered.com/en/faqs/view/6AD7-820D-8BE5-E51F]Steam[/url]
- If the game is crashing during gameplay, clear the cache in [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-us/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/emptying-the-cache-of-ubisoft-connect-pc/000061966]Ubisoft Connect[/url]

I hope that you are able to keep playing the game without issue, but if you ever need any further assistance then please do not hesitate to create a [url=https://support.ubisoft.com/en-US/Cases/New?method=Chat&platform=29&game=50003&category=219&hideFields=all&af=1&source=help]support case[/url] with us and we'll be happy to help!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972090300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1552282794}
review:
Before this, I had never felt motion sickness in my life... Who the hell said it was a 'bad' thing?  Our bio-photons have been preparing for this for... well, photons don't experience time, so they've been prepared, and waiting for us to catch up... and we're finally here.  I've never experienced anything like this, and yet it's old Deja Vu, straight out of my dreams.  I can't tell if this is the beginning or the end, but anyway, all time exists at once, so see you soon. o/
Calling all Space Cadets, get your tin foils on, and get outta town!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042288340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1614423887}
review:
This is not Subnautica in space. 

The gameplay loop closely resembles the gameplay of Subnautica. However, because Breathedge is hell-bent on convincing the player that all of their actions are meaningless, the gameplay becomes tedious, and because resource gathering tools in Breathedge are essentially one-excursion-use, the game becomes TOO tedious. Too many times I had to leave at the climax of a "main quest" type mission, run through empty hallways for 10 minutes, build the tool or "Useless garbage the devs made so you could proceed" (I'm not kidding, this happens multiple times). This sort of humor happens so often that I can't help but feel like the story was seriously neglected, or as an excuse for poor level layout. There are genuine moments where this sort of humor hits, but it isn't at all balanced by the solemness of the setting, and the constant breaking of the fourth wall serves only to enhance the feeling of tediousness. 

Spoiler Example: You need to run through a long, empty airplane hanger, and then two long, empty hallways, and down some stairs, only to be told you need to build something to proceed. So you backtrack up the stairs, through the two long hallways and one empty plane hanger to your base, build the item, and return. 

Oh wait! That's only if you had the correct tool with you, when you made your first trip down, because there was a resource you needed to gather that was located at the bottom of the stairs. 

So, if you don't have that tool, you need to run through a long, empty airplane hanger, and then two long, empty hallways, and down some stairs, then backtrack up the stairs, through the two long hallways and one empty plane hanger to your base, build the resource gathering tool, then run through the long, empty airplane hanger, two long, empty hallways, and down the stairs, collect the resource, backtrack up the stairs, through the two long hallways and one empty plane hanger back to your base, build the item, run BACK through a long, empty airplane hanger, and then two long, empty hallways, and down some stairs, and use the item to proceed. The thing that gets me is that the developers knew this was a hassle for the player, because the game offers for the player to fast travel, runs a loading screen, and then informs the player that unfortunately there is no fast travel. This punchline is pretty funny, but I didn't really enjoy the build up of the joke, which was [i]the player not having any fun for 20 minutes.[/i]

You'll never feel like your trying to survive in a dangerous environment, like in Subnautica. You'll just feel like your doing meaningless busywork. Which the game will literally remind you of, all the time.
developer_response: Thank you for your detailed review!

author: {'steamid': '76561197996402942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 16403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16144, 'last_played': 1623385142}
review: fucking horrible dealing with Uplay. Even if you reset your password the game still will not work. Its so important that they enforce (((security))) you're not allowed to play the game even if you bought it. I still can't get into the game I paid for.
developer_response:
Hey there, delivery 20 minute! I'm sorry to hear that you haven't been able to play the game. I can understand how upsetting this would be! I checked out your account link, and I'm not seeing your [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-us/help/account/article/linking-other-platforms-to-your-ubisoft-account/000075524]Steam account linked[/url] to any Ubisoft account which could be causing this problem. 

I recommend reaching out to any of our Support teams and provide through case or private message your email address, username, and [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/en-us/help/article/finding-your-steam-id/000060565]Steam ID.[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197997367466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 355, 'last_played': 1464636402}
review:
This game succeeds in replicating all of the fun we once had in the dungeon keeper titles.  Unfortunately that is where the problem with this title is as well.  I would not so much say that this game isn't recommended.  It just is not worth the price that it currently goes for.  When this goes on special (75% off at least)- take it.  
It does have replayability in exactly the same sence as the old dungeon keeper games had - that is to say, doing exactly the same over and over again (because it was fun).  For me, this doesn't translate so much in modern gaming.  
Further more, it was a massive surprise to learn that coop wasn't available for the campaign.   The campaign itself is rather easy and very short.  Skirmish and sandbox modes are pretty much just free for all bash - ups being made moderately fun by the swathe of different map designs out there.

Does this game succeed in what it sets out to do?  Absolutely.  It brings an old, nostalgic experience into modern times.  That in itself begs the question - do you buy this game or get Dungeon Keeper 2 to work on your current os?  The latter wont cost you any money and all you sacrefice is the graphics.

Technically this game is a disaster.  It chews up pc resources equal to something double its size and depth.  The graphics are pretty, particles are sweet and animations are "okay" - yet this beast eats up more resources on both my pc's than just about anything I have.  I'd go so far as to suspect that there may be some serious memory leakage going on or just not very clever design.

Again, this game isn't all that bad but I can find very few reasons to recommend it based on its current price.  As someone who played dungeon keeper for years, this game could hardly provide me with any reason to do so beyond 5 hours (that is how long it took me to complete the campaign).   Mind you, it appears the average playtime for the campaign varies between 6 to 12 hours, so do not use my time as the average.  Some of us grind harder than others :)

Coupled with the lack of any kind of intelligable innovation, the technical presentation of this title is atrocious.  Something "appearing" of this quality should at least be half way better designed.  I'm not sure if it is bad resource management or perhaps bias towards more mainstream hardware combinations.  What I can say is that between the group of friends I play with, all of us experience this kind of issue where the game is just hogging an inordinate amount of resources.  Things like this can be polished out with further tweaks from the developers whom appear to be quite active in community engagement (although, i would note in a very quetionable manner not befitting PR).

Multiplayer:
Coop campaigns are not existing yet.  It doesn't look like they will either.
Multiplayer is stock standard player vs player or player & player vs AI (this is what they deem coop - beware those steam tags).  
The game devours resources so you can imagine what a horrible experience multiplayer becomes with 4 players on a large map.  That is, IF you can get the game to work on multiplayer.
Multiplayer requires you to download their little guide (or just go read the resources) so as to unblock the required ports and the likes.  Yes folks, we are talking peer to peer multiplayer.  Not only is this problematic for a whole swathe of players to set up, but (do i need to say this really?) it is NOT SECURE.  Not recommended (dont take my word for it - use google).

In closing,

The game is one of those "could have beens".  It could have been great, it could have been really fun.  And, hey, it still is for a few hours.  But not at that price.  You can buy 4 good indie games for the same price that would each provide you four to five times the play time.  
Thus this is purely a title you'll invest in out of nostaliga and nothing else.  Guaranteed.

My recommendation:
Buy it on special!
developer_response:
Hi Pixelporn,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2016. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

Most importantly the performance and stability of the game has been now greatly improved after thousands of man-hours of development from our two-man code team. 

There is also now the second expansion, the Crucible survival mode, that was free for all! 

If you've not tried the game for a while now might be a great time for you to jump in and see how far we've come since release! We'd love to hear what you think now.

Cheers,
Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561198025335794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1499196659}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018671613', 'num_games_owned': 1209, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1624809991}
review:
Primordia achieves a rare mix of everything that makes a good adventure game: great dialogue, captivating setting, complex plot and worldbuilding, and satisfying puzzles that fall on the hard category.

Like one of the classics, the big non-linear set piece that occupies most of the game's playtime is a masterpiece of design and interconnected narrative threads and puzzle elements.

This is one of the best adventure games of all time.
developer_response: What a wonderful review to wake up to! It's particularly gratifying to read your kind words about the puzzles and non-linear design. Poured my heart into this stuff (the whole team did in into what everyone worked on), and it means the world to hear that it connected with players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054153027', 'num_games_owned': 665, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1797, 'last_played': 1379305115}

author: {'steamid': '76561199143922133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1673882661}
review:
I first played Adventure Quest in elementary, so I was thrilled when I saw the 3D version here on Steam.

The storyline is interesting, and the dialogue is entertaining. The quests are easy since the game tells you what to do and where to go. This makes it perfect for people who are new to MMOs. The character designs and costumes are also quite nice.

I'm not a huge fan of the control and navigation. It's not as intuitive for me, making the gameplay less smooth. Sometimes I can't even see where my character is.

I'm not sure if I'll continue playing, but given that it's free, I'm not complaining too much. It certainly was a fun way to pass the time. It won't hurt to try it – who knows, you might actually like it.
developer_response: Hey there, thank you so much for your years of support for our games! Our team is so thankful that you decided to reach out to let us know about your AQ3D experience. We are working hard to make our games fun for all players, so we really appreciate your feedback regarding the controls in our game. We will pass your concerns on to our dev team, so we can continue to update our game. Thanks again for taking the time to write us and thanks a ton for giving AQ3D a shot. Battle On!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994478854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 271703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 867, 'playtime_at_review': 9588, 'last_played': 1712901928}
review:
I hesitate to write this review, because there just aren't that many people playing CR right now and that is part of the joy.
There really are not a lot of people, compared to other STEAM games, playing CR. It's funner because there are WAY fewer cheaters. WAY fewer.

It is SUPER FUN to beast the piss out of someone with a golden pan.
The Garand and the Thompson Subgun are my other fave weapons.
TONS of great guns in this game. The MG42s mounted in the bunkers can be a highlight of crossing that terrain, remember to stop in and see if anyone is in the kill zone of  the bunker MG. Super satisfying long distance massacre. Use short bursts. People that hold the trigger down find our real quick how few rounds are in that drum.
 
Now I still play a sneaky game, and avoid trouble as though on a recon.
But when the blue zombie noise pushes us all together, lots of guys try to ride their bunny slippers, and they are lurking on roofs.
I kill them with a KAR98 or a Garand. Usually just one good shot with the big 30 cal to 8mm rifles is enough to end the enemy.
Even the .30 carbine is pretty deadly with one or two rounds, if you get the body or head hits.
Scope is not essential, these rifles shoot true with the iron sights also. 

It's also real great, you know, safe and effective, to have a submachinegun of some kind.
ANd sometimes better at the end to have two subguns, or a buttload of ammo for the one you have.
You have to really work at getting enough ammo to be ready for a gunfight in this game.

The one map will surprise you. You think that you know it pretty well by now, but then you end up next to a pond when you have only been in rivers, or a church or ville on the other edge. 

There's a couple of secret things that many current players obviously do not know. They suffer for that ignorance.
I am going to give a couple of clues here, but you have to figure some stuff out yourself to work the system.

A. When the weird noises start, it's annoying. It's also a signal that if you do a thing, or goto a place, it might work out better for you.

B. Get a pan. If you see a pan, and you do not pick up the pan, you are wrong. Not a pot, not a waffle iron, pick up the golden saucepan. It's a whacker, but also does a ninja bullet thing that you like a lot.

3. When in some rooms of buildings ... look up.

And, in the words of my personal gamegod, his STEAM handle is rangersauce, do not forget to:
SHOOT
   LOOT
       and SCOOT

Have fun, and let's play some DUO and SQUAD Cuisine Royale !

Doc Morrison - the guy that you hope is on your side
developer_response: Thank you for a great review! We hope game will continue to give you great emotions.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962875467', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1574365214}
review:
Update:

Since they've decided to release this game unfinished, and have functionally asked modders to finish it for them, you should not buy it. 

The economy is still terrible, the inventory system makes MSDOS look advanced, every battle is the same since they all take place in a forest, and every single fight starts with opponents a mile away from one another. Even if you're having a conversation with an NPC, and then you have to fight,you're instantly a mile away and have to walk.

Since the distances are so great, whoever has optics on their weapon wins. That there is no descent cover and the sneaking mechanic is that awful one where once one enemy knows where you are, they're all instantly psychically linked, there are just too many unfinished parts to warrant the price increase they've announced. 


Go back to playing Insurgency: Sandstorm or Mount & Blade. This attempt to combine them has given up, as it still needs what looks like a full year of development and they're releasing it anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074316564', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 1487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1487, 'last_played': 1505341913}
review:
Just a short review, in short, this game is great, it takes everything that was good about starpoint gemini 2, and removes/fixes a LOT of the drawbacks. Combat is fun, ships look and feel great, there is a ton more to do than in previous games, and the strategy element is in depth enough to be fun, but simple enough to not be daunting (*cough X3 cough*)

If you have a space sim fix, but don't want the massive learning curve of the more complex games, or the insane grind of something like elite, then definitely  pick this up. It's amazing.

Also, the devs are VERY active in forums (even on older unsupported games) and are extremely passionate and dedicated, something wonderful to see in this day of anti consumer game dev teams.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979919184', 'num_games_owned': 1190, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1392078331}
review: Ah the good 'ol days of point and click adventure games.   This game is no exception, with its riveting story of unexpected twist and turns you never know what clue will unlock the story.   This is story is had me sucked in from the beginning to the end leaving me with wanting to know more!  The puzzles are very well designed so you don't progress to quickly through the story but not so difficult that common sense isn't enough to solve it.  Maybe one day there will be a sequel, hopefully, I sure would like to think so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023470386', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1517697179}
review:
Even if you've been waiting on this one for years now, like I have, I'd recommend that you chill on it for a few more months until it's more enjoyable to play. As of right now, it's unintuitive, unoptimised, buggy and generally difficult to play.

I'll start with the things I enjoyed about the game. Starting off on the rioter side in the Arab Spring scenario, I found that the game succeeded in evoking a strong emotional response while also being suitably challenging. It was genuinely disturbing to watch the police units fire indiscriminately into my crowd of peaceful protestors, and even though I ultimately won the scenario, I was still left feeling morose at the thought of the number of people who had died for that victory. I suspect that that's exactly the sort of emotional response that the game is going for, and in that regard, it succeeds.

However, for everything the game has in its ability to evoke the emotions associated with the scenarios it portrays, it lacks far more in its actual design and gameplay. In designing the controls, I suspect that the developers wanted to simulate the chaos and disorganisation in trying to direct people in a riot, but it comes off as feeling sluggish at best and outright random at worst. Targeted abilities, such as projectiles, can either land directly on their mark or fall completely flat, seemingly at random - I'm not expecting a one-hundred percent hit rate, obviously, but any indication at all of factors that could affect my unit's accuracy would be appreciated. 

The various items and abilities you can confer onto your units are not sufficiently explained and lack almost any feedback when they're used - I can give my protestors laser pointers to 'slow down' police units, for example, but there's no feedback to indicate whether the ability actually landed or had any effect, and even if it did, what's the use in making a single hostile unit move slower for a few seconds? Slingshots are supposedly a more potent way of harming police units at range than the rocks and random debris that all mobs have the ability to throw, but targeting them is an exercise in guessing, as is working out if they had any effect whatsoever. The same goes for many other items, and the only way to discover which ones are actually useful is to play and lose a few times before you hit on a winning combo.

This lack of feedback is unfortunately a running theme on both sides of the protest line. Police units can be individually outfitted with different gear, but there is no indication [i]whatsoever[/i] of the pros and cons of different kinds of gear versus one another. What's the difference between a 'crude long baton', a 'wooden stick', and an '18in plastic tonfa'? How is 'Gasmask 2' better than 'Gasmask 1'? Why do my ballistic units have a choice of five different smoke grenade launchers, and again, how do they differ? Why, after I threw aside my moral values in total frustration and gave every ballistic team lethal ammunition, did they kill [i]less[/i] people than when they were using less-than-lethal rubber bullets? The game makes no effort to answer any of these questions, and even after a solid hour of trying different bits and pieces of cop gear to no visible effect (the first hour being spent playing the protestor side), I'm left no closer to finding out.

The game attempts to model the media outlook on a protest event and supposedly punishes the more violent side by giving their opponent a bonus in the next mission, but once again, precious little information is given on how gameplay is affected. After a particularly bloody day in Cairo in which over a hundred of my protestors were shot dead, I was told that my side would have a 'massive advantage' in the next mission. How that manifested, however, is a mystery to me. I was given fewer units to field, a more difficult mission to fulfil, and the police were no less armed or brutal when they turned up to once again to - quite literally - shoot my peaceful protest down. 

Bugs, too, are rife in this game, which is odd after the huge period of delay it was subject to before launch. Protestor mechanics mostly work well, but the police side is barely functional. Riot shield-clad tactical units occasionally flee their positions and concede ground to peaceful, non-aggressive protestors for no discernible reason. Assault units sent in to strategically separate and arrest vulnerable protestors, proceeding to drag them off-screen, sometimes disappear from the map for up to a minute at a time before trickling back onto the field in disarray - were they indulging in police brutality where I couldn't see them or something? Shotgun-toting ballistic units occasionally only fire one or two of the ten guns available to their squad, and whether or not they hit anything is up to factors that the game makes no effort to inform the player of. Units tasked with throwing stun grenades into the crowd will often seemingly have a seizure and flicker from left to right on the spot, trapping their entire squad in inaction until given a new order. When pushed to it, enemy protestors seem to either phase directly through my testudo of riot shields or merge together into one single super-protestor, making them impossible to dislodge from a map area in either case. 

The relatively static camera has trouble following the action in some maps, and I lost one scenario as the protestor side when a police unit charged off the corner of the map, leaving me unable to target them with attacks or abilities even though they were still counted as being inside the 'objective zone' for the game's purposes of resolving the scenario. As for protestor mechanics, I haven't once been able to get the 'build barricade' ability to work - a frustrating problem, as it's the only way that units in the 'aggressive' stance can attempt to hold a position.

There's a few extra modes to toy with in the 'Custom' section of the game, but I had even less luck getting those to work properly. I gave 'spectator' mode (also called 'journalist mode' when you unlock it, for some reason) a go and attempted to pit 400 furious, heavily-armoured, molotov-tossing guerrillas against 120 equally well-armed officers of the law. When I started the game, I was surprised to find that only four rioters showed up. They promptly ran off-screen, handing an immediate and anti-climactic victory to the police. I figure the cops must've been more confused than I was.

The game's performance, particularly for a two-dimensional game with deliberately low-res graphics, is surprisingly poor, particularly when aiming abilities - it goes without saying that trying to drop a molotov on top of a charging police line before they run out of its landing zone is already challenging, and it becomes impossible when the framerate drops into the low single digits. To its credit, the game didn't crash at any point, though it still escapes me how a 900mb game that seems quite undemanding in terms of system requirements can run as poorly as this one does at times.

To conclude: it's a great concept and it certainly succeeded in evoking the emotional response it was surely aiming for, but as a game - as a collection of interlocking mechanics that responds to player input - it has a long road ahead of it. Hopefully, most of the negative points mentioned in this review will be obsolete after a few months of tuning and polishing from the developer(s?). At present, though, I'd advise putting your purchase on hold.
developer_response:
Hi,

Thanks for this in depth feedback!

It is great to hear your response to witnessing the events portrayed in RIOT.

The targeting issue is something we are working on now and we will have a patch up soon for that. Please keep an eye out for announcements either on the store page or in the News section, we will post bug fix logs there.

You raise the issue of lack of visual feedback. This is mostly intentional as we did try various forms of visual feedback through development. We quickly noticed that with so much being displayed on screen, it quickly became chaotic. We will assess this however and return to it. Regarding laser pointers: There are abilities that the police have to charge and push forward. You can slow them down while you regroup, prepare an attack or construct barricades.
The slingshot point I think comes back to targeting but also visual feedback. We'll address this with an update.

On lethal and other weapons and the outcomes of their usage; It is possible that this would happen because using lethal weapons causes the crowd to disperse. Other weapons would have a reduced effect in this way so more people stay and more violence ensues. Of course, on the surface this seems counter-intuitive but I hope this explains this issue. Regardless, we will look into this. Thanks for the feedback on the item loadouts, these are excellent suggestions and we'll see what we can do.

Thanks for reporting the issue on level difficulty progression. We'll push an update for this soon.

There is a lot to address in the bug reports here. Police fleeing their posision is possible as the fear response is based on group density and numbers. The more dense the crowd, the more sway they have. However I do see that a non aggressive crowd should really not have quite as much control, we can look into patching this. Disappearing from the screen is something we can fix in an update. Shotgun units not using all available shotguns is intentional as a blast from all of them would be overwhelming. However, we can look into addressing this. The impact I believe comes back to targeting. The animation glitch is something we can fix with a patch too. Pushing through the testudo should not be possible and we'll work on that.

We'll work on the camera and barricade construction issues and we'll get an update out for that.

The rioter numbers is a surprising bug! We'll get a patch out for this.

The performance issues you noted are something that we are continuing to work on. The reason why RIOT is extremely resource intensive is that the game, while appearing very light, actually uses a system of AI and collision across each unit. The game calculates all of the physics involved in each interacting with each person you see, the environment and the units as a whole. All of these considerations do lead to a persformace hit, however we will continue to work on improvements.

Thanks again for the review. We'll be sure to list every issue that we address in changelogs that we will share on Steam. You will be able to check out the progress there. Our intention was always so address any issues raised in this Early Access phase but if you return for release to play the game again, we hope you review RIOT again. Hopefully, with a thumbs up!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992804317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1428132681}
review: I started game up properly but main game errors when i start, wish i could get my money back
developer_response:
Hi SpecialK,

I'm not sure when you last played but we've made huge sweeping improvements since your review in 2015. We released the game in an unfortunate state in April 2015 but never stopped updating it. With over 80 updates since then, 7 major updates containing tonnes of new features it's an entirely different game.

Since then we've been regularly updating the game with 7 major patches, over 80 minor ones and four expansions. As an early access supporter, you even have the first expansion for free, and the second expansion was free for everyone! 

Most importantly the stability and performance of the game has been now greatly improved after thousands of man-hours of development in out two-man code team spent patching it up.

If you've not tried the game for a while now might be a great time for you to jump in and see how far we've come since release! We'd love to hear what you think now.

Cheers,
Cian

author: {'steamid': '76561197993493467', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1446999334}
review:
This game is pretty. There is no pause. I think those two data points outline the depth of game mechanics.

There is a great open world game here, but right now it is too open. While the tutorial has a handy merchant, your first area does not and you fill up with items that most games tell you are useful. But then your bags are completely full and you realize that the only way to clear space is to eat the food which is really the only useful thing that you are gathering. That magic item you carry around forever until you can get it identified? Still garbage compared to your starting gear! Quest reward you worked so hard for...  Yeah. Let's just get rid of that so that I can hold onto another piece of roasted bear that these swamp dwelling cultists must have imported.

The general consensus of 'Mixed' is pretty accurate.
developer_response:
Mung, thx for your review.
In first area you have two merchant.
Bag system can be expanded so that you can have 1000+ slots, this is enormous space for items.
We have new simpler rules for cursed items and now when you put cursed item, he is immediately identified.
Some quest have very rich rewards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112228691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 73922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8713, 'last_played': 1685811892}
review:
Elite Dangerous, During its initial launch was hailed as first for many reasons, first to simulate a playable milkyway galaxy in procedural generation, First to include VR as a gameplay mode, First to include a space based rpg with freedom of movement and progression. 

4 years on from their retail release Elite has stagnated and become quite stale, the first couple of years it was filled with so much content a new thing was happening every month, update refreshes each week brought new lore into the game's background sim engine. Thargoid's were starting to be revealed as well as other ancient races which with their technology left speculation on the future of this game positive. However the hype and the routine updates which led to a game feeling that the rush and thrill would never end found out that was not to be and thus towards the end of 2018 things in game started to slow, we learned of many developers jumping ship and lead designers moving onto other games, PR staff who we had followed and loved to be around saying their farewells. Most thought this was a transition period and gave frontier the benefit of the doubt. 

Soon after the silence started on the forums and in other social media outlets, we had learned Micheal Brookes had also changed his game development to an "in house" game in frontier. 
This then opened the forums for the trolls and naysayers who questioned everything. We soon started seeing players we had flying with on expeditions becoming forum moderators overnight and known staff keeping quiet. A period time went by where we the community accepted this and just got with the game playing it part time to keep things moving along hoping frontier would pull a mighty big rabbit of their hat for us. Over hyped expeditions led the way, with players running the show and organising mass player meet ups just to prolong the stale content in the game. Those who stuck around kept believing this would be just temporary thing and frontier would start to generate new updates for the older players with bug fixes. 

There was a lot of hype and buildup to the April 2019 update with frontier as usual promising a load of fixes for known bugs and a new player experience which fell very silent on the community, that new player experience was 4 years to late. Before the update a player who knew a developer in frontier submitted a time line post to reddit just as friendly heads up on the speculation of the future of elite and frontier. A day went by and that person got a friendly request on reddit to remove his post or face legal action by frontier.

We techy folks found a way to see what the reddit post and what was discussed and yes it showed to us in our disbelief that frontier had moved elite into maintenance mode till the latter of 2020 and so future updates planned, the post also went into how frontier were now outsourcing their development on other games, pretty believable if you just know the artists and developers who worked on the thargoid artwork and guardian's stuff like i do, to know this wasnt a one off thing from frontier. Now most people in game now think there is plenty of content most of it is hidden behind mysteries and complex puzzles which only the developers know about. 

Again the post on reddit ended with there is no raxxla. Even drew wagner a storyboard writer and book author recently told the community in a youtube blog that no author who was working with frontier had access to that storyline and it was kept in house and to only 3 people of which are not story writers. They have no idea how to write a story in elite or otherwise. So the statement is very believable yes there is raxxla in the game, its in the code but thats where it stops its no you cannot visit it, no there isnt a gateway to another dimension or galaxy and no its just not in the actual in a playable format. Think of it as being a #raxxla footnote in c++. So Its there in game in the code and Mr braben can rightly state so. Oh just so you know Drew Wagner did fall out with frontier for this as it was as close to breaking his Non disclosure agreement as you can get.

So in a nutshell is Elite Dangerous worth playing.  Yes as long as you paid under 5$ and as long as you know that this game isnt going anywhere despite the hype train telling you which is player created leading you to believe otherwise.

Now with even more broken content they spin more lies about future development and roadmaps which a child could of done in a preschool setting. Sorry but if you have bought the expansion you deserve the guilt, shame and disgust the rest of the community have about Fdev's broken promise scheme.

Yet here we are in 2022 and Fdev are still up to their spin and tricks. David Braben has finally jumped ship knowing full well this is a doomed title. Players now forced into story without their consent or choice. Some of those players were hanging on by a string hoping the story would still have drive to peaceful solutions but the kids at fdev chose to shoot everything ask about it later. So long termers now leaving. Well it was fun while it lasted, oh wait no it wasnt fun at all.
